ZJMrk2BwAkN0Dtc73qtN8g.review_text: You know a place is impressive when the band you just paid 40 bucks to see stops mid set in awe to appreciate the fact they are allowed to grace that stage.  The fillmore is one of the all-time great venues in the country.   I've seen such a variety of acts here, and they all work.  Only once have I had to forcefully usher(with the help of some guy) some drunk imbecile who was trying to accost some girls. The sound has never been bad.  They've been doing it so long that they never screw it up.  The staff have that slightly scary, hell's angels look, but they let you have your fun and only lay down the law if you really mess up.   Drinks are a bit expensive, but hey, its a landmark.  The poster collection in the upstairs bar is unparalleled.  Some posters are even in SFMoMA.    Go see anyone here.  Bring out of towners here whenever there happens to be a show.

FLwY5zLEIgmBr0H-n4eyoA.review_text: I have been dreaming of going to this venue since i was a kid and it has NEVER disappointed. Apples at the end of the shows, great sound and the most interesting band posters on the wall that make you remember being 16 and dreaming of being at the fillmore.  i have seen cornelius and billy bragg there.  doesnt get much better.

Vjk5FemZ5rwJuJ7Sznd3fA.review_text: 26 years a native san franciscan, and I had never been to the Fillmore until Sunday night.  Alright, bring it.  What do you want to know?  Whether I've lived in a hole my whole life?  Whether I'm a total dork?  Whether the creative half of my brain is just inert?  Whatevs - pass your judgements.  You were right.  I totally should have made it there earlier.  I was literally trembling walking in to the place - and not because it was on a shady corner on Geary and Fillmore - but because I knew I was walking into a legend.  And then the red velvet curtains and chandeliers - so deliciously seductive.  And the photographs!  Beck looked like 14 in that photo!  Sound was fantastic, not a bad seat in the house.  And the free posters - what a nice touch to help you remember.  It feels good to be among people that appreciate good music, good times, and good art.

oqitPG6jysyKKn4HXojb2Q.review_text: Great concert venue. They bring in excellent acts, and this place has tons of history. A SF icon.

YofxgpBlD4ByHYF7iOWRpA.review_text: I've been here twice so far - once for Kristen Schaal's stand up show and last night for The 1975!  The parking is GREAT - I don't think a lot of people know about the Japantown Center garage but parking is $1/hr after 6pm so we literally paid $3 for parking last night instead of having to take the bus or use Uber! Score!  The line was around the block when we got there but we got in maybe 5-10 minutes after the doors opened, so that was a plus. The venue's interior is gorgeous, my friend & I kept admiring the vintage-esque chandeliers!   -1 star for the venue being ALL AGES - there is literally nothing worse than being around drunk high school girls - they're not really old/experienced enough to learn how to handle their liquor (especially in a public setting) but they sure know how to kick the fun out of a simple night...or maybe, I'm just growing into an old, bitter lady at 22! Sorry, I also just had to be the one out of everyone to voice my opinion loudly to one drunk teenage girl in particular....(she knocked her elbow against my head & then started grinding up against me). Um, HELLO little girl, we don't know each other like that! Class, not ass please.....at least not when the concert hasn't even started & there's no music playing.....lol.  I also think the waitresses handing out the water bottles throughout the crowd is a really horrible idea. A lot of people get the idea of following right behind these ladies in an effort of cutting through the crowd to get to the front. I had A LOT of people try and force their way past me...I say "try and force" because hell no, I'm 4'11" and I'm not gonna let anything else obstruct my already-limited view of the stage! It's not really fair to the people who have endured the two hours of sound checks and opening acts just to have a bunch of inconsiderate people try to creep their way through five minutes before the headliner starts.  The venue hands out free posters of the night's concert when the show is over!

gR7is-YzJRnRdQ0AhbiWHA.review_text: This place is sooooo old, or just old looking.  Ive seen it on tv a few times before coming here.  Ive seen dave chappell on tv here and it seemed a LOT bigger than it was when I went yesterday to see Augustana.  The chandeliers are cool with a tint of purple, I tried to take a picture, but it didnt show very well on my camera.  THere were a couple went on stage yesterday night and the man proposed to her, he said this was the place they had their first kiss, so I guess its a sentimental place for many people who have come before for previous concerts.    I wish they had real seats though, i swear they used to....standing all night is NOT fun.  Augustana made up for it.  The Fillmore gives out free apples :]  There is a bucket filled with them near the center entrance/exit.  Minus one star for needing to park in the Projects.

Ytq1HaAK4Dc84UnShCnI6g.review_text: I love this venue.  1.  Parking near by and cheap 2.  Good drinks for fairly reasonable prices 3.  Chandeliers hanging from the ceiling 4.  It's a tiny venue  I've seen a few bands here and it feels really intimate.  I love this place.

Bs-YIZ4KwRv5g7UfDkJdug.review_text: I really love smaller venues where I can actually see the performer. In this case it was Erykah Badu a couple of days ago. There's a big bar with enough bartenders so I can get my drink and get back to seeing the show.   It is spacious inside (much like the Great American Music Hall), but getting out is another story. It's like a cattle run with all of us trying to squeeze into the one very small exit/entrance.   Overall, it was a kick ass concert held inside a great venue.

ejgukmIqm9yfBAuEl_at4A.review_text: If you've been, you know; if you haven't, you should go. Consistently attracting some of the finest shows in the Bay area, the Fillmore provides a space and vibe that let's you create your own experience. Posters and photos frame this historic venue, and there are still free apples for the hungry. Go soon, go often, and be sure to say hello to Tim at the top of the stairs... SF's kindest greeter. This guy is for real, and when he says "welcome to the Fillmore," you'll know he means it.

CZQUtmO5NIY-bZWkCqHeJg.review_text: Fun night with friends Imogen Heap played here this evening! Loved her new songs and her tour groupies... amazing! Left with a FREE poster in hand Mellow crowd lovin' the beats Oh, can't wait when she's back in April 2010! Red apples, chandeliers, great view of the stage Enjoyed my first show at this small and wonderful venue  *~* I M O G E N  H E A P *~*  I have to confess, I didn't know how to properly pronounce the name of the performer until the day of the concert! Yes, I'm quite embarrased. -.- So to get some things straightened out, it's Imogen Heap (pronounced imoJEN... not imoGAN) ahaha The name might not sound familiar to you at first, but think Frou Frou and Garden State! She has an English accent, has crazy awesome hair, and has a unique voice when she sings.  The Fillmore: It's quite a small venue, kind of reminds me of House of Blues on Sunset in LA. Very nice crystal chandelier lights hanging from the ceiling!! Loved the dark painted walls! Bars and benches along the walls. Upper balcony seating only on one side of the venue. Coat check in (I think you have to pay). A huge basket of red delicious apples await you at the top of the stairs as you enter. When you exit, get yourself a nice souvenir (a FREE Fillmore poster of the concert)!!  The concert: It was awesome! I've not paid for many concerts in my life. It's quite sad. I've either won tickets or was on a list to get in for free. Probably this is the second concert I've actually had to pay for. First one was a Matchbox 20 concert at the Staples center in LA way back in high school. O_O So about this concert... I LOVED the stage decor! It looked like a winter wonderland! This giant white wooden tree that lights up! The backdrop had the same silhouette of the tree. Grand piano on stage was transparent with a feathered boa inside! The cellist's chair was made of white fur too! And cool blue lighting! The opening acts were great! They were also incorporated into Imogen Heap's main concert! My favorite act was the cellist Zoey! Loved her dreads! Overall, I just couldn't believe how close we wer to the performers on stage!  The crowds was great! Very calm, mellow, civilized group. Thank goodness for no crazy mosh pits, loud-blasting-screaming music! O_O I could still hear very well after the concert!  The ugly: The only annoyance was the security guy on the floor who kept try to get through the crowds of people who were taking picture with flash or recording the concert. You're enjoying the moment and some old guy in a hawaiian shirt (and a bit smelly) =X tries to push through in front of you every few minutes! OMG, come on! They should've announced in while you were entering the venue not to do those things.  Getting there: From our friend's house, we took the cab from Civic Center for about $7 each way.  Left Mountain View: 5pm Got into SF: 6:14pm (traffic was horrible) Fillmore: 7pm The Fillmore: 7:45pm (doors opened @ 7pm) Opening act: 8pm Imogen Heap: 9:15pm- midnight Got back to Mountain View: 12:45am  Tips... - Try not to bring too much stuff with you (leave your big purses at home) - Don't bring a jacket, it's going to get HOT inside - Bring a water bottle, you might get dehydrated... or even pass out (someone did that evening) - Wear comfy shoes if you plan to stand the whole time on the main floor - Grab yourself an apple when you're there if you get hungry!

B4slngfcqvH1T2cEIb69FA.review_text: What can I possibly say about the legendary Fillmore that hasn't been said already? This place gives me chills. I love catching my favorite acts at this venue, always will.  *update*12/6 Jefrree Star touched my face omg! Front row baby! lol!

6IGMJbGve3Fa5FKFyQ5zdg.review_text: While I do enjoy myself whenever I see a show at the Fillmore, there are a few things that bother me about this place.  1. The box office is not open during the day.  It's only open half an hour before show time, and apparently on Sundays.  For those of us who like to avoid the $10 "service charge" on online orders, this is a major annoyance.  2. $4 for a bottle of water when there are no water fountains or places to get some of Hetch Hetchy's finest = LAME!  3. Don't know who does the sound checks, but I found it very hard to hear the singers because the other instruments were turned up way too high.  4. Odd food smells...where are these coming from?  I'm sure I'll be back here again, but I won't be in a huge hurry.

-Ak9LVDH8GYyWtIMnNo5Ug.review_text: The rudest staff in the world.    WTF.  Bill Graham would be pissed if he were here.  It starts at the ticket window and continues with the event staff inside.   I will not be back !  EVER

0bQIbFSdy0Rcdj5-Le4C9Q.review_text: If I was a rock star (other than in my pathetic fantasies), I seriously think that the end of the road for me would be to headline at the Fillmore.  You might find me face down in a bathtub the next day, because there would be nothing left to achieve.   The Fillmore is not only the coolest, sexiest concert venue anywhere.  It is ground zero for the greatest San Francisco music and much of the SF counter-culture movement.  This is where the legends of the 60s played and called home.   The Dead, Cream, the Doors, Hendrix, Joplin, and on and on and on.  The people who work there are all damn glad to see you.  40 years later, they're still handing out apples as you enter the building.  Some recent and not so recent awesome shows I have seen here:  The Eels, Richard Thompson, BB King, Midnight Oil, Ben Kweller, the Jayhawks, Joan Armatrading and Tom Petty.  There are probably a hundred more, but those stand out in my mind.    I love the fact that in my younger days I puked on the corner of the stage probably only a few feet from where Janis puked.    We share a bond, Janis and me.

0t7BDBc447MURh8DH5d16A.review_text: i have no sympathy for corporate america. i also refuse to pay an EXTRA ten dollars on top of regular ticket prices to forgo fun fillmore posters!  going to try everything i can to avoid going here ever. funk that!

jzN-h77GBVJTUyE58BnAMw.review_text: Mostly writing this because I went there last night and I'm trying to get back into the habit of yelping (after starting up a new account).   So, we went to see Mike Doughty last night. And that's why I'm writing, but that also illustrates why reviews for concert venue are kind of dumb. I mean, if your favorite act is playing, you're going to go whether or not the place is a craphole, right?   Not that the Fillmore is a craphole. It's totally decent and normal. Fine sound. Average drinks and bar food. Amazing music history with 50 years of show posters all over all the walls. But, still. If it were a craphole and Justin Beiber were playing, all the Belieber fanatics would flock there anyway.   Not that Beiber would play the Fillmore. At least not for another 20 years until he's a washed-up has-been that only the aging Millenials remember. Then he'll play here. Oh, yes. He will. Every year.   Friggin Justin Beiber.

aX89FrVSRSPn4Pn5PtBKhg.review_text: free apples and drinks being served while you are standing in the crowd? sweet! super cool staff and venue.

nP4J-c3_-MhAZbMryYEE8Q.review_text: Seeing all these positive reviews about this place almost made me want to change my 3 stars to 4 but I got to be honest.  As far as decor and the historical aspect of the place goes, it was cool. The fact that it's open space and you're totally packed in, nearly elbow to elbow, with a whole bunch of folks made the experience more like being in a crowded club...or at a high school prom.  But then again the concert WAS for N.E.R.D. (maybe not the right choice of band to see for general admission)  Great show. Not-so-great venue.

2Gg59k99LrvGm4J1fAKQ8A.review_text: i've only been here once, i saw Smashing Pumpkins in 2007 it was alright.   However, the decor is beautiful from what i remember, there lighting is perfect, great sound and nice bathrooms ( which is a plus) the place is not too big & not too small.  If im in SF and theres someone good playin ill be down fosh.

Rx7DNBmPPShVjlcQidGuTw.review_text: i love this venue...it always feels like a special occasion when i step into the fillmore.  it's awesome to look around the walls at all the pictures and posters of the dif bands who have played here.  i also love getting free posters here everytime i come see a show!  seeing ozomatli here was definitely one of the highlights of my concert-going experiences.

QVAmRIrCxhYLqh7wl4Vlog.review_text: I saw my favorite band, N*E*R*D, here about a year ago. What an amazing place to have it. The size of the venue was large enough to accommodate hundreds of fans, and with the stage being small and elevated at a good height, plenty of people were able to crowd around it and take pictures, and pretty girls were able to just get up onto the stage.   The lighting and acoustics were also amazing and really added to the experience. I'm not able to give it a full 5 stars because of the number of crazy drunk ass people there and the lack of security helping out. Usually at most concerts you'll see a couple bouncers or guards watching out for everyone, but during this concert where N*E*R*D encourages people to "go ape shit and just SHOVE the people next to you as hard as you can!" things got a little crazy.   The only other problem I had was that I wasn't of age yet so I couldn't try out the drinks. Not sure if it was a full bar or just beer, but everyone had a beer and it looked like it would hit the spot in the steamy hall. Oh yeah, there were also waitresses walking around the dancefloor selling drinks! I thought that was unique to a concert.   So aside from the low security, this concert was almost perfect. Good times at the Fillmore.

AFCGei97rV53X7HMsrEG7w.review_text: I've never not had a great time at the Fillmore. The vibe is always good. Even at a sold out show they were efficient at the bar and the bathrooms were surprisingly clean. Yay for free posters after the show.

AgzHzIzC6ZHTKgker0egAg.review_text: Every time, and I mean EVERY time I have plans that I dread, I end up having the best time.  Whenever I look forward to something months in advance, fate somehow always jams me and I end up hating said event.    Three events, in particular, stand out as being in my top 5 "most super  awesome nights" ever.    They happen to be three concerts.  And looking back, I never even realized that they were all at The Fillmore.    I'll spare you the details about getting knocked over by John Popper or "catching" Mike Ness' gum as he tossed it out at the crowd for apparently not booing loud enough when he was ranting about lollapalooza.    Those two evenings I would rate #4 & #5 respectively on the all time scale.    #2, however, was the Millencolin concert at The Fillmore.    I was dragged here against my will.  Not that I don't like Millencolin, I just didn't feel like going out that night.    So we get there, and my dumbass friend forgets the tickets.  We are at the front door with no tickets at a sold out show that I don't even want to be at and I am not even buzzed.    Picture me doing the two thumbs up with the fakest smile you have seen at this point.    I am not sure what sort of karma was being paid back that night but apparently we did something REAL big in our past lives.  The bouncer looks at both of us, says, I understand, and hands us two backstage passes and tells us to go in.    Nervous and with a severely deficient blood alcohol content, we decided not to go backstage.    Yet.  Needless to say, we got drunk, and Millencolin rocked like none other.    We must have been on some sort of high (or an actual high, I can't remember) but after Millencolin's set, we decided to use those backstage passes.    Drunk ass Archie comes screaming in like a coked up manager who has known the band for years and hugs every member of the band, raids the little food setup they had (I just really remember Doritos), gets his picture taken with the band, and leaves.  To this day I like to picture Millencolin sitting  on their tour bus talking about that night in SF when that weirdo barged in and all of them swearing it's one of the other band mate's cousin that none of them can remember.    Evening #1 on my all time list?  Let's just say that it involved one case of beer, a 1994 Defender 90, a bottle of 10W30 motor oil, two fishing poles, a swatch watch, three water balloons, and 6 "day old" apple fritters.    Family.

CbwJmOCldNyzO1nh9ouNJA.review_text: This is an excellent place to see a show.  It is big with lots of interesting decorations. If the music gets to be too much in the main room, you can skitter off to the side rooms to mellow out. This is especially important for me as I don't especially enjoy large crowds.  The best part is they give you a free poster for the show you just saw at the end of the night. How cool is that?

XxikEWjUdux95sBL_kq9sg.review_text: I almost died trying to drive here to see Hieroglyphics with Little Brother and People Under the Stairs....BUT it was soo worth it....  I've always had a great time here, no disappointments.  There is so much history here that how can you rate this place with a negative rating.  Its an intimate place meaning its just you and the concert.  You can be upfront near the stage or be all bu shied up at the balcony watching from up top.  The AWESOME thing is that there is a bar everywhere you go....The really want you liquored up.    STORY....but for those of you who do like to smoke...but during my santa cruz years...like i said i almost died driving here and so we had to leave our crashed up car at a shop to get it fix...i was walking to the show carrying a bong...i was so worried i would get it taken away.  The bouncer or dude that was checking our bangs looked inside...looked at me....and give me a node and said..HAVE A GOOD TIME...only at the fillmore...  Go and have a good time Everyone!!!

QOxFaysm2kMRJ0_8t_GB0w.review_text: It is historic.  When you look at the posters it is a walk through time.  It sometimes appears to me like the kind of place that folks like Mae West would perform at.  But it's not that old.  My Aunt told me she first watched performers crash guitars on the stage of the Fillmore in June of '68.    I like the traditions of the Fillmore: the posters of the sold-out shows, the apples, and the greeter especially.  I like the open spaciousness of the floor.  But I don't like my shoes sticking to the floor because there is too much beer on it.   The last time I was there someone asked the greeter if he could go to his car to "medicate."  The Fillmore has a policy of not letting people come and go.  The coat check is similar, once you check something, you've checked it for the night.    What is really cool, though, is being close enough to the performers to really see them, all of their gestures and facial expressions.  And I think they like the coziness of the Fillmore too.

rCKLhzDdPofFLK9TC6UTyg.review_text: I saw Drive-By Truckers for their three-night run.  Once gain, the Fillmore did not disappoint and neither did the Truckers, and I expect this venue and this band to be amazing.  See 2011 review.    Do I have anything new to say?  Yes!  I tried the Fillmore's food for the first time.  The food is excellent and quite reasonably priced for what you get.

wZjWqmmBFKmFv3b49Y_1qA.review_text: I want to love the Fillmore.  But, if you value your lung health, don't go here.  The venue is supposed to be no-smoking.  The Fillmore makes a mockery of the no-smoking LAW.  Apparently, the management of the Fillmore cares little about the health and safety of the patrons, performers, and employees.  Interesting that security here has no trouble telling people to move out of the aisles, stand or don't stand in certain places, or frisk entrants.  So, why is it so hard to enforce the no-smoking LAW?  I'm not a square or an old cranky man.  I 've been involved in rock'n'roll to a small degree on the business side for 18 years.  To be able to see my favorite bands in a safe and clean environment is amazing.  Unfortunately, the Fillmore doesn't provide that opportunity.  How long until some crackhead crazed maniac goes wild and hurts someone here.  Or, an asthmatic suffers a life-threatening episode?  You would think the danger of such events would convince the management here to abide by a fair law everyone else has to abide by.  But, that's not the case.  So, think twice about going here, I won't be back.

cfK_CHlE2EJ_YVHmcHiOhQ.review_text: Saw Lettuce on 12/14.  I must say that this is one of the tightest bands on the planet.  The sound quality of the show was terrible.  The overpowering bass frequencies completely destroyed the mix.  The sub frequencies were more visceral than audible.  Between the bass drum, the bass and the low end of the keys, it was impossible to discern actual notes.   It was like eating 15 scotch bonnet peppers before enjoying a delicate meal.  The audio palate was obliterated before the intricacies of the funk could be tasted.  The clav was impossible to hear.  The B3 barely audible, the chank of the guitars and horns cut through a bit. The bass was a continuous rumble that destroyed the articulation of the bass lines and wiped out the higher frequencies.  To be honest, it was nearly impossible to discern a single bass note.  As a bass player, I was psyched to hear Eric Coomes lock in with Adam.  You could see that the band was tight as hell, but the subtle syncopations of the funk were completely washed out.  The mix sounded like it was set up for soulless EDM, not the organic articulate funk of Lettuce.  Please kill the subs!!   Beautiful room with lots of history.  Unfortunately the sound quality is of little concern.

cMrqmXH7e4FxMZq_3L3oSA.review_text: This is probably one of my favorite concert venues I've been to. Very intimate, beautiful, historic theatre. You can get very close to the stage, and the sound is great as well. The staff was probably sweetest I've encountered at a concert venue, and were very efficient. Will definitely return soon, and hopefully have more time to look around at the beauty of the venue and its history.

B76PF6CJBVW6LU3JcC1nPA.review_text: My review is for the upstairs kitchen/restaurant. I went to Bunburys concert last wednesday, we get there early and I was SO hungry, I am a very picky eater, and I did not expect anything quality food there, but to my surprise when I saw the menu: 1/3 lb Grassfed burger (grassfed, wow), I dont eat wheat, so I asked them if they can wrap my burger on lettuce, this super nice dark haired girl said: sure!, and I had a AMAZING lettuce wrapped grassfed burger with homemade tomato marmalade or something very fancy and delicious. AND I dont drink beer, so it was very nice to see hard ciders on the menu too!!

r3UmPWmn_e62xJpEngrAxg.review_text: Great music venue- there isn't a bad seat in the house! I love how it has that old time intimate feel to it :)  Came here for Clean Bandit and it was once of the happiest shows I've been to. Really good energy.   If shows sell out you get free posters!!  The 38 bus drops off right in front and the Fillmore/Japantown area has tons of yummy food choices for bites before/after show.

mwhZvzmCwiqUc1wPhfzHlg.review_text: I've only been once but it was an amazing show at an amazing venue.  Looking forward to more concerts there soon.

RVEo3hKrwSglj1vc6vu5SA.review_text: The Fillmore is a venue you must go to if you're a Bay Area music fan. The venue is great and the sound system is really good. I've seen quite a few shows here and the sound has always been top-notch. You feel like you're very close to the action here as there are no bad sight-lines and the lighting system illuminates the stage very well. Besides these technical aspects there is also the feeling of being apart of a greater musical history when you're here. All the posters on the walls (too many pics of The Grateful Dead if you ask me. I mean I get it. The Dead played here a lot) and the nice guy who greets you at the top of the stairs (albeit after the real nasty guy who "controls" the line outside) makes you feel like you're at some place really special. The drinks here are pricey but let's face it, they're going to be expensive at most live music venues so the fact that this club actually has kind servers who make their way into the tightly packed crowd with a tray full of drinks and somehow find you to drop off your order is very impressive and worth the extra cash. With a mostly friendly staff and a consistently great line up of artists, this is and remains one of my favorite live music venues.

BmxqEeNmHW2b2nju1vMhmQ.review_text: This is such a great place to see a show.  The posters alone make standing up all night worthwhile.  The sound quality is a lot better than other venues in the city and even when it's packed, you still feel the love from the staff.    You'll often see old school heads walking around munching on apples.  That's a Fillmore classic for those who walk past and wonder why they have apples in the lobby.  Oh, and I think earplugs are donation only.  The management here is still hella cool even as other venues have gotten really commercial.   Can't speak for the men's room but the ladies room is always pretty crowded and Fillmore employees have guaranteed line cuts.  Understandable, but I always make sure I hop on line about 5 minutes before I get desperate.

s4O8baEyijx68SOrz668rg.review_text: I'd say music is probably the only thing I like more than, well, at least equal to, food.  I've seen many concerts at many places, massive shows to cozy performances.  The Fillmore is by far the place than The Fillmore in San Francisco.  The Whiskey on Sunset in the late 80's was great, but it's not as eclectic as today's Fillmore.  Where do I start? History, this place has been around since.. I don't know, but I don't really need to know since both Janis Joplin and the Dead played here.  The photo of Jerry Garcia on the wall of fame inside the Fillmore says it all. It is intimate but yet exciting to be at this mecca of live music.  This place rocks, yet it can be soulfully and poetically virtuous.  The acoustics were amazing, great sound.  Expect a wonderful time when you make it here.  I guess after 600 reviews there isn't much more to write except you have to go check it out for yourself.  I would go as far as seeing a performance at the Fillmore by someone I don't really like or care for.

BPocdupppjxeGFLml0VgLA.review_text: Absolutely amazing venue!  One of the best places I've ever seen a show... it has so much character, and I LOVE how small it is.  And you gotta love the posters... what a good way to end the night?!?!

JxvPY8dd0dcxRfOWjBg35w.review_text: I love the Fillmore. It's small enough that you can actually see the bands and get up close, but large enough that you can move around and dance. I also love that the hallways are coated in old rock posters from shows my parents went to and that they often hand out free (and well designed) posters at the end of shows.

B7ecAeAIrXg7sgmabS38pg.review_text: Like having hot 'n' heavy, sweaty, Whiskey mouth sex.  Yep, that's pretty much what seeing Government Mule here on Saturday night was like. It was my first visit to the legendary Fillmore and I couldn't imagine a better show to pop my musical venue cherry. The place was packed with a really wide array of folks. Everything from Allman Brothers fanatics and little Goth boys to joint smokin' grandmas and everything in between. It was awesome.  As for the venue itself, it was really cool. The walls just wreaked of history and there was a definite energy and soul to the place. I loved all of the band posters that adorned the top floors and the sound system was perfect. Not too loud and clear as can be.   About the only bummer was the fact that they will shoo you away from the bar after you get your drink, but I get it, keep it moving and everyone wants a drink. I know, I know, but after the contact high I got from all of the, um, "concert air" I needed a place to lean. So shoot me :)

5SDwdNaU0c3cf-Oum-J3Xw.review_text:
Sound:  Check it's good
 Food: Okay but who goes to concerts for food
 Music: Singing in the diversity many different types of artists. 
 Bartenders: Nice as ice...
 Security: A-wipes but where in SF is there nice security???? 1 point off for that.
 Avoids: Nights with Hip-hop acts unless you really luv the group because the Thugs and WannaBeGangsters will be out frontin.

KJ87Msot6SV617-30SyKOw.review_text: the fillmore itself is great. not as big for alot of people but it is roomy. it better not to have so much people at that venue. . speakers and everything are good. drink choices are MEHH...i dont know. location wise sucks. i hate to have to worry about my car getting messed with. i love coming here. i saw most of my favorite bands here. cant wait to go back.

UODpd47cXfHQLSIzo-bdMQ.review_text: It is the Fillmore for Christ sake! It's history! I've seen the best shows of my life there... eat dinner in Japantown or the surrounding neighborhood and skip the Fillmore's fare...don't want to experience a disturbance in the force at show time!

DQB3NVlBlXvvVPGFQqaXVA.review_text: Don't slam the Fillmore or Hendrix and Morrison will climb out of their graves and come get you!    Honestly, what can be said about a venue that is as legendary as the artists themselves who have performed there?    Let it flow and let yourself go!  The crowds never cease to be anything but cool and that all too familiar herbal aroma is as welcome today as it was back in 60's.  If you want to get technical, the acoustics at the Fillmore are phenomenal and right up there with the best venues in the country.    Anyone else hear the rumors about the Police getting back together?

ILz8ApVEgTqbv5LnC6PyuA.review_text: Currently my favorite venue in all of San Francisco. The sound and overall ambiance were perfect. I didn't even sweat up by the front of the stage, due to the high-powered air conditioning. And what other venue gives out free posters for every sold out show? None that I've ever been to besides the Fillmore. I couldn't have asked for a better venue for Gnarls Barkley and their 13 member ensemble...

q_nO8GkPITWy7fOeeFRYQw.review_text: great venue with an infectious vibe and a legendary history to match! the location is in a great spot - right across japantown, down the street from harputs, and a thai restaurant too! i havent tried their food, but the bartenders are quite friendly. they offer fat tire for $5! there are two bars, which is always convenient. from anywhere you sit, you can see the stage..so in case you arrive late, you wont be stuck staring at the back of the head of a total stranger. cant wait for upcoming shows!

nXsMrhO9c9dO--Jbi5CHYg.review_text: I've never been to The Fillmore before. I know, I know... who am I, right?   Well, I went here last night for the Blue October concert and I loved the venue. It's the perfect size venue for a concert. It felt like such an intimate affair. Can't wait till my next concert here!

mn2dBGX5-brzrPr8gx8XoQ.review_text: I love the Fillmore! The outside is not the nicest and street parking is not always available however when I go there for a show I probably shouldn't be driving anyways :-) The venue itself is killer, good sound and a classic feel that can host almost any type of act. I have seen comedians, DJ's and many many live shows there. It is great to see large acts that you would normally see at a arena or festival play at here. If you haven't been you really need to find a reason to go, if you have been there already you know what I am talking about.

fNLvsiGqs-knYh-ZE_-EEg.review_text: The Fillmore is an iconic and charming San Franciscan staple. I saw Dita Von Tease here several months ago and had a blast. It does get kinda crowded, someone is always smoking weed, and the neighborhood is shady...but it's still a really lovely place.

49aCB1D8ga70-57ZR7KhjA.review_text: My favorite music venue in SF. Awesome vibe, decorated with the classic Fillmore gig posters. Friendly staff, and incredible lineups nonstop. Doesn't get any better!

YB55wsqgqViDARjZaalkZg.review_text: I have been to quite a few shows at the Fillmore. Usually we have great time. Street parking is easy in the area. The bar serves some pretty good drinks and there is food upstairs if you are hungry. There is a wonderful sense of history here with the walls covered with posters and photographs of the many famous acts that have played there. There is isn't much seating so be prepared to wear your comfy shoes and stand all night. The sound is good here and atmosphere nice. Sometimes they give out free posters from the artist as you exit the venue after the show. Get there early to snag a closer spot to the stage at this popular venue.

QHMvAOw_SwQNc7Em46m6Rg.review_text: What a great place to see a show, everything is great, the atmosphere, the fact that it's GA, you can get tickets without the service charge if you buy the tickets on a Sunday!    the only bad thing is they have this stage security guy who looks like a blonde iggy pop, it's really sad. He takes his job way too seriously ruining everyone's time in the first couple rows. It's sad because I think this is where he derives all of his self esteem.  Dude! you are like 50 years old, you need to cut that hair and stop dressing like a rock star when you are just a glorified bouncer!

ju6Xb78b1LS75VHjpF0LkQ.review_text: I've been coming here to see shows since I was 16, It's so beautiful and I love that you get a personalized poster after each show, I have around 20 of them set up on my apartment wall in a similar fashion to the venue. The one gripe is their sound can definitely be off, it seems more often then it should be, over many genres of music too. I'm not sure if it's the building or the sound people not being consistent but when it's good, it's a magical place to spend an evening.

O2WfOgwdSxIl-4UkqY88dA.review_text: As the daughter of a musician, I have seen a lot of music venues.  And I can say without  doubt, the Fillmore is one of the top places in the country for Rock and Roll Afficianados  to see a show.   From the staff members that will die before quitting their jobs, to the famous poster-lined walls, to the bucket of apples at the front door (to commemorate the days of the laced apples served in the 60s), this place is a museum unto itself.   If you have never been to the Fillmore before, I would suggest you go when the doors open to give yourselves time to walk around and view the incredible photos  - Only then can you appreciate the legendary status these walls have earned.

m2svF5GrHzhoeePYHPED1w.review_text: Why 5stars?  - found my musical soulmate(s). - best rum shots of my life. - the crew and I got trampled by crazy fans trying to make it to the front. - lost my phone-found my phone-got my phone stolen out of my hands. - got myself a free a supply of glow sticks here. - had a "Hey, I know you from Facebook!" moment(s). - rode in a taxi with some pretty cool hippies after a show. - met a few people with my name. - got a random massage. - have a bunch of, "Hey, hey - remember when..." lines. - made plenty of new friends. - I wanted to take a "legendary" apple home. - the vibes are awesome. - met Jesus twice here.  Watching my favorite bands live @ The Fillmore = drunk, crying, euphoric moments.   Yeah, I'm coming back.

ZXNwO2bY3QTYP0k_5bhG1A.review_text: I can't believe I've lived in the Bay Area for over ten years, and it took me this long to catch a show at the Fillmore.  Why yes...I am embarrassed.  My buddy P. and I were here to see an old favorite, Bob Mould, and we arrived slightly early after a scrumptious dinner at Fat Angel.   P. had been here many times and gave me the tour: -- I liked the upstairs lounge, where live music is played before the opening band hits the main stage. So you're pretty much guaranteed access to music during your entire time here, if you want. -- I loved checking out all the posters of all the great shows over the years. -- I liked the huge, slightly springy main floor and all the chandeliers  Once the show started, we squeezed up front and stayed there. The opening band was really fun, and Bob put on a great show too.  The sound was not overly loud but it was a bit muddy (I suspect this was the band mixer's fault, not the club's).    One thing that surprised me was the ubiquitous servers taking drink orders everywhere, even within the press of the crowd on the main floor. But then again, they make about $7 of profit on each beer, so I guess I shouldn't be all that surprised.  We had a great time overall, and on the way out they handed us a Fall schedule poster. I have been studying it carefully, because I wouldn't mind coming back here again before the year is up.

g6lj-rWPYgyUKobZCjCwjQ.review_text: I've had the oppurtunity to see several shows at the Fillmore, and they have all been amazing. There's so much history to this place, and it's fun to walk around and see the posters from bands that have played there, from the Grateful Dead to the Doors to Led Zeppalin.  For a music lover like myself, it's awe inspiring.  The venue is relatively small and has an intimate feeling.  The atmosphere is great, we sometimes get there early and have drinks up on the balcony while we wait for the show to start.  And they give out posters of the bands, as well as the famous apples.  The only downside is the security guards can be a little overzealous.  But overall, seeing a band at the Fillmore makes for a great concert-going experience.

RlXfOTtpgTfcisRmukrGbw.review_text: The Fillmore is a live music venue that is absolutely saturated with history and is really one of the best venues in the Bay Area.    They have big coolers of water and cups placed at the end of the bars on both floors, as well as a big bowl of (free) apples.  The interior is decorated with all the posters from shows over the last 40 years or so, walls painted in rich dark red hues.  The main floor area is actually pretty big - but not so big that you can't see the band on stage.  There's also a coat check that is very efficient and well run.  All that said - I have to confess that the Fillmore has not always been my favorite venue for live music.  Often the acoustics and sound are so overpowering that I can't really hear what the singers are singing.  This was especially the case with a Halloween 1998 performance by The Residents in 1998 -- but completely the opposite for a Billy Bragg acoustic show in November 2000.    I've been vexed by muddy vocals more often than not - and left disappointed by the size of the crowds generally, preferring The Great American, The Independent (aka The Justice League) and for bigger acts - the now defunct Maritime Hall.  Let's not even talk about the Warfield - I just can't stand that place!  My most recent experience at the Fillmore was for a Yonder Mountain String Band show - I first saw this band in 2001, and that show was full of long haired hippies with dreads, blue eyes and shiny straight white teeth, all wearing long skirts, dancing in spinning circles like dervishes.  This show was completely different - sort of nouveau hipster blue grass chic with lots of scruffy beards, plaid shirts and narrow leg pants.  The acoustics for this show were much improved over the last show I attended there -- I could understand everything that the vocalists were singing at the front of the room (not just the back by the sound board as with many shows).  It's hit or miss - The Fillmore is definitely one of the more popular places to see big shows, but be prepared with cash for the coatcheck lady and ear plugs.

OeaaE-v-x5qmR6ZIwGWHig.review_text: How is it that I've lived in San Francisco for over two decades and I've never been to the Fillmore (nerd alert!)????  Okay, without exception (especially including Mike and Marcus of the security ilk), the staff was amazingly friendly and helpful.  Let me re-emphasize, THE SECURITY STAFF WAS FRIENDLY AND HELPFUL.  What the what!?  And I'm completely pickled due to the bar staff's generous pours.

FrXbdCEBc3SBh-g5OWQSHg.review_text: Easy parking nearby and lots to eat as well.     The club itself is a great place with a lot of character to see that small, up-and-coming band you like.

vv1UqWpCyTxA-6H-cWh-Dg.review_text: i wish i could go to more shows. but when it comes to spending money, clothes get first priority (urbanoutfitters.com & a desk job do not mesh well). if i was able to control my shopping addiction, i would definitely be at the fillmore more (hardy har). this venue is just the perfect size & i love the balcony seating. the hallway, stairs, & bathrooms can get a little crowded but hey, it's worth it. dancing to live music under chandeliers is always a good time. even going out for a cigarette break is awesome, so many crazies to keep us smokers entertained. i will never forget seeing girl talk here. one of the most epic dance parties of my life (behind daft punk at coachella of course). daft punk means 'dance party' in french, right?

io7NI06ByR7JthVlS29YPA.review_text: I came, I saw, I was inspired.  I come here as often as possible. I am constantly checking to see what bands are going to be performing. I love everything about this place. The set up reminds me of an old school rock club. Everything from walking up the stairs to entering the main room.  You can head up to the balcony for insane views, charge up to the front to get sweaty and jump around and hang back behind the crowd sipping on your drink of choice and vibing with your friends.  The fillmore has been around for a long time and has so much history. A lot of great muscicians have walked these walls. From my first concert here in my youth with Courtney Love throwing cigarets at the crowd i knew i was in love.

5x7U7DOOQ985gw-wFalljg.review_text: i saw big head todd here, and i loved everything from the stagefloor to the posters upstairs. don't forget to grab an apple on your way in!

HpBvzMzchFrJ6XJmtRIsMg.review_text: Because the Fillmore so obviously needs a 713th review...   I LOVE YOU FILLMORE!!! BIG, BIG, BIG L O V E.   Solid: 1. sound  2. drinks  3. eats  4. ambiance  5. people  + AND a sweet FREE(!!!) souvenir poster as you walk out the door.   Radical.

ciTccgifDnETqLT0RNaNKw.review_text: Thanks Greg from the Fillmore for not kicking me out and letting me sit in your first aid area when I blacked out and also for believing in me when I said "I just didn't have enough air" even though I really just drank too much  Thanks Fillmore for being a dope venue and having a bar right next to the stage, which lets you be sooo close to the artists.    Thanks N*E*R*D for amazingness!

aOxFSXUEvy1cuSw7wfiJwA.review_text: Finally made my maiden voyage to The Fillmore last night after driving/walking by it countless times.  What an awesome venue!  Saw OAR (who puts on such an amazing live performance) and everything was perfect.  Cool vibe, great staff, cold beers, pretty girls and an all around awesome atmosphere.  OAR delivered a perfect 2+ hour set, doing an acoustic encore, wrapping it all up nicely.  I'm already looking at the calendar for upcoming shows.

j-wjUN4NTR8j51yMDa8Byg.review_text: Is there a requirement that to work here as a security person, you have to be a jerk? I think so because on more than one occasion, I have seen security people grab concert goers who were using a camera or recording a song on their cell phones. I have also seen them push people out of the way to keep the "aisles" (aka access to the bar) clear. And, when a fight broke out next to me at a show, the security people pretty much did nothing. What's the point of security then I ask you?   Anyway, I really like the Fillmore as a venue. It's historical, good lines of sight, smallish size, and pretty darn good acoustics. However, some things, including the security, make it so I can't give the venue 5 stars. I don't like the fact that the tickets are sold through Ticketmaster for a ridiculously high markup (or at the box office if you want to brave it on show nights or Sunday mornings). I also don't like the fact that they seem to be doing away with the posters (last four shows and not a one!). However, god bless those cocktail waitresses who have to weave their way through drunken revelers while carrying a full tray of drinks and looking for someone who has changed positions to get a better view.

lsZmt8AMGhQ86hLROMo5tw.review_text: There's nothing to hate about the Fillmore, really. Sure, It's a Live Nation venue so tickets aren't cheap, but thats the world we live in. The history alone of the Fillmore is reason enough to spend a little extra money on a show.   Besides the rich history, It's strikingly beautiful inside and has several different areas. The upstairs balcony seats, to me, are the best place to watch a show from. It can be tough to get there first, though. Theres a big side-room with hundreds upon hundreds of framed fillmore posters on the walls dating back 50 years. It houses another bar and sometimes has a small band playing as well.   The sound is fantastic and the lights are always great. Sold out shows are crowded, obviously, but not too much so, they have limited the number of occupants perfectly. Drink prices are what you'd expect, and parking is pretty difficult sometimes so be sure to go earlier than you intended.  So glad to have The Fillmore nearby, and I always look forward to seeing shows at this historical, gorgeous venue.

pasazXgye6i0TCGmfWu72w.review_text: The folks that do tickets for the Fillmore got in touch with us and rectified the situation, so I'm changing my rating.  Can't wait to see the show!

6HfGx_gVu1IHFnPL66kAOQ.review_text: This seems to be a favorite among many of my friends.  I love the interior and the sound is great.  I'm just not a fan of all the flat floor space that makes it difficult for shorties like myself to see the stage.  I don't think I'm even that short at 5'5.75'' :), but every time I've come here some gigantor being is compelled to stand in front of me.  This place is best suited as a dance hall, not for gawking at your favorite band.  Street parking isn't so bad and has earned The Fillmore its fourth star, saving it from being A-OK.

zAF6yw7Bz-U6fj8NXFa3gw.review_text: One of my favorite venues for live music in the city. I love the sense of history, the glam chandeliers and the walls o' historical posters you can browse before the show. Grab an apple on your way up the stairs, get a drink and head upstairs again to check out all of the posters from the shows over the years. Good, loud soundsystem, only drawback is the larger crowd, which can sometimes make it hard to see. I have such fond memories of seeing live shows here- totally recommended.

q2q0mZYs9c-iKU4pat31fQ.review_text: Beautiful venue.  Love the chandeliers and how they give out apples after the show.  Plus if it's a sold out show they hand out these cold vintage looking posters.  Awesome.

tx407EtvKoXXEZqYQFQVJA.review_text: SUNDAY, 10am-4pm- THE BOX OFFICE IS OPEN, NO FEES!  That's right- if the show says it costs $22, and you go to the box office on Sunday to buy your ticket, you will pay $22.  No convenience fee, no print-at-home fee, no nothing.  Face value.  Novel idea, huh? Been here five times now.  Once in 8th grade to see Weird Al with my mom, once in high school for Lowell's winter ball, twice for the Sounds, and last night for theSTART. This was great fun.  We went upstairs to the lounge overlooking Geary for a bit before the headliners, and aside from the $5.75 Red Tail, it was quite nice up there.  No lines, lots of seating available, and the bartenders were nice.  When we heard screaming downstairs, we headed down.  We were pretty much at the back of the floor , and we could still hear and see quite well, even the wee tiny ones I was with.  Sounds was good, as were sightlines.  My only complaint was that we seemed to be directly beneath an AC vent.  I actually had to put my hoodie back on.  Oh, and I almost forgot- roving waitresses on the floor!  I didn't even have to move to get beer (though I did have to flag down my wayward waitress when I saw her in the crowd wandering around meekly repeating "Red Tail...?  Red Tail?").  At the end of the show, you get that show's poster, which will be a nice addition to my bare yellow walls.  I look forward to the next show I get to see here. Minus one star for having to pay $34 total to pick up a $20 ticket at will call.  I suppose it's not the Fillmore's fault per se, but it's still part of the experience.  The Fillmore being in ClearChannel's hands may be disappointing, but its fate is a lot rosier than that of The Matrix. (plumpjack.com/pjmatrix/h…) They do check for cameras, but they don't seem to care if you have a small one.  The security guy saw mine and asked the other one if it was okay.  Mine was deemed "professional" and therefore not allowed in, but all you guys with pocket-sized cams should be fine.

Y577vGM-zQhIhfJzDujf_g.review_text: A great place to see a show!  But, bad parking.

OaJlwMnbJwHmMjlmgX6jmg.review_text: legendary. every show i've been to has been sold out, and yet the floor is still possible to navigate during the show. sound system is awesome, the coat check makes it easy to chill without the burden of bag and coat (ahem, girls with diaper bag sized purses, nudgin' them things to the front with you), and while a nice size, just feels so intimate. mega bonus for the free collectible poster after every show.

P_0ZKmG6jPbsJwfzZbDH1Q.review_text: So since moving up to SF ive already have gone to about 8 shows. Three of them i have had the honor of witnessing them here. a great venue, good sound, plenty of room(to get sweaty) and the staff are superbly nice and friendly. Though the pricing for drinks, food etc. are way too pricey, but it comes as no surprise, it is a music venue....in SF.

LAwptwS7nJwPkV5Niy9jkg.review_text: A memory I will never forget - "Lips", the lead singer for Anvil (a heavy metal band from the 80's that never made it big - buy "The Story of Anvil") standing up on stage playing his guitar, a huge ass grin from ear to ear.  He leans up to the mike and shouts "I can't fu#@ing believe it!!  I'm playing the fu#@ing Fillmore!!"  It may not be the best place to see a show, but it is a classic venue that has a meaningful history int eh story of rock music.  Classic setting, well run, decent sound and not too crowded.  I have been there a handful of times and will go again.  At the Anvil show in 2010, I accidentally activated the flash on my camera.  As soon as I flashed, a security "guard" grabbed me and said if I did that again, he would take my camera.  I apologized and all was cool.  As we were standing there a guy walked right by us smoking a pot pipe - the guard didn't say a word.  Only at the Fillmore - flash photography will get you kicked out but smoking pot (in a city where smoking anything indoors is outlawed) is ok. :)   gotta love it.  What I like about the Fillmore: - not too big, so even if you stand near the back to avoid the crowd by the stage you are still close enough to the band - they don't oversell tickets - I have been to several sold-out shows that were not overly crowded - the history - between bands go into the bar/dining area on the top floor and check out the cool concert posters lining all the walls - 3 bars - so the line is never too long to get a drink - a kitchen - for the munchies, and the food is not half bad - friendly staff - mostly, anyway.  Yes there are some grumps, but you would be grumpy too if you had to deal with 100 people every night telling you that they were friends of the band, knew Bill personally, and the other lines they say to get access to areas where they aren't supposed to go. - they have a coat check - if you are walking here you will likely have a coat to check - the little things - like giving you apples when you leave (or arrive for some shows), or giving you a concert poster to take home with you.  Another nice touch - we went to the Monday night Willie Nelson show when he was in town in January.  In the upstairs room they had a bluegrass band playing before the show as well as between the opening band and Willie.  They didn't have to have them, there were already 2 bands playing.  It was a nice touch and they were quite enjoyable.  What I don't like about the Fillmore (a short and obvious list): - ordering spirits or a cocktail is a rip-off - over priced for a small amount. Stick with the beer, still pricey for beer in a plastic cup but better than the hard liquor. - bathrooms - small and always a line  I am sure there are a few more things I don't like about the Fillmore, but the contact high put me in a happy mood and made me forget the negatives.  So for any "medium" name bands reading this, you should tell your manager that the next time you are coming through SF, book you at the Fillmore for a couple nights.  You may not make a ton of money, but your fans will love you for it.

bnfFzo_1xaJwrzPNDw5abQ.review_text: First time here for the Colourist and Wombats concert this past Friday (awesome show btw). Chandeliers, balconies, a fine looking stage -- seems super classy, right? Yeah.. no. The Fillmore is kinda gritty and grungy, which parallels their musical talents and it's great because there's a ton of history and character in this place. The venue was more spacious than I expected. The floor vibrations are a little unnerving though; it feels likes it'll give out at any moment. Didn't really get a chance to explore more, but I know it's a great music hall that showcases awesome bands of various genres. It's very close to the Japanese Center parking garage. Their box office is open for will call 1.5 hours before showtime. Only thing I hate is how they sell their online tickets through livenation grr. Regardless, can't wait to come back for more good music!

SwhybJ9ENKYvq--AWTgMzQ.review_text: This is the best venue I've ever been too.  I've seen so many good shows here...

8YDS3fnHvqnJ-Sk3X-ytsQ.review_text: Venerable institution, great sound , nice staff and cold beer on tap.

o7MQeI-3kM_5QXHFSm7R0Q.review_text: My ideal show at the Fillmore will consist of the following things: 1) A fabulous band 2) A clear view of the stage with nobody holding digital cameras or camera phones above his/her head trying REPEATEDLY to get a clear shot of the band.   3) Apples! 4) A cool free BGP poster! I've paid for #3 and #4 in my freakin' ticketmaster.com service fees.  I feel robbed if I don't get either of them.  All ticket holders are entitled to #2 so if you are one of those camera snapping folks at a show at The Fillmore or anywhere else for that matter, please minimize your attempts for a decent shot, turn off your blinding flash, and stop elbowing your peers in the head as you hold up your camera.  Thanks so much!

Hhc5iKV5CDoFLruTunY7YA.review_text: So this was my first time seeing a show here, and upon entrance, I was VERY impressed. It had this old feel, 30s-40s, with the low lit chandeliers, high ceilings, lush carpeted curtains. I mean I could go on. Everyone was nice, where are the bathrooms, where can I get water, etc.   They had a coat check, the girls bathroom wreaked of BM, so there should be someone checking every 30 minutes to spray, or install a window! My best friend said the men's toilets were disgusting as well.... But other than that, we only used the facilities once each, and we came here for the show. We saw Brandon Boyd and his side project, and they were great. I cannot believe it took me so long to see a show here! I usually go to the Warfield, but I will definitely be checking up on my favorite bands that play here!

2w03TT-I-6qXA4hm3O1Q_w.review_text: Yeah, i've been to the Fillmore.  What of it?  It seems like just the other day that i was there with lil' Billy Graham and janice came in and puked all over my new suede tassel vest and Jimi laughed so hard that milk came out his nose...  Then I woke up.  Good times.

m07sy7eLtOjVdZ8oN9JKag.review_text: Oh there he is, the smiling greeter..."Welcome to the Fillmore!". And the basket of red apples. Check. Well, I finally returned for the first time since April 2008...and creature of habit that I am, I came back for the same band, Brit-hop ensemble Morcheeba. The last time I saw them here, there was no sign of Skye Edwards, the effervescent singer who bopped with conviction in the contagious video for "Rome Wasn't Built in a Day". Just a French girl singer who sounded like she had one too many.   So imagine my glee to find that Skye has reunited with the Godfrey boys for this tour. Looking resplendent in her own self-designed pink frock, she was a major delight singing Morcheeba's hits with energetic abandon, while Ross Godfrey was showing impressive chops on guitar (see photos). What can I say? That trio makes me happy. I swing my arms up like a buxom Texas cheerleader and dance almost as good as the Bee Girl in the old Blind Melon video. Jamie W. was not overly embarrassed by my faux-hipster behavior since he was doing some swingin' himself.   Just love this space even though sitting is at a premium. Standing is your only option even if you come for the opening bands, which we did and regretted. Terrible. A tuba doesn't belong on a Fillmore stage, but who cares? We could sit in the lounge upstairs with a beer (see photo) or just hang at the bar downstairs (see photo). But when Morcheeba came on, it was a sea of bodies writhing in rhythm, and this whale was maneuvering through the waves...oh wait, that's me. The band played for at least 100 minutes, but my God, where's my song? Dammit, they fooled me again. It was their last encore...   "You and me, we're meant to be  Walking free in harmony  One fine day, we'll fly away  Don't you know that Rome wasn't built in a day..."

4IlFpxJ-HU1iBKo89WV7IQ.review_text: What a venue. The history behind this place is great, and the Fillmore really has a historic vibe inside. An old ballroom with a big stage up front and everyone just packs in and dances, jives, and has a great time. The crystal chandeliers are a nice touch.   In the front are pictures of hundreds of bands who have played the Fillmore over the years. I spent a long time looking at all of them and just pondering the history.  The medicinal herb smoke in the air, the intimacy of a small venue such as this, and knowing that the worlds best bands have all played here makes the Fillmore one of the top places to see a show in America.

-tnyoelmWwWj4vYh2hSSKg.review_text: Saw "The Dan Band" there last night.  Sound was horrible: lots of distortion, like when you turn up a bad set of speakers too loud.  Couldn't make out half of what Dan was saying between songs, and that is about half of  the show.  Saw him last year at The Independent, that was so much better.  Staff was nice, but that really doesn't matter when the sound is so bad.  Won't waste my money there again.

f2kprM12LzRr9KcP_X-87Q.review_text: The full live experience is right here.  The operators have clearly not lost sight of the goal to immerse the audience in a physical space that is stimulating to all senses (with a particular emphasis on the sound - it's gorgeous).  Best feng shui in the city.

s-LBWRdCHlNHW2mDUJ58Ig.review_text: Don't stand outside at 5:00 pm for 5 minutes when they are not open waiting to meet your 74 year old mother. They'll harass you and say you're loitering.

1cX_Wvc3HZHGW813_VJLhg.review_text: i thought i had been to the Fillmore before. i was wrong, i had been somewhere else some other time. last night was the first time i had the pleasure of doing more than buying tickets at the window on a sunday.  whenever i told people i was going to see a show at the Fillmore (Andrew bird, last nite. woo) they would make a little sour face or say  " i don't like the Fillmore" i hadnt been, i didnt know why, and most people who say they dont like something cant always tell you why.  well i could only agree with them on two points.  1. the floors were disgusting.  the dirtiest floors i have ever every walked on, and in the first 20 minutes of the show! i have a feeling they haven't mopped for the last two weeks. i actually lost my shoes dancing because they would stick so hard and come off my feet when i lifted my legs.   2. maybe the size of the venue. it is a larger space and of course if you cant count the buttons on the drummers sleeves, you aren't in a small enough venue to be totally hip.  oh well.  that is fine by me cause that place rocked my socks off and was one of the best indoor venues i have EVER been to!  the class! the history! the service!  we walk up to the door and have a very polite pat down from nice people not dressed to intimidate,  they pop your pockets, pat your jacket and see you off with "have a good evening"   then there is the ticket guy, he smiles, says "welcome to the Fillmore" and sends you  up. show your id on the stairs if you are drinking, and even the ID guy is all "enjoy the show, David" (reading it off my id)(very nice, totally useless, mindless and fluff, but it puts everyone In a very happy friendly mood on the way in) and last but not least, a man at the top of the stairs that just welcomes you to the Fillmore and OFFERS YOU FRESH PRODUCE FROM A BASKET!!??? that was amazing, i have never had something like that happen before.  i gave many thank yous back and went to check my coat, fearing the 8 dollars a piece that i am sure it will cost, and the 40 mile wait.  instead, i walk right up to the empty window and it is SEVENTY-FIVE CENTS A HANGER.  my jaw dropped.  the first time in my life that a coat check has cost exactly what a coat check should. something fair and aimed at pleasing the patron. none of this first 30 minutes hemming and hawing to decide if its worth leaving your shit with them, or just toughing it out and holding it, sweaty palmed all night.  now i was in a great mood and it was a great show(i wish you could review shows or music on here.. can you?)  AND THE BEST PART OF IT ALL WAS THAT ON THE WAY OUT YOU GET A FREE POSTER OF THE SHOW.  soooo sick. amazing care, the best venue. the best.

tGgTIueZy1JNTzQD9rkZLQ.review_text: 01.24.10 - Utada Hikaru  11.10.09 - Imogen Heap  11.05.09 - Mat Kearney  The Fillmore is by far my favorite concert spot in the city.  You can tell it's full of history as you walk through the halls filled with various concert posters.  The ceiling is high and the acoustics are amazing.  The staff is always helpful, even if they have to play bad cops (e.g. be security guards when people are obviously on drugs, bring cameras into coat check when artists don't allow them).  There's just something magical about being at the Fillmore, surrounded by your fellow fans singing the lyrics to your favorite songs together.  Makes me feel warm and fuzzy inside.  That or the air ventilation is pretty bad.  But I digress.  Coat check is $0.75 per item.  Drink prices are surprisingly reasonable given the venue.  $6 or $7 a beer, maybe?  The apples at the top of the stairs and the concert posters at the end are just icing on top of a decadent cake.

G5LXEaxhQMF_BVjNHkVr7g.review_text: The Fillmore rocks, have seem numerous shows here and there isn't a "bad seat" in the house. The acoustics are perfect, and despite being a medium-sized club, the performances always feel so intimate. There is so much history at The Fillmore, I feel that every musician/group that I've seen has played with a certain sublime respect, and that somehow comes across in the performance.

NN5jldDW0Puf8E3ZZjKqsg.review_text: A venerable venue, with great spaces and decidedly un-concertlike bathrooms. Personally, I love the upstairs room full of old show posters, the fenestration, and the balconies. Surly bartenders serve up the smallest drinks on record, but it's a great place for whiskey and your favorite band.

hq1X6tIBTNQufilIhrZK7g.review_text: I love this place.  To name some of the bands I've seen here: Foo Fighters, Weezer, Sonic Youth, No Doubt, Cake, the Donnas.  NEVER had a bad time.  Not only does the Fillmore have great, great musical ambiance, but it also has tremendous acoustics.  Parking is tough, and the area is quite sketchy.  But you'll love this place.

VopIGiWC6A1QN8FfoeMn-Q.review_text: I had a great evening here and it was my first time.  You walk in and everyone is friendly and you can feel the history of the place.

D41pJpZFKQR6Hm9P5sVV0Q.review_text: This is probably the best place to see a show in SF.  Famous, full of history, and still just like it was back in the day (or so I hear).  A cool atmosphere, surprisingly friendly security, and good food and drinks make going to the Fillmore always a fun experience.  Plus the posters are awesome.  If you need tickets to sold out shows, just ask around outside for Mr. Jones.  He'll hook it up.

AM4uQRNYUxvUbQEcOSaykQ.review_text: Never going to The Fillmore again. Have lived in the Fillmore Center for 6 years and go to concerts at the Fillmore all the time. Tonight at the Sonic Youth concert, I was harassed by security for standing too close to the bar while trying to watch the concert. I was the only person at the bar. The floor was packed and it was the best place I for me to see. Im 6' tall 220lbs had 2 drinks and was not even remotely drunk. Security guard wrote a black X on my hand and said I was cut off from the bar for causing a disturbance. I WILL NEVER GO BACK TO THE FILLMORE because of this.

HCtEYgABFgwGhHB3rPQeQQ.review_text: Moved here 2 1/2 years ago and I've had the opportunity to see many amazing shows here. It's a great venue!  Also love checking out the bands that play upstairs before the show starts.  Usually pretty good!  Awesome to check out all the posters of all the acts that have performed and don't forget to have an apple while you are there.  I always look forward to that and if the concert sells out, the posters when you leave are pretty cool to have. : )

nXMMoDzXRByQiWH9cf-FAQ.review_text: Book of Love, Front 242, Siouxsie, Legendary Pink Dots.  Oh... this historic venue brings back memories.  I'm going to try and see the Echo and the Bunnymen there in April and I'm excited to go back. Beverages are still very pricey, but it's still a hot spot to see obscure bands.  -- I'd recommend drinking at a nearby bar before the concert and then just watching the show once you're at the auditorium. The bathroom lines can get  very long too. All the more reason to not drink at the show or not to drink period.

2xb2kHnC-mFhtGggWBhZFQ.review_text: 3.5. I love the Fillmore's rich history, the intimacy of the smallish venue and ease of access via public transit (and parking if you're willing to walk a few blocks on questionably lit sidewalks). Staff is friendly and helpful. The guy checking IDs actually looks at the birthday and wished me a happy belated! If they don't have a female working security they won't pat women down at the door. They give out free posters for sold-out shows, which is awesome.  However, I'm not sure how many more shows at this venue I have in me. The drinks are strong but pricey per ounce and the crowds can get obnoxious getting up and down the tiny staircase or through the main floor to get a drink or use the restroom. I'm a short-ish person and it drives me nuts that there's nowhere for me to go but all the way to the back wall if I want to see the entire band. Venues like the Warfield or Fox at least have tiered railings on the GA floor. If you can't alter the main floor, maybe could you raise the stage by a foot or so?   Overall, I'm on the fence about this place. There's really great things about it, but I think I will have to *really* like the performer to see another show here.

Vw7gtSNnFm9AmLDWFdQJ7w.review_text: Saw A Perfect Circle here back in November (2nd Night-13th Step). We got there about 5 O'clock to wait in line for the show. Let me say...it was worth it. The Fillmore is a somewhat small theatre which makes for an intimate setting...especially when you're front row (which we were). They are quite strict on photos, so make sure to stow away your phone unless you want it taken away. Parking is a bit of a pain, but there was a garage a few blocks away which wasn't so bad. All in all, it was a wonderful night and I will definitely take in another show here. I didn't have the privilege to take home an apple or even a poster...mainly because we were too busy getting guitar pics from the roadies. I tried to get one of Maynard's unused water bottles....but no dice!

8d9HhuKC0fK3OtQJUWmr1A.review_text: Fillmore Virgin No More!  I've tryed the others, Great American Music Hall, Cafe Du Nord, Slims...etc...but yesterday I experienced pure bliss inside this hall when I saw James Morrrison. Before I get to the main dish let's just say this place is everything everyone has written about, so there's not much more i can say but..give me more of that Good Stuff.  Getting to the show..the appetizer of the night was a sweet little band called HoneyHoney, a melodic fusion of soulful folk-rock who got the crowd pumped for the  heat of meat that was to come. Beautiful songs which included one of my fav's called "Thin Line" had a profound effect, but unfortunately there were no more of their cd's to buy. Oh Well..Next Time!    Enter James Morrison and his ever-so talented band..(GUYS WITH ACCENTS WHO SING GREAT ARE SO HOT!) in his brown leather jacket,white symbol-embedded T, and jeans looking quite comfortable, but yet oh so fab that he had the men in the room swooning too(including heterosexuals..lol) The voice is incomparable to any singer-songwriter I've heard in his genre so far and I've heard and seen plenty. Deep feeling is put into every word uttered from this man and he was worth every dollor I spent to come and see him and more! Ladies and gentlemen if you ever get a chance to see J. M live, please do so, I promise you won't regret it.  Thanks to all The Fillmore pose for making it a wonderful night :-)

dWiSL_jVrDuindcBoHGTDg.review_text: Along with the Great American Music Hall, The Fillmore is the best music venue in the Bay Area.  You simply can't beat it. The acoustics are top notch, you get free apples, and the place just exudes history. Just thinking about all the legendary bands that have graced that stage is enough to make any music fan drool. I can't wait for my next show here.

7iM1-Fw0dC4OIdmg0DruXQ.review_text: great venue! saw social distortion and tumbledown here. i got there early enough and was right in the front.   getting out of the place sucks but the free posters are the bomb!!!

r-8eQ28RhnQPJdZXHcTXrw.review_text: I came here awhile back for One Republic's show (which had like four opening acts... Phantom Planet did a particularly memorable set) and returned for Amy Schumer's Comedy Central taping.    1iota hosted the event and were organized and helpful.  They put in an extra row on the right side of the stage to fit our group of six.  Parking was surprisingly easy on the street.  I ended up parking just across the street from the venue.

fE65QsHN6FdkzJ15AU3iOQ.review_text: Beautiful venue, chandliers, red curtains, etc.  Great architecture....  The upstairs is a great vantage point to see opening band and have a relaxing drink. Bartenders are always good, seem to pour strong for a music venue, and you're not actually bent over the counter for your single shot drink.  This is the biggest venue I love going to, because most of the time its just hipsters, a bunch of underage kids who want to be hipsters, etc. It's JUST small enough that I haven't seen the usual douchebaggery afoot that you can get at larger shows.  The floor is nice and open, so there are no "bad views", and the whole apple thing at the top of the stairs is just great.

dpEtyfB2o7MH1Mc_Ygoolg.review_text: Sorry The Fillmore, your sound engineering has become an insult to every musician that plays here and every customer that buys a ticket.   I can only assume that this is some kind of prank by the staff against Live Nation (AKA Ticketbastard) for purchasing the venue -- like some deranged high school student unscrewing one screw per day from their own school. I hate Live Nation too so I guess I'm sort of with you guys.

o84PuZsGPbQeJsax5j5oyg.review_text: They do not answer their phones!  Even during the times they say they are in!  Left numerous messages no return call. I guess thus isn't where I go for customer service just a concert.

QkWMqG7hQps6w487TAb35w.review_text: God I love this place, the posters, the history, the people but why can't you  take a two week time out and put in like 5 more women's bathrooms? This way I won't miss 30 minutes of the show I paid a lot to see.

_r97WFqU9dj0_QgwbiISxQ.review_text: When Daniel Tosh added an additional tour date right here in Charlotte, I was super psyched! I had never been to The Fillmore, so I stopped in here on Yelp to check it out and get an idea of what to expect. The reviews sounded good, so I was in! Unfortunately, I hadn't read any reviews about seated shows at The Fillmore. Tosh was a seated show, turned out. The cheap plastic chairs were horribly uncomfortable for 3 hours of sitting and were so close together there was minimal leg room and the kid sitting next to me literally sat on me when he took his seat.   The in-house bars closed promptly at 7:30, leaving several people who had been waiting 5 or 10 minutes in line stranded without a drink. The outdoor bar was still open, but was in the smoking lounge. Not an ideal place to wait for a drink if you're a non-smoker. I had read that the drink prices were exorbitant, but actually thought $9 for a 24 oz. tallboy was pretty reasonable. So they get one point there, but lose it again when you consider a VERY small well cocktail was $7-8.  The uncomfortable chairs were arranged such that you had to do a little bobbing gopher move throughout the entire show to catch a glimpse of the headliner through the people sitting in front of you. The people making out in front of us through the entire show (yes, at a comedy show) made these occasional glimpses even more difficult to catch.  The venue itself is really cool looking and is perfect for a more "intimate" show. Tosh even commented on how many cool chandeliers there were in the building and that there must've been a sale at Ikea. I would imagine for a non-seated concert it would be a lot better since there wouldn't be horrible plastic chairs involved and being tall would have its advantages. Parking is definitely a non-issue and we got in and out easily, which was a big plus.  Overall The Fillmore is a cool theater, but avoid seated shows here! Your butt will thank you.

PoixeJcdOAu4nycedmYcsg.review_text: Came here for the first time to see Lotus a few weeks ago, which totally rocked, but the Fillmore itself stole the show.  Aside from the fact that this place is packed full of iconic memories, incredible art lines the walls, the sound is impecable and the space is intimate.  The best part though? They have a big bucket of apples for you to enjoy throughout the night.  Might not seem all that awesome, but trust me, it is! (and they are SO delicious!)  There is plenty of dancing space and who can complain about groovin' under the chandeliers?   All-in-all, I can't wait to go back!  P.S. back in the 60's, they used to does the apples hehe!

pDiPepbuk1jf5KnxoIWfvw.review_text: Was here for the Gnarls Barkley show.  Small and cozy, a nice getaway from the stadium shows where you need binoculars to see the artist.  I was pleasantly surprised to see an eclectic mix of music followers. From the 16 year old emo kid to the 61 year old grandfather of 2. When the music starts pumping, you can literally feel the floor starting to shake beneath you.

MNem_eG6HsZ5mqtMjMK1RQ.review_text: wow you have to go see anyone just go.

0ZG8CwVOFFYrUdybrNzNOw.review_text: The Fillmore stands as one of my favorite music venues because of its relaxed atmosphere. The house is intimate but not claustrophobic, and the vibe rocks forth as a cool mixture of fun and class--which is nicely reflected by the chandeliers. The staff equally reflects an ease of spirit from the moment you step into The Fillmore.  Finding yourself thirsty while dancing in the dark? You have a full bar at your disposal. And, here's a tip: if the concert is sold out, don't go running out. Stick around and snag up a very free, very hip poster of the show you've just enjoyed--yep, the same kind of posters that have become valuable collector's items over the years. Excellent!

j0aLNLDM0H5CiUbduni-BA.review_text: This spot has always been one of my favorite venues since I attended a concert here back in 2006.   Again, if you don't mind standing in line all afternoon and throughout the entire concert to see your favorite artist up-close and personal, this venue is definitely for you.  You will get the most personal experience if you get there early enough; therefore, you will be literally feet away from the stage so if that's the case, I highly suggest you get there a few hours before doors open.
