Every concert I have attended at The Fillmore have been memorable and extremely fun. Oh and the fact that tickets are always for general admission floor (cheap) only make everything all the better :)

NYPLXaW-ErP19GrZqW3rVQ.review_text: One of my favorite concert venues in the world.

tvZKPah2u9G9dFBg5GT0eg.review_text: Hubby and I saw VNV Nation here.  What a great place to see an always fabulous show.

JWbODUP_sodo9mQvTS-_FQ.review_text: Ok, Kiddies. I've returned home from the Nylon Summer Music Tour concert at the Fillmore, featuring She Wants Revenge, Be Your Own Pet, The Virgins, and Switches. The concert ended at 1AM! Woo!   I hold in my hand a reflective Fillmore sticker (backstage pass? REALLY?) that says 'MG SWR 6 20 08'. Mind telling me what the hell that means?   : )  I LOVE this place. Probably a little more than I should.

a7TeC6dAgiu5QjeaHOjUAQ.review_text: First time here for the Danity Kane reunion tour " No Filter" Excellent venue, sound was great great views from anywhere. The bar downstairs was crowded but we had access to the top floor where there was a less crowded bar and you could order food. Best show Ive been to in a while, cant wait to go back!

eRPHfffCXi1j119IgEcEDA.review_text: It seems all my favorite artists love to perform at the Fillmore so every experience has been a memorable one.  Location is easy to find, the bartenders are nice to talk to even at the end of the night, and you never feel overwhelmed in the space.  It's a good place to meet new people as well as enjoying a musical performance with friends.  I saw Ladytron and Missy Higgins among others here and this was the one place that made the artists feel comfortable enough to meet with fans after their concert was over.  You can't beat that!

NReVNXrPveDiLvTrVYP2KQ.review_text: Hands down my favorite venue in San Francisco.  I've gone to my fair share of shows here and the atmosphere is awesome.  Dark drapery, candeliers, full bar, and being able to get so close to the stage that you can get the performers can sweat on you.  The mix for the perfect night out.  The staff is awesome and so are all of the bands that play here (i.e. Sonic Youth, Violent Femmes, etc.).  I've never had any problem getting to the very front of the stage and the crowd is normally pretty mellow.  I highly recommend that everyone go to at least one show here.  I promise that you'll want to come back.

pMltyeuU4SjT6Y8YVy7HBA.review_text: The Fillmore is historically famous having been the site of performances by 60's bands such as the Jefferson Airplane, Grateful Dead, Jimmi Hendrix, The Doors, and CCR.  The Fillmore was also neighbors to the People's Temple, a religious cult infamous for the Jonestown Massacre (and murder of Senator Ryan) when Jim Jones lead over 900 followers in a mass suicide in the self-created city of Jonestown in Guyana.  I've seen a few gigs here including Book of Love, Legal Reins, Ned's Atomic Dustbin, Suede, Fishbone, Bauhaus, and Simply Stupid (or a title similar to that).  I have to say that the sound at the Fillmore is horrible.   The atmosphere is ok, and, the bar service is questionable.  Let's just say I nearly got thrown out of the show once because I asked the bartendress what the appropriate standing distance was in order to watch the concert from near the bar area.  If I can, I try to avoid seeing shows here, that is, unless the band is really good.

0zfEKjs81Ri0EOXFWjb7JQ.review_text: I only been to this venue once but it was a real good experience.  There were lots of space on the main floor near the performance and other areas that you can occupy to sit down and chill and such.  The staff is pretty cool.  They were well organized and took care of business well.  I like this place a lot, I may need to find other performances there so I can go back.  This has been another Mike Vuong PSA!!

nwegLle0AogFpDODr3rY3Q.review_text: Though I've only been here two times, it's one of my favorite venues in San Francisco. It's a medium-sized venue, really gorgeous inside with beautiful chandeliers in the hall and show posters framed along the walls of the balcony. The stage is high so it might be rough on your neck depending how short you might be. The staff is incredibly nice there. Unlike some places where you might get thrown aside if you're recording video, they'll politely tap you on the shoulder to ask you to stop recording. There's a coat check there too. They give away free apples, and there's someone that always gives away posters at the end of every show. I really hope I can see more shows at the Fillmore soon.

CMN9c2PhtkMZHid8PphxjQ.review_text: I've never been here but it sure looks great. I mean, they have like a whole street named after it so you know its good. And sometimes you can walk by and there are big  tour busses outside, you know the ones with little windows so the rock stars can ease their hangovers in peace and you can walk by and think like oh my god I'm so close to fame right now i bet there are some VIPs (very important persons) in that bus but then there are two big bald guys standing next to the bus kinda looking at you and you have to act cool and be like psssh whatever i'm not impressed with your rock star bus or your steel toed boots whatever i'm gonna get some sushi.

zMEdR4h7FHNExwQLKvPP8g.review_text: Very cool little venue. First of all, I thought it was very unusual (and neat) that it's located on the second floor! I went here with my boyfriend to see the Get Up Kids on their reunion tour. It was a great show, and we managed to get right up near the front. Whoever described this venue as "intimate" was definitely right; the distance between stage and where you can start standing is seriously minimal. And as an added bonus: the bathrooms were clean. I love it!

4z6CFZLpbpWSEbJsasFFQQ.review_text: Great Venue For Intimate Shows.  Go Early and Enjoy The Wall of Posters.  Not Much Sitting Room.  Fits about 1000 people give or take. If you're lucky you will get a free poster at the end of the show.

iuKdlVt549hc2Kd9_tYepg.review_text: Besides it being really shady outside, I really like that the stage is raised (short girls where you at?) because at every concert, 6'2"-7' men love standing in front of me and despite this happening at this venue, I could still see 60-75% of the time which is a win for me. Great crowd (at least when I came for Clean Bandit) and the bartender made drinks strong. I say not bad, Fillmore, not bad.

T8AcaLi2dcDTCvPtFgxKxg.review_text: If you can see any favorite artist at this venue, might I suggest one thing ... ? GOOOOOOoooooo! In my recent experience with the Fillmore (which hasn't been recent at all), tickets sell out so fast it's headspinning. The place is small enough that you can hear and enjoy the music at any point in the venue.   Here, concert-going is an experience. It's about the whole room being into the music and the performer. Since the venue is small, not that many big artists go here a lot and if they do,sometimes it's at the point where they are about to break it big, and this is their last tour before you have to shell out the big bucks to see them as a tiny little speck at the Bill Graham Civic Center or the Greek Theater. Also, there's a history here that makes seeing a concert here so special - they've been playing concerts here since ... well, forever.   Whatever it is that's so special about the Fillmore, if you get the chance to see a favorite artist play here - I say go. It's the best opportunity you'll get to see an artist play (and you won't even have to break the bank to do it). It'll spoil you for concerts, and leave you wondering why all concert venues aren't like the Fillmore.

yZFT7XcGFO-Dcw4Z99wHXQ.review_text: By far the best venue I've ever been to! It's small, holds maybe 1500 people tops and huge bands play here! a Much more intimate atmosphere than a huge venue! I saw the Smashing Pumpkins here back in summer of 2007 and it was just amazing, two nights in a row... There's booze and they sometimes come through the crowds to take your order. The prices are steep, but not too ridiculous. If you're in town and someone you even mildly want to see is performing there, definitely check it out!

0Il7yXuovxMrjJcfpzImwA.review_text: I'm trying to be fair. The old days of Bill Graham are dead and gone (since almost a quarter of a century now), but this venue has turned IMHO into the worst of the Bay. A perfect example not only of corporate greed but also of laws and regulations devised by some CEO used to manage a supermarket! Unfriendly and rude staff, weird policies (you cannot bring in a felt pen... go figure!), full body search for whatever they may decide they don't want in (including smart phones... yes, it happened to a friend of mine while I was watching... he made the mistake of saying loudly that he wanted some memories of the event!). Sorry, but no more Fillmore for me. Only the Greek Theater in Berkeley compares.

qAuZ9Qi7iSqukH40iQdWXg.review_text: RIPOFF!!!!  Paid $640 for VIP tickets to see Crosby Stills and Nash last night. I feel like I've been robbed! Drove over 600 miles to see a special event by a band that I've seen now 46 times ( actual number) over the last 40 years! And out of those 46 times....this is the first time that I felt ripped off and disgusted with a venue, a group, and an overall experience. Couple that with the fact that we had to spend $160 per night for 2 nights for a piece of shit hotel because of a huge convention in town.....just put crappy icing on a very bad experience!!  Buyers beware!! The VIP seating is not that. It gets you 3 hours of standing room only. I politely engaged everybody in the place including the site manager. She told me that they knew the special seating was a scam but that it was facilitated by the band and the ticket company!    Sorry honey!! It's your venue and YOUR responsibility as well!   Oh...and there was...evidently  reserved seating. Upstairs there were tables reserved on the balcony.....but my VIP ticket, that I paid double for, wasn't for those seats!  Shame on you! Shame on the band, shame on Ticketmaster!! I won't be back to the Fillmore, I won't buy from Ticketmaster again, and I won't be spending my hard earned money on. 3 guys who profess to be a generations guiding conscience, and are nothing more than old sell outs!!  Nope.....you can't hold me up like that more than once!  And for the record, what I paid an extra $80 per ticket for???....a commemorative VIP pass!!!  Can you spell RIPOFF!!

DCvzFgRoFJp7KB7n83Mhiw.review_text: So, I've been going to this place off and on for years.  It's always been a fun place to see a show. Don't really dig the standing on a floor for 3 hours thing, but whatever.  I went to see the Butthole Surfers last night, 12/30.  The sound REALLY SUCKED.  I'm a big fan of bass frequencies, but this is all the front of house mixer seemed to want in the mix.  I stood in several spots and never found a good sound.  Most of the detail in the Surfers' sound is in the mid range.  Paul Leary's guitar was lost most of the time.  Gibby Hayne's vocals (while obviously highly effected) were barely audible.  I just have a hard time paying $50 for a ticket (after all the wonderful "convenience fees") in 2008 for bad sound.  The equipment is too good now, and there are many qualified sound engineers.  Essentially the Surfers sounded better at the dive club I saw them at in Dallas in '87.  To be fair, this could have been the Surfers' FOH mixer's fault, but my friends told me that the last few shows they've seen there were boomy and muddy as well.  That's too bad, as I've heard great sound there.  Also, the service fees to buy tickets are just plain stupid.  This may also not be the Fillmore's thing, but seems like one corporation may essentially own the venue and the ticket company??  Makes me want to stay home and spend my hard earned money elsewhere.  Too bad.

MQTF8C-3xd5tcTAwPPXZyQ.review_text: Four stars for the history, alone.  The sound is ok. The staff is usually pretty cool. It's much more enjoyable to see a band here than a super huge arena..

otpElPpfSqATlyE2g0EKdg.review_text: OK, as far as a concert venue goes, the Fillmore is an awesome *building* and has a nice small sized *stage*, HOWEVER having just been there to see Duran Duran (07/07/09), I can tell you the Fillmore staff are some of the rudest people I have ever met.   It's true they do these great commemorative posters that are limited, which is what they don't tell you. They make 1000 only no matter how many they know are attending the concert. I went to the show having spent more $ on the ticket to be up close and ended up right next to someone who paid 1/3 or 1/4 the ticket price I did. Fine, that's disappointing, I got over that. But coming out of the venue is so hard with these 2 small doors and so since I was in front, naturally I'm one of the last few to come out. A small part of the reason I went all that way (from Las Vegas) to see the show there was the poster and they were gone. I asked the staff where they were and they just said "All gone." I was quite upset about this and was given no sympathy like, "Hey, sorry they only make 1000." No. It was complete rudeness about telling me to get out of the way. I said innocently, "I drove 10 hours to get here and paid $350 for my ticket and I don't get a poster? Surely, there has to be ONE just lying around?" The response was, "I don't care where you came from or HOW much you paid, get the F (not what he said) out of the way, NOW." I was so shocked at how rude this doorman was to me. I just stood there dumbfounded. Then I stooped to his level and called him an expletive. Eventually, because I just stood there and wouldn't leave, he sent me back inside just to get me out of the way, where I asked around to several staff members about the poster and was shunned at every turn. Even the t-shirt seller was rude about having to repeat herself once again about the poster.   I tell you the venue alone would be GREAT if the staff actually cared about their customers which keep them in business and in this bad economy how nice it must feel for them not to care at all about their patrons' feelings or whether they return (I have actually been there before, but never again now). There's more where that came from, right? More suckers going in and coming out without the poster and staff telling them to shove off belligerently.  The reason I know they knew how many people were going to be in attendance is a) ticket sales (obviously), but also b) Duran Duran's fan club didn't even get some for their office. They told me that The Fillmore knew how many were coming and purposely didn't make enough. Yes, Duran Duran'd fanclub *should* have secured enough for their ticket holders, but the Fillmore should have made enough.  Now, even that wouldn't be such a big deal if they told people ahead of time only 1000 are made and were NICE to people who didn't get it. You just cannot be in business and not be nice to your patrons! I haven't been treated so badly at a venue since I was in New York City (no surprise there) but in 1990! It's time for the staff at the Fillmore to go through some customer service training. I should know; I have been in customer service for 20 some years.

bh907W3AGBio52dM1TpHiQ.review_text: Erste Sahne! Ich war hier auf einem Travis Konzert und hatte einen super Abend.  Der Raum ist klein und gemuetlich, dennoch gross genug fuer eine Konzertstimmung. Neben der beeindruckenden "Ahnengallerie" hat mir auch die Empore, und vor allem die kleine Bar im 1.Stock mit eigener kleinen Buehne gut gefallen.  Man muss absolut mal hier gewesen sein...

6Etrqb9lJiKZpjN7vMge4A.review_text: There is truly a feeling of history at The Fillmore.  Walking around and seeing the posters from previous shows is awesome.

VPINiUt71jfnBkGcf-XX_A.review_text: Not my favorite venue, but I do like that if you stand near a particular vent in the middle of main floor, you can smell the fried goodness from the food (?) they serve upstairs.   But if you are more interested in sound quality, stand about 15 feet in front of the back bar--something of a sweet spot.

bkT1wsuQkOyOVk0eOFM_8Q.review_text: second fav place in the city to see a show and you get a poster if you stay till the end....

xMnTIOIHq9wgC5O5DqpFMQ.review_text: My favoritve venue in San Francisco!  If you haven't been then we can't be friends.  Great sound system, drinks are easy to get, the staff is super helpful and they have great touches like:  A barrel of free Red apples for the hungry ones Posters given out after shows Did I mention the chandeliers! And if you are hungry the food ain't bad  Thank you Fillmore for some of my favorite concert experiences!!!

l5g_sCgZ4vdty5fFkauuQA.review_text: I really like the Fillmore.  I've been to a few shows here, including Beck, 311, Blackalicious, Smashing Pumpkins and the Fratellis, and have always had a good time.  Then again, when you're seeing Beck, 311, Blackalicious, Smashing Pumpkins and the Fratellis in a small venue how can you have a bad time?  The sound has always been solid and bar access is easy.  The free posters are kinda cool and crowds are always positive.  It's a solid venue and the history makes it that much cooler.  I mean, how can you not enjoy a good band playing on the same stage that Zeppelin played in 1969?

qluQa4MUao9gaoOpcqbGSQ.review_text: So almost a year ago I went the the boyfriend to see Robby Krieger and Ray Manzarek of the Doors play there and upon getting tickets and heading up the stairs I'm greeted by two dudes escorting/hefting down the stairs a totally tanked guy blathering on about how he was "just fine" even thu it was ridiculously obvious that this man was far from sober. So, get up enter in and two hours zip by as if time were on fast forward. This place is amazing...it's small so there's no real nose-bleed section, there's a bar at the back and also waitresses who shimmy their way thru the super crowded parts to take drink orders which is a wicked huge plus.  The lighting was amazing as well as the sound and even the bathrooms were pretty clean and not as congested as one would think after the show.  Coat check at the front and 38 and 22 bus line right outside the venue is super convenient.  Go see anyone here and you will enjoy yourself.

F262q88zc7zsdEeNCzcA0A.review_text: Got here right when doors opened and secured a great spot right against the stage. Steep drink prices, but it's SF, and a venue. All ages show can be a bummer. Yeasayer drew in a ton of little girly fans who thought it would be cool to rudely push their way in front of me, flail their hair and swing their arms while, "moving sexily" in order to try and get attention of the band. Kind of irritating to be surrounded by that.

3ZrjvKpBvez2uHzvDNxa_g.review_text: The Fillmore: one of the better venues I've been to.  Large enough to fit a lot of people and make getting tickets possible, but small enough to feel intimate and have decent sound.  The place has a seriously historical ambiance about it; you definitely understand that it's something of an institution when you're inside.  The two shows I've seen here in recent memory, Sonic Youth and Jose Gonzalez, were both well executed.  The various additions - fog and lights - were more or less tastefully done, the sound was pretty good, and the crowds were enthusiastic.  That's pretty much all you need for a good show.  Plus you get a sick poster on the way out.  Also, for the last show, tickets had actually sold out by the time I got to the box office.  The dude on the corner selling tickets from the hood of his north face puffy initially offered $50, but ended up parting with the ticket for $35 after I just stood there for a while.

iToDawcrukgElIWoqtc0mQ.review_text: I couldn't believe my ears when I bought my NERD tickets to the FIllmore for a measly $26. I had previously paid upwards of $250 to see them at the HP in San Jose, and I hated the restriction of staying in my seat. Even if it was the 5th row center stage area. Not here! I got in relatively early and I merely stayed standing close to the stage, and I loved the view, which was so much less than the other price tag. *sigh* Pharrell crooning to me from that close was beyond a dream come true. =P  The show ended a little after midnight. I wouldnt recommend hanging around to wait for a bus. The cabs came pretty frequently and I got home exhausted, but exhilarated from the concert.

swocJWD8R1iH20-lveXh0Q.review_text: I had a great time here despite the way my night ended...  The drinks are poured with a heavy hand and thankfully there is seating upstairs when you need that moment or two to rest your feet.  The lines in the woman's bathrooms are never good but I do recall this time it was unbearable.    I don't know if they're aware of the smoking going on in the main room but that combined with the heavy hand pouring of the drinks caused me to get a, "cut off" X on my hand.  How embarrassing!  At least the bartender was sweet about it.  lol    Top that off by leaving the house keys in a friend's car that's no where near my own house.  Let's just put it this way, my friend and I spend a chilly morning locked outside the house until our neighbor helped us back in at around 4am.  Never again.

XJhmTEAJuYRgIP4b9wMcTw.review_text: We were walking back to the car.  I was going to take you home, or were you going to take me?  Not quite arm in arm, but drunk enough to make us both let a little too many of those old memories back into our heads.  He came up to us, thrusting tickets into our hands.  "What's this?"  Free tickets, he can't use them.  We look like a cute couple, so here, enjoy the show.    We watched from the balcony, a band we've never heard of, but fell in love with just the same.  I put my arms around you, my chin resting on the copper waves of hair falling down your neck like the dark red velvet drapes that fell across the balcony.  Did we kiss?  Even though you were no longer with me, you still felt that old tingle as my breath brushed across your cheek.  He'll never know, will he?    The music was incredible.  The crowd adoring.  Lighters and pocket lasers lit the stage when the final set pounded to a breathless end.  I bought you a shirt that night.  What was it?  Some kind of twisted tree swooping across the front.  Do you still wear it, and think of me?  I still have that faded ticket.  I keep it in my wallet, and I think of you.  I hope you're doing well, wherever you are.

ipM70dVcbx5T3RAnHDxTow.review_text: History, man. This places oozes it. My parents used to go here in the 70's. I started going in the 80's and I first brought my son in the 2000's. Three generations of this Bay Area family LOVE The Fillmore. And we still go all the time. I was just there for Sonic Youth and Sic Alps and it was FANTASTIC! I've been to well over twenty-thirty (if not more) shows here and it is probably my favorite SF venue. A stroll through the halls to check out all the past show posters is worth the visit alone. I don't know how many awesome posters I have from shows here. And I always appreciate the fruit they give out to their guests. Way to retain the hippy vibe!   I saw Johnny Cash with Rev. Horton Heat and Ted Hawkins here. I think it has to be the best show I've ever been to in my life. Some guy in the audience was drunk and loud and Johnny said, "That's alright, I remember my first beer, too, son". CLASSIC!   The sound is usually SPOT ON. It's a big, cavernous venue so I know it can be hard getting the right levels but they do a fine job. Be prepared to stand because there aren't really many places to sit down except for upstairs or against the walls where you can't really see anything. If they have food going the night you're there, you can get some decent grub for a reasonable price. Not totally reasonable, but considering the "captive audience" factor, you could do much worse. The drink prices are a bit steep for what you get but I just chalk it up to the "night out" budget and let it go.   If you've never been to the Fillmore, you're missing out. This is truly a gem in the crown of what makes SF special. I've never been to a "bad" show here EVER.

0RHUgJ-dwwu7fR_FtzOh2w.review_text: I love the space, the options of seating and the atmosphere here. If you wanna dance, you can dance. If you wanna sit, go upstairs, if you wanna drink look in any direction and there is a bar so you don't have to spend the whole concert in a line missing your favourite song. When I was there last this douchebag looking guy walked up the stairs with his arm candy and demanded to know "where's the bar at?!" and the man with the 'stache that meets and greets at the top of the stairs, "Welcome to the Fillmore! Enjoy the show!" he told the dude to look in any direction, go through any door and he'd find the bar. I thought it was funny... obviously Douche & Arm candy were new to this fine establishment. I love love love when they have the apples, cause usually I get really thirsty and hungry after dancing and standing and drinking for so long that the apples just quench everything in me that needs quenching. Plus, when they have the posters, those are the best souvies! If I wanna dance, I gotta dance! And here at the 'mo I can do just that. I swing my arms furiously as the Violent Femmes strum so vigorously to "Blister in the Sun". I feel like there is no reason to not be yourself here which I think is important for concert-going. Even if there are some puffs of smoke in the sea of fans nobody minds and everyone minds their own business... you don't have to worry about being shanked, shivved or mauled inside the Fillmore (unless you want to), it's so full of love and history...  I suggest if you get there early, to check out the band in the upstairs bar lounge, it's always a fun atmosphere with up-and-coming artists, loads of posters to keep any A.D.D.-kid captivated for hours... I wish the drinks were cheaper, but still decent for SF - maybe pack the flask if you have a sneaky pocket to put it in! On that note, BRING CASH! Or succumb to the evil charges of a non-bank ATM fee... boooo...  AND, this may be important if it applies to you, but if you are handicapped or bringing someone who can not climb stairs, just call in advance and they are SUPER accomodating and you'll get a table and everything reserved for you.

6aIL5um7BTPhk4RPpe1Lgw.review_text: Such an awesome music venue.... and here is why:  - rich history, which is displayed on walls by posters of the countless musicians who have performed here  - great stage and huge dance floor to rock out to your heart's content  - upstairs with seating for those who want to passively listen but still enjoy the show  - an extra room with dj and bar upstairs for those who may want a break, or for a little pre-gaming with your friends  - always books great bands  My body still aches from all the hardcore dancing we did to Hot Chip last night. Even Free Blood made our bodies move. Fantastic. Saw them last year at The Fillmore and they were equally awesome. GirlTalk was another danceable show, perfect for this venue. They even opened up the stage for us audience members to dance with the group together. Got a little crazy! But, again, Fillmore was perfect for that. Can't wait to see the next show here....

2spogYybHdhMbMJ4_DsB6w.review_text: I love this venue and have seen many great bands here.  Coat check is great when its raining and you don't want to be all sweaty and humid in the masses.  LOVE LOVE LOVE when the line is moving slow to get out and you get a free poster!  I love the open floor.  Great atmosphere.  Minus one star for the fact that the carpets are so booze filled and sticky that they are like quick sand. Oh, and ive literally never left this venue without seeing atleast one pile of sawdust on the ground.  We all know what that means.

XbOve7rrtBOC6sLs_ZpWsg.review_text: LOVE, LOVE,LOVE!!  Saw 2 nights of Umphreys McGee in March. It reminds me of a giant house party with the stair case leading upstairs. Sold out shows still felt spacious. getting up to the front- no problem. All of the art work is amazing and worth checking out throughout the entire venue. People who work there are pretty friendly and helpful. Coat check is awesome. Upstairs stage is cool. Never had to wait in bathroom line even though there are hardly any stalls. Banging sound system & light show. Am I in Heaven?? Nope, it's just The Legendary Fillmore. A Legend For A Reason!

gmaWUt02_ixItBN2gQsMGQ.review_text: April 5th, 2010  Owl City concert along with Lights and Paperroute  I love this place.  It is such a classic.  You can tell it's full of history and it is one of the auditoriums that many famous artists performed at.  Five years ago i saw the band Play performed here as well.  Amazing. The auditorium is seat-less. haha by all means, you stand wherever you want.    The Owl City concert was amazing.  The atmosphere and people are just wonderful.  they do coat checks out by the front door, but no worries, nothing serious.  For some reason they had apples by the end of the concert.  Complimentary apples haha.

p2dEYOZ8i84eet0hsfbPaw.review_text: Saw Young the Giant here on February 8th and there is not a bad seat in the house. I showed up a bit late and was towards the back but could still see the band perfectly. This is such a small, intimate venue and the chandeliers were gorgeous. Can't wait to come back here for another show!

wsEo7QUn6fenj8SwAlp5qQ.review_text: Yes, this is a cool venue, in part because it's historic and hip, so cool bands want to play there. It's large enough so you can actually get tickets to great shows, but small enough so you can actually see the performers without wishing there was a jumbotron.  But the sound quality is never really very good. One show in particular was played so loud the clipping was quite obvious on the massive speakers. Or maybe the clipping was in my ears. In any case, there's been a random clicking in my left ear ever since. Like when you yawn, except I'm not yawning and those noises aren't real noises. Not cool.  But I still go back sometimes--wearing musician's earplugs so I can actually hear the music properly if they decide to make it stupidly loud again. Unfortunately, with or without musician's earplugs, the sound is never very good. Not sure if it's the venue's fault or the sound engineers'.

IBaDaTxp2yC_-AD2QscBOA.review_text: Been here twice. First time was a corporate party (our company rented the Fillmore) at which Modest Mouse played. MM played under duress - you could tell they felt like they sold out, hated themselves and that event altogether, playing at a corporate party. It wasn't a good show, their guitars seethed the hatred they felt for us the audience --- but apart from their despise of our corporate presence, the atmosphere was sweet.  The second time I went for a Jamiroquai show, and it was seriously up there with one of the best most memorable experiences I have ever had. In my life. I made it up to the edge of the stage, crowd was awesome, I made some of those temporary at-the-concert buddies where we jumped and had fun for two hours straight -- seriously kicked ass all around.   So I love the Fillmore.

TEtzbpgA2BFBrC0y0sCbfw.review_text: Went to see the Augustana/Fray concert. The place is beautiful. Hanging chandeliers reflect the stage lighting brilliantly (literally). Posters of past performers adorn the walls. Free apples in the lobby. Even the freaking annoying teeny-boppers couldn't ruin the moment ("Honey, what's the song they sing that you like?? Boston, is that what it's called? PLAY BOSTON... BOSSSTON!" ...  Shut up...).  There is one bar area downstairs and two upstairs in seperate rooms. One of the rooms featured a solo acoustic act who performed between sets (he was actually very good). The other room offers reserved balcony seats to view down to the stage (the sound isn't mixed to be heard upstairs; go down for a better sound).   Drink stats: Bombay Gin and Tonic: $6.50 (decent quality) Jameson on the rocks: $5.50 (can you really mess this up?)  Someone complimented me for my choice of whiskey. Did she invent Jameson? Still, it was pretty cool...  I'm assuming they accept credit cards, but I didn't ask. I hate having someone tell me about the "limit." There is also a service rule of one drink per customer per time.  Parking in the Japantown lot cost me around $5, but we got there early and ate first. We left during the encore so we wouldn't have to fight traffic (we were there mostly for Augustana, anyway). They gave us cool posters of the concert when we exited. Other venues would have probably charged up to $10 for these...

xSae7uRscWkxUJIHLqDzlA.review_text: Great place to see live bands - small enough venue where you can actually get a good view of the band.  Also, they get really good english bands - our favorite to see since in England you wouldn't get such a good opportunity to score tickets and get so close up to the band.

ss1PGLjfjitXP2o0_95SCA.review_text: I mean come on, it's Classic San Francisco and an icon to any music lover of any genre.

qt-TXVSzK1EUXtyu9Cb_VA.review_text: Love love love this venue! Especially as a concert photographer. It's pretty big. Parking is relatively easy. Taco bell next door. Free apples. I love all the decor and the upstairs area where you can sit in between acts if you get tired. Good lighting, photo pit. A few negatives, if you're on the guest or press list and are having issues they'll refuse to help you. At one show I was not on the list for a press pass so I showed them my email confirming that I had been approved but I guess that doesn't mean anything to them. Called my contact, no answer. All I needed was for someone working there to tell the tour manager that I wasn't on the list. Thankfully another one ofy photographer friends got inside and the tour manager came out and let me in. On top of that, while already angry and annoyed waiting outside one of the security guards decides to start hitting on me, asking If I'm single etc. Yeah real professional. Aside from that whole incident I do like this venue but wish the people working were a little for friendly and helpful

WT8aIJxPmLfqex3aLtK75Q.review_text: I love this place like a fat kid loves cake... I can't get enough. It's the Haunted Mansion on LSD... wait ... The Haunted Mansion is on LSD. It's a dark and euphoric dream, The lighting is great and the crowd is great. I'v ebeen there 3 times to see Goldfrapp and some one eles I forget .. but the place is awesome... I don't know about how the booze works I go for the music... drunk and concert-deaf don't mix... The crowd is great usually and the are really fun and dance around you and usually don't shove.. so yahhh I love it.

O2yU8xqhluPdPzm7BCVUiw.review_text: Great place to see a show. I've been there when it was crowded and I've been there when it was so empty the dance floor was all cocktail tables (Jonatha Brooke, great show) definitely not to be missed when your favorite artists come to town. The walls are covered with posters and pictures from historic shows you wish you had been to. Plus you get a free apple.

Wo_NHSfx08F0-A_vS0M28g.review_text: I love the Filmore! One of my favorite spots in the city to catch a show.   The best part of the Filmore is the venue itself. It has that great old school dance hall feel with high ceilings and creaking wooden floors, and they always have a great stream of bands that roll in.   But I got to dock a star for the horrible parking. Grant it it's the Filmore, so its hard to find street parking and yeah I can park in the Japantown garage, but I drove all the way from the east bay, so give me a break.

lrp5aQP31ar3JDlbwccfHQ.review_text: I've been to the Fillmore for a lot of shows. It's a wonderful, historical venue. The upstairs is plastered with classic Fillmore posters and the downstairs with photographs from the performers that played there. The carpet in the main room sticks to your feet from drunken dancing. The speakers will make you go deaf for a couple of days if you are at the front of the stage. And, usually, they hand out posters at the end of the show.  My only complaint is in the women's bathroom, mainly the handicap stall. The window is open for all the world to see your ass. But, whatever.

8wHKhb9wqIHca43Xr1xJZQ.review_text: The Fillmore gets me everytime.  The History, the amazing photos on the walls and the high ceilings.    While I like the setup of the Warfield much better, the Fillmore is the better venue to get up close and personal with the band or whomever may be on stage.  And whoever started the whole free Gig Poster idea?  I want to kiss you.  Hot Makeout.  You deserve it, because it's my favorite memory of any show, no matter how f-ed up or ugly that poster may be.

4eFEIEBoLU2HZLOVYD2D0g.review_text: Sneaky trick: If you're there for a concert, get there right when it opens. You can grab dinner upstairs and snag a table in one of the balcony portions so you can eat and enjoy the opening acts seated. If you know, you're getting old like me and you're legs can't handle 3+ hours of standing anymore. Note: I haven't managed to do this yet but noticed people happily eating and listening to the opening acts. I showed up 1.5 hours after the doors opened and it was not busy so I imagine you just need to get there right when the doors open.   The Fillmore is one snaaazy venue. I got the chance to come here for the first time for The Get Up Kids reunion concert last Monday. The venue isn't too big so you always have a decent view of your favorite band (as long as you stay away from tall people) and another bonus? Bathrooms are CLEAN! I dread concert venues I haven't been to until I can verify the cleanliness of their lavatory but the one at the Fillmore was decent. Yay! I know, I have issues with public restrooms but I'm working on it.

53bZ_EsXH71L7iFs5MP9_w.review_text: Very impressed by the history of the venue and the rockin' staff.    Coat check: 75 cents/item, you'll probably need to, gets pretty steamy inside.

dd1DYMDWv5QpZ954G4zh4w.review_text: There's a bowl of apples at the door and they're delicious -- if you're not hungry enough to eat an apple then you're not hungry. They also give you a poster when you leave. Delightful people, amazing experience, always one of the best places to see a show if you've already missed your fave band at a smaller venue. Go go go.

ZeiM3Uspn6CUThUBt03JSw.review_text: 1) This is where I met JeannetteZ.  She was sound checking when we came in with our gear.  I grabbed my friends camera & swapped in a 70-200mm for a better look.  As Christopher Walken would say... "Wowwww". Later in the evening we would meet, talk shit, get trashed, enjoy a bizarre cab ride to her hotel. I would act the perfect gentleman while I 'escorted' her to her room, then lose my cell phone, lose my car keys and finally stagger around chilly foggy SF in a t-shirt all night etc etc... you get the idea. One to tell the grandkids.  2) This is where I played. Anyone who knows what a backline is, or who knows how to tune a drum kit, or who knows how many strings are on a guitar or who can hold a microphone can understand the relevance of saying "I played at the Fillmore". It was a lifelong dream to shit in the same toilet as Janis Joplin.  To do "rock star stuff" in the green room.  Our singer even took a "where's my bloody blue M&Ms" freak-out. For one night we were famous.  For one night we were stars. The sound was amazing. The staff were amazing. The beer was free.  Apologies for not inserting my usual witty crap... This place gets me all sentimental.

hr19wCd01g0QQzhyX_JZzw.review_text: Best venue to see concerts at!

YbZg36FoMgkKcTEPae5siA.review_text: The legendary Fillmore has so much charm and history, everyone should see a band perform here at least once in his or her lifetime.  The walls are covered with posters throughout the years.  There's a killer view from the balcony up above.  The restaurant is pretty reasonably priced if you want to grab some food before the show.  Chandeliers line the ceiling.  If you want to see music history in the making, go to the Fillmore.  Parking does pretty much suck, but sometimes you can get lucky and find something close to the venue.  Just don't park in the KFC lot, you'll get towed for sure!  Great sound, great venue.

zQx3zsBsej7JlLj91aD8-g.review_text: The best music venue in SF, hands down.  Big acts in an intimate setting.   Even when there is a full house, you can navigate your way through the crowd so much better than in other venues of it's size.  AND you can buy tickets without the extra fees at the box office on Sunday.

PS80V0SCQiTtyt_hVuIsyA.review_text: Free apples! Concert posters!  Oh yeah, and great music in a small, intimate venue.

KNP8AJ_FWh6Y9eUTkbeE2w.review_text: The Fillmore, with its history as a San Francisco landmark stretching back to the 1960s, is an amazing venue for a concert. When you first walk in the doors and up the stairs, you're surrounded by photographs of past acts, from Johnny Cash to Radiohead. Be sure to grab one of the free red apples at the top of the stairs. The auditorium itself has a simple setup, with just a few tables lining the walls, leaving the majority of the floor standing-room only. Gorgeous crystal chandeliers dangle from the ceiling, dappling light on the deep red walls. Upstairs, there is a mezzanine level where the walls are covered, floor to ceiling, with copies of the kaleidoscopic posters that are sometimes given out gratis after performances.

KW3siwYbnIW2uvUxxQZbCA.review_text: I adore the Fillmore, however there are as many drawbacks as there are advantages. One of the biggest drawbacks for me at least, is that it's a bit out of the way, after the show is over it's late at night and you can't just walk down to the bart station, you have to either wait for the bus or catch a cab, however, a lot of time it is worth going a little further when you want to see your favorite bad. Another thing is the setting, while I enjoy the smaller venues, the Fillmore packs everyone together, though they do have a seating area on the balcony, there aren't enough seats to accommodate a lot of people, and when the pit gets crazy, you can find yourself either being dragged in or assaulted. I do enjoy coming here but the Warfield is more convenient. The memories I've taken away from the Fillmore make me a fan of it.

JwQ8oI5iXKaqfBgZSpm19Q.review_text: Great Chicken Cesar Salad (both my former roomie & I agreed) Not that great speakers (My boyfriend pointed this out & I agree) I like the chandeliers & the artwork posters. Pretty cool.

w37I_X9BTpxTo8mCT-BAZw.review_text: So this is a legendary music hall? Does that make McDonalds a "legendary hamburger place"? I'm not one to give credit for tradition, so if that's what the high ratings are for, that's rough.  I'm not saying it's a bad spot. I like it just fine. I saw Aziz Ansari here and would be happy to see another comedy show here. But, it's an average venue for comedy shows. Here's why   1) The seating was average. They brought in plastic chairs like we were at a high school graduation. I'm guessing that is because it's a concert hall and they want open space for people to dance, which is fine, but this review is for a comedy show, and I'd prefer to sit in a real chair at a real table.   2) Sub Par food and Drinks. I'm fine with event pricing, but $10 for a draft Bud Light in a plastic glass? Even AT & T Park only charges 8.50, and I could get Blue Moon there. The girls in our group paid $16 dollars for a double vodka soda with grapefruit, and it came out in a small plastic cup that also looked like it came from a high school graduation party. So that sucks. Also, our waitress recommended the Nachos, because they were "great for sharing". Yeah, not really. There was about 20 cheap tortilla chips on a paper plate with some melted cheese and pre-packed guacamole. The nachos at On The Border are better.  Overall, i'd go see any good show there, but I'd skip the drinks (they didn't have a minimum, which I respect) and buy Take-out food from DOSA across the street, which is fantastic.

ZIFiQi_qdtFkBkX3mMagMQ.review_text: The Fillmore is always a good time! Some of my most favorite shows have been at The Fillmore...I love that it's a smaller venue, so it's more of an intimate feel. Also, you get a free poster after every show! Can't beat that!

Z7rKy3T5HETMznaZwk9zSQ.review_text: This is one of the few venues I'll travel to see show at until i die.  Drive-by truckers blew this place up on Saturday 5/8/10.  Bands really dig playing here, and the sound system is top notch.  It would be nice to only serve booze/beers in plastic cups for the floor tho.  On Saturday i saw a girl twist her ankle bad when she stepped on an empty bud bottle(not mine).  the ability have your own consumables inside is a plus as well.

yarKTvl9r4f6ZTpQPszDQg.review_text: **This review is for the food only**  $11 Queso Fundido - we thought it might be some fancy nacho dish for $11. It was the opposite of fancy: a paper plate with a handful of stale tortilla chips, and on the side were 2 tbs of bad store guacamole, 2 tbs of salsa that had no heat and 1/2 cup of bland nacho cheese sauce. ELEVEN DOLLARS!!  Such. A. Rip. Off.

5rr_-knFqsX8AuTb4RNLZQ.review_text: Great place to see live music i would give it 5 stars if it wasn't all ages..

nCYcZqc1S2q-8_NvL2Lrww.review_text: Love this venue - great place for live music. I've seen everything from indy rock unknowns, punk rock, and 80's legends -- quintessential music spot. Beautiful old style music hall feel.  The fact that it is walking distance from my hood is amazing!  Even more amazing is how the cocktail waitresses are able to maneuver through the crowd to deliver full drinks to the packed in crowd.

AUOb8U2Wa31Z2DThPpvAgg.review_text: One of my favorite SF concert venues. The perfect size for an intimate crowd but not so small that you'll be shoulder to shoulder to strangers or stuck in some crazy fan's armpit.  I love the posters and art they have around the interior.   Alcohol prices are a bit steep but standard for SF concert halls but ticket prices are around the median.   PRO: The venue hands out free posters for the artists that are playing.

yRtajw-lGYoOXdOdfwV9hQ.review_text: I could see Billy Bob Thornton strummin' a banjo and singing lead and I'd be happy (err wait I have)  I love luv love this venue :-) If cher, dido, michele branch or jessica simpson come through SF, I'd die happy if they played here

OMoBzr4FhDkk7yV8zYtmiw.review_text: Another glorious evening spent with Cypress Hill!  I love the intimate nature of the Fillmore.   Every show here, past-present-future, is one to be remembered!

e-Bh0XDCOgYMaC-BmdxkAQ.review_text: Love this venue.  I've been scouting shows here since I was old enough to drive (ahem, cough, cough da eighties, cough) and I've never had a bad time.    Love the intimacy of the place. Love the rich history. Love all the cool pictures of shows gone by, almost museum-like. Love the bar area and its friendly staff. Love the sound system. Love being on the floor and being a genuine fan. Love the walk out and sharing the smile of a great time with fellow fans.  Oh Fillmore, what a long and beautiful relationship we've had.  Till we cross paths again old friend.

vUbriwBC83J4KWHnfjhCWg.review_text: My favorite place to see a show.  It's just big enough to hold all the history, and just small enough that the shows still feel initmate.   The chandelliers are beautiful and the posters are amazing.  If you're hungry, they have a (limited) dinner menu.  The quesadilla isn't half bad.

56vERWd2VPTfjytCQlSc6g.review_text: Perfect sized venue.  Big enough for a crowd to make the concert sound fun, but small enough not to lose your friends.  The smell of pot lingers throughout the place, if youre into that.  There seemed to be an abundance of waitresses which was nice.

3HeEnOEPXDtTpqajZB9Nhg.review_text: This is really a great venue!  I love the walls.  They are filled with posters of past bands that have played here.  It is a great reminder of the history of the place.  The chandeliers, and the lighting of this place in general, is beautiful.  I understand why they don't give away a poster after every show.  I believe they only hand out posters for shows that sold out right away.  Still, I think they should at least give you the option of buying one when they aren't giving them away.

KNiSAPf3RKUR-DALI2mesQ.review_text: Tons of history,  check out the poster room upstairs.  Smaller acts play in the poster-room upstairs between bands.....the food isn't half bad for a music venue either.

U2I4GBXRi9xYeiC0cXM1JQ.review_text: It's hard to dislike this place but leave it to the staff to piss me off enough to have to write this.  I go to the bar at the back of the hall where there are two female bartenders working.  One of them is in the middle of helping some girls ahead of me and asks me what I want so I tell her.  Then I notice the other bartender is free so I walk over to her and tell what I had ordered only to get berated by the first one for "double dipping."  Both women lectured me on how I should properly go about ordering my drinks.  Fine.  When she finally brings me my drinks she tells me they cost $24.  I have $19 in hand, so I take $2 and out and put them in the tip jar, and then get out a $20 to give her $25.  When she gives me my change I start to walk away with my drinks and she says "What, you're not going to tip us, nothing in the tip jar?"  I told the snooty coot that I just put two bucks in despite her and her friend slamming me for what was a result of their poor service.  So she tells me that shes sorry, they're just having a bad night.  I'll say.  I had to go dry for the rest of the night.  Give me a break.

s-c1Pr-_V09D8RINclufmg.review_text: This is a great venue. I saw the wombats and the colorist here. I am 20 and the funny part was that the guy checked my ID and thought that 1993 meant that I just barely made it to 21. So I got stamped for drinks! Besides that, drinks were kinda pricy going at 8$ for a vodka tonic. But nonetheless, awesome looking place, great bar. This gets 5 stars from me.

tJD_nNtVL6xhZTexZKr6Rw.review_text: It would be better if they threw out the pot smokers. It's a public place and they should let them smoke outside. It's a great place to get a good view of the bands and it's pretty big. Maybe better ventilation or something so us people with jobs that get drug tested will feel comfortable going.

4nIEoWJSb19c1YJAzRGt0A.review_text: Great venue, awesome music.    Why not 5 stars?  Here's why.    They need to stop having servers bring drinks to people.    If you want a drink, you should have to go to the bar.    I mean, here I am, staring and drooling while listening to Jarvis, when I'm pushed aside by someone precariously carrying a tray full of drinks.    Then I have to hear the loud conversation about how much the drinks were AND the tray is cock blocking Jarvis!   So not acceptable.    We're here to listen to the music.  Drinks are not the priority.  Be like me.  Get trashed BEFORE getting to the show.

mFCyzWgNJ0ULyvgdD2yPag.review_text: Great venue for a show. Lots of history and the food upstairs id pretty good. Lots of diiferent kinds of music. The bar is close to the stage :)

CP7ECIG5MXbZ18LKN2mzrA.review_text: The Fillmore is the best place to see your favourite artists.  Everyone who is anyone has played here (and a few who may have never heard of.)  It's intimate and definitely worth checking out.  Few that I can recall seeing:  Willie Nelson Etta James Steve Miller Billy Idol Death Cab for Cuties Santana Snoop Dog, Master P, Dog Pound, Warren G Fiest Mudcrutch (Tom Petty) Devotchka Augustana Tapes n Tapes James Blunt

Tyg1anGJ9asyyhnEegTzcg.review_text: An S.F. institution!    Small, intimate venue with beautiful chandeliers that's located in a pretty nice neighborhood (right next to Japantown).  The sister venue is The Warfield, located on Market St., and it's equally impressive in it's own right.  TIP:  If the show sells out early, they pass out free, limited edition posters (just for that particular Fillmore show) when you exit the venue.  TIP #2:  Grab yourself a red apple near the stairs.  It's a  wholesome tradition. :)

zx6EpMx2MR31GPorpFFWlQ.review_text: Getting here was a tad stressful for me. For me I get so stressed driving around SF lol! But it was worth it this time. We went for a Clean Bandit concert, on a saturday night. Parking was really tough to find, but luckily one of my friend, Nick told me to park at the Kubuki parking structure. So damn cheap! I parked from 7-11? And I ended up paying about 5 bucks? No need to go discuss that further more. Again my friend told me that finding the Fillmore would be a little hard to find and it was. It was very low-key but once you stepped in, it was very nice and regal looking. It was an open dance floor when I went so I was able to stand so close to see Clean Bandit. One thing that I didn't like was how it wasn't ventilated or air conditioned so when it was later into the concert I was sweating bullets. The bass and the amount of people moving around literally shook the dance floor and that was a crazy experience. Water bottles were about $4, I didn't get to look into other drinks though. The waitresses were really nice and the crowd was really respectful of one another and gave the waitresses space to maneuver around. Even the violinist of Clean Bandit interacted with one of the waitress. That shows you how great the vibes were that night. A great tip is that after the show, the Fillmore will always give you a poster, so be sure to get one. Another is that they give out FREE apples as snacks. Bathrooms were a bit small, it wasn't super clean but I can't complain about it. I do recommend if you get the chance to go to the Fillmore go for it and don't pass up on it!

PVpeB-fTAd5qi1vxDTSehw.review_text: Went there last night for a concert. Had a blast. The venue is small and totally intimate. The chandliers hanging from the ceiling were pretty rad along with the upstairs balcony. All the posters and pictures on the walls are great and it really makes you feel like a party of history. Its a but grundgy but that makes it feel like you're really taking part in a grand old place.

qI3l8JVM8EO4uBuisCkgEw.review_text: Been here twice and they were both great experiences.  I kind of felt honored just to be there.  I biked there are parked around the corner in front of the market store.  They have a bike rack on the side street, but it actually looked for sketch than locking up right on Fillmore.  The bag check was pretty weak, and the one time they did find my bike tools they let me in when I explain what they were.  ("That's a pump.... no,....FOR A BIKE!)    Being inside was great, when I wanted to relax I went upstairs and sat in the lounge.  The floor is nice and wide open with plenty or room to get involved in the crowd or stand back and enjoy.    I saw both music and comedy shows there and the sound quality was great for both.    Good job, Fillmore.

pmLabvtvAOB7rtMh8eoZSw.review_text: Other yelpers have called this place magical, and for a music fan it really is special.  The walls are covered with posters and photos from performances covering the past 40 years, so when you come up for air between acts you get a sense of just where you are - a sort of musical mecca.  You're guaranteed to find one that makes you say "I wish I would have been here for that!"  (I've been lucky enough to see the Cure, Lush, Travis, and most recently the Yard Dogs Road Show.)  The sound & lighting has always been good for the shows I've seen here, drinks are strong (and expensive as you might expect in SF), and the staff is really cool.  Also, it seems like they don't oversell their shows, which means you can actually work your way thru the crowd at capacity - great if you have to hit the bathroom or grab another drink at the bar.  If you get the chance, find an act that you'd like to see and see them perform here.  It will be an experience to remember.

Pud5uhlfZoFNWwYbxswmNQ.review_text: I saw My Morning Jacket here one time.  It's a great place to check out indie music.  The staff are chatty and friendly.  I think every band known to man, big and small, from rock to hip hop played here.

xqe8QcpRryKuK2wn5TZJYg.review_text: So amazing this place.  One of my favorite concert venues ever.   They have a beautiful collection of original art posters for every rock show that's ever come through.  I think I could spend 5 hours just staring at their walls alone.  Tiny and bare.  It forces acts to strip down the fancy sh*t and just get to the music.

bWxxfPP08zWJuM5wKG0LvQ.review_text: Hands down the best concert venue in the city. I love it with a passion and will pretty much only see a band if they play here. I was fortunate enough to score tickets to see Coldplay here a couple years ago (yes, I love Coldplay, shut up! They are not derivative of Radiohead or any other EMO band) and that was probably one of the best concerts of my life. I've also seen Soulive and Devotchka here. Fabulous.

-nkf1EI9VjW6MucS1b7VdA.review_text: Was an honor to be in such a historic venue for music in San Francisco. With the posters, the beautiful hall, the great music, and the wonderful staff, I hope that more artists I listen to perform here.  As you enter the Fillmore, you are greeted but knowledgeable staff and a lobby full of show posters and photos from concerts past. Entering the music venue, you are welcomed by beautiful chandeliers, a solid stage, room to dance, and drinks to lubricate your joints and ego so you can move and groove. A place with a bar and balcony? Solid.  The sound for the performers (Clean Bandit and Little Daylight) was great for the most part, a few static glitches at the beginning of the sets, but the balance for the show in general was great. The lights, the sound and what the performers provided meshed into a wonderful production.   And the traditional apples and posters? Best touch ever.   Would definitely watch a show here again!

0tEg1pUyRyOCf1jWvB0R2A.review_text: The venue was okay. Nothing special other than the walls covered in posters of past performers. There was a really grump, old security guard that constantly complained and "critiqued" (read: talked out of his ass about music) the entire time. He was borderline racist as well. The opener was a black rapper and the security guard was making some very politically incorrect statements about him. Additionally, one of the younger security guards was on a power trip. He was constantly yelling at people over the littlest things.   Overall, I'm completely neutral over the place. I won't see an artist solely because they are at The Fillmore but I also won't avoid seeing an artist because they're playing here either.

azivU1jkJhPSKS6ASMegQQ.review_text: Ive been here many times, from concerts (Pepper, O.A.R.) to stand up comedy (Zach Galifinakis) and it has been great for all. I love going to shows here, its probably my favorite bay area venue.   I am always bummed when I don't get a poster - I have two!  Oh, and to the whiner about getting reamed for trying to sneak a bottle in - you are just not very good at sneaking booze in - maybe you should be smarter than the pot heads who easily slide through security haha

fZxazDhgaQMHeV4Xsb-h_w.review_text: Just watch a show here.  Yes.  Really.

lXl7w34iFh7Z0nnE_JIWgQ.review_text: One of the best venues to watch your favorite band! I saw The Smashing Pumpkins here in 2007. It was great! Anywhere on the floor has a great view!

t1NmJ-g09NijXqycgF-evA.review_text: Great space - huge with a lotta cool posters, good acoustics, clean bathrooms, they give out free posters when the show sells out and the bar lines are long but move quickly due to efficient bartenders and doubling up on bartenders. Also it's not cash only. And it never gets too hot. And you can sit down upstairs.

LXQLTfi2p6ZFEodfW3MyMg.review_text: I really enjoy that the culture and buzz at the Fillmore is always very upbeat, no matter what band I am seeing. The drinks are very expensive, but that is what happens at arenas and concerts. If you can find a speedy bartender who is attentive, tip them well at the beginning of the night and keep going to them! Unfortunately, it is all standing room on the floor, which means that I can usually never see the band (I am 5').

G1cpx6l83FYwk82kizb-bw.review_text: went to my first show here.  cake.  about 13 years ago.  we were sitting at a table along the side, the waitress came up and rudely said we needed to order food.  to which i replied, well then bring us some food. the food isn't good, but the shows are fantastic.    and it was the first time i smelled weed.  my shirt reeked of it, but i loved how it smelled so i didn't wash it unti the smell had been all smelt up.

z3fyMSMx-yl8YndFCpO0wQ.review_text: I hope this story illustrates the highlights of the world famous Fillmore.  I came on a recent Friday night for rave rockers Klaxons. I had an extra ticket and sold it to a hipster wearing a brown leather jacket on the street corner. Outside Fillmore there's usually a couple of wily scalpers selling tix for twice face value, but not tonight. This show didn't sell out.  After my friend and I got inside, we went straight to the bar. We both got Stellas, which are $0.75 more than Buds. We walked onto the dance floor. The crowd was a mix teeny boppers and indie rock fans in their 20's and 30's.  We nestled up to the stage. In front of us was a petite brunette. She wore a gray tunic, blue leggings, tight boots and the cutest bangs this side of Anna Friel (of Pushing Daises). As my friend and I talked about nothing in particular, Ms. Friel fished a small notebook from her bag. A pensive look crossed her face and she jotted a line down. She tucked the notebook back into her bag, only to retrieve it two minutes later and do it all over again. "Maybe she's a reporter for the Daily Cal," my friend remarked.  My friend stepped away to buy another round of drinks. The brunette remained in front of me, alone. I really wanted to ask her what she was writing, and more than anything, I wanted to see her toss the bangs out of her eyes. But the more I thought about it, the more my arms and legs locked up. Bangs even took a step back--I could hear her fine writing instrument scratch the journal's acid-free paper--but I couldn't budge. As quickly as it had opened, the window of opportunity shut. She walked away to the side.  My friend came back with beers. I grabbed mine and knocked it back. "What the hell?" he asked. I explained how I had just dropped the ball. We looked over at her. It had been just a couple of minutes since she left, but already she was talking to someone. Her new friend wasn't just anybody, either. This guy--one tall dude, if I may say so--wore black-rimmed glasses and a brown leather jacket. It was the hipster I sold my extra ticket to. Not only did he get a tremendous deal on a concert ticket, he also got my girl. Over the next ten minutes, waiting for the show to start, I snuck a few glances at them. They talked the whole time. If there was any consolation, she kept her arms crossed, marking her personal space.  The lights dimmed and Klaxons emerged. I put in a pair of earplugs, available at coat check for a small donation. The show rocked from Minute One. The teeny boppers threw their arms into the air; the indie rockers gyrated and pulsated low to the ground. One rocker was really getting down. She cleared a 5 foot space around her and shook her body like it was going out of style. It was Bangs, sans Brown Leather Jacket. Bangs passed by me but before I could react she flitted away. I shook my head and redirected my attention to the music. Klaxons put on a damn good show.  The concert ended 70 minutes later. As my friend and I trudged along in the inevitable cowherd that ends every show, I scanned the hall for Bangs. Perhaps off to her next assignment, she was nowhere to be found. I grabbed an apple from the barrel at the top of the stairs and bit in. It was sour.  Final tip: don't bother bringing your own ganja to The Fillmore. Two words: contact high.

A2GArf1Nc-Kb1EK3TubKYA.review_text: My husband and I were thrilled to see Guster perform here the other night. What a quirky and fun experience in a packed room.  We scored street parking a couple blocks away, and we got to stroll down the lovely Japantown street on the way to The Fillmore.  Hassle-free entrance, friendly employees, intimate venue, strong drink.  The only reasons for 4 instead of 5 stars:  - Venue got hotter and hotter as more bodies packed the place. Big bonus points, though, because the staff realized this and then blasted the A/C. Was so much more enjoyable after that. - I wish the drinks were a little less expensive. It was $16 for one easy mixed drink and a beer. - Also, I think they should do away with servers taking drink orders from the middle of the packed floor. They do a balancing act with the drink tray high above their heads....Unfortunately, we witnessed one of the servers drop her tray of drinks on someone's head! Fortunately, she made up for it by apologizing profusely and for returning with napkins and a bottle of water.  Otherwise, what a cool place for a show. And getting a free high-quality concert poster after was a nice touch.  You can bet we'll be back.

jmhAZXgDDeuPMyxrnBA77g.review_text: This is definitely a standing/dancing venue. I've seen Ladytron and the  YYYs here..maybe another band, but I don't remember.   It's small, but not as small as The Independent. They have very pretty chandeliers, so be sure to glance upwards while you're there. =)  There isn't much seating; most of the seats are on the side or upstairs and usually they're reserved. There's a full bar of course.

G0jy3hldFyLBbxtMoF4PkA.review_text: What is it about this place that makes the most magical concerts?  I have seen every type of show here. Rock, Pop, Metal, Electronic. The crowd and attitude changes yet the spirit remains the same. People will mosh, dance, sway, show their chest.. anything to make this an enjoyable experience.  This place has usually sounded better than most venues I've been to. I can't say much about the acoustics because it's really too loud where I stand to tell. But I certainly can't complain.  I've never had a problem with the staff working there. When most tend to be rude, they have usually shown some decency. Drinks are good too!  So thank you, Fillmore. I look forward to losing more of my hearing with you!

iRFWXQpFgGCkhfc6EIbSWg.review_text: Great place.  When I am there I like to imagine what it was like in the 60's.  Once the smell of that good 'ol marijuana starts to surface I smile.  They are strict on where you can stand.  They have this damn line that you can't cross toward the side of the stage.  Don't know why.  If I want to have my eardrums blown out then that is my choice.  Anyway, as I mentioned before, great place.

J4g9cE-lq3LxMm0bfqr3-A.review_text: Perhaps the single best venue in the entire Bay.  The Fillmore has an old-school flair with a lot of history. You really feel something simply being there. The intimate room means that unless you're short, there isn't a bad place to stand on the floor, and if you're determined enough to get close by arriving early or by gradually making your way forward, you'll be very close to the stage. The sound is always expertly mixed.  There is an upstairs area where there is a bar, a small lounge/seating area, and oftentimes there will be a local guy with a guitar putting on a small little performance of his own during or between the first few bands.  Parking on the street isn't that bad, but San Francisco can be San Francisco no matter which way you spin it. At the end of the show they hand out concert posters, so those seeing their favorite band will most likely walk away with memorabilia worth framing.  As far as the venue itself goes, The Fillmore is quite simply one of the best - or THE best - in the Bay.

ORf0NEGHNkyHzmFE4MOxWw.review_text: The Fillmore is probably my favorite place to see a show in the city (there are a few other favs too).  I've seen many many bands/groups/artists here. The drinks aren't that expensive considering its a music venue. The bartenders are nice.  I love the decor, all the music posters. And I LOVE that they give you free posters on your way out for the show you were at. I've built a nice collection. I love the Fillmore!!

YmTS2FFbScIKrGNywXgkag.review_text: Love this venue. Pogues rule, great time. Every band i've seen here has crazy drunk front men who kick ass. Love it.  Tuesday morning after... still loving it with loads of coffee.

hE34xpG35WugHznWf79HfQ.review_text: Why oh why do so many bands I want to see have to play here? Alas, I keep coming back. I am a slave to live music, that is all I can say.   Pluses for the bands they host, the fact that you can get food here and the fact that the place holds a good amount of people.  Minuses for the sound quality, the fact that the nachos are $15 and that, though it holds many people, the space is not set up efficiently enough to actually SEE the band you came to see.

zVZVKHFhcbLl8MQXyX_Dsw.review_text: One of the most classic venues in all of San Francisco, I only wish I had the pleasure of going here more often. The drink prices are kind of high, but I love this place so much it doesn't even matter.

apX-FaMlzeBDx38Tba2nUw.review_text: The best place to see a rock concert, bar none! Standing room only, so if you are short (and I am not), you may have a problem. The history here is unbelievable.  Great, intimate setting with a bar in the back and off to the left of the stage. The chandeliers are a nice added touch.

P3onMWiIYufwVxHhX7BKXQ.review_text: I like relaxed intimate settings, and I know Snoop Dogg does too. All he ever does is "play in the sheets, sheet, sheets, smoke him a cigarette, and go back to sleep."  Him and I are totally alike in that way, minus the smokes, and "Gin and Juice." On the other hand, I do like to "Drop It Like It's Hot."  And, I was doing just that, while belting Snoop's legendary lyrics with a smoky, sweaty, sold-out crowd on January 18th. God, I fackin' love this place! I have been here two other times, once to see Grace Potter and the Nocturnals, and another group I can't recall. It must have been another one of those nights stuffed with maryjane laced crowds. There isn't a bad spot to stand or sit in the place. Unless, you get stuck behind a Herman Munster. I, absolutely, love that it is so easy to grab a drink here. There is barely ever a wait. Them bartenders are quick!  My only sadness is the parking sucks major nuts and it is not close to BART, but for the bus avengers you can take the Fillmore MUNI bus to Fillmore at Geary, or the 38 Geary to Geary at Fillmore.  When you walk into the Fillmore, you will be impressed. It is like going "From tha Chuuuch to da Palace."

BjURDSCEmPIj5A2Xxf1Zgg.review_text: Great venue to get up close and personal to the performer but next time I'm going a little earlier and getting a seat on the second floor and grabbing a bite to eat while I sit and enjoying the show from afar. I guess I'm getting old but standing up for 3 hours is a little hard on my legs...and feet...and back.  What the hell am I doing going to a show when I sound like such an old fart.   Also, bring cash for the bar. There is a $30 minimum. I guess if you're with a group of friends and get 5 beers for $6 a pop then you could easily make that minimum but there were only three of us. Lucky me I brought lotsa cash so that I could cover the drinks.  Another also - park on the street...for free. People talking about garages when Geary is right there. Okay, so you have to park like 2 blocks away to get/find parking but it's free.

epGQfAOfJ7WzO-10Hg4Yng.review_text: The Fillmore, what can I say?  I've seen more shows than I can count here and it remains my favorite venue with the fondest memories.  For some reason every crowd i've been in has rocked it and noone stares at you funny for dancing.  Even when its packed I can find some little corner or space to dance in.  Memorable events?  Hot Buttered Monsoon playing Kashmir...I got goosebumps and there wasn't one person in that whole damn place without their body moving.  Article Here: (jambase.com/headsup.asp?…) Other memorable events?  Railroad Earth last year was fun...so fun!  Anyways, enough memory recall...this place rocks!

mul5X8OwCAlYBSAJE5GIdw.review_text: Yeah, this place is the dogs bollocks.

RbwHFSWgVul0IG_o88L8CQ.review_text: I love the Fillmore! Apples and good music, plus none of that space in the front for media.

zpnd-D0-ahcfrYYLvt04oA.review_text: So, I get back from a relaxing week in Monterey just in time to pound a drink or two and get to the Fillmore to see the Roots.  Unfortunately, I can't seem to shake the relaxation mode part.  So, I end up sipping my drink (vigorously) all the while searching high and low for the ticket, which I explicitly remember noticing something about the fine print saying "YOU MUST HAVE THIS TICKET TO GET IN THE DOOR AND SEE THE ROOTS KELLY."  I call the Fillmore and tell them I've lost my ticket and don't have a printer (truth be told, I could not remember which email account I had it sent to and even though I searched through all three, I couldn't find it), could they do something.  The manager said they'd print more tickets.  So, phew, the stress that I should have felt, disappeared.  Which meant, I had more time to relax.  Finally, by the time I got my act together and got to the Fillmore, there were a whopping 20 minutes left of the concert to which I held a very coveted ticket.  When I arrived and started to explain my predicament, they laughed and said the show's almost over, go on in!  Thank you Fillmore people for being rational.  I'm sure some upidy venue would have made me shuffle around the red tape until I could get in for only one minute.

aqQ0MR0a9Ht9srz7PTRE3g.review_text: The Fillmore is a beautifully constructed venue that somehow remains very intimate despite the fact that it somewhat large. But you can see the band very well from just about any place you're at. This is probably my favorite venue to see a show. I always have an amazing time here!

zF23ZNDizE0ZmwRDfG-BWA.review_text: Love it love it love it.  Such a cool place to see a show.  It gets five stars for the history alone.  I love that you get to see the bands up close and personal.  Oh, and I met Chuck D. from Public Enemy there.  He was just chillin' in the crowd checking out HIS opening act.  He had kind of a 'bubble' around him.  I kept asking my girlfriends, "Is that Chuck D.???  it really looks like Chuck D.!"  So i finally got the balls to just go over and ask him to sign my ticket.  He was HELLA cool!  He even had his own Sharpie, like he was just WAITIN' for someone to ask for his autograph.  After that he was totally bum-rushed by everyone.  I'm proud to say that I was the first one to approach him!  :D

0uxOyZZUHLNj5Czo_TneUA.review_text: What can I say about the Fillmore? I just going to give you a over hand review of the whole venue. If you like drinking, you likely to find Bud Light there. There are shows nearly every day of the week, with three days or four days apart. Shows prices range from 20 bucks to 50 bucks. Kinda expensive. Shows are on sale on sundays at 10 AM.  There are several doors and shows. Most of them are going to be at Door 8 or Door 7. The music played there, ranges from hip hop, folk and rock. Most of the artists are Indies. You will rarely see a high time main stream artist here.   I think the oddest thing I went here for, was the Air Guitar Championship. What a waste of money.

GhlI5NEo3C0ST0rqd2JQ_Q.review_text: I saw HIM here and it was amazing not only because I got to see one of my favorite bands, but also because the lighting and sound was so amazing. The bartender I ordered a coke from was funny and cracked jokes. Although my friends said the chick bartender was super rude to them and gave them major attitude (whatever lol) I loved it it was awesome!!

vgwdQ0fpDZdoTidJuwYq7w.review_text: I would avoid seeing shows here at all costs, while the sound is great and the bartenders are pretty nice for a club this size...the overzealous fascist security really sucks. Went to a TurboNegro show a few months ago. It was a madhouse, we had to leave to get a drink elsewhere and they didn't want to let us back in because it's very much frowned upon to drink elsewhere when you've paid $20 to be at this venue. We had to say we had been smoking in order to get back in. But they still didn't like us, who doesn't like a group of coked up drunks at a Pseudo Homo Glam rock show? I don't know.

p6nBKyT9Y_pFJ1WxVEowwA.review_text: Nice venue. We saw Aziz Ansari there. There were 2 bars. You can have an open tab. The prices are a little high, but that's expected. There's seating attached to the walls, otherwise, there were tables and chairs brought in for the comedy show. They have the trough for the men to pee in so a tip to the tipsy, don't fall in. Sound was good. Staff was helpful. Will definitely go again.

ZvSqgWMTN1U2LA3zHrtlQw.review_text: Loved this place. We were here last week for a small concert for the first time. The history in that place was just awe inspiring. The poster rooms, are very cool. There are posters from groups like, the Doors, Led Zepplin, and of course the Dead. Apparently they are all out of room for any more posters, according to a very chatty doorman. There are 3 bars in this venue as well, and you get your money's worth of liquor, which is a good thing, since mixed drinks are expensive! The show was GA, but I could see the stage just fine. The restrooms are ok, there was only a minimal line for the ladies room. Maybe it was because it was such a small show, but there was nothing wrong with the bathroom, it remained relatively clean throughout the show. I'm sorry it took us so long to see a show here, and I can't wait to come back!

OaRk-RwFEzfOtc45ff0fGA.review_text: Even though it was rainy and cold outside, I avoided bringing a large coat for fear of having to hold it, in the event that it got hot and crowded during the show.  Fortunately, the temperature was perfectly chilly such that I could keep my light jacket on throughout (if at all curious, it was  for Hollerado/Gang of Four).  I stood in the back, which was okay for the most part, up until all the tall people showed up and stood in front of me.  As luck would have it, one of the venue staff (Tom) took pity on me and shuttled me to a sweet spot near the stage where the vantage point was clear and the speakers had mercy on my ears.

1eb6LGB2yDCTc3klUjzpxg.review_text: the best venue in SF.  we are blessed to have it.  so historic.  so intimate.  so perfect.

Fm1Xnzl7S0MOHaQ4Buf__A.review_text: This is my favorite SF venue.   Now, to be fair, I've never purchased any food or drinks here, so my opinion only applies to the venue itself. With that in mind, this place is awesome!  They consistently book awesome bands, and they have fantastic sound. The sound setup, and the people running it, are excellent. You can always hear what's going on. And they have free water (why doesn't every venue?) and apples.   The Fillmore also has an awesome vibe, with walls covered in framed pictures and posters of famous musicians and performers who have performed there.
