Just walking around and looking at all of them is a great activity between sets.

QTLL0xbcy7AyLUPJogk5kg.review_text: Saw Jenny Lewis here, it was a phenomenal show and I had forgotten how great the venue is. Free apples, yeah, expensive beer but thats okay. Its a great space and I am so in love with the chandeliers.

YFuKPzVsfVlWpyYDwNl8yg.review_text: the Staff here is the worst. All of them, truly disappointingly for being such a staple of SF and music. I will never go there again. No Stars & No love. Bad Karma- and who manages this place & hires these loser people????

74Am8W44at2GybFyYcLJAw.review_text: General admission theaters rock!! Yeah, I waited in line for probably way too long, on Geary, in front of the Post Office, but it was well worth the wait. The Fillmore provides that mixed feeling of a local club for local bands and something more worldly and welcoming for larger gigs. The history alone makes it a formidable gig, but the sound quality that has been preserved throughout time, the professionalism of the staff, and the energy surrounding the stage, makes it a venue I will come back to time and again.   **As a note, the water cost $3.50 a bottle, which blows severely. However, there is free, good tasting water that you can pour into cups at the end of the bar nearest the stage.

yN3cBeSdhtFRcFPdLgDlbw.review_text: This venue was great! I went the weekend of Halloween to hear Galactic play and I have to say I was pleasantly surprised upon my virgin embarkment upon this adventure. I was able to see the artists perform (and at 5'2" on a GOOD day that's a pretty good feat), without having to stand on anything or anyone. It looked beautiful and the sound was right on, with the bathrooms being a 3 on a scale of 1-5 for cleaniness. Not too shabby for a place catering to a few hundred drunk women eh? They at least had the good graces to maintain the toilet paper stock. I had a few stiff drinks, thanks to the cool bartender who liked my dress, and I made out with some randomly cute blonde girl who decided I was her new best friend and wanted me to meet her boyfriend. Awesome. My date was sorely disappointed that he missed this part of the evening..boys (note rolling of the eyes).  So if you're in the mood for some good bands/artists coming into town, and fun venue that allwos you to dance and sing along loudly if you so desire, then I say check out the Fillmore. It has the intimacy of the Independent, but on a larger scale.

Ou6eJFvev_6yCXVMEhg1cQ.review_text: Dear Fillmore Security (big fat white haired dude with beard), I've never been so offended by the security team. I was a guest backstage of the opening band Blue Angel Lounge during Brian Jonestone Massacre's set. You didn't ask me for my badge, and you rudely just shoved me out the door. Brian Jonestone was clearly upset with the sound guys, and lighting guys. He should really have been upset with the security as well. You should never touch a woman recklessly when you don't know who she is or where she's coming from regardless of anything you have in mind! The venue is absolutely stunning and the only saving grace was the very friendly woman at the door as well as the nice man helping by the will-call window.

d1VXeXMq67_QgdvWY1tcKQ.review_text: Remember, 5 stars doesn't mean perfect. It just means f--king awesome/incredible.  There's just about no other place to go to see a concert where you feel as much history as you do here. That's not to say it's the most historic concert venue (do you really feel that special at Madison Square Garden), but you feel like you're among the legends when you're here. The pictures on the walls of all the previous performers, the enormous picture of Jerry on the staircase, the posters from past concerts. Sound system is quite good, too.  Love the free apples and the greeter. It's nice to see some places that still do these things.

cDAdfpWUkpP9BB_aW4qjbA.review_text:
The venue is fairly large but still allows you to get very close to the performers.  Multiple bars have pretty easy access during most point points of the show and the bathrooms were adequate.
  Times visited: 1

Y2g8dSSkKEFu_f_-xmrvlg.review_text: This is a landmark and if your a SF dweller, YOU NEED TO SEE A SHOW HERE!! I have been to 2 so far Graham Parker and the rumor, and Scott Weiland (who was amazing and STP needs him). Going inside is like going into our own version of the rock n roll hall of fame. The posters, the way the place is lit it's a whole experience. You feel transported to another time. I am now always checking live nation to find what shows are coming there.

thVVcfYTwix9BbaTUYFn-g.review_text: Next to The Bottom of the Hill this place goes down as one of my all time favorite venues.  I am a musician and I have played almost every major venue in the Bay Area and abroad and this place continues to amaze me.  From the memories as a little kid running through the backstage and crew areas when my pops worked there to going to shows now a days and still feeling the same rush of excitement.. this venue is EPIC! I still remember meeting Green Day for the first time after they shot an HBO episode for Dookie!! SWEET!

uSyPtqgXYsAwdiPvostnLg.review_text: I come here at least 5x a year to support my favorite musicians (which lately has been Zion I). I also meet some of the best people here!  When first entering, you see a huge open space where all the excitement happens. Being in the middle of the dance floor is all sorts of crazy because you feel the ground shaking when everyone's dancing - like it's about to fall apart at any moment.  You'll know what I mean when you're watching a concert with the right people. It's one of the best highs you can get without being on chemicals, you know? The crowd usually kicks ass anyway.  The bar is on the left side, but for you underage kids trying to get your drink on WATCH YOURSELF! They're really strict and there's a guy with long beard who keeps tabs on who's ordering and making sure they have a stamp on their left hand that 'proves' your ID was legit - he'll even go as far as following you to make sure the 21+ year old who ordered doesn't let an underage kid take a sip or you'll both be out. End of story with that.   Also, you might want to pre-drink, because the alcohol is expensive :(  Upstairs, there are two separate rooms: to the left is where you can chill and get great seats to watch from above without missing a thing. The walls are decorated with different posters of bands that have previously had sold out shows at this venue. Tons of great legends to see here! I was honestly awestruck. Very dim here btw.  To the right room is where you can grab some food. It's almost like entering a whole new place because the blaring music from downstairs almost disappears and is replaced by another. You have to make a $30 purchase to use your card so unless you're hella hungry, I don't recommend spending so much here - you have tons of other choices outside the venue.  The coolest part about The Fillmore is it's just down the street from the famous Haight shopping district AND right across from the Japanese Mall!

gEFMsglx22OfLM2lN8EU7Q.review_text: Wait, the douchebag bouncer we encountered wasn't just a fluke? I'd never been to a concert at the Fillmore before, so I thought that we were just lucky to have met such a fine individual. Not only was he a homeless-looking mega douchebag, but he was totally drunk, stoned, or both. Here's how it went...  After standing for three hours at the La Roux concert and not being able to see a thing (I'm of average height, and there were people way shorter than me who had it worse), it was finally over. Yay! Now we're waiting for the crowd to clear, but it was going verrrrrry slowwwwwly. We got out into the corridor and saw there was a major pile-up of people trying to go down the stairs. I was starting to get claustrophobic, so we moved to the side by an emergency exit. Of course, the douchebag bouncer had a problem with this. He kept mumbling under his breath about how we wouldn't leave, what was our problem, etc. He finally gave it a rest when a few more people took refuge by the emergency exit. My boyfriend alerted a staff member that didn't look drunk or high about the douchebag, but now I see that that was probably useless.  I've never been to a concert venue that had such difficulty clearing out. I can't imagine if there was ever a goddamn fire in there. Ever hear of the Station nightclub fire? Yeah. Overall, it was probably the worst concert venue I've ever been to. I don't think you could pay me to go back.  And, one last thing... no smoking? Really?! I don't think so. Everyone there was smoking a joint, including an actual little person who was busting some awful moves. I was getting baked just standing there.

8pPkMMy_VpBeN2ASHC2eIw.review_text: I'd never been to the Fillmore before last week- but I have to say, it has some of the best sound of any venue I've been to.  The bars were conveniently located, the staff was friendly, and the decor was interesting- and I felt like I was at a truely historic site.   Overall, I'm impressed at the sound, and would definitely go again.

awl2tjJrK1XcizOJBBQxqg.review_text: I love this place. It's small and has an intimate feel. I haven't had the opportunity to watch a show from the balcony, but hopefully I will in the future. It's great when everyone on the floor gets into a song and starts jumping up and down, the floor feels like it's going to cave in! I love browsing the posters. Makes me wish I had seen some of them here back in the day. They also have free earplugs in case you forget to bring your own.

2zvUWE9erOVhGn8lLzdzuQ.review_text: I know what you're thinking--"how can you slag the Fillmore?"  Admittedly, the place has an impressive history (though it hasn't always been at its current location) and it's famous for lots of good reasons.  It's a great-looking place, long on atmosphere, but the acoustics here are frankly terrible.  I don't know if it's the high ceiling or the materials of the room, but high-frequency single-note instruments get completely lost from the mix in a cavernous wash of reverb here.  Want to hear a guitar solo or horn player?  Good luck.  I've tried standing all over this place, thinking there might be a good spot, but the only "good" option is to crush your way to the front of the stage to hear the band through their own amps...and then you tend to lose the singer(s).  Too bad--I hope they figure out a way to fix this.  The posters are a way cool bonus, too.

4b2Ll_iYGWKEBRbDGjgtXQ.review_text: You might have a good time here if you have always wanted to see The Fillmore, but if you have already done that, I don't think many will be impressed with the service.  Drinks are always in plastic cups, even shots at the bar, classy. Tall boys are $10, this is the same price that I pay at professional sporting events, need I say more? That is ridiculous even for San Fran! The bar tenders are rude. I asked for a cup of water and got a bottle, then the bartender pretended not to hear me plead for a cup. There was a cooler of tap water at the other end of the bar, come to find out later with no help from them. It takes an eternity to get a drink. And lastly, the bouncers are thugs. They are definitely running a racket, and letting people bribe their way into the venue to the point where it is beyond capacity. I would not want to be there in the event of a fire. I also saw one bouncer punch someone on the sidewalk. If this occurred inside the venue I may have a different perspective, but once on the street I don't think they have the right to regulate. I overheard the cops have arrested this individual 3 times for assault (African American individual with shoulder length dreads that always sits behind the chain link gate).  They also were trying to shoo people standing on the sidewalk after the show, in front of the adjacent post office. I'm pretty sure we all own that property.  If this venue weren't so famous, it could never compete with the other venues. I would advise everyone to write their favorite band and ask them not to play here anymore. One time will do ya.

hm6QTNOogoqogEbRM-3qCQ.review_text: 700+ reviews later, and I feel like I can't add anything that hasn't already been said. Spacious venue, the line moved relatively quick once doors opened, street parking was fairly easy to find, apples, free posters, etc etc. I can't comment too much on acoustics, mostly because my boyfriend and I came here for a comedy show (Aziz Ansari) and also because I have no working concept of good/bad acoustics.   Two things, though:  1. If you happen to go here for a stand-up show and are worried if it actually is "Standing Only" as your tickets say, don't. It's seated. They set up plastic chairs and round tables, and ushers seat people as they come in. I imagine that this would make it difficult for larger groups who don't arrive at the same time to save seats for friends (an annoying habit, anyway).  2. If you've never been there and you're relying on GPS/Google Maps for directions, 1805 Geary STREET is not the same as 1805 Geary BLVD (the actual address). Keep that in mind or else you'll end up about a quarter-mile away wondering where the venue is.  Last night was my first time at The Fillmore, and I have no complaints. Yes, seeing a stand-up act is not the same as coming for live music, but I'll be returning again in November, so we'll see how my opinion holds up after that.

AUaHB1IM-jkYzuICCHgvOg.review_text: This was the birthplace of my rockin roll life style back in..... 2001 HAH! I went here for multiple shows, can't recall all of them but I was thoroughly satisfied with every event held here. I love the fact they have a cushioned floor that bounces.. Not sure if it's still there but that sure made jumping and moshing easier ;D  I'd definitely come back for another show.

fxJcpYyCBgi61PtmlZXTjQ.review_text: This is my favorite live music venue in San Francisco. The sound is always fantastic, it's never oversold, lines to get in and out are efficient and professionally staffed, and you get a cool poster to commemorate every sold out show if you're one of the first... however many to leave after the show. I've seen dozens of fantastic bands here throughout the years, from alt rock to electronica to trip-hop to classic rock, and am always extra excited that they've pulled what I consider to be THE pro move when playing in the Bay Area by choosing this venue.  I greatly appreciate that it's completely feasible to get drinks during the show without really missing anything since there are two bars in the main room - one being on the open upper level - that are long and not in such a tight space that it takes forever. There's also a bar in the lounge area upstairs that serves food well before and during the show.  Bars are also well stocked, including a nice variety of draft beers.  The upstairs lounge also contains an impressive display of Fillmore show posters from throughout its long and illustrious history as (IMHO) the premier live music venue in the Bay Area. I'm a huge rock history geek so I like to get here early just to eat, drink and soak up the vibes of countless classic shows I'd give my left arm to have attended.

Tm0rpSKczb9Uu-eo2OF80g.review_text: Great Venue.. HORRIBLE STAFF!   We saw Train here last night.. fun.. great concert. but wow .. the staff was hands down one of the WORST put together teams I have ever seen!   Everyone at the front door was a JOKE. Don't even mean to bring this up.. but honestly.. has to be said. Literally 80% of the people were over weight, mean, negative, miserable people yelling at everyone. I was actually shocked at how rude each of them were.. not just to me but it seemed like everyone around me too! It is just sad that people are that miserable. No one was even doing anything wrong that I saw.. just pathetic unnecessary attitude is all I saw. Really.. keep in mind none of you RUN The Fillmore or own it in any way.. it's a front door job which all of them should  be THANKFUL for and attempting to be positive might help!  So.. Train was amazing.. inside was ok.. no seats.. just standing around drinking. so.. will probably not come back unless their is another great band playing their.. sad that unhappy people send out such horrible vibes and actions to others. I would defiantly recommend to whoever runs the hiring seriously re-evaluate all their employees.

NBNIUJj60tVBKvWHhy3egg.review_text: + The historic appeal of The Fillmore already grants 5 stars. + Traditions: Free apples (Red Delicious kind) & posters. + Great acoustics. + Courteous and efficient staff. + Simple layout of a large dance floor, bar, bathrooms and cool posters of past acts covering the walls. + Free metered parking in the surrounding area after 6pm, and at least lots available nearby in Japantown.

orII73gLXBT2QLjJcJWb8g.review_text: Ok. So music snobs are always jerks.  I imagined the people working at the legendary Fillmore would be some of the worst indie snots I've ever seen. I was intimidated to go see Built to Spill on Friday night for this reason. I was so pleasantly surprised that I was wrong! The staff at The Fillmore is one of the friendliest groups of people I've met out and about. The bouncers, the check-ins, the hostess, the bartenders - all amazing and helpful. Loved it.  The Fillmore as a theatre is legendary. It's dark and theatrical. It has great acoustics. The bathrooms were actually very clean. It is the best place to see a concert.  Built to Spill put on a great show! It wasn't packed out, the crowd was into it, and I had such a good time.   This will be my theatre of choice from now on.

ZhATZtcAivCoCVCup3VSeQ.review_text: The Fillmore is legendary. Just walk inside and scope out all the amazing posters of the acts that have played here! It's actually one of my favorite things to do at this venue during set changes. They line all the walls. Definitely check out the dining room upstairs where you can order food, chill out in the ample seating and explore all the posters that line the room.   I love the FREE apples at the top of the stairs as you enter. Although I have made the mistake of chomping into a juicy apple during a band's set numerous times and having to rush to the sink mid-set to wash my hands. The apples are extra juicy! Take a napkin with you or save it for later. The apples usually run out by the end of the show.  The sound system is great. The venue is very pretty. There are ins and outs. There's a water cooler and cups near the bar to stay hydrated without bugging the bartender. It's near Japantown (yum! yum!). Parking can be hard to find. I sometimes find parking on Laguna.   One of my favorite things about this venue is the free poster you get when you exit! These are actually collector's items. *Note: The posters are only made if the show has sold out.

-0jQI-Ru2BAJsGsGcFglPw.review_text: One of my favorite venues in SF. I've seen many of my favorites on stage here and I usually have a great time. The only time I've had sound issues is when I was too close to the front left side of the stage. All the vocals sounded like the teacher from The Peanuts cartoons. I'm a short gal and I haven't had too much trouble finding a spot to see the stage which is always a plus in a standing room only venue. I can't really think of any reason to not see a show here. So go! Dance! Have Fun!

gjZp61JZaqcLrKjEDVSPIQ.review_text: To me it's almost worth it simply to check out all the memorabilia.

XnbGrJNw0wglmqXekW138Q.review_text: a san francisco tradition for seeing live music.  i have seen several concerts here and always had a good time.  its not too big so you feel like you can get pretty close to the stage.  be sure to go upstairs too so you can see the view from the balcony area and check out the collection of posters from bands that have played there.  all throughout the whole place, they have tons and its really cool to see the old and new bands.  they also have food upstairs.  i do wish they had more seating (does that make me sound old??) just in case i would want to sit for part of the show, or for those opening acts that you've never heard of.

FXafwYB41-0jeC8cRqsn2g.review_text: It's hard to believe I had never been to a concert at the Fillmore in S.F. but it had somehow eluded me till I saw moe. there recently. Three of us drove down from Tahoe for the moe. concert and we all had a fun time, moe. was amazing as usual, but dressed in suits which was strange for a change.  The nostalgic venue itself was cool and generally speaking the staff had a good vibe which elevates an already good experience to a great night out. The Fillmore is not too big yet not real small either, a nice size for a concert venue. It was set up for general admission so the main floor was free from seating and open for viewing, dancing & mingling except for some tables and chairs along the side wall which are served by the cocktail wait staff. I liked how the band was elevated up on a stage above the main floor so everybody had a good view of the band playing.   The moe. crowd was chill too, I could roam around the sticky main floor, go right up to the front for a close up look at the band. The sound system was OK, Typical of concerts today, it was good n' loud, but not enough gut pounding bass for me, I have friends with car stereos that punch better, I wanna' feel that bass at a concert.   There's a nice lounge with tables and seating on the second floor overlooking the main floor.  It was interesting checking out all of the concert posters from past shows framed and hung everywhere, particularly upstairs on the second level. During the set break there was a performer in the upstairs lounge playing the guitar, singing and entertaining, it was a nice touch. If a performer you like is appearing at the Fillmore you should go, it's good times.

9QUc43ndukaWJn4zp9qKbw.review_text: GREAT VENUE!!! I had my dream of seeing THRICE live at the Fillmore a few months back, and I must say the Fillmore was the best place for it. Big enough to form a nice pit and crowd surf, small enough to get close and see the strings on Tepei's guitar. Not to mention it's legendary for hosting the greatest bands of all time. THRICE played with Circa Survive and Pelican, the sound was pretty decent, and you could hear the vocals clearly through the music. They also supplied FREE water which is helpful after jumping around for a few hours. The chandeliers above make for a cool crossing of past and present. The décor inside is faded and reeks of memories and good times. I'm definitely getting tickets to another concert here before the summer's out.

DH7ABAMHvl6IQfJ_yK7x5Q.review_text: The Fillmore is as much of a historical landmark as any in this town.  As I ascended the steps and took an apple, the faces staring back at me reminded me that I was in the presence of greatness.  Janis, Jerry, Jimi, Johnny... all the acts that had lead movements and changed lives had at one time been on that stage.  The high ceilings, balcony seats, and red curtains gave that classic theater feel, which made the show even better, along with the stiff drinks, solid entertainment, and amazing acoustics.  Although I doubt I'll ever have the opportunity to witness the magic of those past generations, at least the Fillmore is still keeping that magic alive.

rJ5mJ18V-2fjW_5OkeHnng.review_text: This is one historic place with tons of famous and great musical artists that have come through and played in the history of this place with many more acts making history here.  I just saw Steel Pulse last night and they were amazing.  It doesn't hurt that they're reggae legends but they're also phenomenal live acts.  The Fillmore also has great acoustics so the sound was perfect, it was loud but still manageable.  They also have bars downstairs and upstairs along with a big food area which is good for all the reggae fans that have the munchies.  I love all the posters on the walls of all the musical artists that have come through the Fillmore.    If you live in SF or the Bay Area then you have to come to the Fillmore.  You can smell and feel the history buzzing through this place.

ui5P9MG2sp36nVVbTfECrg.review_text: have seen at least 15 shows here, great place, only place better in SF is the Warfield.

WI9UJah3bVB258wzEIh34A.review_text: What can I say?  The place is steeped in rock n' roll history.  Just steeped in it.  I remember the first time that I went to The Fillmore after moving to SF... my (at the time) boyfriend and I spent most of the time that the local opening act band was playing just wandering up and down the halls looking at all the pictures of the rock legends that line the walls...  I may have even gotten a little teary when we paused at the various pictures of Janis... *may have*...  Over the years I've seen countless shows here.  Each one sublime perfection.  It is rare to find any business where you've never had a bad experience... I think that The Fillmore is the only SF business I can say that about.  My favorite (by far) concert at The Fillmore has to have been Quasi and Sleater Kinney in 2004... my first.  What makes it sweeter? An apple on the way in and a free poster on the way out. :)

h-JFMxJnQdxQiWf1CDLgAQ.review_text: I love this venue. Friendly staff, top notch sound/stage setup overall. I'm not sure if they still give out posters anymore. As expected, my only ambivalence was towards the bar. The bartenders look anxious and the drinks are ridiculously expensive. Nevertheless, I got a draft beer the last time I was here and it turned out to be really seedy and gross. I actually got sick from it. Beware?

40mk02Nf8iTqk3wAQfe3JA.review_text: Not my favorite place to see music live but I will always have a good time when I choose to see a show there... kinda loses the local music vibe for the "bigger" shows...

gmdZMvimMDXYFOcPi4O5Ww.review_text: I saw the Bravery here just recently and they were fantastic. The Fillmore is one of my favorite smaller venues because all the tickets are general admission, the drinks are super strong, and even if you're standing in the back the sound is still really cool. The only problem is sometimes you end up standing next to a drunk-dancing, hair-whipping, funky-smelling asshole, but at least you can fix that by walking to another piece of real estate on the dance floor or just whipping your hair back at them. I've seen like 10 different rock and hip-hop shows here and I've always had an awesome time, so if you know that your favorite band is going to play there, get your tickets asap because resale on craiglist or stub hub can get pretty pricey.

wIToYOaSGbG0-c7VCsdJTw.review_text: Awesome place to see a show. So much history - I love that in a music venue. Went to see Pinback here and it was so mellow and friendly, I could have stayed forever.   By the way - what is with the apples?

g14SmRmnHn6WCwCusUG5eg.review_text: Love comming here to see concerts! They are so nice and accomodating. They always give us a table bacause my friend us handicapped. I love the venue. It's old, but neat looking. Looking forward to my next concert here.

lktvZdRSa1zqxYcaL0-Dsw.review_text: Fillmore, you're amazing. Don't ever change.   One of my favorite venues in San Francisco for live music. I've come here to see everyone from Zion I to Chromeo. Every show has been brilliant and completely different from the last. Icons have performed here for decades and it has undeniable historical charm.   The walls are covered with framed photographs and detailed posters from past events.The staff are always welcoming and the concert goers are chill and enthusiastic. The quality of the lighting varies from show to show (depending on the artist's budget) and in my experience, the sound has been consistently pretty great.   I love the orientation of the venue. Once you walk upstairs from the entrance, it's like a brand new world. A dark color palette complete with velvet curtains and chandeliers. If you're on the main floor, you can still get a good view of the stage from any spot and there is usually plenty of room to dance. The balcony is my favorite part. I love looking over the railing at the crowd going nuts.   In terms of refreshments, I appreciate never having to wait long to get a drink at any of the bars. The drink prices are standard for San Francisco and pretty strong. They have food and more memorabilia upstairs. Merchandise and coat check are on the main level.    A few notes... Ladies, you might want to skip heels that are hard to walk in/aren't strapped to your feet if you're planning on spending a lot of time on the main floor. It's always really sticky...  Parking can be a trick. I always make sure to get there at least 30 minutes before the show to drive in circles, hoping to luck out. The upside is that there are plenty of nice places to eat beforehand. Yay Japantown!   Sorry to all you people who have grumpily resorted to posting grainy Instagram shots but I actually love that they generally don't allow personal cameras. People get flash photography happy despite being asked to refrain and it spoils the experience. I don't need a shaky, blurred video of my favorite song of the night to get my money's worth. I guess that makes one of me! Ha.   If you stay for the full show, don't forget to grab a free poster at the end of the night (while supplies last, of course)!  Last but certainly not least, the craziest thing that's happened to me here was during one of the Metallica anniversary shows...Jason Newsted came on stage to perform "Battery" with the rest of the band and this ecstatic 7 foot tall German guy in an orange correctional facility jumpsuit screamed in my face and then picked me up and swung me around like a sack of potatoes.   Never a dull moment at the Fillmore!

IMduCo7CtFWSHIUrfJ4dzA.review_text: Today's best poets - those who can move you through words with a connection, imagination, insight and passion are writing hip-hop and thug-hip-hop.   It's not about dance.  It's not about beauty.  It's not about guitar playing.  It's not about a enjoying a catchy melody. It's not about exceptional musical talent.  Its about the message.  It's about memorizing and delivering without hesitation. It's political. It's evangelistic. It's deeply felt. It's genuine. It's urban. It's violent. It's clever. It takes chances. It's entertaining. It's confrontational.  Last night (11/23/11) Immortal Technique brought his Martyr show to The Filmore.  See photos.  The Bay Area crowd was mostly white and hispanic 17 to 24 year olds. It was 40% women - sometimes couples - women with women-friends. But only a few African Americans.  About 300 people came for the show.  I saw a quite a few young couples too - teenagers.   Walk-in tickets were just $25 a piece. An amazing bargain considering Technique's intense energy.  The Bay Area crowd was psyched up too.  My date loved the show and iphone-videoed most of it. One of the pics I posted was hers.  Google "Martyr Immortal Technique". You can download Technique's latest CD for free. Listen to it.  Ah - The Filmore is a good venue to see a show. If you really wanted to get up close last night you could have.

zBc9PS0G00vGpYuQwLueiw.review_text: Boy o boy o boy o boy o boy did I mention that I'm going to the Fillmore to see oh boy o boy oh boy einsturzende neubauten echo and the bunnymen the cult ice cube ministry peaches st. etienne turbonegro interpol marianne faithful sigur ros siouxsie and the banshees b-52s skinny puppy oh boy o boy o boy I simply cannot CONTAIN myself, I'm so bloody excited after all it's the wait that's almost as fun as the show and why because I'll tell ya why I feel the same way about this venue that I felt when I was fucking six years old and my parents are gonna take me to six flags magic mountain and oh my god, the day of the show's come up and oh boy oh boy this is so FUCKING cool, I can't wait to go there and get that Over 21 stamp on my hand and get greeted by the kindly usher with the mustache who knows me by name and then I ask him if there's going to be a free Fillmore poster at the end of the night and most of the time there is and then whee! I'm in the hallowed hall that is the Fillmore and the most opulent and beautiful live music venue in the City and come on! come on! let's go in the hall and see all those gorgeous chandeliers burning dimly with their purple lights and the spacious bar and that's tom behind there who always gives me good pours and sometimes even throws me a freebie and there are so many people and once when Ladytron was playing I bumped into Mira and she was gorgeous and then there was the time when Sam and I hung out with Blixa Bargeld and some of Einsturzende Neubauten and discussed marijuana and cheese and wine and drove some of them around the Ciy looking for a bar that was open after 2am and let's not forget the upstairs food area where even though the food is outrageously expensive you should have eaten beforehand you know oh boy o boy o boy this is gonna be SO MUCH FUN I'm almost peeing my pants because this is after all my Six Flags, my Disneyland and my Great America all thrown into one great live venue package and I feel six years old with all that giddy excitement and really, if something makes you youthful with all that unbridled anticipation, then it will never earn less than five stars in my book in fact I'll give it TEN stars because it's worth it in fact FUCK THAT I'll give it ELEVEN.  Whew!  So there.

x3sWIDL6zJgGHMTfpwi3YQ.review_text: The Fillmore in SF is another great venue to catch a show. I've been there twice and both times to see Keller Williams but always enjoyed myself thoroughly. I usually park in the underground lot just up Geary @ the Kabuki theaters. The Fillmore also allows audio recording which means I'm usually hanging out in the back with the tapers to the left of the sound board. There's a poorly placed bar to the right of the sound board which leads to stupid drunk people doing stupid drunk things near the sound board & near the rigs of tapers *sigh*  The coolest thing about the Fillmore is the purple chandeliers. When they come up it's a sight to behold. Keller always requests them explicitly during his act and the crowd always goes wild when they come on.

4wIC7J1x3Rp3fKb361xj2A.review_text: Fillmore is great except they tend to pack WAYYY too many people into one venue.. Nearly died once at a show here.. but otherwise the venue is great and a very fun place to hang out

jyHW1rFxcoJ8gYBmcyk-FA.review_text: The best venue in San Francisco.  It is so small and intimate, the bar is easy to get to and you can be as close or as far from the performers as you want.

Sk7t3I1hxYRvJ-JIf_xong.review_text: I love this venue! I've seen multiple shows here and the ambiance is great! I always park in Japan Center, its close and affordable and there isn't a time limit.  The aesthetics of this place are incredible and the acoustics are equally as amazing.  :)

pfKQOhOhJJi5OQSMnrkMqQ.review_text: I love going to shows here. It's a smaller place, so you can actually see the act you came there to see without having to use binoculars! If you get there early, you might even snag a seat in the balcony! Drink prices are a little high, but it's not impossible to sneak in a small flask, if you are so inclined.   There is plenty of artwork, photos, and fillmore posters to look at on the walls. They always have a big tub of fresh apples to munch on in case you get cotton mouth. Then, as you are leaving, you get a poster of your own, commemorating the gig you just saw!

EgvES8rWgKa5x9vAfMU6Yw.review_text: My favorite place to see live music in SF....  The history aspects.....Easy to watch from a great vantage point and still get a drink, use the bathroom etc.... Just a great vibe in here..... Plus my band opened for The Damned here once in 1999 (thank you Captain Sensible!)

ojm14lh_LrlO_-XXHbu7AQ.review_text: This review may be biased because of the following: This is where my concert-cherry was popped (n/h). I'm the biggest Roots fan EVER. I've been to 5 shows here: 4 out of the 5 were to see The Roots.  The Denny's in Japantown serves SPAM.  I don't think I've heard any feedback here. Ever. The sound has gotten distorted on occasion, but not very much. The lighting is also good - not blinding and just bright enough to see what you're doing.   I've been to similar venues and I have to say The Fillmore was the cleanest out of all of them.  5 stars for all the memories.

qxdFzjdZew_bs-rbX82CdA.review_text: I was so excited when Bay Area's own Finish Ticket announced they were having their Ugly Xmas Sweater Social here because 1. local music is the best music and 2. The Fillmore is such a historic venue, every bay-arean concert goer should try to cross a gig here off their list.   Security here is pretty chill. They do make sure you're not smuggling anything dangerous, but i'm also pretty sure they don't let DSLRs slide without a press pass because they were awfully hasty to question me about my polaroid. I snuck in a sandwich in my bag and even though they told me to throw it away, i was still able to smuggle it in.   Show started at 8, doors opened at 7, my friend and I arrived at 6:30, and even though there were maybe 25-30 people in front of us, we were still able to secure a barrier spot. It all depends on who's playing. As with any show, if you're short like me (5'0" lol), either get there early to secure a barrier spot or drag along a tall friend to push people out of the way so you can see. There's an upstairs area if you don't want to fight your way through the floor.  The security guard at the barrier passed out waters if you asked, but he was really fickle on pestering people who vaguely looked like they were taking a video, so be weary if you're in the front.   Finish Ticket was amazing, but if you have sensitive ears be sure to bring earplugs because the speakers are pretty loud. The lighting was amazing, mad props to the lighting designer for having the colors complement the show.   Pro-tip: They only pass out free posters if the show sells out, but the apples are always there! :]

A-q5Rz4z7k6Kafos0Vx96w.review_text: This is easily one of my favorite music venues in San Francisco. If I can, I prefer to see bands here than anywhere else in the city.   When you go to The Fillmore, you are going to gain an experience and not just check out some band. You walk in and immediately start getting an education on great bands. The photographs, the posters, all amazing. I get the feeling though that Jerry Garcia and the Grateful Dead have played there about 100 times. Everytime I go there I see a new Dead poster about a performance at The Fillmore. Not to mention the homage to Jerry by the stairs.   An awesome perk about going to The Fillmore? The apples. They still give out apples. What better way of getting the fruit you should be eating at an awesome venues listening to some awesome band. The best part is you can take one... or two... :)  As you leave the venue still coming from the high off of listening to awesome music, you get a kick ass poster of the band you just saw. They are so creative and only you and whoever else goes to that concert get that poster. AWESOME. Someday I want to have a room solely decked out in posters I got from the Fillmore.

9mhTyH2cleSaMRZ_FgOk3w.review_text: Great venue. Drinks are a little expensive, but its SF, so it is to be expected.   On sold out shows, you get a free poster, which is awesome.   Great parking at the Japan Town Cultural Center parking garage. Good rates. Also, if you got the time, cruise around the local area and what not while you wait for the door to open at the Fillmore.

K-NT_xHy7q779oSPLCyvNQ.review_text: Okay, honestly, how can I NOT give the Fillmore a great review? It's legendary. Even though the venue might have bounced around from location to location over the years, and it's fuzzy which tales of rock greatness happened where, THIS is the container for the Fillmore legend... And it's flat-out a fantastic place to see a show. Really, it's hard to beat in my book.   I especially love chillin' in the upstairs lounge before the main event. They even have pretty decent food on the menu. Veggie fare, even! Yeehaw.  And the free posters? Now YOU can be one of the truly cool! YOU, TOO can have your own "Live at the Fillmore!" concert poster from tonight's show! Sweet.  But honestly, why DOES it take a million years to get out of this place? It's like everyone falls into a trance from the music and forgets how to walk down stairs. It's only one flight of stairs, too... It simply confounds me. And makes me very agitated. Especially when I start thinking about that nightclub fire back east a few years ago...   Augh... Minus one star for bringing back that memory! For momentarily making me feel like I'm in a fiery death trap, every time I go there.  Otherwise: stellar.

5jLkKtE4HPlrbjw-0w9lvg.review_text: I've been living in SF for a few years now and only just recently got to visit the Fillmore. Fortunately, it was twice in one weekend! I've gotta say, the Fillmore lives up to its reputation. As you walk up the stairs into the venue, you're greeted by multiple staff members who are all super friendly, welcoming you and wishing you a good time. Also at the top of the stairs is a big barrel of apples!  As you turn the corner, the venue opens up completely to the good size stage way up in front. The venue is big enough to house fairly established bands without being a giant theater. This makes it very easy to see the band playing from anywhere in the room.   One thing that really struck me at both shows was how good the sound was. Most venues love to crank up the volume, and I always lament the times I forget ear plugs. But at the Fillmore, the volume is actually really reasonable. Sure, it's loud, but not so loud that you'll be deaf afterwards.  Looking forward to attending a show that's sold out. Everyone keeps telling me about the free show posters they give out.

M10TyM4muucT7RQNsx1KqA.review_text: I got ma'am'd here a month ago.  Boo.  Granted, the crowd was mostly pre-pubescents and it was a very *polite* ma'am, but still!  I've been here three times in a month now and love it more and more!  The crowds are completely different every time (for example - the Chris Isaak show,  definitely not ma'am'd then) and can be even downright douchey.  Who would guess that a hippie-ish folksy singer like Mason Jennings would have such idiot fans?  It was like wandering into a frat party, yuck.  And not to mention getting stuck behind FOUR 6'3" dudes standing and bouncing around in front of me.  I was in danger of elbow, meet face.  But, I digress...  This is a wonderful venue with an amazing history, good line ups and great sound.  It doesn't get 5 stars because it is a TicketSatan venue.  I just get my tix at the box office.  $10 fee on top of a $25 ticket?  Puh-lease.

pKbM1n-RPfQxo6zQDmnxkw.review_text: Dude, it's the Fillmore!  Probably one of the best music venues in the nation!  I would rather see a concert here than any arena or amphitheater in a heartbeat.  The size is perfect where you can decide to push right up to the stage and get intimate with the band or just chill in the back of the room and still not even be that far.  The sound system is great, there's a full bar, and (at least for the shows I go to) the other patrons are family.  One small tick: the door staff are a bunch of d*cks.  But whatever, you have to deal with them for 30 seconds as you go in.  When you hit the wall of music gods, you forget all about them.

nJ_y2tmS0N8P1eDOyFs6yA.review_text: The bands I saw there, they were great.  They put on a great show.  That being said, the large man with the eyeglasses at the box office was terribly rude to me.  I wanted to have a good time and I wasn't expecting to be treated with attitude.  I get it, you see a lot of people everyday, and not all of them are pleasant; but you are working, try to act cordial to your customers because you reflect the establishment you work at.  I won a pair of tickets from KZSU Stanford.  So I brought a buddy of mine to go.  When I talked to the people at the box office, they said they couldn't find my tickets.  So they told me to wait.  I thought fine, it's a minor inconvenience but I am sure they will get things straightened out.  They called me back to the window and told me they hadn't given out any free tickets...   I was upset because I was expecting a pair of tickets to the show and the dude just shrugged it off, tough luck, he couldn't find them.  He gave me one ticket and said figure it out, tickets are $22.    I didn't know what to do at that point.  He wasn't in the mood to figure out anything.  As if I was a liar or someone trying to sneak in for free.  Now, it isn't as if I didn't have another $22.  I wasn't about to pay them more money especially after having been talked to so rudely.  I wasn't happy, my friend and I basically sat outside trying to figure out what to do.    Finally we were called back and the dude said he'd give me another ticket.  We also had a bit more to say to each other but I'll leave it at that.  As we were about to head inside, a woman approached me and said she had been treated with the same disrespect.  She was apparently the photographer, and they wouldn't let her in either.  What she said to me at least reassured me that I wasn't wrong in my assessment of the man's rudeness.

N7BVcUvWh4lZW4UuNiG5wA.review_text: If Lupe played here, then The Fillmore=THE SHIT.  Unbelieve, the first very first concert I wanted to go to was 30 bucks here. But no way was my boyfriend gonna let me go. He was afraid of boopers and wannabe urbaners attacking me. ._____. so was I. It's okay I passed by always pass by wishing I was in there jamming to lupe. BLAH. But over all I love this place. The whole street can take days and days to walk!

VRNF7v9PRqnfU3XpNmRxpQ.review_text: went here a few years ago now to see a show.  the venue is pretty big and sound was great.  i don't think i took advantage of the bar or anything else so i'm not sure how that goes.... anyway, i did enjoy the show and it's nice that the older venues still operate

R9FsuO_Np2nChWAdyNEaEA.review_text: I just have to say that hands down, this is my favorite venue in the city.  Not just because of the history, the great ambience or the quality of the bands they book there, but because of the staff.  Seriously old school, the staff is ALWAYS extremely nice and accomodating, even when breaking up a fight.  I've never had a bad experience there and attribute that the to great energy that's been in the venue since it's inception.

aPpyWnpndrRSeAt8CMzAZg.review_text: I went to a Cake concert here several years back and quite enjoyed it.  Great venue to see a band you like up close and personal.  Sidenote, my buddy and I ran into Jason Giambi in the lobby after the show, on the same day when he'd hit a walk off HR to beat the Yankees (He was still on the A's - and steroids - at that time).  Great guy, he laughed and seemed quite amused by my semi-drunken re-enactment of his HR from earlier in the day.

ucvTVzBMSGkLjzHqPdCM9A.review_text: Definitely one of the staple venues of San Francisco. I usually park at the parking garage near Yoshi's. Usually comes out to $5. Bathrooms are clean. The free posters at the end are really nice. Drinks are pricey and strong but small. Sadly, it's another venue that is strict about video-recording. The decor is absolutely beautiful. You gotta love those chandeliers and all the big open space. The sound here is great, however, they seem to have problems with their vocal mics on occasion. The first time I saw Jamie Cullum here about 6 years ago, it was so bad at the start of his set that he exchanged it for a new mic and started the first song over again. He was really nice about it but the venue really needs to be on it when it comes to soundcheck. In the end, though, this venue is one of the best.

e7tMTMdGICe5LL9pSXQgmQ.review_text: When you're talking music history in S.F., the Fillmore is your top spot. The photos on the walls are amazing -- Janis, Jimmy, Jerry. And it's got a vibe that no other joint in the city does. But having been to a couple of shows there, it seems like they're banking on the past and that it's not so good in the present. It's stuffy, overpriced and the bar staff isn't all that great. All that I ask is that you open a window once in a while.

LNHtt3ydkZ14D2ZXXs6Gxg.review_text: This classic venue is a must see -- go there to see any band you like. The venue is small enough to feel intimate, so tickets tend to sell out fast. The Fillmore has cool things to see all over their walls. It's like a small collection of rock history on those walls. Lots of cool posters from previous shows are on the second floor. Japantown is right next door, along with Fillmore Street, which has lots of good places to eat. Even if you can't have dinner before you get there, they have a decent kitchen and good selection of drinks to boot. It's nothing fancy, but you will have a decent meal to go along with your drink and the music. Generally parking is easy at the Japan Center, which has reasonable rates and closes at 2:30AM.

h2zCM6PBiI2xrKmbU4tQtQ.review_text: Yeah, it's a good place to see a show and I've seen some great stuff. However, the whole place smells like dirty feet, the drinks are totally over priced (to be expected of course) and most of all, could you please play music before and between performers that kinda sorta goes with who's playing. That would be really nice. AND what the hell is up with you liberal hippie San Franciscans serving beer in big plastic cups?  WHAT A WASTE! STOP KILLING THE PLANET!!!! PLEASE FIND SOMETHING ENVIRONMENTALLY FRIENDLY TO SERVE DRINKS IN!!!!!!!!

ZSretWXlve11q9hP6SrScQ.review_text: Lead vocalist: "How many of you guys have class tomorrow morning?"    Everyone else: (screams) Me: FML Little did I know that artists like Ratatat, The Shins and Death Cab attracted such a young crowd. Which makes me one of the "oldest" concert-goers at the Fillmore (minus the Dads who are watching over their underage daughters). Aside from the screaming teenagers, The Fillmore is a great venue. Full bar, easy parking, no issues with tickets and good bands. Needless to say, if you enjoy live music and don't mind the crowds, check out the Fillmore.

8dlM2tKae0a99cXUI9J4RA.review_text: I love this venue. It's spacious, beautiful, has food and booze, and good acoustics.

SFXZLhlUEFT-GcwxVusmjg.review_text: Don't judge this place on its food or price of cocktails. This is the Fillmore, the mighty, the legendary Fillmore. Magic happens here. At certain shows the sweaty, elbow-to-elbow crowd and the band collectively plug in to the moment, electricity courses through the room, the wooden dance floor bouncing and bowing as everyone rides the same wave-- and oneness is achieved. Such moments are my religious experiences. I've found religion at shows for TV on the Radio, Gang of Four, Hot Chip, The Prodigy, Iggy Pop, Primus, Eagles of Death Metal, Queens of the Stone Age and many many more.   At 900 capacity the Fillmore feels intimate whether you are right up front near the stage or hanging out in the back of the room for air. There are tables along one side of the ballroom and upstairs, but I like the immediacy of being on the floor. The best bands play here, and revere it.  The acoustics are excellent. Lovely cocktail waitresses somehow weave their way through the crowd, bringing alcoholic beverages or cold bottled water to parched  audience members. Bless them. The Fillmore still rewards the faithful by maintaining the tradition of commissioning concert posters for sold out shows, which they hand out one per person at the exit, but only after the encore is finished. If you leave early, no poster for you.  Depending on the artist or the band, some of these posters attain decent resale value relatively quickly.   There ware some minor negatives: the collective body heat of the crowd, the stickiness of the dance floor after 500 people have spilled their beers, the long bathroom lines if you have bad timing. Exiting requires patience and civility as everyone must use the one rickety staircase. Not every show attains that legendary Fillmore status. I've been to a few stinkers here. That stars do have to align properly--show needs to be sold out, band needs to be cooking, crowd needs to not be overly filled with a**holes. But it is worth it!   If you live in the Bay Area you owe it to yourself to attend a show here. You may be lucky enough to experience one of the legendary ones. Get there early and check out the opening band. They are usually very good. And it's an all ages venue, so bring your  kids!

rEuJ2MADbG5ZEVTPqkKoFg.review_text: My favorite venue in SF by far. Where else can you enjoy great music and apples all in one?

tlY0QMQDyfjQAEwHnzvFnw.review_text: I've been to the Fillmore a few times now and I have to say the place is amazing.  The venue is so cool and classic - you realize you're actually in a part of major music history.  I love going to concerts and the best thing about the Fillmore is the intimate setting that's provided - you really feel like the artist is performing just for you...it's usually pretty hard to feel like your favorite musician is accessible and this venue definitely helps with that feeling.  As you walk through the lobby area (grab one of those infamous free apples!) you can see just how historic the place is with all the pictures and posters from decades past of amazing legendary artists who've taken stage at that venue (Joplin, Hendrix, Prince).    The acoustics are great and the place is well decorated - it's not over-the-top or anything, but it has a nice classic look with hints of signature pieces like the sexy chandeliers that hang from the tall ceilings.  5-star all the way!

b9w9Uv7pSmtz4WLia8R-0Q.review_text: Clear Channel, the Media conglomerate who organized Pro-Iraq War rallies and banned the Dixie Chicks when they bashed Bush, own this venue.  Which sucks because it's a decent venue to catch a band.  But I refuse to knowingly give Clear Channel any of my money, and I urge others to do the same.    Better venues are Bimbo's, Slim's, Great American Music Hall, Bottom of the Hill, and UC Berkeley's Greek Theatre.  Clear Channel owns The Warfield and The Shoreline as well.

5zk5oqnyLH7dahN6fTNtMg.review_text: great place, hit and miss acoustics. Saw Galaxy Asteroid tour last night. They were great but the sound was awful. Looked like the band had a great monitor set up as they were having fun and the stage sound guy was into it. The front of house guy must have been sleeping. All drums, huge kick, the lead singers vocals were barely audible along with the keys and percussion  Lazy, sloppy sound. It's because of this that I became a sound engineer myself. Got sick of  useless sound guys killing my band.

AC8KmV75wASdwVDwbyXpnw.review_text: This is a good place to see high energy concerts. It's a bit of a small venue, but that matters very little. It's beautiful inside, what with the gorgeous chandeliers and lighting. The floors are really bouncy too, so when the crowd starts jumping it's almost like standing on a trampoline. It's seriously amazing!  Only had a couple small problems that don't even need to be voiced. Great venue!

YDNfY5wFvIrmd0GiLe-wpQ.review_text: It is amazing that people around here feel so casually about live music. I have seen more concerts in the last 2 1/2 years here in the Bay Area than in the 11 years I lived in Holland. You guys don't know how lucky you are with this abundance. And what's more, it's all from close up! Places like The Fillmore are small and intimate, yet world-class artists want to play in it. You don't know how surprising that is to me. And how pleasing that is to me as well.  The posters they have all over the walls are an awesome pastime when waiting for the show to begin. They do make me jealous, though. I've missed out on so many good shows!  Too bad the BART is so far away, and why the hell can't BART run later anyways? This is one of those places you need to drive to, but then you have to watch how many you drink...

DHUfDrzWi0rTSel-14RLoA.review_text: Came here last night to see Somo. Its a pretty cool venue but we almost missed it walking by. The outside is dull and no big signs. Venue drink prices are outrageous. Had a great time but sound system didn't sound all that great. Knocking off a star for sound.

gM4ScYLBhy_9X4QJ7F3RNg.review_text: Simply awesome...Now my one of my favorite bands has to play there soon.

mKMMiiegYGAHmjP4dnDQcg.review_text: Have you ever felt those dreaded cringes of utter hopelessness, the ones that effortlessly force out heavy breathed sighs of discontent?  That was me and my GF for one fucking hour. When you've got sold out tickets to see the cutie patootie that is Lykke Li and the clock just ticks as you search in failing faith.. those four letter words start looking like this:  H-------------------------O---------------------U-­---------------------------R  But we found a parking spot, eventually. *throws confetti  As we walked up the doorman informed us that they've delayed the show to wait for more people to come into the venue. *more confetti  The beer was $11.25 EACH, I could have sworn I felt my pockets get tighter and a little voice in there even said, 'Yo fuck that!' But hey, it was Valentine's weekend, and I love my GF, and I love Stella.. Artois. End of story.  Things I learned that night: -Plan to arrive at least 2hrs prior if you're going to a sold out show -Bring an umbrella-ella-ella if its raining cause you'd probably have to walk blocks for parking -The sound at The Fillmore is impeccable -I love Stella Artois best when she's half the price of $11.25  And finally,  Lykke Li is nothing short of amazing. Oh wait, I knew that already.

G8P886SgzpVvRglMEVZa8g.review_text: Went here for the Dethklok concert last night.  The first band was only two songs in when there was a fire somewhere in the building.  Everyone evacuated and after an hour of waiting around they cancelled the show.  Things happen, but the one star is because it's the next day and they haven't notified any of the ticketing agencies about the cancellation yet.  If I have to throw the charges into dispute to get my money back I won't be a happy camper.

g2oseja9mnTSA8Qq7GXqBg.review_text: I like this place. It is not out of hand cool or anything just a solid big room to see bands. The drinks are over priced and weak but every city sould have a place to see medium sized acts and although ours isn't perfect it will do.

nTanHRMIJMQmI33HVhvTPQ.review_text: WTF..can't turn on the damn air conditioner until 2 opening bands finish their sets? Ugh. Staff working the door..a few nice ones, others treat people like cattle, off putting to say the least. Bartender was dialed in and promptly served drinks. I felt sorry for the guy selling merchandise working by himself with no help, not his fault, at least he had some class. Enjoyed the show anyway, too bad the band didn't turn up the amps until the last song.

AlF4v-kTQVnvEkoxzY0xXw.review_text: I finally went to this iconic venue last Thursday. The first thing I noticed was how much smaller the venue was than I had expected, but I don't mean that in a bad way at all. I like the feeling of the artist being intimate with the crowd so that was a big plus!   I have 1.5 complaints about the venue: the  flooring and the staff. First of all, when the crowd starts jumping, it's only obligatory that you should also. Now let me tell you, when I started jumping along, I thought there was an earthquake going on! The floor feels like it can probably only survive a few more months of hardcore jumping. It was scary but at the same time also added to the fun.   My second complaint goes to the staff. The artist we saw perform was kind enough to sign all the autographs he could  after the show. Of course everyone gathered around the stage for an autograph. The staff wanted everyone to get away from the stage so they could clean up, I understand that. Some of the staff directed us to go outside into the lobby so we could continue the autograph signing over there, so we did. After a few minutes of waiting, we were then getting kicked out of the lobby and out of the venue. Another member of the staff said it was the last chance to get autographs at the bar, which they didn't tell us was going to be there, so they let some of us in. Once we got in another staff member told us to get in line. Once we got in line, another staff member yelled at us for getting IN line. My point is, the staff needs one unified level of organization. We were cooperating with the staff yet almost got kicked out for basically following THEIR directions. Sheesh!   Anyway, that obviously wouldn't stop me from attending another event from that venue again, but that does stop me from giving it 5 stars.

yJ_PiCl4OR9bYqHpvsgDog.review_text: I just saw Devotchka their the other night.  THEY were amazing of course, but the techies working the sound?  Could of been a bad batch of apples or just an off night, but at least half of the show was bombarded with feed back, blow ups and other ear stabbing difficulties.  The band were super pro and kept the show moving, but come on!  The techies were on stage crawling around, going back and forth while the band moved around them trying to perform.  Soooo sad.  The space and layout is amazing to see a show, but they really need to assess their sound crew and get some competent folks.  It's not 12 galaxies.  It's the Fillmore...

WfQiUY1fRpodZV16mACN6A.review_text: I have seen everyone from Mat Kearney to John Mayer to Joshua Radin to Common here.   I've stood in line outside this place numerous times waiting for shows to start to ensure a good spot next to the stage, but really all views are good.   The drinks are spot on, which is always nice.  This venue blows me away every single time. The atmosphere is perfect. This place is legendary for a reason.   Also, the manager RULES.  Parking is never available, but there is a parking garage directly across the street. But who drives a car in this city?  If you want the quintessential San Franciscan music experience, go to The Fillmore, people!

qr3MYNEtnxBvB8NOtuW0Gw.review_text: Every show I have seen here @ the fillmore I have always enjoyed  Artists seen: Primus, Les Claypool, Cypress Hill, Trentmoeller and multiple others.   ++Free posters @ end of the show  + If you are a good concert go-er like me, you get used to cruisin' through the crowd and bein able to read pathways in and out.  - If your 5'4 like me, sucks to get stuck behind a pack of 6'5 ogars. But, I just groove my way to the front so never really a problem anymore.  - Kinda sucks how the bar is only on 1 side. When I go, I always make sure that I can stick close to the bar because thats a good way to enter the front of the crowd again. Depends on who is playing  - Hate how the shows always end early, but o well, there are always after parties in the city  + Vibe is awesome with other concert go-er/music lovers.   - Kinda shady area. I wouldn't walk around alone, let alone with a group of girls. That is just a screaming target, be sure that you have good transportation or a buncha dudes around ya to shield ya.  If I could, I'd probably give it 3.5 stars. But since I have seen so many awesome artists here, I rounded up.  Conclusion: Obviously in SF there are going to be some areas that are good, and some areas that are bad. This place just happens to fall on the cusp of both worlds, so be sure to play it smart and be safe. If you do drive, park on Geary, Ive always had good luck. Arrive, pre-game in the car and of course, party like a rockstar!=always a good night @ the fillmore

65uUyG9yuF0rdMh0z7ajaA.review_text: The place is sort of a wacky dive, with the huge empty hall with it's black-light chandeliers, but it's possibly the best place to see a band in the city, because there's no seating, so you can get as close as you want to the stage, and it's really not that big, so the shows feel intimate.  Great sound, plenty of bars so you don't have to wait in line too much, there's a big bucket of apples when you go in, and they hand out custom posters for each show when you leave.  Cool stuff.  Expect people to be smoking out; they always are.

3gvQuIg6QFac7brGFgY9EQ.review_text: If there was an option for 0 stars that's what it would get . The most rude employees I didn't go in and all I got is Sorry when I asked for a refund they said that because we didn't like what you said your not coming in . All good there's about a 1000 other places where my money and jokes will be ok

06gL9VaAyAl6WoYVu_nPuA.review_text: We went to Not So Silent Night here a few years ago and it was fun. I hit it off with the security guards and it was pretty easy to get close to the action. I'd rather go to Slim's but the Fillmore isn't too bad either.

tl7BzUtnzAj_r1WYFXLiug.review_text: Been living in SF for 5 years and my first time here was for the Waka Flocka show!!!   I think it's gross that there is carpet in there.....and the faux luxe trap vibe this establishment tries to give off. -_-  Went thru 3 different security checks before even getting in. It's not that serious.   I twisted both my ankles and threw out my neck and back at the show doe, so it was wurf it.

0Chi_CzoTmkw1NvZg0sksg.review_text: For my 300th review, a confession:  Growing up in the Bay Area and waiting until age 27 to step foot in the Fillmore is beyond sacriligious, sort of like:  -Coming back from France not having eaten any pastries -Walking into a cathedral with an ironic Jesus t-shirt -Driving 30 miles out of your way to visit your boyfriend only to realize he's at your house -Filling up on cheap crackers before an expensive, delicious meal -Going to the beach without taking off your shoes -Paying for a whore and not having sex -Sitting through every repetetive televised political debate and not voting -Finding parking in North Beach and deciding you're not hungry -Driving a minivan and hating soccer  My crappy, inexact metaphors aside... Believe it or not, I do get out a lot, and I do love music, so don't completely discount me when I say: this is one of the best venues I've ever stood foot in.  -A veritable history of music in neatly arrayed, artistically devine posters -Lovely upstairs balconies and bars -Not a bad view in the house -Chandeliers! -They do outstanding, beautiful things with spotlighting -Cheerful, friendly people working here  And believe me also when I say, the sound could have been a little better - namely the balance between vocals and instrument amplification.  The bands I saw (Think About Life, Stars) seemed to get the hang of it a few songs into their sets, so no harm done.  I am ready to start my poster collection now.

JvAmZO_KMpXsSbSlwksWtw.review_text: i was charged $23 for a double Maker's Mark and ginger ale.  'nuff said.

2GkogPPtOGDL7a0jJwBDsg.review_text: I came here with a friend to see Snoop and jeeeez was it fun! The crowd was totally unexpected- families, youngsters, older folk, twenty somethings, you name it. The show was awesome, the the venue played a huge part in that. I didnt have to wait more than 2 minutes to get a drink at the bar. The crowd was definitely straight west coastin, with drinks overflowing and heavy smoke in the air. There isnt a bad place to stand in this venue (unless you get stuck behind that ONE dude who is 7 feet tall like we temporarily did...). I also loved the classic feel of the venue with the old fashioned balconies and dark red/gold painted walls. All in all, fabulous evening and I cant wait to go back to this historic theatre soon!  tip: make sure you get your free poster when exiting!

pzprdk8f8wfsRpfTSFUmbw.review_text: Went there. Saw that. Will go back again.

vD0XRuZnvRzhJS2Xxzipwg.review_text: This is a great iconic theater where history oozes from every nook and cranny.   Beer selection is okay, full(modified) bar. Impressive efficient bar tenders.  As much as I loved this Venue, I was surprised by the lack of ornateness in the ballroom  itself.   And the acoustics are probably a 8 on a scale of 10.    But its a great time in a great city.  I really enjoyed my Fillmore Apple that they hand out before every show.

z7KsQ_nfTZq6mm6ZPAk_Mg.review_text: I have seen Alkaline Trio and NOFX here. Sound travels really well here so even if you are further away from the stage, it still sounds good. Parking isn't too hard to find if you are willing to walk and I think they have a full bar.

ACUVZ4SiN0gni7dzVDm9EQ.review_text: In Denver there is a copy of the Fillmore Theater (probably in other cities, too, but I've not been to them.) And in Denver I have to say I wasn't a fan of the Fillmore. There was never a good place to stand and the sound was awful. And I'm glad to say they didn't do this Fillmore justice when they copied it because I have been to a few concerts at this Fillmore now and really enjoyed it.  The crowds don't get too crazy big, the light shows are amazingly rad, and I love that the store lets the bands decide what to charge rather than telling them. The only downer is that they are a Live Nation venue which means tickets have ridiculous fees. So, I go to fewer shows here than I would if they weren't part of Live Nation.  I also like that the staff has always been incredibly friendly to me when I've been here and most of them seem happy to be there. It makes for a really nice environment.

9SrJ24dGd6641cvMXTSMbA.review_text: I've been to the Fillmore a few times. It has good sound and overall is a good spot to catch a show. Security can be funny sometimes. One time I happened to have a sharpie pen still in my jacket and when they searched me and found it they acted like it was a gun. Another time I was having a drink with a friend at the bar and the security were telling us we couldn't stand at the bar because we needed to leave that space open for people that wanted to get drinks - the bar section was half open to begin with. Oh well, I guess some security people like to boss people around to make themselves feel important. At least the last time I went to the Fillmore it was smooth as butter. Went to see Tamar with Prince. At midnight (when the show was supposed to start) and I had to pee. So I chanced it and went to the back bathroom. As I walking to the bathroom people come out of a side door and low and behold there's Prince 10 feet away from me. I should of said something to him but what would I of said... "hey Prince, I'm going into the bathroom. Peace".

4bJtq3yY_aAqm2Ikg-WJYw.review_text:
I just caught the M. Ward show on Friday.  Nish was standing right in front of me the whole time.  It's good to know he's got good taste in music as well as food.  Word 'em up, Nish mahn!!!
  Needless to say, the show rocked, the Fillmore rocks.  One more reason to stay in San Francisco.  God, the great things about this city just don't stop, do they?
  I'm in love and always will be.

bMMRPKHC1LdASDbRHl7RnA.review_text: I've seen a few good shows here but I can not stand how stuffy it is inside. I felt like I was going to pass out on 2 occasions due to absolutely no air circulation and a packed crowd. I will not be going back for sure.

JUcKPkZRza8i3n3qD1KbVQ.review_text: This fantastic venue is one of my favorites.   It's close to Japantown so parking isn't a major issue if you're willing to walk a few blocks.   With it's reputation of being a famous live house, walking into the Fillmore feels like walking into a place where you know instinctively that you're going to get a fantastic concert no matter who the artist is.   I've been here for Jason Mraz's first show as well as many Japanese artists like Puffy (otherwise known in the U.S. as Puffy Ami Yumi) and, most recently, GLAY.   The Fillmore has fantastic acoustics and no matter where you are on the main floor, you have a great view.  The bartenders like to make the drinks strong so be sure to get a your drink of choice (you need a 21+ stamp and only 1 drink at a time) and get ready to enjoy the concert.   I love the way the floor bounces when everyone's dancing and rockin' out. GLAY put on amazing show and the Fillmore was a great place to showcase their energy. The amazing guitar solos by Hisashi and Takuro and Jiro's epic bass solo thrummed throughout the entire venue and just heightened the crowd's energy.   It was their second time at the Fillmore and I hope they keep coming back. No other venue can convey simply how amazing they are other than the Fillmore.

T7UwgRoLAi3Eu6J5saI4gQ.review_text: The Budos Band was a fun concert last night.. obviously this place is an awesome venue with great musicians having been there however $10 for a vodka redbull and $9 beer.. doesn't really make you want to suck those down really quick that's for sure.. kind of wishing they had PBR for like $3 but that was a dream.. lol

ybk_vGgqfsSDBRteWVCrfQ.review_text: An amazing venue. I live maybe 5 blocks away and I honestly have to admit that I need to go to more shows, however every show I have attended is always worth the sqeezing and groping you should expect from the audience....which in my opinion comes with the territory. Inside the venue is gorgeous. The walls are jam packed with priceless silkscreened rock posters in gaudy bronze frames from past shows. In the main auditorium large drooping crystal chandeliers hang down from above giving the place a feeling of "properness" as you see your band rock da house. When you are finished dancing and you manage to get out in time you might even get a free poster...yay! The only bad thing that I can say about the Fillmore is that it has an amazingly obstrusive sign that you cannot see unless you are standing across the street from the structure, but once again....inside the building has crystal chandeliers....even though it is in a sort-of dicey neighborhood across the street from Mr. Bling Bling's. :). Nontheless, the neighborhood wouldn't be the same without this place as it is a gem of San Francisco.....gleaming with awesomness.  My last concert here....Sonic Youth on July 14th....with Awesome Color and no, their T-shirts do not come in Awesome colors.  Here's a marketing thought....Awesome color (the band) should merchandise colored condoms....I mean it doesn't matter what color the condoms are....it's the idea that counts.

rJUcY7tEp5hCGpxMHOz8ig.review_text: Great place for great shows. Lots of room and the dance floor bounces under your feet!!!

xlACoXuuSZmb83hJcDxgSg.review_text: For a venue of its size -- which, for me, is a pretty big place -- the Filmore does a great job of avoiding most of the problems that plague similar-sized places: the security is actually pleasant -- I mean, for security -- and they don't bother you if you're sitting on banisters or leaning up against stuff. The sound quality was really crisp. There's enough space that you won't have some dude's nuts pressed against your asscheek for the entire show -- I mean, unless that's your kind of thing. It doesn't feel like a sauna.  Buy tickets at the box office to avoid the ticketmaster service charge.

ZqrobMCSS2byuW0aD95Vtw.review_text: The fillmore is O.K.   it's got some cool history (a classic spot)... also cool that they give you apples, and if i remember correctly, the food was pretty good but a little pricey.. the shows are definately a little bit expensive for my tastes, but hey, you get some really good acts in..  I like to see venues with more seating for the old men like me, but it's cool.. it can get a little crowded, but the sound is pretty decent.

u2cN-tN3T37QajH4rhDStQ.review_text: going here to look at the photos on the wall is good enough. the bands they book these days are lame anyway.

KtR2zXLfKTRN3grDxfkvqA.review_text: I don't know how many times I've performed the public service of setting a confused stranger straight, but for the last time:  Yes, you can eat the fucking apples.

m9vkagc4KEn5X47J9WGOBw.review_text:
This is my "emotional rollercoaster" venue. 
  Note: "Bad" feelings are denoted by "BF" and "good" feelings denoted by "GF".  Carry on.
  BF #1:  big, smoky outdoor crowd - no discernible lines, loud voices yelling to "clear the sidewalk".  Feeling is similar to trying to figure out where the sirens are coming from so you can pull over.
  BF#2:  Frisking.
  GF#1:  Thinking, "yeah, there ARE some people here I wouldn't want to have weapons".
  GF#2: ID guy always comments on how you couldn't possibly be as old as your DL proclaims, think, "i am young and dewy".
  BF#3:  Hear him say the exact same thing to Siliconia McWrinkle right behind you.
  GF#3: White haired man at the top of the steps who says, "Good evening and welcome to The Fillmore" with what seems to be genuine warmth and well-wishing.
  GF#4: Get drinks from veteran bartenders for fairly reasonable prices - one of them always buys me at least one drink per show.  (I like to believe it is my aforementioned youthful dewiness).
  GF#5: Excellent sight lines from any part of the venue and you can get really close to your artist.  Like sweaty/spittle in your (free) cocktail close.  Like "i can see your cellulite" close.  Cool.
  BF#4: Being constantly shuffled away from the bar, shooed from seemingly arbitrary "fire lanes" on the floor, prevented from sitting sort of anywhere (it seems to change each show) by barking bouncers. 
  BF#5: Never quite loud enough to drown out the high pitched girls (and it's always the girls) who are finally having that slurred "catch-up" conversation they paid $37.50 to have in public, at a concert.  The blessed silences are randomly broken by sung (screeched) lyrics (usually wrong verse entirely).
  GF#6:  Good, balanced sound, decent lighting and how bad can a night be with great music pumping into your system?
  All and all though I would not recommend doing any sort of hallucinogen here.

4bEBiMJCZemLPGJYMGHzkQ.review_text: i have seen Gil Welch, She Wants Revenge, and Cat Power at the beautiful, beautiful Fillmore.  i love the fillmore.  even if the floor is always sticky from decades of spilled alchoholic drinks.   Gil Welch-  mix was perfect.  concert was amazing.  concert was long.   concert was wonderful.  She Wants Revenge (with Kenna and the Start)-  mix for the Start- pretty good, synths could've been turned up a little more  mix for Kenna- bass and drums needed to be a leetle bit quieter. i could barely hear the lead guy singing.  mix for She Wants Revenge- perfect.  concert-pretty coolio.  it was a little too short, but oh well.  Cat Power-  mix- pretty good, excepting for the fact that i couldn't hear Chan Marshall's prettyful voice half the time.   concert- awesome.

RCmp-pCAkdAiAcMa2BXwDg.review_text: I love this venue for concerts. You feel that history has happened here. It's just the right size to be not too far away from the artist/s and has good sound. The best things are the posters you get when you leave. Only happens if it's sold out though.

ozWYBGRTGx4Axv84FoailQ.review_text: I have a ridiculous love affair going with the Fillmore, so this review will be biased as HELL.  If you can look past the hoodie-sporting emo kids that never fail in attendance, this place is oozing with history and San Francisco culture. Every time I go I always seem to get lost in staring at the photos and posters adorning every inch of wallspace (it's a wonder I ended up a photographer...).
