Drinks are expensive, but I'd rather stay semi-sober for these shows anyway -- sound is always killer, and they bring in some of the best acts around.   To the staff: keep it up, and to the public: keep it around!!  My absolute favorite venue... love you :)

o_ijeBF5WkdsCUgQC_fZfg.review_text: Great historic theatre with a nostalgic atmosphere and friendly staff. Only way it could have been better is of the Grateful dead was still the house band.

CKE7bImVY81KJD8PiiuDPQ.review_text: Awesome place! I love that i get poster after seeing a show. the small venue is great for an intimate music listening experience.

RjJPMMiW_PD7durIEMBIBA.review_text: personally, i've always perfered the warfield to the fillmore but last night, I was lucky enough to see Ozric Tenitcales. i was a wonderful show.   the one thing that disapointed me has to do with management. I was pretty upset with the show being cut short last night. I'm sorry to say there was a verbal/physcial heated argument between the artists and the management after the show.  All this over stage time.  so to all musicans: please be careful when dealing with the fillmore, make sure you get EVERYTHING in contract, including when your set when be ending. Aparently, this is important.

yU0sTbaC8NZvJu4noyYiOw.review_text: The Fillmore gets 1 star for publishing that the Me'shell concert had doors at 8pm, show at 9pm and then starting the show at 8:15 pm. Totally lame.

AT6NwNkLKxgW2fsQGNs-gA.review_text: Not only is history staring you in the face -- c'mon ... you KNOW the Doors were banging Penny Lane's backstage here in the 60s, and that Janis was puking her guts up and then wiping her mouth on a fur coat before gigs -- but you also get to stare your favorite artists of today right in the face, literally, thanks to its mosh dance party environ. You just don't find this caliber of accessibility at most venues. Bill Graham did a very cool thing many decades ago, and his legacy is still vibrantly alive in this hall. I do worry, though, that all that encore stomping will land everyone down in the check cashing store directly below one of these days, but The Fillmore remains as iconic as its long roster of notables who have performed there over the years.

VdVanfxCyXIvkUYW6r913Q.review_text: The Fillmore is my happy place. If those walls could talk!! My favorite venue, hands down.  Great sound, reasonable drink prices, good food, great staff.  Some of THE best bands have come through this place.  And the posters! I always look forward to the posters.

0O46kvTi6Kp-_4IC1kRJiw.review_text: Without a  doubt, the Fillmore is the best music venue in San Francisco.  Anything bigger lacks the intimacy or sound quality you want in a memorable show. The crowd is almost always cool; laid back relaxed San Franciscan's who dont push and shove as Ive seen in other cities. So, I'd avoid the Warfield and of course any coliseum.   I've been going since 1994 and theres still nothing like seeing your favourite band here while having a bottle or two of Anchor Steam.  Best to take a cab or a bus here, as parking can be especially challenging, and consider beginning the evening in Japantown or a restaurant in Pac heights just to the north.

8pYGe9IKNHcbuj6NDgrqeQ.review_text: get there early for the better locations and spots.  Seating upstairs can keep you fresh for the beginning of the show when you might want to relinquish them for a better view of the stage.  Pee early and save the wait.  Be  VERY VERY careful to hide and/or remove all valuables from your car.  Even parked on the busy streets in the area does not protect you from some opportunist who thinks that they may have spotted the mother lode in your car window.

mVkleKlvkNyhiK794Numxw.review_text: As a venue, everything that can be said has already been said.  This is one of the finest live music venues in the country.  But let me tell you about the security staff.  At the conclusion of one of the shows, a female friend of mine partially scaled over the front of the stage to snag the set list.   Granted, it's not a good idea to go onstage at all, even if she was only leaning slightly to grab the set list.  However, the security guy manhandled her so viciously, it's fortunate for the venue she was not seriously injured and litigation would be pending.  She was fucking mauled by that guy and other patrons noticed and were pretty bummed.   So if you're at the Fillmore, better chill the hell out or you will get pummelled.

JxotojpExvYIaT4JZpH9pQ.review_text: If you sell out the Fillmore you are a rock star. Not a  tiny venue, but intimate and well-kept. The upstairs bar area is cool. I one day dream of filling my walls with posters from shows I've attended much like the walls of the Fillmore are filled with  posters from some of the most epic rock stars of all times who have all performed there.

xtAH_eikJZa-zp4CLPLOxw.review_text: I used to think the Fillmore was the absolute best live music venue in the city, but after last night I have defiantly changed my tune. First of all, since when did it get so corporate? Even their website is now run by Live Nation? The drinks are weak and EXPENSIVE. $9 for a watered down Stoli and Red Bull. While some of the people that work there are still really nice, there were alot of employees who stood around with nasty scowls on their faces (true- it was an industrial show- so maybe they were just trying to fit in).  In my not-so-experinced opinion the handicapped accessibility is pretty sucky, maybe it's still better than other venues but I still was not pleased. Handicap accessibility is something I probably never would have noticed before but since I was there with a friend in a wheelchair I had an entirely different experience. So first off you have to call ahead to "reserve handicapped seating". They said only one person could accompany the wheelchair and there were three of us total- lame. Then we get up there and we have these little stickers on us so we can sit at our special reserved table. But the table is full, first there is only one person (who had the same table reserved?) then later in the night the entire table was full of random people. Do they just call it a reserved table to make us feel special but then over book it? What's the point of the table anyways- since someone in a wheelchair couldn't see at all from there. Luckily they did help my friend wheel to the front right side of the stage where he could see. But by see I mean an 1/8 of the stage, most of it was still blocked by giant speakers cause it's way off to the side. Again, maybe this is way better than other venues for wheelchair accessibility I don't but I thought it was sorta lame. On the positive note (there are still 3 stars- so obviously I still got love for the Fillmore) it really is overall a great place to see a show. One cannot forget to mention the fact that this place is a San Francisco institution with a legendary history. It's the perfect size for a venue - not too big or too small. It's got great sound. A nice high stage which makes it way easier to see. They often give you free posters after the show. They've got the apples of course ;)

Qt6t6i4RDbgXIOg6EXUbvQ.review_text: i always forget how much i like places like this. big, fancy, sparkley, and FREE APPLES.  i always take at least two.  that, sort of, anyway, makes up for how much it costs to get into this place.

A-HI7Mcr_-SL60T3WvSjiQ.review_text: On the way home this evening the radio played Peter Frampton, a recording from so long ago, not recorded here.  And it got me to thinking, remembering, of other things.  Peter Frampton played earlier with Framptom's Camel, then with Humble Pie, and when I was smaller one of my favorite vinyl renderings was Humble Pie's Live From the Fillmore.  When it was recorded there were two Fillmores, one in NYC, the other in SF.  Fillmore East was down the blocks from my growing up and by the time I might have enjoyed it was boarded, but interestingly, no less energized.  I'd be by, on my way to double features that strangely always had Harold and Maude on the bill, past the eastern Fillmore, not registering how crucially important this venue, or the other, was to the growing up of our generation.  Different stimuli trip different triggers - some have memories anchored by tastes or smells, some are more physically sensate.  The telomeres that are my life are aural.  Hearing the older songs this evening dragged me back to a different day, to when you could purchase admission for less than a week's salary, to when artists seemed more earnest.  This contemporary Fillmore will give you all you need,and more, as a small concert venue can give,  But if you can, maybe for a small second, open yourself to its history, to all that's gone before you tonight, I think you'll be for the better,  That's me, thinking.

nXa2KNrGsk5mxxxt3-3KzA.review_text: Maybe it depends on the artist you decide to see. Just yesterday I went to the Jurassic 5 show and it was amazing. And I am not only talking about the show. I def like the setting.  The interior is gorgeous and the main floor practically encourages you to dance. And that is what everybody did!!! People were going crazy and nobody cared what the person next to you did or said or looked liked ...... The sound was good and the people that work there are nice. The old bartender that was mentioned before was super friendly & attentive. And I feel the staff in general is very helpful and nice, especially if you compare them with people that work at different venues (i.e. the Warfield.)  So why not 5 stars? No Red Bull or something comparable. I just need my energy drink once in a while ;)

Zcr90BeQ8QWV32XIqpH82A.review_text: An SF classic, and in my opinion (that of a rock music snob), this place is an icon of American culture.  The Fillmore is amazing because it has provided the SF location for so many great artists from around the world to put on epic shows.  My dad saw Hendrix here.  Wow.  I have seen Wilco absolutely bring the place down--I'm about to see Beck there tonight, and I have no doubt it will be spectacular.   What really sets the Fillmore apart though is that it is still going strong.  The sound is amazing, they book great talent, there are still free apples and the guy at the top of the stairs--and the great posters after the show.   Sure there are downsides--there always are.  But why list them here when the Fillmore is one of my happy places?  If you have never been to a show at the Fillmore, go.  If you aren't really into music, and you don't know any of the acts they book, ask a friend who does and go with him or her.   Once you discover what a great experience live music is at a venue like the Fillmore, it is time for you to find a friend who knows acts that play at the Great American Music Hall, the Independent, Slim's, etc.  San Francisco is a great place for live music!  Enjoy!

OcmSdNfek2Lp2NaTdsxvlQ.review_text: I've been to the Fillmore twice now. The second visit was last Thursday to see Mason Jennings. During the opening act the entire venue rocked with a passing earthquake. Rock and roll SF style!  The show was fantastic, but you can't credit the venue with that. However, the acoustics are fantastic, the stage is at the perfect height and angle, and the floor space is comfortably wide. I dig it. It was a bit crowded, but there was still room to move around and dance. The staff is mediocre, but I've never personally had problems with them. They did frisk me rather abruptly when I entered, which startled me, but it was no big deal. I didn't feel harassed. I didn't bother with the bar since it was already crowded when I arrived. Mostly I just hung out by the stage. The only thing I'd really change would be the seating. After a three hour show, I'd have loved to rest for a minute, but there are no chairs other than up in the balcony. And if you don't arrive super early, good luck getting any of those tables!   Complaints aside, this venue rocks. I've been to most of the major venues in SF, and this is definitely one of the best. It is a beautiful old building, very ornate inside, and the spirit of rock and roll definitely resides.

-8ZM-jzJEGkKCxYEJnFrqQ.review_text: I don't know why I never reviewed the Fillmore until now, seeing as I have been there ten million times- maybe I just felt that it had all been said before. BUT, there have been a few notable instances which add up to five stars. Upon returning from 2 weeks in Spain, I was *ahem*, a little out of wack. Ed had to remind me that we had tix to the Stephen Malkmus show, and no sorry ass excuse involving purloined Spanish goofballs was getting me out of it. This was back when he was bossy. So I dragged my ass from my office down to meet him- he had taken the day off and was camping out in order to score that table upstairs to the left of the stage. Which he did! UNTIL a lackey skulked up to us and informed us that this table was reserved- for Stephen Malkmus' father!? WTF? Bossy, I mean Eddy, tried to argue to no avail. So we go to speak to the manager (SEE? Bossy.)  The manager is working coat check and has no time for this. So we head out to the floor with the unwashed masses, and now Ed is spitting nails. Finger and otherwise. I actually didn't mind too much, because our friend Michael worked the floor there and I used to love watching him maneuver our cocktails out to the middle of the crowd- this guy is Dangerprone Daphne normally, but at work he was some sort of spillproof robot. Anyway, after a while the coat check/manager individual comes barreling out onto the main floor screaming "ED AND DAVID!!!!! WHERE ARE ED AND DAVID!?!?!?!?" We meekly responded, expecting I don't know what, when she graciously apologized about the table and gave us box seats. The box seats are kind of far away from the stage, but whatev. It's the thought that counts.

va-b4ZNKI4emcL_WsERU0Q.review_text: Great venue, spoiled by its employees. Try to skip the bar, or anything else that would make you deal with one of their needle-dick drones, and you'll be OK. Weirder yet was getting some kind of challenging e-mail after having posted that preceding commentary- I reminded him that we yelpers need not justify what we opine, and he vanished- but evidently, in the true spirit of Evil, Clear Channel monitors these posts. So, double fuck the Fillmore, and those that toil there. Ha.

ZX6c8p2IlbdhdNnM-vREJQ.review_text: lucky to have this venue here were one can just walk in and see some of the best acts in the world up and close.

fHypZQSHGU8Zg4PkyaPopA.review_text: I love seeing bigger bands here. I almost always end up with a lovely new poster. The sound is good and some of the bands do great things with lighting/stage decoration (e.g., Beth Orton's setup was gorgeous). There's street parking nearby and it's easy to get to. For as big as it is, and it pretty much the largest venue I'll happily see shows at, you never feel lost in the crowd or like there are too many tall people or that tickets are obscenely priced (on the high end, sure, but not obscene).  My biggest problem is the death trap that is the line to get out at the end of the evening. Two people at a time can flood out the door and until then, it's chaos. Makes me irrationally angry.

QpuN5OAnJUdrvWTWq-RI7A.review_text: Was here for the Gnarls Barkley show a couple of weeks back. This is by far the best concer venue that I've been too. Small and cozy, a nice getaway from the stadium shows where you need binoculars to see the artist.  I was pleasantly surprised to see an eclectic mix of music followers. From the 16 year old emo kid to the 61 year old grandfather of 2. When the music starts pumping, you can literally feel the floor starting to shake beneath you.  This is the one place that can pull off having both large suspended chandeliers and bartenders serving fat tires at the same time.

FWDc1xn1meMZRbv57CTDHw.review_text: Great place to watch standup. or your favorite musician.  its kool i guess.

56zJO0uLaZbwOzw63LOrOA.review_text: The Fillmore is far and away one of my least favorite venues in the entire bay area.  If they were falf as competant running a business as they were at booking great acts this would be the best venue around.  Instead they seem to think that because they get really great bands and shows, its okay to run their business in a half-assed, rude, and condescending manner.  Everytime I go to the Fillmore, I tell myself it will be my last time there and somehow they wind up dragging me back with a great show.  This last time really WILL be my last!    We showed up early to ensure we got a good spot for the show since we were really excited.  Not only does the Fillmore have the most expensive drinks of almost any venue ($7-$10 each) their bartenders and servers are entirely unpersonable.  Even if you want to pay more for a neat instead of a shot the drink comes in a thimble glass for $10.  After having our drink and waiting at the nearly empty bar to order another beer, a different barback came over to inform us we would have to leave since we were "crowding" the bar and preventing other patrons from ordering. Considering the bar was nearly entirely empty except for us, I can only assume a "crowd" at the Fillmore consists of two customers.     We then wanted to go have a cigarette but were informed by the door staff that the only time you could smoke at the fillmore is after the opening band goes off and before the main act goes on.  Okaaaaay...Didn't make sense so we asked one of the servers why this was the case.  They informed us that they had recently had a "mexican show" with a lot of "hispanic" customers.  These "hispanic" patrons had been using their tickets tickets to get entry and then were reselling tickets to other people once they had left and these people used the already used tickets to get in.  After realizing how offended my girlfriend had been by what she had said, she came back to enforce us that we shouldnt be offended because she was "100% Mexican."  beyond the offensiveness of what she said, her statement is just rediculous.  If they scan all tickets when we get in, then it should SHOW that the ticket had already been used for entry and was invalid.  Are they really telling me that you can just print multiple copies of the same ticket and every single on will work because this is the first venue I have ever been to where this would be the case.  Why waste everyone's time scanning every ticket and delaying entry if the scanners cant even detect whether or not a ticket has already been used?  If this is the case, I can only imagine how much money has been made by scalpers using this loophole!   After sitting through the opening act, we went to have a cigarette.  As we were attempting to reenter the venue, we were informed that we could not enter because we were "intoxicated."  Ummm you have bar.  you serve alcohol.   This is a rock concert.  We are SUPPOSED to be intoxicated.  They then had to add inslut to injury by emphasizing that we werent being kikced out we just couldnt come back in until we were "sober" and to come back in 10 minutes.  Ummm what?  In what world can you be too drunk to get in, but be able to sober up in 10 minutes.  It should be noted that I have gone to hundreds if not thousands of concerts in my life.  I have been to hundreds of bars,clubs, and venues in the bay area since moving here 5 years ago and have never been denied entry or removed from a bar/club/venue.  EVER!  At this point, We were so sick of the terrible service, and rude, self-aggrandizing employees that we didnt even want to wait the 10 minutes to try and get back into the venue.  We simply took a cab home, stopped at our neighborhood bar, and called it a night.  Not too surprisoingly, neither the cab driver, nor the bar felt we were "intoxicated" much less too "intoxicated" to let us in.  I will NEVER EVER go to this venue again no matter how great the billing.  In the past I had told myself it was worth dealing with their incompetence to see one of the great acts they book but after the disapointment of the last show, this will never be the case again.

c8qFkI_VusWo0xZvkjfBWQ.review_text: So many famous people have played here it is impossible to name them all.  Line up early to get a good spot and NEVER believe a word the scalpers say when you're walking up to the show.  Avoid the Thai restaurant across the street if you need some pre-show chow, that place is terrible.

HzIIEAdbEa5G_Hi6JpT7Bw.review_text: i really was intent on giving the fillmore a bad review but after the show started i knew i wouldn't be able to.   really, i am kind of disappointed in you, yelpers. not a one of the reviews i read mentioned ANYTHING about how EXORBITANTLY overpriced the drinks are here. maybe you are all under age (judging by the crowd at ratatat and the third reich-like enforcement of the over 21 hand stamps a lot of you probably are) or maybe you don't like drinking at concerts (what the HELL is wrong with you) but i nearly choked when i got charged $10 each for an ounce of kettle soda in a urine sample cup. then i decided to switch to beer (ordered a 24 oz of fat tire) and proceeded to sign over my first born child to the tune of $11.25 and the sassy attitude of the bar tender upon not receiving a tip (hey, we are all suffering- let me get over the shock of how much i just spent on a BEER in peace). so, needless to say, i'll be living off of ramen for the next week.  ratatat was so incredible and standing 2 feet away from the band, feeling the bass reverberating through my bones, and feeding off of the energy of my fellow concert goers (and getting a contact high from what seemed to be an over consumption of ecstasy and shrooms) was unforgettable. i also love that they give you a free commemorative poster as you are leaving. i can't hear and i sound like tara reid after spring break in cabo but it was so worth.  BUT LET IT BE SAID: IF YOU CARE ABOUT DRINKING, FOR CRYING IN THE KITCHEN SINK, HIT UP THE BOOM BOOM ROOM BEFORE ENTERING THE FILLMORE. you've been warned. learn from my mistakes, that's what i'm here for. you're welcome.  also, i have to just make a side comment about the reviewers who complain about the pot smoke. i'm not sure if you are aware of this, but pot smoke and live music go hand in hand. they have for a very long time and i don't think that's going to change any time soon. and, this is san francisco, we all know they don't enforce any "laws" regarding the puffing of the cheba. peace and love.

bA6sFAZTIc5ddwpnB_WJUw.review_text: I used to love the Fillmore.  So many memories, great shows, all the history.   Years ago I would get in free thanks to something involving my roommate and the ticket office. It's one of the most chill, respectful, all-about-the-music venues ever.  Until tonight.   It's the scalpers.  They stand outside hawking tickets.  Sold out nights they're expensive, quiet nights as low as half price.  I avoided them.  I don't like shady things.  Don't trust them.  Bad karma.  But tonight the ticket office was closed when I got there.  It was early, 10:30.  A guy lurking just around the corner motioned me over.  He had an ID badge and insisted he worked there.  I said my most polite no thank you.  Then another guy with the same badge introduced himself as the head of security. Said if I wanted a ticket I had to talk to the man around the corner.  The gaggle of ticket takers, ID checkers, and hangers on in the portico saw all this, it seemed cool with them.  So I made the transaction - one preprinted ticket and a laser printed sheet of paper.  Cash only.  That got us in as promised, no problem.  Security badge guy frisked me half heartedly, didn't ask for ID.  VIP service, I guess.  As I rounded the stairs the concert let out.  Shit.  Fifty bucks for fifteen seconds of singing and a minute of clapping, plus one apple, all from the lobby.  Badge guy was standing out front with a bunch of other employees.  I didn't feel like a confrontation right there.  He must have known what he was doing.  Why blame the venue?   Bill Graham started it, and it's where the Grateful Dead, Jefferson airplane, Janis Joplin, the Doors, Pink Floyd, jimi Hendrix used to play.  Then Black Flag, Dead Kennedies.  And some other acts, Red Hot Chili Peppers, Love and rockets, Social Distortion,  Smashing Pumpkins, Tom Petty, Underworld.  Los Van Van.  The Decemberists are playing there Thanksgiving weekend, then Ozomatli, Etta James, Debby Harry.  Perhaps you've heard of some of these people.  Stanley Mouse and friends more or less invented hippie art there, the day-glo concert poster that's so famous.  And they've been bellowing "Welcome to the Fillmore" and giving out red delicious apples almost forty years now, as many as you want, free.  The owner, Live Nation, is a $2.8 billion a year, 18,000 employee spin-off of Clear Channel Communications.  Am I just sore over corporate big music greed?  Kind of.  Either a publicly traded corporate lawyer suit company just sold me a ticket at full price to a show that was already over, or it is so sloppy that it lets its employees do it openly right in front of the ticket office.  It's totally obvious, and flagrant.  Either way, if anyone at Live Nation had a pulse they wouldn't let their ticket office fleece the customers.  I've been had.  It just isn't right.  There are so many people in San Francisco eager to make a chump out of you.  I guess it's part of the grand tradition of pirates, pickpockets, and swindlers, that's our town as much as the hippies and the drugs.  But I feel like a sucker, and when someone makes a sucker out of me I don't return to the scene for more.

dXaRg6RJL51s5l22P7AXkQ.review_text: The Fillmore - a classic  Of course I'll echo everything everyone else has said... Though I do have to drop a WTF to Live Nation about that new Verizon text messaging screen they posted... leave that shit at the Shoreline, fools!  Soooo lame and not-Fillmore-eque at all...  Also let's be sure we have posters at EVERY show, come on now!!  But all in all, a fantastic, intimate venue that never dissapoints.

zZ_88k3uh5yVwZOoLIkBnQ.review_text: The Legendary Bill Graham Bay Area Club.  One of the best places in the world that I've experienced live rock, blues, soul concerts.  The Sound, Lighting and Room Acoustics are great, it is all standing room only, there is no significant seating (except for a very limited number of A-List VIP balconies) so get there early and get up front - especially if you are short.  I had been here around 10 times back in the 1980s.  The place is fixed up much nicer than I remember or what I could remember from the 80s.  But it still has the same great ambiance.  At The Fillmore, you know you are at a Rock Concert Hall and not some multipurpose arena.  Unlike other reviewers, I had no problems with the staff.  They are direct and speak loudly to you but its really because they are dealing with a ton of often loaded or stoned concert patrons.  If you are nice with them, they are nice with you.  If you want to make lots of Fillmore friends, wear SF Giants gear.  Seeking to get razed, wear Dodger blue - on 2nd thought, maybe not a good idea.  Get there early, be sure to grab an apple on the way in and make your way upstairs to look over past concert posters and to grab a drink or two.  Drinks are higher priced but it is a concert venue.  But I found prices no greater and perhaps less than at AT&T or a downtown theater.    Lot of easy parking in Japan town lots.   Be warned however, you might catch a 2nd hand high from the exhales of numerous concert goes smoking nearby.  Every so often inside even, you catch a whiff of what B-Wizz calls '4-20 in the air'.  Not that I partake in any of that.

kY6EE2_ajFuA_BNeYGRXeA.review_text: This is definitely my favorite concert venue in SF. I've seen plenty of concerts here including De La Soul, Common & John Legend, Lily Allen, Gym Class Heroes and India Arie. The venue is intimate and the atmosphere is nostalgic, especially with the wall full of posters of artists that performed there before.   The bar is overpriced and it can get crowded. Also, I have these moments when people are jammin or jumping up and down to the music where I think the floor will collapse, but I prefer this venue overall.

uPTEUwRTCZur0eQktqdZxA.review_text: Love the Fillmore. Great acoustics, rich history, and minimal waiting for a drink if you know where to go. The free apples are a nice touch, as are the occasional free posters.

g2YnG8VUb9opaWF6fx6viQ.review_text:
One of the best clubs to see live music in SF.  I came back last night to see M. Ward and was totally impressed. The people who work here are cool and the place is very accomodating with a nice preshow room with food and booze. We ended up having cocktails and missing Mike Watt but when we came in late we still had a great view. M. Ward was on fire and put on a fantastic show and threw in a double encore.  
 A true San Francisco music landmark.

-tZz4Ls62fWvmN49JOa45A.review_text: What's left to say that hasn't already been said about this historic venue?!  Came here last night for the Blue Scholars show.    Looking from the outside, you wouldn't be able to tell that there was a huge stage/floor on the inside.  When I was walking up the stairs after being checked by the bouncers (who seemed really friendly), I was just talking to them and told them it was my first time here.  Immediately, they directed me and demanded me (in a friendly manner, of course) to grab an apple from the bin at the top of the stairs.  The famous Fillmore apple.  Nice and cold.  Crisp and juicy.  I felt like it was my initiation into The Fillmore and can finally and officially say, "I've been to The Fillmore.."   After devouring the apple (I hadn't eaten dinner beforehand), I went around to take notice of the venue.  The floor was huge and you can get a great vantage point of the stage from anywhere on the floor, it seemed.  I didn't get a chance to check the posters on the walls outside because I wanted to secure my spot up front.  The bar was lined up against wall and they seemed to be getting drinks out fast to the patrons at the bar and to the servers, who, by the way, does an amazing job keeping the tray from falling while walking through waves of waving arms and bodies.  Acoustics sounded nice and resonated well throughout the place.    I recommend catching a show at the Fillmore.  If you see that one of your favorite performers is performing there, jump on it.  You won't regret it.  It's definitely worth catching a show in a venue that's full of culture and a historic presence that's set by those who have performed there from years past.  **I should recommend, if you're catching a night show there and you're worried about parking on the streets (I've heard it can lead to broken windows and whatnot), park at the Japan Center Garage, just a block or two down on Geary.  The show was from 8pm and when I got to my car around 11:45pm-12pm, I only paid $2.  Definitely worth it.**

VW4KVBkiB7eABL-hkZHcKw.review_text: i just saw social d here (first time at the fillmore) and i have to say it's my favorite place to catch a band in SF. the history and all the cool posters each band has for this place kills.

4grjQPPp9awiC8j3jBR66g.review_text: I have got to give props to the fillmore.  I F-ing love this place.  It has done me well every time I have stepped inside their doors.  If I go in then I am ready to get down, and lordy hopefully who ever is playing is under the same assumption.  I don't understand why people go to show that is a slow show here.  This place is fo getting down.  SO if U READY...then you're at the right place.

vpio8XtROMjHbm6eI4Za1A.review_text: What can you say about the Fillmore that hasn't already been said by the incredible history of the place? The amount of legends that have played here is a who's who of music. From Led Zeppelin to Jimi Hendrix, The Who, Pink Floyd, The Doors and Metallica just to name a few, this place has history oozing from the walls.  For a place so old it is surprisingly in great shape. All through out the place are old vintage posters of rocks yesteryears.  The kind of posters that would make you feel like you're on something even when you know damn well you're not.  The venue isn't too big. Which is great because it gives you an intimate feeling. The backstage area is very small though. Not much room to move around.  The stage is a good size. The sound is awesome! The place rocks! Sitting in the VIP seats in the back of the room gives you a straight-on view of the stage. There really isn't a bad seat in this place.

pQEwYeq8jGVeCRUl3wLmQw.review_text: i do not love the fillmore.  there.  i said it.    i used to live up the street (on fillmore at clay, right across from the clay theater), yet i only ever managed to go to a few shows.    for lack of a better description, it just isn't comfortable.  they have some fun quirks that other venues might do well to adopt, but otherwise it's just *meh!*.  i'd definitely go again for the right show (say, if james brown were to return from the dead for just one show at the fillmore), but otherwise i'll pass.

W5d-Nx2T2OtOECRBNUbqqA.review_text: i really like this place.  sometimes, because of the size, you can't get too close or you cant see the band too well, but hell the place still rocks. couple of bars, nice wooden dancing area.

m33100p9jye0Pcq8ybozPQ.review_text: I love this place.  The acoustics are fantastic!  It's easy to get a beer and there's plenty of space to roam.  I love going upstairs before shows and checking out all of the posters.  The only thing keeping me from giving this venue 5 stars is my personal preference for smaller, more intimate venues.  However, though this place is rather large, if you see a less popular band here it's certainly possible for it to feel small and intimate.

ctU-R89nKL2-A8ze9I-6AA.review_text: I went here to see Bill Burr and it was pretty cool. You definitely get the historic "wow, that's pretty neat" vibe when you go in there. The place looks really cool and kinda big on the inside; which is surprising considering from the outside it looks just big enough to fit about 5 people in it. Prices are meh, I guess I'm used to like $60 a ticket from a place like the Enormodome instead of a theater. But with that in mind it's cool. Definitely check it out if you get the chance, I mean it's right next to the post office, who would want to miss that?!

J-uigTGOF7K0GpgDAkemeQ.review_text: One of the better "big" clubs for live music. You can still see the bands and you get posters at the end of the show. Plenty of food around the area as well. Parking's not that great though, you may need to park near J Town.

4Gi0DanAQaYnG8SWZIut_g.review_text: I can now say that I've been to the SF trifecta of rock and roll concert venues. The Warfield, The Regency, and The Fillmore all have quite a bit in common with their austere ceilings and balcony looks from an earlier period.  The Fillmore, though, is a step above in terms of nostalgia. The greats have played at the other places, but the Fillmore is legendary for making music happen.   I would have bought my tickets way in advance to get that precious balcony seating. I could have danced all night, but I'm starting to creak a little. So, if you're like me, order them early.   Otherwise, it's a great time. There's some service that goes into the general admission area. If you're just a little polite and sly, you can work your way slowly to (almost) center stage at the very front row.  I love a good rock-n-roll concert. The acoustics are fine, the atmosphere is lively and casual. Enjoy.

Q5cbHM1nM-RqvS-r_Gg30Q.review_text: The only venue to truly deserve the five flashy stars.    It's such and intimate place that you can usually meet the folks you are standing around swaying to.  Buddy Guy, Carlos Santana, Ozomatli....  brilliant performers at a perfect place.   STRONG drinks, small and pricey, but worth it.  Always a way to work up to the front of the stage after a few vodka sodas.

_q_z9bIwYg2q0mSNbwxmGA.review_text: The Fillmore is the best place in San Francisco to see a large act. It has the size and the affiliations to attract the band-of-the-moment (Coldplay) and has the history and charm to draw long-established acts there for multi-night gigs (Tom Petty).  The upstairs area is helpful for avoiding awful opening acts, getting some food, and looking at the posters. The size of the club and the crowd means it's usually standing room only, but the sightlines and the sound are good.  I find that getting an apple on my way in and a poster on my way out generally makes up for having to pay ticketmaster fees, but others obviously strongly disagree. I've not had the same problems with staff that other reviewers have. Parking is usually doable, though mainly by paying for a space in the small lots nearby. Several bus lines (22 etc) run by the venue.

FGVc4UCv7KT12PRmsckeMA.review_text: This is my favorite venue to see a show. The first time I went here was to see Third Eye Blind kick off their 10th anniversary tour, right in their hometown of San Francisco.  The crowd was chill. I was able to enjoy the music, and not deal with any assholes who were too drunk or obnoxious. (Okay, maybe just one, but everyone else was fine.)  And after that experience, I realized this is what a concert venue should feel like. Not too big, not too small. Great lighting and sound system. Even better people. No longer was I going to deal with all-day music festivals, sweaty and chaotic. The Fillmore offers an intimate space that makes it possible to really enjoy music.

HdW_VZSVFiZTt7VcGIu52w.review_text:
since there are 91 reviews on fillmore, i won't bore you with a useful review. instead i will present the following story.
  so i hear that the one and only ll cool j is coming to the venerable fillmore next week. this brings back one of my fondest memories at the fillmore... a few years ago i went to see 'lady loves cool james' at the fillmore in a full boxing attire. you see, i found out he was coming about a month before the show, and since "mama said knock you out" was my favorite ll cool j song, i thought it would be cool and quirky to see the concert in a full boxing attire. so i went to various costume stores and got myself an entire boxing outfit with robe, trunk, gloves and all. i was so effing excited until i tried them on and looked myself in the mirror. oh boy, i'm way too flabby to wear this. i look like a clown than a boxer. i must train! i have one month before the concert. so i went all rocky balboa and subjected myself into all types of torture. eating raw eggs and farting. running in the morning and throwing up. lifting weights at night and getting stuck under a barbell. shadow boxing during lunch time and accidentally hitting my boss. practicing "yo adrian" and annoying my friends and neighbors. i swear on some days i wanted to quit, but i fought through the pain. soon i was getting stronger and faster. the day before the concert, i even ran up the stairs at the city hall and raised my arms (rocky theme song in the background)... finally, the night arrived. i put on the gloves and trunk and stared myself in the mirror. not bad, but my stomach was still hanging out. must suck in stomach. ok, that's better. then i put on the robes and pulled the hood over my head. hey, i look kinda tough. definitely tougher than cassio p. it's ok, cassio. you're smarter and prettier than me. anyway, i headed over to the fillmore in my boxing attire. the door guy was like, "what the eff?!?!?!" i was like, "dude, let me in or my mama will tell me to knock you out." he was like, "oh man, that's cool. that's cool." so i got in! as expected, everyone was staring at me and thinking that i was a fool. oh yeah? so i was like, "what you looking at? you have a death wish?" they were like, "oh man, no dude. you might want to suck in your stomach though." shit! thanks for pointing out the obvious. after a boring opening act, it was time for the main event. ll cool j in the house! ladies and gentlemen, it's time to rumble!!! so i made my way to the very front of the stage. trust me, when you look like a freak, people let you get to the front. ll cool j was like, "what the eff?!?!?!" i was like, "hey j, you better bring your a-game tonight or i'm gonna knock you out!" he smiled and nodded. so all night as he was rapping, i was shadow boxing. it was beautiful, and we went to the distance. of course, when he performed "mama said knock you out," he pointed at me and gave thumbs up. yup, it was a memorable night indeed.
   * apology for multiple usage of "so" and "like" and run-on sentences, but you know what? rocky was never the brightest bulb.

ghost_id_1.review_text: Historic place with great free apples, unfortunately.... everyone who works there was very very very rude to my girlfriend and I. Unfortunate because it seems like the best places with the most history usually hire people they think are hip and will carry on the legacy of their great venue... only to hire pricks. Never going back... ever. No matter who plays there and which friends come to visit me and want to go see a show. I'll just hope on jambase.com to find another show in some hole in the wall venue to try out. Alex from New Orleans and new to San Francisco

ml3vS1NZTMeXTuxamvAZgw.review_text: There's really nothing like the Fillmore.  I could spend hours checking out the pictures on the walls upstairs of all the amazing bands.  The venue itself is pretty good, but not perfect.  Decent access to bartenders.  I've always had a good time there.  However, everytime I go, its the history that draws me in, as much as the band.    Maybe I just haven't seen the right performance there yet.

j_yNLTgzGzHDpg0EIJysQg.review_text: Highlights are the decor (standing under chandeliers while listening to Jonny Lang.. hell to the yes!), all the posters upstairs (make sure to take a trip up there to oogle them all), and the fun idea of putting a trough of free apples in the lobby for the dry-mouthed, wink wink. Definitely something to experience!

3vHNhZ5zrpZMTM5CgTE6rg.review_text: I hate to post this with all these 5-star reviews, but I can't stand the Fillmore. They get one extra star for the apples and the other for some rather nice staff, but the venue just gets me down.  I think it might be the way the hall is shaped, but the acoustics are always a bit wonky to my ear. I also find the space fairly claustrophobic (more so than other halls. I can't figure out why.) and I've just never had good luck with finding friendly people who go to shows there. Oh well, my loss I guess.

3F7WioJnKO9VudxbiAYZBw.review_text: best place to see a show.  u get to mingle with the crowd and get nice and sauced at the bars they have around the joint.  crowd surfing, moshing, and watching 2 folks who desperately need to get a room is what this place is all about!  plus the purple chandeliers waft out a wicked essence to the atmosphere of the world famous joint.

lpp4N_3g1eVy_0wcNuyEQQ.review_text: I dig the set up.  I like the 2nd floor.  Lots of bars.  Very nice.

Bkyj7Du5OgF4ah6KkKfjQg.review_text: Went here for a Kate Nash concert on 11/22/13...it was pretty awesome. I really like the venue because it's surrounded by a lot restaurants and a Safeway.   The floor is very spacious, but I got kinda scared when everyone started jumping around because the floor felt like it was about to give way. Lol, it felt like I was on a trampoline.   One thing that I thought was very cool were the pieces of album art on lining the hallways. They kind of made you feel star-struck knowing who has played here before and who doesn't appreciate that?   The only thing I wish they had was food here, but other than that I felt comfortable here and will frequent in the future!

ALfmjwpbsVrEjO-4mNlYXg.review_text: Pretty good sound set up, even if close to the stage.  They were giving out free apples, which was a plus.  Another plus is that because of the set up, the band had to park their tour bus right out front so we hung out after and got to talk to them a bit and got autographs.The drinks were pretty pricey, but typical at a venue I suppose. A craft bear and a gin and tonic was $17 I think.  It was a cool spot and parking wan't too hard to find, even on a Saturday night.  Just plan on spending 10-15 minutes finding a parking spot nearby and walking to the venue.

iUADnqGkr9xvTrnRpa0JoQ.review_text: Saw Gerard Way here and it was an awesome experience. The venue was clean and the woman with the top hat who greeted us when we got inside was nice! They offered free apples and ice cold water that you can pour yourselves instead of bothering the bartenders. This was one of the first times I went to a concert without having any issue with anyone, all attendees were really friendly!  The location is are so really great because it's by a bunch of restaurants/fast food stops/bars/coffee shops/liquor stores/ and there is a bunch of parking garages right by the venue. Awesome place. Wouldn't mind seeing another show here!

IBrL-6twlZmQBGLdV2DQiw.review_text: As beautiful and friendly as ever.  (And cleaner, it seems.)   Love it.

HPJY5cQ7Za6Hi07eB3gvZA.review_text: The Fillmore - wow.  Can't believe I was going to see my favorite band at such a historic venue in San Francisco.  I saw the Los Lonely Boys this September and they were amazing as usual.  Waiting in line all day was worth being right up front.   The walls were decorated with photos from past performances.  Beautiful chandeliers hung from the ceiling.  It is a standing room only.  With tables and booths along the wall and on the balcony.  Excellent sound.  Would definitely come back here again.

BAYRxyOA85kURkjNBVtWnw.review_text: I went last friday, but before I hadn't been there for a few years. As a teen, I often took bart into San Francisco for events, so I used to go hella back in the day. I guess I didn't really miss anything, cause it looks the same inside. Umm, bottled water costs $3.75- and thats for the standard small one. Gotta make $ somehow...

2obAyPuH-G3Dn3EUdQnQlA.review_text: i absolutely love seeing a live show here. you can feel the history of the place walking through the halls with all of the posters and photos on the walls. they generally have the best selection of shows from old to new at the cheapest ticket prices. and you don't have to order from ticketmaster.com if you don't mind waiting in line at the box office.

zyCUBfCjEidb3nMbUDWyfA.review_text: You probably don't need another 5 star review telling you how great this place is. But i will tell you this....  The large chandeliers are what does it for me. I absoluteley LOVE chandeliers. When I die, I want to be reborn as a chandelier.  So who was at Prodigy on the Friday after Thanksgiving? That was an AMAZING show! The Fillmore was THE PLACE TO BE that night - for those who stayed in SF and did not travel during the holiday.  Any show is guranteed to be good there.

ieDHg0fbgipcWgTpq2CvVA.review_text: I had a great time at this venue when I saw Anberlin a while back. I love venues of this size because you can actually see the band. The staff was friendly and kept the vibe cool.

Vrz9RvM3skJHbMp8EltOQA.review_text: One of my favorite venues in the city! I love that it's easy to get to via public transportation (the 38 bus stop is RIGHT THERE) and it's possible to find parking a few blocks away.  I saw my very first concert here so I guess I'll always have a special place in my heart for this place. It has great acoustics and a fairly intimate venue. The Fillmore is not as big as the Warfield but frequently hosts big acts here. There's a lot of history here, as you'll read from the previous reviews, and one of the best things about seeing a show here is the free poster! I also love how the floor is extra bouncy when everyone's jumping/dancing.   When I saw Two Door Cinema Club here last year, there was an after party that was only for people with passes. I didn't have one, but after waiting awhile security or TDCC's team gave out extra passes. We got to hang out in the poster room while Kev DJ'd. Fun times!

yTvzCAW78Il9IOKt1QcozA.review_text: This is my favorite concert venue in San Francisco. There are cuter and more intimate ones like the rickshaw stop, but I think the Fillmore is the best of all worlds. Just big enough to still feel intimate, tables upstairs and a small food selection, beautiful chandeliers hang from the ceiling, and my all-time favorite thing about the venue- every show you get a free concert poster! They're always original, done by local artists, and its nice to have something to remember the night by. Drinks are insanely expensive (paid 10$ for a cosmopolitan in a little cough-syrup cup!!) and they look through your bags at the door, so you have to be creative. :)  Still my favorite venue.

cIOx0eDqYSxlkckH2QYn4Q.review_text: Great place to see a metal show !  Sound is good and loud, staff were really friendly and helpful, good drinks, and didn't see anyone hassled for vaporizing weed. That is about as good as it gets. Parking garages are within walking distance, but the BART is very far away from the venue.

cjx2vRJhjEDrglytleMXeA.review_text: What can I say about the Fillmore that hasn't already been said?  It's awesome to think of the parade of hippies and rockers that stood in here and drank Michelob in days past...My friend and I saw The Sounds here last nite, and it rocked.  The decor is classic, loved the Haunted-Mansion-esque chandeliers!  The bar selection is pretty scarce (unless your drink of choice is Jack & Coke), sound system is bass-heavy but overall a quintessential SF music experience.

2ihuZ28Eqpxz1UtENFdwPg.review_text: WOW. HOT DAMN.  I'm an LA kid, but my gal got me tickets to see Lupe Fiasco up in the yay area, so I'm all like whatthehey. The Fillmore might be in the janky part of Japantown, but it's the most unsuspecting concert venue I've ever been to.  Once you get past the front door where all the scalpers are, you walk upstairs to the foyer with helllllla fotos of all the famous artists that have played the Fillmore. They even had a big-ass foto of Dave Chappelle! Hah, love it. They have several standing areas to watch the show, including a balcony.  Plus 10 points. They have a separate restaurant/lounge/bar area where they have a DJ and you can get your drink on before the main act! How sweet. I just remember the DJ playing the instrumental to Snoop's "Signs" and I was in a good effin mood.  Ok, one last thing: free apples? "Really, I can take one? You go first." We wanted to know the truth behind the free apples so we asked the old-timer guy greeting all the people in the front. He said that the owner of the Fillmore used to give out free apples after the show because hippies were usually parched/hungry after being on drugs for the whole concert. Nice! These were seriously the juiciest apples I've ever had IN MY LIFE. (I do get worried about the potential danger of fans throwing apples at ppl on stage tho.)  Oh Fillmore, I shall come back to your velvet hallways once again.

TfCiTlXWva3YLxmdey-Mgg.review_text: First off, this is a review of 'The Fillmore", not of the show I attended last night.  Billy Idol kicked butt and puts on one amazing show.  That being said, The Fillmore had it's ups and downs and unfortunately had more downs for myself and the people I went with.  Positive Experiences: 1 - Greeter was a nice touch 2 - The photos from previous performances lining the walls is very cool 3 - Our bartender was great!  Very nice and even comped us some waters at the end of the show.  Negative Experiences: 1 - Security was incompetent.  Before the show even started my girlfriend was pushed by a woman and gentleman in front of us.  I stepped in and told them to stay where they were and we would stay where we were and everything would be fine.  That wasn't good enough, the guy proceeded to bump into me and then got the security guards attention to say that I was the aggressor.  Things settled down, the show started and all of a sudden a security guard comes up to me and says I have to go with him.  I've worked security at events myself and I know the process, so I went with him with no argument.  Once out in the hall I was informed that I was taken out because it had been reported I had a knife!  What?!  All I did was defend my girlfriend from a older stuck up couple and I get accused of this?  I thought I was in a twilight zone.  The guard went on to search me and obviously found no knife.  By this time my buddy and our both of our girlfriends are freaked out by what has occurred and the guard realizes that security had been 'used' by the over zealous guy.  I asked for the guard to escort us back to where we were (up front) and he did, but he did nothing about the couple that had started the entire ordeal.  I'm a 'right and wrong' type of guy and when someone abuses the system to cause harm to others I expect it to be dealt with.  BTW, this same couple had pissed off others in the area due to their 'entitlement' attitude of at least a three feet radius around them.  The woman even went so far as to say "I'm an ex of Billy Idols"....LOL.  Additionally, I found out today that it is misdemeanor to falsely accuse someone of brandishing a weapon.  The Fillmore security staff obviously is not trained in this or they decided to ignore this fact.  Either way, they were incompetent in their duties last night.  2 - The  Fillmore is famous for their poster giveaway at the end of the event.  Probably not a big deal to many, but they ran out long before the crowd exited.  This was our first time there and was a semi-major disappointment.  Needless to say, I won't be returning to The Fillmore anytime soon.

xUKN7-XHqlplkkFSJqVNtw.review_text: One of my all time favorite places to see a great show! So many great bands and musicians come through his place! Great sound; moderate size venue; stage at perfect level, decent quick eats upstairs; box office hours to buy tickets without a service charge!!! There's really nothing more I can add that hasn't already been said by all the outstanding reviews of this amazing, and historical music venue! And the free Poster's rock!!!

wcdl2ss00oKw1NavZAze-A.review_text: The house that Billy laid the foundation and Jerry built. Period.

ZVv5L0pSR92arGVhUqD-Yg.review_text: Saw Dream Theater some time back and loved the venue! I will definitely be coming back.

uSxeEUPMW1nUJr-5jHYt6Q.review_text: One of the best venues in San Francisco, hands down.  It's a rare experience, seeing your favorite bands up close and personal, and The Fillmore is one of the smaller venues in SF where you can actually do so.  Some of my most memorable concert experiences have taken place here, and I still have all of the posters I've gotten after the shows.  Ticketmaster charges do suck though, so try to get to the box office asap when tickets go on sale.

3dWlXVNlOn-wML0MkHJcLg.review_text: I've been to The Fillmore countless times for various concerts and I personally love the feel and vibe of the venue. A lot of my friends don't prefer this venue due to it's general admission standing room only ballroom, but hey, it's a concert, that's part of the experience, learn to deal with it! The venue feels and smells old, but it's got a lot of history to it, and you gotta learn to appreciate old buildings like that. If you plan to drink, I recommend sneaking in a flask of your favorite liquor haha! Drinks are over-priced and made really weak, as you can probably expect from most live-music venues' bars.

ryTKBT8w4PGf2bofEfCitw.review_text: Awesome place to get up close and personal with your favorite bands! Unfortunately at my last Chevelle concert there yesterday they did not give out the posters like they used to, also no apples at the end of the show! So much for traditions live nation:( sadly disappointed after telling my wife who had never experienced the Fillmore in its prime those traditions, she missed out. Bring back the one of a kind posters and the silly apple!!!!!!

X2uF3C3YBD24xcgKA104Sw.review_text: OK for a concert experience, this really is a great one to have. The venue is as equally memorable as the show itself. So, allow me to introduce:   ** the man in the hat greeting concertgoers as you walk up the stairs ** the bowl of apples which is available to all (a venue that cares about your health? That gets me right *here* and also *here*, keeping me regular, as they say) ** the many many concert posters, never before have I been able to appreciate some of the fine graphics poured into such receptacles, nor encountered such psychedelia in place. Dude, they have so many words written in bubble text, it will make your head spin. No wonder hippies always sat down.  ** so much pot being smoked in here. Actually, if I think about it, maybe that was what was making my head spin. Nope, nope, definitely the bubble text, but the aromas did bring back a lot of memories of back in the good old days, when I was but a lass... sigh.  I was watching the Yonder Mountain String band - who played for over 4 hours. I was not expecting that. When they walked off the stage after the first set, I was extremely confused as to why everyone was just standing. Not clapping, not moving, just standing. Were they that under-impressed? Oh no, there is a second set coming up. Wait... what?! So good and boy those boys (oh boy oh boy oh boy) can play a mighty string.  One of the downsides to the Fillmore (and I understand that every concert is overcrowded, queueing everywhere blah blah blah) but honestly, during the break, most of the venue filed outside for a quick smoke. One poor bouncer had to stamp every persons' hand in order to re-enter. A couple of musings on this:   1) I had a stamp already when I first entered. Can't we do a twoferone combo?  2) maybe the man in the hat at the top of the stairs could have doubled up or during these hard times is there only one stamp available? We can setup a fund, a half marathon or something if this makes it easier.   Also, yeah, fire? Don't really want to be there if that breaks down, unless some other exits spring forth to save the day. On the plus side, by the time I got back in, there was no queue at the womens - which in some way is a minor miracle comparable to the image of Jesus on a slice of toast.  One final note before I attack my first coffee of the morning after - I know we were in the heart of an institution with roots firmly embedded in the 60's, but the whole rainbow lighting of the band was super-awful. If that (and I assume it was) was the band's choice, then they need to go on some reality show like 'What Not to Light' to show them the way. As my friend described it, it was like My Little Pony on crack with a little Rainbow Brite and Wicked (purple and green) thrown in for good measure.   Anyway, I did have a wicked time at ye old Fillmore, and definitely added that to my 'experiences had only in San Francisco' list and if you haven't already, you should really rethink that decision.

QPhKwoNEGYzIeidIOh-5gQ.review_text: This is one of my favorite places to see a show. I start in the upstairs bar with a couple drinks and then head down in the main area. The place isn't too big but it's big enough to have a great crowd.  You can also take the 22 or the 38, which both let you off at the door to the venue.

gSDkhYBIAJIE5sKB_AVZyw.review_text: Anyone who knows music, knows that the fillmore is one of the most well known venues with a lot of history. During a trip to SF, I was fortunate enough to catch the Black Crowes during one of their end of the year 6 night runs at the fillmore.   As for the venue, if you were walking by it on the street, you might not even notice it, as I did not see any signs, I just followed the crowd once I got out of my cab. Once inside, their was a basket of apples, which seems like some kind of regular thing they do over there. There is also a great room with a bar, tables to sit down and great posters of some of the most famous concerts that the venue has hosted.   The room itself was nice. Chandeliers stand out and it was a good open space, I did not feel cramped in the sold out show. Sound quality was great as was the overall vibe, could be the fans of the band I was seeing or just the SF music community.   I look forward to hearing more music here.

anWCqmHrzNMIoMY6N6PcCw.review_text: Here's how their bar goes . . .   Me - "Can I have a double Wild Turkey?" Dickhead - "Do you see Wild Turkey over here?"   Me - "I'll have a double jack then" *dickhead pours a single* Dickhead - "$11.50" *I don't tip dickhead* Dickhead - "You can get me next time" Sure thing dickhead  . .  .  Crowds are lame.  They pretty much stand around like mannequins. Sound is muddy. Fillmore sucks. Apparently it was good at one time but it's now garbage, I'd rather listen to music at home then spend time on the bus to arrive at this craphole.  Seriously though, worst bar I've ever purchased alcohol at . . . wow.

XjskDljKnO2H5RVPs-aKxg.review_text: I won't be returning to The Fillmore regardless of who performs there!  Bad experience, overpriced drinks, sub-par food.  I purchased what were supposed to be wheelchair accessible seats and a VIP meet and greet package.  I called ahead to get additional information (which they did not have) and let them know that I was coming in a wheelchair.  We got last minute instructions (7:45 pm the night before the event) to show up no later than 5 for the meet and greet.  Well, about 80 of us showed up before 5, and we waited in the cold for over an hour before they even started to let us in.  They took me around the back for an elevator from the street level up to the main floor.  Come to find out, the meet & greet is upstairs on the balcony and there is no way for me to get up there in a wheelchair.  They forgot to put 2 and 2 together when I called ahead of time.  The artist was gracious enough to come down and take a photo with me before the show.  From there, we were seated to the far right of the stage along a wall.  I had to sit parallel to the wall in order to keep the "fire lane" clear, so I couldn't actually sit facing the stage.  Then with standing room only, they don't keep people on the dance floor so I ended up with people standing in front of me the whole night and couldn't see anything.  So I paid for a VIP experience and didn't even get to enjoy the show.  Neighborhood is sketchy, very poorly organized venue.  Drinks were WAY overpriced ($4 for sprite or water, $13 for Courvoisier on the rocks) and the food selection was VERY limited and not good at all.

TMLVzNYs-zwwREudyvI08A.review_text: It is mind-numbing to think about the talent that has been on this stage over the years.  A serious must-see in our fair city.

cNH1JUZmWZfkjJdUtnhSFA.review_text: first time at the fillmore and we were here to see young the giant... this place is a lot smaller then I expected and smelled a lot more MJ then expected too. Walking here was like taking a trip down a tunnel of the history of music. it was a nice personal setting as far as ambiance goes and you can really sense the history here. the only thing is they really take it to you on the drinks but then again its a theater not a bar. Will for sure comeback for the right venue. everyone should go here at least once... just to be a hipster and say you have been here.... Also parking SUCKS so come early of wear walking shoes.

RUygcP9uhl8FfQMO0J9nMg.review_text: The greatest moments of my life were here. Its the anti-Shoreline, where EVERYONE has to stand unless they WANT to chill. And when a band makes it here, its this experience you can't have anywhere else. Its just my idea of where I want to go to enjoy my artists. Even the food, pub as it may be, is just the best. And the staff? Fun people.

T_4pBqf2C6JxLoBJAn2h0A.review_text: I want to take home the Willie Nelson art....    We came, we saw we danced.  It was so great.

gosNE62t1GQnbdITjC2bBg.review_text: A stunning venue. I saw Dita Von Teese's final tour here and the space complimented the performances perfectly. The location of the bars made it convenient to get a drink, and their bathrooms are a blast from the past (complete with multiple vanities, toiletry baskets, and someone there to constantly maintain it) and the stage is gorgeous. Easily one of my top 3 favorite large venues in San Francisco.

5j0QmE-ktdY2wfEYX2YStA.review_text: I saw the Charlatans Uk here a few months back ... absolutely SWEET venue! reminded me a little of Brixton academy in London. the sound was great , i was stood right at the front being totally blown away by the incredible Tim Burgess ... god there is something insanely sexy about the way he sings ... hmm anyway i digress ... what i meant to say was i still got waitress service ! Yes you heard right ! The waitress came round through the many people jumping up and down and dancing to serve us beers so we didnt have to lose our place or miss the music .. now that i have not seen anywhere else.. is that common!???!!! Iwould recommend this venue - it was great for me as they are one of my favorite bands,  i dont think the Charlatans are that well known in the US and so it wasnt absolutely packed .. in the UK i would have had a hard time getting a ticket to one of their gigs. I will definitely go again .. awesome !

WbPrQlOtQsUC1kdeJBAfAQ.review_text: Used to live near there and my favorite venue in the city. Have seen so many good shows!!

7W-K0_0hLnkYx-2gUbKdig.review_text: Okay, what the fuck??? I didn't get a poster like everyone mentioned below!! I wanted a poster, dammit!!!   I even left like one song before the band was completely done...because I thought I would get a poster.. Mother*beep beep*...*beep* okay...... well.. Jzvj-iaCO91OM03Kcy-iHA.review_text: I love the Fillmore. It is probably the smallest venue that can attract some of the best bands and artists in the world. And because it is smaller you get to enjoy the show, the company and a drink at a usually decent price. You'll be closer to the band here than pretty much any other venue of it's class.

3tJcTVPckkv7ZOrn1EcqPg.review_text: Obviously the classic San Francisco venue.  Unfortunately now corrupted by clear channel/ticketmaster: expensive drinks, high ticket prices, and a "too clean to be a real rock venue" feel.  Still, nonetheless, you can't deny the love of Bill Graham's original dream.  It's a great place to see a show, and bands give some of their best performances on its stage.

_5RIYNwxyB499Ao07KQFxg.review_text: I now know what it is like to watch a concert from within a bong. I saw Meshuggah here during my third visit to San Francisco in May and I just love the laid back atmosphere. There are security guards who, before you enter, give you a minor pat down and ask if you have "anything dangerous" on you but I'm guessing you could bring in a hookah the size of a camel judging by the aroma on the inside. I also didn't notice any guards on the inside, which is alright, becuase they weren't needed. It was laid back and everyone enjoyed the music. I hope nothing changes. The atmosphere for a concert was great and the sound was awesome. This is the best indoor venue for a concert I have been to. I didn't notice any apples. I guess they don't waste those on the heavy metal type.

FyxD0c7BYO-rzFWavTm-og.review_text: From the outside the building doesn't look like much....but once you get inside...ALLELUIA. It's so beautiful inside. There is limited seating in the balcony but the floor area is very big. I've had a lot of good experiences here. I've seen awesome bands here and met awesome people here. I can't go on with this review because there are too many good things to say but the words are not coming to my head. If you're in the area...just visit!

Xqvz7wAAapUI8YAIydfaSQ.review_text: I've been to the Fillmore several times, but I was very disappointed with the service and treatment the last time I came here.  I came to the Fillmore with a group of friends for the 4/14 Yonder Mountain show (great show, btw). I was on the ground floor and my friends and I decided to head to the back bar to get a drink. We're standing near the bar waiting to order drinks when one of the waitresses literally PALMS my friend in the face and shoves her out of the way.  It all happened so fast, we were just in shock. She just..... took her hand and shoved my friend's head out of her path, pushing her into the bar, and kept on walking.   Didn't know the Fillmore was into abusing its patrons, but now you know.. beware of the waitresses.

KvLR4nV5RwCCfmKstixKUg.review_text: This venue has to be the coolest venue ever built on earth.  Yes, although Winterland closed, a live show at the Fillmore is about the most fulfilling and life changing experience ever.  And to top it all off, they got some of the most amazing pictures of muscians that I would steal in a second especially the Jerry Garcia and Grateful Dead portraits.  I wish I still lived in San Francisco just so I could go to the Fillmore every week.  Some of the best shows I've ever seen were here.  Bill Graham really had a dream.

tXniX6htgGRgpfMnRZO4zw.review_text: I love a place with history and it's oh-so-lovely that The Fillmore has been preserved over the years. This mid-sized venue attracts big acts so you better be on it when tickets go on sale!  What I love about The Fillmore is that it's general admission. There's just something about standing towards the front of the stage squished between sweaty fans and singing at the top of my lungs that makes me feel so alive. There are some seats available on the edge floor along the wall or upstairs in the balcony, but the balcony seats first-come-first-serve and hard to score... Not that it matters because who the hell pays to sit down and watch their favorite bands when they could stand and rock out?!  Gotta love that they give away free posters after sold out shows. Best San Francisco souvenirs ever!

oP9GMq0sVDsJOkSMEBc6xg.review_text: Watched Steel Pulse play here a few years ago, cool place. I had a balcony seat, so I was stoked! I will give it five stars when ever I head back to experience another show.

-gokwePdbXjfS0iF7NsUGA.review_text: Fenway Park, IB Hoagies, Zach's Pizza....   the Fillmore  ok.. maybe it's a bit odd to put Fenway in with 2 eateries and a music venue from SF, but they all have something in common... and that's their unequivocal spot at the top of whatever list extolling excellence.  Doing a review of a place like this almost seems like a waste of time.  Anything that I say about my one experience here a couple years ago, good or bad, is going to have little meaning or difference when weighed in with the (at the time 527 previous) existing reviews.    I would actually say that doing a review of the Fillmore is actually a BAD idea if I gave the Yelp statistics any credibility from the standpoint that I look at my review stats and this is going to make it look like I give away stars to easily or I'm not really critically reviewing places.  Ether way...  yes, this place is pretty cool... left an impression on me and while I doubt I'll be back here any time soon, because the venue sucks isn't one of the reasons why.

UHVEmIZVpqNBooomp9cZNA.review_text: can you say fly off the charts music /digs? hell yes!  great venue...epic! five stars there.....  but, the worst bartenders I've ever have experienced in my life. they fracture if you want to use a card and not cash, in addition, they are so slow and pour drinks like they hate every fiber of their life.. There may be 1 nice bartender, but their attitudes are so sour puss, they suck and they are miserable... how about being happy that you have a job in this economy?  I've been a bartender before and had my share of douchebags and drunks that i could not bear to deal with.. but how hard is it to pour a stupid beer'? please....the management at the Fillmore sucks balls huge to allow this staff to continue to be the most awful staff in sf. why not smile and be happy? ...you only go around once.  maybe they dont like live music?

ivUm66jjAoIa1GGJBrJaUg.review_text: Big enough to entertain, small enough to get close to the artist.  I was one of Debbie Harry's front row bitches last night!  Who kept slipping their hand into the back pocket of my jeans and stealing my candy huh?  I needed those for energy!!

y9-bfJEhXvU98vwt5UejuA.review_text: Lots of reviews here, so I'll keep it short.  The venue is great and it's small enough that from the back of the room you can get a decent view and only be steps away from the bar.  After 930pm parking in this section of town is pretty open on a weeknight.  It's a decent size place, but for some reason the service people there made me feel like it was a cozy neighborhood theater.

ti4lRf8rv9KICw6msOJT0w.review_text: For sure one of SF's best venues.  I've seen about a dozen shows here and am still impressed by the ability to see the acts and the quality audio system.

pqkwx219sN-otJoqzCMo1g.review_text: Unlike many other classic concert venues in this country that have been bought out by the man and now limp along in a lame, pathetic existence, the Fillmore is still going strong. I realize things may have changed a bit, and maybe its a bit cleaner and nicer than it was in its hay day and that detracts from the character and mystique a bit, but give me a break. This is one of my favorite places to see live music in the City.   Seeing an artist at a venue this size or smaller will always trump a huge stadium or one of those silly outdoor, sit on the grass venues. ALWAYS. Parking at the movie theatre across the street is relatively painless considering that we're talking about parking in San Francisco.   The staff is always great, and its fun to look at all the framed photos and posters of people who have played the Fillmore in the past. In addition to all that stuff, playing at the Fillmore should be a huge deal for any artist i have any interest in seeing, so they usually make sure to really put on a legendary show for a legendary venue. Being able to see that happen with a fair amount of consistency is pretty sweet.  Next up for me at the Fillmore is Taj Mahal performing with a large brass band. I can't wait.   I love you Fillmore.

DB717wes6bHyiPq0oDl_3g.review_text: If you're visiting San Francisco and you're into live music, you can't leave without seeing a show at the Fillmore.  It's up there with visiting Alcatraz and going to AsiaSF (if you're local... shhhh :)  The Fillmore and the history of Bill Graham are legendary around here.  Just go in there, say hi to the greeter, grab a free apple, and check out the concert posters of bands that have played there since the mid-60s.  Epic...  And most nights you'll get a poster of the show you just went to on your way out!  Who does that?  Other pros:  The venue is General Admission and if you can get through the crowd (not super hard wth 1250 total), you can be right at the stage.    Tickets are generally $20-40.  That's not too bad considering they get some pretty good bands.  I've seen the Black Crowes here multiple times, Medeski Martin & Wood, P-Funk, Buddy Guy, the Black Keys, etc.  There is food available on the second floor, although you can't watch the band from there.  For a sit down dinner, there's a great Ethiopian place right across the street called Rasselas.... and many nights they have live jazz!  Cons: As of 2006, Live Nation (a part of Clear Channel Entertainment Group) owns the Fillmore and other Bill Graham venues.  They've completely ruined the venue websites with a generic, heartless page... and the few employees I've talked to said that old management has had to fight to keep some perks available to customers (ie. no service charge at the box office).

0lDl1Jg1Qz2KhvkfJKk6fw.review_text: Very courteous employees, great sound, pretty decent food options and marvelous beer options. The cocktail servers were awesome. We needed handicapped accessible seating and were accommodated like royalty. Loved the entire experience. It's all I can do to not go back tonight to see Holly Williams and Jason Isbell again tonight.

1ljC2JgUafYC9wtEUXJ3bQ.review_text: 1) The 38 takes you RIGHT outside - Woo hoo!   2) Staff is so nice!  Welcomes you as you walk into the door. Talked to staff afterwards too.  Manners go a long way!  3) Nice, high ceilings, so it doesn't get stuffy at all :)  Pretty chandeliers + love the feeling of this place.  Not too dark, not too bright.  4) Bar was raised and easy to get to, so you can easily see the stage if you're there instead of the floor.  5) The concert was sold out, but there was enough room to walk around without pushing around.  Easily the nicest crowd @ any concert I've ever been to, but then again, The Weeknd is not The Offspring!  6) Of all the venues in SF, I am definitely keeping my eye out for concerts at The Fillmore next time!!

Ia5hoo1NpvvliwZeXug8dg.review_text: I've always entered the Fillmore sober and have never remembered leaving.  My #1 favorite place to see my favorite bands, hands down.

37HswRimgBEf7_US-c3CDA.review_text: BILLY IDOL popped his cherry with me at the Fillmore last night  ........and it was gooooood  Dripping with sweat; my legs hurt, my arms hurt, my boobs hurt, I've lost my voice & I left completely satisfied  Billy made me do things I thought I had long since put behind me & I liked it. I found myself involuntarily fist pumping, doing the Pogo, screaming for more!  More!  MORE!    I aaaaaccccccche to see him again.....and I will......oh yes, I will..... tonight Billy will again be MINE  And THIS is among the many reasons I LOVE THE FILLMORE  Everything from the greeter at the venue entrance, to the free apple bucket, to the atmosphere-filled venue room, complete w/ chandeliers, to the staff who totally knows how to handle obnoxious-about-to-spew drunks w/out disrupting the show...and especially the freaktastic sound system - props all the way!  Can't even begin to tell you the number of phenomenal acts I have had the privilege of seeing at the Fillmore; up close & personal; nowhere can you be so intimate w/ the creme de la creme of the music industry  Just take a look at their wall of pride - hundreds upon hundreds of posters to commemorate the fantabulous, amazing, wonderful artists who have graced SF & filled our hearts with music  And the latest to do this, goes by the name BILLY FU*KING IDOL.  He played the Fillmore for the 1st time, after 30 yrs in music......& I was there.  And I'll keep coming back like a giddy school girl

1JG49cOLy4aASYB9Yc240A.review_text: I saw Ratatat here for the first time. The atmosphere is chill, the bands that come around here seem great, and the little unexpected things made the place great.   Not overpacked (except when the show ends), perfect ventilation, good staff, free posters when the show is over. Apparently free apples too.   It's in Japantown, so there's plenty to do right before the show. There's seriously not much more to ask for.

MfxdEmaH-0_ITpuXU4Hgzg.review_text: The last time I was here which was quite a while ago was for a Los Lobos show. Not just any show but the first show of the Kiko album tour. What a treat to hear them play this album in order start to finish.   As if that was not enough, opening for them was Alejandro Escovedo, another of my favorite performers with a long storied history spanning the years and different genres of music.  The sound here was really good, and the joint just reeks of coolness... among other things.
