My only tip would be when the show is over, do a slow count before you head to the bottle neck exit as it can get a bit treacherous. Only downside to waiting is you may not get a cool poster if they still hand them out after the show.

qzu4UQbwcqdTQte0PccVvA.review_text: Recently went to the Mutemath concert here.  First time ever here.  Definitely not the last!  I'll be upfront, I love small venues.  Not too crowded, chill crowd where it's all about the music.  I love the acoustics and my gfs were able to take some kick ass pictures of the bands without having to say 'excuse me' 28947947233 times and having people stare at you in a glaring fashion as if we don't live in the freest country in the world!    Really chill place.  Even had the opportunity to dance around.  Bartender made some really heavy vodka tonic drinks which I really appreciated.  She even helped us take pictures and the bar wasn't terribly crowded where we had to wait 5 minutes just to order.  The only disappointment I had was that no one came dressed up as vampires.  You know..Twilight soundtrack?  Hello!?!?  It's close enough to halloween where you can have a pre-run with your costumes, no?

mo6rKMelgZZbbDhOxGMDSw.review_text: The only thing I can say negatively about the Fillmore is it's GA so expect all that comes with that.  Other than that, it is magical.

Uc2ZtQdTThtNSw_lNzfrpw.review_text: It was never my plan to visit the Fillmore, but through friends and work I have been fortunate to see OAR to Band of Skulls at this venue. Mixed between a decorated history of artist is simply one of the best locations to for Live music in the city.  Why 3-stars then? As much as I love the venue for its calm, San-Francisco style atmosphere, quick and efficient bartenders, and of course music, there were not any high points that made me feel a need to trek out from the Mission on a regular basis.    Overall, if you want great live music or if you're a rock and roll fan, I recommend giving this historic venue a visit.

T5_fCbNOLoiXAJsIgyJJPg.review_text: Ive seen my absolute favorite blues singer here.  This place is really cool with all the art deco posters of all the famous bands that have played here covering the walls.  Its the perfect place to have concert.  I can't wait to go back and see my other favs there.

0HaHgC8F9pzTNOeKWD-qeA.review_text: The Filmore is the classier version of soma in sd. There is a bar for those who are 21, but it is all ages. Some of my favorite bands have all come here, which I got to see including Cursive, The Cramps and (almost) the Smashing Pumpkins. I dont remember them being that strict on booze consumption before, but apparently now they are. (Note to self, next time, dont get wasted, go to the filmore and attempt to drink a rum and coke when you aren't 21)

zdagYszm6GQceMnAz6_leg.review_text: If it weren't for the amazing performance by Beach House, I wouldn't have even given the place a star. Bought two tickets, $100 each. It's an OK sized venue, great sound. Redbull and vodka, $11 for a tiny cup.  It gets worse. Leaving the place was horrible, everyone was trying to get their things from coat check. ($1.50 an item.) It was crazier than a mosh pit.

h0fNBxo0qFtrxX59PIzv1g.review_text: The best Venue to see your favorite band or singer hands down. You can get close or end if your standing in the back you can hear and see! What a concept. Its small and intimate but not to small that they can get a good size of folks inside. I've seen "LIVE", Peaches, Detroit Cobras, Black Keys just to name a few and whenever I see someone I really love playing there (gotta have those tickets!) Plus they give you those cool posters when you leave, Like the ones all over the walls upstairs. The big ass shows at Oakland Arena or Cow Palace (is it still open?) or even shoreline...bleh! You're just too faraway, and parking! Whenever we park around the Fillmore its fairly easy to get out and on your way, which is a big plus.

Fz3y-d7Ru7wMRnPuwG-OLA.review_text: This is about as big as i would like a venue to be. Its just big enough to hold assloads of people, and yet still be considered warm. There is a room upstairs with a second bar that has this window that you look out of and see this skinny dude with a gut in the next apartment over vamping. He knows we see him, he walks around with his shirt off showing off his twelve pack. Think of all the great shows this guy misses just to parade around half nekkid for all the metal chicks named Tammy and Lisa Rae.

19I4YAfuhNtGQIjd2HDo5g.review_text: This music venue is one of the best in the city.  Great acoustics and an open floor plan so it is not heard to get up close to the stage.  So many great arists have performed here in the past, and you can see proof of this with all the classic Fillmore Posters framed on the walls.  For any music fan this is a must see venue.  Another nice perk is the location.  Right on Geary and Fillmore makes it easily accessible by the 37 Muni.  Also, if you are still craving some more music you can go across the street to the Boom Boom Room which stays open late on weekends.

Z0weV6b4pd3mL1cyYX6-_g.review_text: Went here to see The Smashing Pumpkins and it was great!  When you want to see bands or performers, you want to SEE them! And you can do that here. Its a smaller venue and you can see and hear the performers but it was so packed that you couldn't easily walk around.   I am really excited to see the Bravery here!

VoJnZC_l9pcPVjEATiH9Dg.review_text: I love this SF institution.  So many great memories of awesome shows.  The upstairs is fun to check out and look at all the old show posters.

3uJmTNv5xKkntHEQtrzHdg.review_text: I mean come on, it's the Fillmore. If you are a music fan and live in this great city and have never been then shame on you! Soooooo much history and continuing to make history each and every year. My absolute favorite place to see live music- not to mention that they have such great, talented artists coming through here!

khvn7hhX08g33N5niO676w.review_text: The Breeders!  Fantastic sound system.  Do not bring your own weed.  People were puffing away everywhere.  Easy access to BART.  Take the 38 on Geary.

vcOtDqQ2Cc731kFjklFeBg.review_text: Somewhere on the internet is a video of me dancing on stage during the Nada Surf show with one of my boobs hanging out.

oeSP4tyY8VKMW-ndSMVv1g.review_text: Came here for the Utada Hikaru concert yesterday.  Plenty of space on the floor, general admission, but since everyone wants to crowd up next to the stage it gets pretty stuffed.  The thing that bothered me the most about the fillmore was the Utada concert was not allowing cameras.  There was no fore warning about a no camera policy on the website, on the ticket, or when the confirmation email was sent.  I have been to the fillmore before and they allowed cameras when Jason Mraz came and played a couple of years ago.  So it made everyone have to stand in line for the coat check to check in their cameras and then make a mad dash for it after the concert was over to get our cameras back.  Definately not a very efficient system and an easy way to get your camera swiped.  Should have been properly communicated to us instead of telling us after we were standing in line.  Other than that, the venue was pretty good but the sound quality was really bad, not sure if thats really the fillmore's fault or the band.  Right outside is the 38 bus line so very easy to get to and from.

6xl9EVLg1MTwq4gw21e4Nw.review_text: The Fillmore = the mecca for good music in the city. The one venue every aspiring musician aims for. Jimi Hendrix. Janis Joplin. Bob Dylan. The Pixies....all played here. You gig here, you know you're a legit musician. Sorry Justin Bieber, no matter how much you try, YOU WILL NEVER PLAY HERE.  Lovie and I came here after the mayhem that is game 7 of the NBA Finals at Gordon Biersch and Palomino to watch a jazz musician I instantly fell in love with within the past two weeks of the show: Melody Gardot. Ironicially, I stumbled upon a TV commercial for the release of her new CD. When I first heard her smooth voice, her genius piano, and hearing that she's actually partially blind and learning that she's actually my age (24), I was hooked. I had to see her.  I was nervous that we had to stand the whole time since I knew it was open floor general admission. But I was relieved to see the tables and chairs. We walked in a little late for the opener, but were able to catch the last seats in the center of the floor - perfect view. The show itself was spectacular despite running late (she came on stage at 10:30, which is pretty late for a work night). But it was well worth it. Her show is sheer genius. Crazy syncopations that rocked my brain. She straight up plucked the strings inside the piano. The saxophonist playing TWO saxes at a time. It was a show that tingled my tympanic to its core, and I loved every minute of it.  The only downfall is the bar. Cash only or $20.00 minimum charge on a debit/credit card, which is absurd. Then again, a drink is pretty much 10 bucks, so you're good with two.   Overall, a beautiful venue which should be on the bucket list of any music enthusiast. I'm scoping out upcoming artists to make sure I come back here again.

dBz_y-VGLlEr4IRrZq-zYg.review_text: The Fillmore is THE spot you want to see your favorite bands. Who doesn't love intimate shows? It's standing room only...but who cares! You're there to enjoy your favorite band in a small venue is priceless.

YnVg0phnwOMA_qVU1ThLpA.review_text: One of the places that if you can't get in front during a show you want to get a table. And to do either you must get there early. I hate standing in the middle of a packed show because I'm short. I've always been in the front at shows at the Fillmore. I've seen my two favorite people here. Beck (twice) and Tom Petty and the Heartbreakers. Oh Fillmore. So many good memories with you.

bQiST5YdWLSH_yk56ccApA.review_text: Awesome place.  To bad the bar is so far away.  The sound is great.  The bands are awesome. Love this place.  Oh look a KFC and down the street sushi.  On second thought better stay away from the fish.  It might want to come up  and play later.  Not a pretty sight.

4MzTss4Hn2sVvwb317xxpw.review_text: As an SF native, I was really feeling like a loser for never having been here. I like the posters, I like the apples, I like the staff. I am sort of too overwhelmed by crowds to see a lot of live music, but this place is cool. Definitely recommended.

a8XQk3YbBKBgctzszG_3Ng.review_text: Oh... the Fillmore... the memories, the musics, the free posters... This venue has to be my favorite in San Francisco.  I saw Death Cab and Jimmy Eat World here with the girl, and it was awesome both times.  The venue is smaller and has a the intimate feel of a club w/out the crampedness.  There are chandeliers everywhere, and balconies on the side for the lazies.  A consession stand in the back of the room serves up drinks w/out having to fight your way outside.  Acoustics were great, makes for amazin' shows....  And yep, to top it all off you get a free poster on the way out.  I still have mine framed from the Death Cab show.  And hey, free apples!

zBqCifNpCHpGZpnw0YbkGw.review_text: I have so much love for this venue. A lot of the artists that are unknown to the "popular" media come and perform here.  I was lucky enough to catch Darren Criss and Kate Nash here. Hopefully I attend many more.  Irma easy to get here from BART, car, or bus. I don't recommend walking from BART to the concert venue. One would have to walk in a shady place and go uphill for at least two miles.  This place is perfect to stand amongst a crowd and jump up and down to the music of the artist you love. Incredibly venue, and hey, they give out free apples too!

Zvq7uP3xOwWdRbhRr1nXwg.review_text: fabulous. i have been there off and on this year.  of course you expect the "hippie" vibe BUT it isn't always there. the venue is gorgeous, staff friendly, chandeliers stunning. the sound is good and you can always get a drink.  I think this is one of the only venues that i have gone to without totally knowing the act just to go out because it is a really fun place. It also doesn't feel like "date" night.  Single people are comfortable there and you meet interesting people. Go enjoy!

0nwGxhxTX_1l0zchn5PBJw.review_text: I've seen so many great shows at the Fillmore.  I remember seeing Ministry there ages ago and some crowd surfing jack ass decided to use my face as a grab bar when he finally fell to the floor, fracturing my eye socket in the process.  I thought  just had a shiner until I got up the next morning, blew my nose, and my eye-lid inflated like a balloon.  Ah, good times.  DeVotchKa, Brandi Carlile, Tom Petty, Demetri Martin, Bob Mould (at least 3 times), and tons more . . . I can't even remember all the great performers I've seen in this place.  And for all its storied history, the staff is cool, chill, and welcoming, everybody is usually polite (I won't go on about the jackasses standing behind me at the Tom Petty show - after all, the Fillmore just sells the tickets, there's no litmus test for manners).  There are always free apples and free ear plugs.  They are not interchangeable.  Last night it was Billy Bragg - on the guest list baby!  I've been a fan since 1985, but I only first met him at SXSW earlier this year.  It was nice to chat with him again.  And aside from his great songs, his political speeches are always inspiring.  It was a great night.   In fact, I don't ever think I've had a bad night at the Fillmore.  Bill Graham's ghost must still be floating around in there keeping it all groovy.

mF1riS0zgG3rxltPD8AVHA.review_text: The best medium sized club venue in the Bay Area.  The Uptown in Napa is great as is the Warfield, The Fox, etc... BUT the Fillmore has a great sound and history. They care about the bands and making them sound good , look good. The vibe, yes I said vibe is usual relaxed and everyone there as a music/band fan. They want to be there for the show and not as a club scene which happens to have a band in it.  When a secondary opening band is upstaris, it makes it a better night.  Also, Dan Dion rocks on as the house PhoTog, check out his work on the walls of the lobby. Envy

pffu1e8OZfEgIWzA3d5mxg.review_text: What other venue hands out free poster keepsakes at the end of a show?! Love it. They get some awesome bands coming through every so often, which is good/bad. It's definitely one of the better places to catch a show in the Bay because it's fairly intimate with pretty darn good acoustics. However, shows can sell out suuuuper fast because there aren't as many tickets available as there would be at larger venues (Death Cab sold out within, like, 20 min! Luckily, we scored tickets but it was sooo stressful with our sometimes spotty internet connection.)   There's limited balcony seating available based on a first come, first serve basis... but come on, if you're there for a good show, being down in the pit is the only way you're going to get the full experience!  BEWARE: For sold out shows, they require that your entire group is in line together as you approach the will call area or else they'll boot you to the back until everyone is accounted for, even if everyone shows up right as they're checking you. You'll get a condescending, "Sorry, sweetie." Really annoying that they don't announce this when you're just getting in line.  Parking around the area is pretty challenging so arrive early and have dinner in Japantown, or take the Muni bus if you can (#38 stops right in front).

2iSBJHVMNsolJ3AH1g_D7A.review_text: I saw Jason Mraz here. I loved it. Absolutely loved it.  I especially love the poster that you get at the end of the night. I'm always down for some free art for my poor naked walls.

7mzACXQ5F4EduE9jF_tI-g.review_text: I am going to write a review about a music venue.. without focusing on how awesome the show was... though I think one of the things about the Fillmore is that you can never get a bad show. Unless of course you are a death metal fan and you are at a bon iver show.   For me, walking into the Fillmore was better than walking into the rock and roll hall of fame. Thinking about Neil Young, Moody Blues and Miles Davis blowing minds in 1970, its kind of euphoric. I spent a good 15 minutes looking at all the posters wishing I had been there for half of the shows.   The architecture is great for live music, great sound, great space. The wood floors were also a charm for me, the sound it creates when people stomp for an encore cannot be recreated.   And of course, the best things in life are always free... yes, the poster. I cannot wait to go back for another show!

7UrpAti8Ft0X8xWR9TxwqQ.review_text: What else can I say about the fillmore?  This place is classic - I saw everything from the doves to hieroglyphics (not to mention ordering my first pint of Stella - cheers!)  Basically whatever act i see here, the intimate atmosphere of the antique ballroom space, the wall of fame in the hallway, and overall chill crowd, it always feels like this is how it should be when u watch live acts.

9jZAXnAaulEC40wtEZK6Fw.review_text: This place is rock and roll heaven! Every new and coming band played here. They got memoribia for days. The interior is awesome. Fill with rock and roll stars from every genre. The bar upstairs is really cool and the people are great. It's probably one of my favorite places to see a concert.

5bFypTn1I3ZixwYW2zEvAg.review_text: remember that one time I was like 16 or something and i stage dove and fell on my face and i was bleedy but it was awesome?   yeah. you're so pretty.  remember that time when I got a little older and stopped going to shows where my face would end up smashed / smooshed/ bleedy and you had awesome bands like Dethklok?   i still love you after 10 years.   and that's saying "me love you long time 'Mo"

2ewsQtQiRqICUdA3mGKE2w.review_text: How do I love The Fillmore?  Let me count the ways...  1. The connection with the past, the really great photographs on the wall of past concerts, the great vibe I get when I think of all the amazing talent that has passed through this venue for decades.  2. The type of venue it is: big enough for major acts, and small enough to still get up close.  I'm so glad it's not set up theatre-style like the Warfield.  I prefer standing with everybody, with the ability to move around and find a good spot.  And the balcony is cool for chillin' out, it has tables and chairs where you can order food.  3. Ok, and while I hate the ticket scalper on the corner (I SWEAR it's always the same dude), I have managed to get into sold out concerts on more than one occasion by really forwardly asking people walking up the venue if they have any extra tickets they're willing to sell to a true music fan, and not some jackass scalper who is only going to re-sell the ticket for 3 times the price.  So if you were ever that person, thank you SO MUCH for your compassion.  4. The posters!  They have some great artists pumping out some great posters for the venue.  I love the separate cafe thingy upstairs with all the really old posters in it.  It makes me wish I could have been around for the good old days.  I've seen probably a dozen concerts at the Fillmore in the past 5 years, and I will continue to be a patron at the Fillmore for years to come.

397N9-g-uc56q97VnaSBCw.review_text: I "heart" The FIllmore.  I saw my first show there late last year.  It was a Mike Ness show.  The venue itself is fairly sizeable with a big floor and a raised stage.  It's got baconies upstairs and a separate room/bar away from the balconies in case you want to just 'hang out' and grab a drink.  I have yet to have any issues with fellow concert goer's here at The Fillmore and the staff seems pretty polite.  I think its kind of cool that the waitresses go around the floor ordering drinks.  It's rather impressive to see these girls hold the trays ever so steady so high above their heads to avoid people bumping into them.    I was there again last night for an RX Bandit/Dredge show.  Of course it was a great show. The sound was phenomenal, the lights were done up as usual and the crowd was nice and mellow.  While Dredge was up, I opted to hunt down a seat off to the side since my poor footsies were hurting.  I was luckily enough to spot 2 empty seats on the first floor by the big bar on the right side of the stage.    My friend wasn't feeling too good (too much to drink) and one of the employees noticed. He immediately asked if I needed help and if we needed ear plugs.  Luckily we already had some but the fact that he asked was a pleasant surprise.    The only gripe about this place is fairly irrelevant because it's expected for almost any venue:  a)trying to find parking can be a challenge b) indoor reefer...

1QxRHWrDAjaOCr9KLsFtkw.review_text: I was just here on Monday night to see The Faint and I must say I have been deprived of such quality in a venue for quite some time.  Not only was there space to move around while the band was playing but the bouncers were quick to act people got hyphy near us.   Drinks were priced pretty okay...you can only expect so much when you're in the city (let's be honest).   I'd probably have to say my favorite thing about this place: the complimentary apples! Yes, apples! Big, red apples! Yummy, juicy, sweet.  I thought it was unique and actually hit the spot quite well after the show.

4SdPhcblG7wuDLQlvOWrdw.review_text: I saw Billy Idol here on Friday and he ROCKED! I really like this venue, it almost feels like he's performing in your living room.  Only downside, you can see how he got his face pulled back...you're THAT close!  He's still got it though.  Very cool.

WSaXBx-Zei0Nq-9_8U6juQ.review_text: What a cool and historic venue! I went to a show here recently and security and staff are friendly and I felt safe inside. This venue definitely has a great feel to it. I believe it was built in the 1930's and used to be a roller skating rink (on the 2nd floor) ...how cool!  No matter what kind of music show you are going to, this place is great. Bar inside, drinks are a bit overpriced but I suppose that's just how it goes when you are at a music show. The acoustics are good, there are some balcony seats, big dance floor, and good size stage. I look forward to coming back here again!

pISAo3ZGTaSoTS9bDiYx3g.review_text: Classy - a popular act sells out in less than a minute, yet tickets are available on StubHub and other 3rd party sellers within 5 minutes.    Hey, remember when you guys weren't corporate owned, when getting tickets was easier, when dollars didn't trump sense?  No, even I can't either.  It's called "Dynamic Pricing" - and, hey, guess what?  Both the acts you book and your now corporate structure would see an increase in profit.  Know why (of course you don't, so I'll explain it for you)...see, instead of StubHub and other 3rd party vendors scamming/spamming your computers buying 8 tix at the maximum amount you charge, then reselling those tix for (WAY) more $$ - you sell them at the price the market would bear.  So instead of only making $28 (oh, silly me, $40, what with your $12 "service charge" (my god, you figured out a way to charge for rape?!?  WHY DO YOU ONLY DO THIS FOR A LIVING WHEN THERE'S SO MUCH MORE YOU COULD ACCOMPLISH!)), you could be making, what, at least $80 per ticket.    Extra money the band might see (not that you parasitic leeches even care about bands anymore), but it's more money in your pockets?  And, really, isn't that what LiveMediaMaster truly wants?

oAz4s21FA2QjE0kCNIDxOg.review_text: Such a cool spot. Small enough to really enjoy an artist, but big enough to draw the big names. I've seen The Bravery and Dolores O'Riorden here and I was happy with both shows. The acoustics were fantastic, the cocktail service phenomenal, and the venue was the perfect vessel for amazing concerts. Good deals on booze too!

2pPNxXnyh6EDUuBJVuoQmA.review_text: I went to see Wild Flag play at the Fillmore recently. What a fun show! I wasn't too fond of the opening band, but I had a great time nonetheless.   I showed up fashionably late, but still managed to find a spot pretty close to the stage. Seems like everyone goes to the bathroom or to the bar in between sets, which gives you an opportunity to sneak closer.   Carrie Brownstein, Mary Timony, Janet Weiss, and Rebecca Cole were all fierce, and I had a wonderful time, despite all of the cackling drunk girls right next to me.    Free apples by the door. Free poster at the end of the show was also a nice treat. It's also close to the bus stop, so if you rely on public transportation, you're in luck.

aJCjOAGLAsA4vJ26Mc99tg.review_text: I mean Duh it's the Filmore. You can get closer than you ever would at Shoreline, Concord, AT&T. I only do small venues for music. The only place that beats this venue for  quality of artists and ambiance is The Greek Theater in Berkley.   Dispatch Stroke 9 Maroon 5 OAR Ice Cube Blues Traveler Grey Boy Al stars.  Just a few of the bands I've seen there.  The staff can be a little snooty but, Hey it's the Filmore!!!  Love the poster collection as well. It's in chronological order. I could look at them for hours.

hZx9whdbiAXjA1RMRw-AkQ.review_text: I can't really add anything but my $0.02 to this highly reviewed venue. The Fillmore is a legendary music venue that has seen a mind boggling amount of acts in its time. Some of those good and some were forgettable.   Anyway let me keep this brief:   Plus:  Pretty small venue Full bar General admission  Minus:  Cost (not their fault its economics) Exiting venue sucks after show

9eNyDuEErTONcbg6E1U9tg.review_text: I have to give 5 stars because it's one of the best venues but DO NOT EAT HERE unless you're so stoned and don't care about overpaying for shitty food. If you have time head over early and go to Frankie's or someplace in Japan town.

qy-JcvcGAaQ4BTx2hghD8A.review_text: I came here for the first time to see Social Distortion (they rocked!) and was blown away by the architecture in this venue.  You can really tell that this is a historic landmark and that the interior has not changed much since its inception.    The acoustics were great and the drinks were reasonably priced.  I would recommend getting there early so you can take a tour of the entire venue, if you enjoy looking at historical architecture.  I also love that they create their own posters for each performer that play there.  However, the posters run out quickly so I don't recommend lounging around at the end of the show if you want to get one.

4r0-Q5eu4FyGQwYwEcxC3A.review_text: Went last night to see Tove Lo at the Fillmore. It was my first time at the venue and I loved it! I got to see the poster rooms and got a poster at the end of the night.  It is one of my favorite venues in the Bay area. It is all indoors and there are balconies as well. There are bars located in the upstairs poster room and on the dance floor and also to the side of the dance floor as well. They serve all liquors and beers on tap and wine. Their prices are a little high, but it is a concert venue so that is expected.  The sound quality was great and the lights were amazing as well. I love the chandeliers on the ceiling as well. Can't wait to go to another concert here!

Q2Iest8oggBub6nVBFEcNw.review_text: Ah, the Fillmore, where the good bands all play.  Why?  Because it's famous.  Why?  Because the good bands all played here, of course.  Or something like that.  They don't let you forget their historic lineups, either--the walls are covered with posters of all the amazing shows you *won't* be seeing tonight (kind of a downer, actually).  But pedigree aside, it's just a big, square room with a balcony on one side, not unlike the GAMH only less ornate (and in a similarly inauspicious location--funny how the MoneyMart sign on the building is far more prominent than the Fillmore sign).  I was here for Camera Obscura, and the venue seemed to handle the crowd easily.  Most importantly, they have at least 3 bars, and even table service in the upstairs balcony (being too old to fight my way to a drink, I'm loving that).    In short, if you go to live music at all, you kinda have to go to the Fillmore at some point.  Just wait until your favorite band comes though--otherwise it probably won't work its maximum magic on you.

kxXjx7KRI9pUKjSvAr0rVg.review_text: glorious, beautiful place with so much history. while you have a great view upstairs from the balconies, it's much better sound downstairs--and what good sound it is!   i love that it's uncramped and if you want to get a drink it's not a big deal... if you want to sit upstairs and listen that's fine, and if you want to sway before the music downstairs that's fine too.

Ya_jdCMfALaBZBLSWG1fXQ.review_text: Instantaneous memorable concerts. Fillmore is the PERFECT venue. I can't even write any more; I have nothing more to say other than it is amazing.

eYK5Xm-s6Fj6-9uzH8lyiA.review_text: There is something wrong with you if you don't like the Fillmore. This is easily my absolute favorite venue to see a show. I've never seen a bad show there, and instead, I've become an even bigger fan of some artists than I was going in.   You aren't a true music fan if you haven't seen and enjoyed a show at the Fillmore. That is all.

pEnPxArLOZlKC94iVkVFxQ.review_text: This is the best place to see a show... its history is amazing... the apples (when they have them) are a life saver!!!  For a few reasons, which im sure you can guess them.... I have seen sooo many shows here.  MOst recently The Living Legends... AMAZING show front row great view, amazing men and even better picture after the show with them... Drink before you come unless you like your pepsi with a splash of rum for a whopping 8 BUCKS.  Good views, plenty of places to sit for the LAMOS and multiple bars... if ur into spending that much.

_36CP1UVgIZjMe7v55WTPw.review_text: this is a really good place to see a concert.  not too big, and not too small.  plus they have a bar!  that could be a little better, but i'm not a complaining.

t5sLbBmbWK2gUdBF1ARpmA.review_text: it was my first time here ,as i had decided to make partial residence in the city... well im from texas and none other than willy nelson decided to play that fateful evening... i was beyond flabergasted... i love the fillmore and loved the warm SF welcome.. visit this place and say you have...

VQC12BRAJoGvGkiRyDYv3A.review_text: I love you Fillmore. Arlene down below should be drawn and quartered for her lame review, but to each yelper their own. That is the intrinsic beauty of yelp-freedom of speech. Anyhow, the classic tub of great big red delicious apples welcoming you at the top of the stairs puts a smile on my face every time. The vintage rock posters are awe inspiring, and it's always interesting to see who is scalping about on Fillmore St. Don't think it's possible to see a bum show here. Plus coat check rules. Many a thank you to Bill Graham, RIP...

iUeZhkI0OK0BisakOkb3pQ.review_text: Ok, yeah, I'll slag the Fillmore too. Shows tend to the short side, aggression by the staff is second to maybe Slim's and the space is nothing special.  I'd choose the Great American Music Hall any day of the week.

7DHI26h1sNDwot13kXN3_w.review_text: Legendary SF venue. How can you give The Fillmore anything other than 5 stars. I've seen some dope shows here over the years and paid for overpriced drinks many times. The trick is to car bar it up before comin in so you don't end up getting bled dry at their bar.   If you have a chance to go to a show here don't ask questions, make like a NIke ad and just do it.

XqKik268cSpBXj_-aPwNxA.review_text: This venue is great and has a lot of personality in terms of its decor. Walls are lined with past concert posters from so many bands. It's small so it's great for intimate performances. Cheap tickets for most shows as they are mostly general admission. Awesome place to check out and discover indie bands. And free red delicious apple for everyone at every show!

eUmVXP9UnoWtz9NSBwY4jA.review_text: I've been to some amazing shows at the Fillmore-Morcheeba, Keane, David Byrne, Norah Jones, to name a few.  Last night's show was The Fray w/ Augustana.  Whenever you go to a show at the Fillmore you are guaranteed a few things-free apples, teenage girls singing/shouting at the top of their lungs, a cool poster after most shows and some weird food smell that fills the venue during just about every headliner's set.  Grape jelly?  Burnt toast?  French fries?  Playing the "What's that smell?" guessing game is almost as much fun as listening to the music.  That being said, the Fillmore books some great acts and ticket prices are much better than Shoreline, Oakland Arena, etc.  And most of the acts I've seen there seem to put on better shows at the Fillmore, almost as if they are in awe of the history of the room.  If you haven't been yet, check out their calendar and make a point of going to a show there asap.  You really haven't experienced San Francisco until you've been to the Fillmore.

n6r1Rl_PYqkQpSCpJdz1Zw.review_text: I have been going to shows for a long time and this is one of my favorite venues. The ambiance is rad, especially the chandeliers that hang from the ceiling. They have awesome bands that roll through there on a regular basis, and I find a show I want to attend almost every time I check their online calendar.   They also take good care of you which gives the good sized venue a welcoming, small business type vibe. A friend of mine had a little to much too drink at a NOFX show one night and they let him "rest his eyes" in the back office while the rest of us enjoyed the show. What a nice thing to do especially nowadays when most places seem to care more about money then people.    The only downside to the Fillmore is there is extremely limited seating so ditch the heels, and slip on your favorite flats; because you will probably be standing all night.

2WzdS28bt1xXJMf4U5KNbA.review_text: best venue in the bay!  free apples all night, food/bar lounge area, and the posters at the end of the night now are a wall of memories of good times on my wall  large enough to be spacious, small enough to be intimate  rock on!

Mb-LDBHBVIS1k8nsQJsOvA.review_text: One of the best local spots to catch a concert in the Bay Area.  I have been to the Fillmore a few times now. The sound system is always dialed in with some kick depending on the act. I love how they show the past history of artists that ever walked in and performed at this venue. I have a honor to experience the Smashing Pumpkins, BLACKALICIOUS, and Morcheeba here... I wish i can bring back the 1.5 hrs I wasted on the recent Fray concert..   All in all Awesome venue.  Easy to get drinks at the bar. And most of the time, you leave with a poster of the performer that night at the end of the concert..   TIP.. first come, first dips on seats.. upstairs balcony or the side railings by the bar..

uIyPV7vIfi9IIxJyb18StA.review_text: First time visit to the Fillmore.  For starters I really, really loved the atmosphere there, reminds me a lot of the House of Blues venues.  I also adored the memorabilia on the walls, the dark colors, velvet curtains, the chandeliers, basically everything about the interior.    Very large floor space for viewing, awesome seating area up stairs, multiple bar locations and the acoustics sounded great.  The only negative about the place was the drinks.  As far as I'm concerned, the drinks were nearly double the price of what you would expect to pay for basic cocktails and were in some of the smallest drinking cups I've ever seen at a venue/bar. Still, I love the place and am looking forward to future concerts.

_5gPub9T4APA0Bjyw2VC-w.review_text: Awesome venue to see real good musicians perform.  It is a very small, intimate setting where you could be at the back bar and still have a very clear view of the stage.  Surprisingly reasonable pricing on most shows and opportunity to meet the musician after the show oftentimes is a great plus.  Definitely my favorite venue in the city.

E-ws0CUwkAYlv5JEfRr9mA.review_text: I wish I had the job to usher everyone inside The Fillmore: "Welcome to The Fillmore" I just love those words spoken by the mysterious looking gray haired gentleman that has been living my dream.He smiles when he sees me , because he knows before he says it, I yell "welcome to the fillmo' " I've seen countless shows there and it's like being a part of history. If you go to The Fillmore, do go there a little early and check out the poster room upstairs - it's killer! And as tradition goes, take an apple and a poster when you leave. The Fillmore is famous for their free crisp sweet apples and hey, don't forget the poster of the band you went to see.

MsHH-CIQraaZ6suG6S5E9A.review_text: Came here on a Thursday night, for the Trampled by Turtles concert and I AM IN LOVE.   This place is so vintage and edgy and hipster and historic and fancy all wrapped into one epic concert venue. It's basically one big room with a bar on the side. Bartenders are fast and efficient, I got a beer on tap for 8 bucks.   It's standing room only with balconies on the side, and I'm not sure how exactly you get your Abraham Lincoln on, but those must be VIP tickets or something.   The stage is high enough to where you can stand behind some wolly mammoth of a man and be a 5'3'' flats wearing munchkin and still see the band on stage.   The crowd was young (20s) and everyone was having the best time.   I don't know if it was the band, the venue, the crowd or something else, but I'm pretty sure it was everything that made it awesome...I keep checking the website to buy tickets to the next concert of a band that I've even slightly heard of.

3o1SBXXYchrB_aKFOILqKA.review_text: One of if not my favorite venues. I've been choosing to see shows here since I was old enough to attend shows. I'm nowhere near the City anymore, but if there is a great band or musician playing I will travel the 6 hours to see them here. Classic bands have played here forever and the remodel awhile back made it even nicer.

LahgT0Dec0B6NSws7VHiJQ.review_text: Every time I visit the Fillmore, I feel like Jerry Garcia is trying to suck me into the floor--his pscyhedelic black hole. My feet always stick to it, whether it's on the lineoleum or carpet portion.   I love this place, and all of its wonderful history...But I can't say I'm very happy with their camera policy. They have the most strict policy of any venue I have ever visited--I can never bring my "Professional Camera" into the venue...even when the band tells its fans that they are allowed. Then I get to stand there and watch people with mini-digital cameras and video recorders instead.   Of all the music venues in San Francisco, this is the one I have visited the most...always enjoy the show but get a bit miffed at the way I'm treated by the staff. They seem to have this weird sense of entitlement because they work at "The Fillmore".  And who is that dude that stands at the top of the stairs all the time? Does he own the place? Is it Bill Graham's son/brother?  Sure...you can buy me off as I leave the venue with that FREE poster, and that is why you still get 4 stars.

YAG90mceVFQLdvl4wndvQg.review_text: I saw the Civil Wars here...  + great atmosphere + not too crowded since they cap the number of people who can come in  - the security is rude

AGraTma9eEgsiJFDIy6tbg.review_text: I really love this venue for concerts!  I've seen India.arie, Natasha Bedingfield, Bebel Gilberto among others here and have always enjoyed its quaintness and excellent acoustics.  Plus, they serve food and drinks, there's usually no line for the bathroom, and I love all of the historical posters and pictures of all the awesome concerts that have come through town through the many many years of The Fillmore.  I'm going to see Pat Benatar rock on this Sunday, and I am so looking forward to enjoying yet another concert at this venue with this rock legend!  Can't wait!

_1dF-cFPPRwuPg-i8lhnSg.review_text: My love... it's very SF. It's an intimate venue and I've seen many amazing shows here. I am biased though because my dad used to take me here to see hippie shows from his generation so it brings back heart warming memories that can make a love hater want to puke.  Check it out.

RWIuUNWFYYWS2tbQ6VzKJg.review_text: Wow. So I went here for the first time a couple weeks ago and saw The Streets. It was very cool - different than how I expected. I enjoyed the free apples and poster. Most of all the music was great, kind of loud, but perfectly sized venue, and best of all Mike Skinner jumped off the balcony into the crowd. WOOOOOOOoooo!!!!!!!!!!!

CF2r1hlXLQifyDwpWFJ7rg.review_text: I'm a total sucker for a venue with a great history and the Fillmore has definitely got just that. So many important artists have graced the stage, but if you could care less about that stuff then that's cool.   The Fillmore stands on it's own as far as I'm concerned.  The sound is great and the chandeliers look amazing. It's rather large yet feels kinda cozy. Also, I don't know who books for the poster room, but every band/performer I've seen there before the show has blown me away and, in my opinion, has given the headliner a run for their money.

EiwxlbR8fb68lMgEXhcWKA.review_text: When MGMT announced their tour date and concert at the Fillmore, I was excited because from the reviews it appeared to be a fantastic location for the concert. I eagerly awaited this date and stood outside an hour prior to doors opening to get a good spot on the floor. I was a bit annoyed that they were very thorough with my tiny bag which fit like tetris and not so much after they ravaged through it, I am not carrying a weapon thank you ... but other than that nothing really stood out to me to be spectacular.  Certainly nothing worthy of more than 3 stars. The acoustics were ok, the venue looked ok, the prices were average and the bouncers were mean. There was seating and tables around but we missed that for the front of the line spot. There wasn't too much moshing going on, but then again it was MGMT.  At the end of the night, we stood outside for about 1.5 hr to wait for the band to come out, and it seemed like the band was calling random folks in, but the bouncers were yelling at the waiters to form a line and get out of the way. Boo hoo. We left, no MGMT in sight, oh well.   I wouldn't not come back but it's not my favorite venue so far.

QD1eSC8gmRJziAa3QMcJcg.review_text: Very good varieties of performances. Okay sound quality. Moderate - expansive admission. Small drinks.  (too small for what you pay for)

gwqVxUenNohQmreJENWzDg.review_text: I love this place. Once you've been to a concert here...you don't want to go to any arena. You can be so close or in the back and still be sooooo close! I took my lil bro to his first concert here before hitting a big venue. It can be a bit tricky to get to. My first time here we missed it several times since it's up on the overpass! LOL!

8qRUM-dShbtwHfjAJdpPRg.review_text: I was at this iconic, popular gem in 1997 for CSN (Crosby, Stills, and Nash) without Young who was at a bridge school benifit for his son, Ben who I went to preschool with, though not in the same class.  Anyhow, it was a rocking night with everyone from 20 somethings to hippies with marijuana and all.  I remembering turning to my father and saying, "Dad, I think I smell marijuana."  A guy in front of me turned to me and said, "Want a hit?"  I said "No thanks."  I definitely got second hand asficsiation that night; the consert was excellent as well as the acustics and overall venu and atmosphere of people there for a good time.  Fastforward to last night; my friend and I saw a Greatful Dead tribute band who sound just like the original band.  Both times, everyone, including the police officers and security gards are very friendly and professional, wishing you a good time.  It was like 97 all over again, people of all ages, a lot of people breaking out the peace pipes and all.  My friend and I were fortunate to be seated upstairs, looking down on it all.  The bench was pretty comfortable and the cocktail waitress cute and friendly.  It was a rocking night with everyone clapping to the beat and singing along with some of the songs.  I had a wonderful time which I hope will be the second of many more to come.  I love the old architecture vibe.  So, for a rocking good time and a lively crowd to kmach, complete with a full bar, The Fillmore cannot be beat.  Rock on and keep up the good work guys.!

C6Jn4YX-2YRzTTAI-M0Yyg.review_text: Everyday in California we hear about gay rights and individual liberties.  Whatever happened to patron rights? Tonight I was assaulted both verbally and physically by power hungry fascists at the Fillmore in San Francisco.    After being seen with a flask of wine ( I didn't want to drink the lousy house wine) I was brutally escorted out of the venue.  The problem I have is that the punishment did not fit the crime.  The security guard could have easily confiscated the wine and flask and let me stay.  Instead, the man pulled my arm leaving bruises and had two other security personnel escort me out of the venue.  He proceeded to call me names and insult my moral integrity.  He told me I was not ft to be a teacher and that I was corrupting the moral fabric of our society.    How can we let this continue? A private venue has the right to belittle and assault its patrons? What would happen if this was a restaurant or another private enterprise? Should I have taken my own wine into the venue? Probably not.  Should I have been dragged out and publicallly humiliated?  Absolutely not.    I beg of you in my defense, please do not patronize the Fillmore.  The entire staff seems to enjoy kicking people out of their shows and laughs at the  unfortunate expense of its patrons.  Is their any justice left for a patron that just wants to hear the musi

mE-hdFF4RgCxspZU72GAsw.review_text: It's a known fact, concert tickets have outpaced inflation by double or triple. It's one thing to shove down $50 a show at the Fillmore, but the fact that they tap on a $3 "service fee" per ticket at the venue door is absolutely insane. "Service" -- What kind of service is that? It's not like other venues are not selling tickets at the door, right? It's not like selling tickets at the Fillmore is an exclusive innovative act. No, people, it's Gosh-darned nickel and diming of their customers. On top of that, drink prices have skyrocketed as well. Now $10 will sport you some so-so medium shelf cocktail. I love the Fillmore, don't get me wrong. The sound system there is great and (some of) the staff are really cool. (And they still have free water.) It's just gotten too expensive versus the experience received. Bill Graham would be agast.

gUyxVA_YYh3tQloAhY5SHA.review_text: The Fillmore rocks!  I love the Fillmore.  Everytime I go to the Fillmore I have an awesome time.

_VjAjQZDlWum7lo2iTWvOQ.review_text: The Fillmore is by far one of the best venues in the city. Like others have said, there is so much history here and it's all on the walls. It's fun to go early and just walk and looking around in here. The place is great to see the actual show too. It's big, but small at the same time. I'm a big and tall dude so I feel guilty blocking people at concerts. So I like to hang back, and even hanging back in this place you have a great view of the stage. And on top of it the sound is great here. Plus it makes it even better that on the way out you get a free little poster for the show....FREE!!!!

_kzPMF9WoGldJZcgaUnTiw.review_text: My favorite venue in the bay area!  I've been to dozens of concerts here and always have a great time.  The Fillmore is a nice intimate venue so you can get up close to the performers and rock out.   The acoustics are always on point and you hardly every hear any distortion.  Because it's a smaller venue, tickets are usually reasonalbly priced and they get a great roster of artists to come here and perform.

ObsMycnFdI80N1bP8K1fDw.review_text: I love it here for concerts.  I always come here for any type of event when I can!

oV3sv0qBlMM2DixCUDr7HQ.review_text: Andrea F has spoke my sentiments almost exactly about the Dita Von Teese gig. I do want to add that that all the staff here are extremely nice and not pushy or excessively rude, which is nice to have. The drinks were a bit pricier than I expected... thought we were at a baseball game for a moment.   The Fillmore is a beautiful venue, intimate while not be cramped. Wouldn't hesitate to come back for a non-burlesque show in the future.

TLa1BS6JUQhd_mPX59eycA.review_text: One of my favorite music venues because it's so small, it's intimate and you feel you're personally getting to know the band/performer. A couple of things to share: 1. If you want to get a poster and apple at the end of the night on the way out, you need to wait until the house lights are on, encores are done and the band has officially finished for the night (it's called manners people, so don't bitch). The beer and food are good for concert beer and food, enough said about that. If you don't smoke pot be prepared to leave the building smelling like it anyway.

khKaHZDNyNdSadFe6E7izQ.review_text: One of my favorite venues in the City. Great size and I always look forward to seeing the black-lit chandeliers. They used to serve delicious apples at every show, but I'm not sure they still do that. But they do play "Greensleeves" after every show, which I think is a nice, unique touch. A lot of history in this place.

mnv-Z2vCfGffzvIV61q20A.review_text: i had real cool experience for the fillmore.  well cool in the weird type of way.  i went saw the david crowder band.  they are christian.  but i thought the place rocked.  it was so diff to be there and see people worshipping god in the fillmore.  thought it was cool that the fillmore let them play there and thought it was cool david crowder band did an all club tour.  living more in the world and not being some subsect.  how great it was to have beer and worship god.  though everytime i drink a good beer, i give god a smile:)

ZQ0qNjGOdUfDClBcFMAXyA.review_text: Went here finally, and as a venue it lived up to the hype. Great sound, amazing space/ambiance, fun crowd.  Only reason I'm giving it 3 stars is the beast of a coat check lady there! She was yelling at me because I needed to check my Flip video camera... maybe she was having a bad day, but seriously... she had some major attitude going on!  Otherwise was a really fun night...

lnACSIS3W7FjSiHWuVXkfg.review_text: I love the Fillmore but am unhappy at their now EXTORTIONATE drink prices. Last night I paid TWELVE FRIGGING DOLLARS FOR A BEER. That's right, $12 for a large glass of Sierra Nevada -- a locally brewed IPA. Now, when I first started going to the Fillmore five years ago their prices were higher than a lot of other local venues, but in the $4-$5 range for a decent sized glass of beer. Since then they seem to have climbed constantly. Come on guys, that's just completely outrageous. It was a decent sized cup, probably more than a standard pint, but $12 for a local draft beer is just ludicrous.

ZttTdHje7TJXG6hZM06CtA.review_text: It's fun to watch the scams happening outside with the ticket scalpers.  Some of them (orange knit hat) had a "thing" going with the doormen (really big short guy with huge earrings).  The doormen take fake/already scanned tickets sold by certain scalpers and get a kickback from the scalper.  Wonder if management knows? cares??  I've seen many many shows here over the years. Good sound.  The bars upstairs are less crowded, usually.

_5uZ9Ur33MnFvpjeryyKMQ.review_text: I am obsessed with chandeliers, ergo I am always easily convinced to join friends when there's a good band playing at the Fillmore.  The chandeliers there are so big and sparkly and pretty when lit by the colorful stage lights!  It's incredible!    You just feel so damn cool as soon as you enter the "ballroom;" it's hard not to have a great time.  A taste of the Fillmore charm: tons of "vintage" concert posters adorn the walls, there are free apples near the entrance, the curtains that frame the stage are old-school movie theater dark red, and if you attend a sold out concert you receive a special poster at the end.  Note: They do a fairly thorough security check of your purse, jacket, pants, etc, but even if your ticket says "no cameras allowed" the security guys usually don't care.  Just don't carry any firearms on you.  They care about those.

pdilmEaeXuntV4eTnc9KcQ.review_text: I believe Bill Graham would be sad if he had to shell out the cash like the rest of us for a show at the Fillmore. The $10 added convenience fee from Ticketmaster is bad enough on top of the $30 tickets.   When did beer prices go to $12?  Do they just not want to sell any? The good:  Lesbians are in full force at this place.  And they love Gomez. The stage and sound are still in top tinitis inducing form, so the shell of a great venue is there, but something bad happened.  Maybe I got older and remember some great shows in the late 90s there, when I was the young person bopping around to bands like Weezer and Soul Coughing.  And I could get the tickets at the Bass Outlet in the Tower Records store down the street for about $20, maybe less. Eh.  Last night's show for me may have been the last Fillmore show I ever go to. Sad for the music business, since well, it's dying for a multitude of reasons.  And high priced tickets and high priced beers are not pulling people back. How about charge less for tickets and beer so that you sell out all the shows?  Instead of trying to milk out every dollar in my pocket and not selling out the shows? And sad for me, because I love live music and I used to really love this place. Bye, old friend, your owners treat you wrong. And just to cap off a weird evening, leaving the place the cab I was in got into an accident with another car running a red light.  I smashed my forehead into the plexiglass divider.  The other driver insisted that she didn't run it, but she was lying.  She was completely in the wrong.  Funny, the cops asked me if I needed an ambulance and I nodded, no.  They kept saying, 'alright, there's no blood, so you can go on your way'.  Is that the criteria for injury?  "No blood, o.k., you can go." Weird evening.  Should have stayed home.

aIk07jxkia9izLMKRbaHHw.review_text: The posters upstairs are completely cool, it is like a history lesson in rock on the walls.  This place is big enough for some great acts to play, and small enough for you to really enjoy them.

urUaAKYkdQ9ncEQ5HWpEzg.review_text: The Fillmore is to San Francisco what Teatro La Fenice is to Venice. Just go and soak-in the rich history: the posters and photos that adorn the walls are worth the price of admission alone.

A7oZKZuvBRp2Ch-XH-aQYA.review_text: I loved the Fillmore for many years, really, and the qualities of this place are undeniable.  They get great bands, great acoustics, decent bar staff.  The atmosphere, architecture and history make it worth going to.  The crowds are cool.  You can look past the broken bathrooms, dirty furniture and lack of upkeep and wallow in the fact that you're in one of the  coolest concert venues in the world, full of history.    It's great, for many years I never had any problem with this place whatsoever.  But recently....  I was there twice for the recent Social Distortion shows and the security staff has become such a screaming bunch of hemorrhoids that I felt compelled to write a review.    So here I am hoping that the management will read this and see  what they need to change.  Come on management!!!  Anyway, we went in and got a nice reach around during the frisk search at the door.  Problem is, said reach around  was not done by a Victoria's secret nymphomaniac, but by a  surly kind of bouncer.  My dismay at being violated soon fled, and we decided to go to the ATM, which we found inoperable.  So a nice coat check girl tells us that if we exit the club and go to the right, there is a liquor store with an ATM.   Off we go to the liquor store, or not.  We exited the club and turned to go to the right and , really, three (3 !!) security guards started screaming at us that we could only go to the left.  I attempted to explain  the dilemma here, but all three were unbending in their enforcement of this important  rule.    We went to the left and another guard, who was working outside said, that it was cool to go to the store.  So, we attempt to go, and as we pass the club entrance one of the  younger guards at the door took time away from his busy schedule of collecting tickets to yell at us, then come running after us, and grab us.  His forehead veins were bulging as he expressed his displeasure with having to tell us twice that we could, under no circumstances, go to the right  side of the club.  My pal told him that while they can make rules for inside the club, they can't control where their patrons go outside.  The guard was then clever enough to come up with this scathing gem...   "If you go to the right, you say goodnight!"  Over my guffaws he repeated this line not once, not twice, but thrice!!!  He then told another bouncer to keep an eye on us so that we would not go to the right.  Seriously.     So we went to the left to smoke a smoke.  Apparently we were not the only ones with a deep desire to go to the right because there was a support group full of concert goers here on the left, all a bit peeved about the goofy rule.  One girl had to go to her car to get something, one had to go meet a friend that was lost, none had a solid enough reason to be allowed to go to the right.   We were going to start a drunken rebellion and just all walk to the right at the same time, but we just couldn't get organized, and Social D started playing "Ball and Chain" , so we all went back in.    I mean come on, The Great American Music Hall, The Warfield, also great venues with much more courteous staff.  The Fillmore folks can learn from them.    ...  And Finally, the point.  Bring cash with you.  Park to the left.  Don't piss off the door people.  This is overall a great place, only marred by recent strange rules vigilantly enforced by an over zealous team of, uhh, door... guys.  And remember... if you go the the right, you say goodnight.

zejhY7mSVWETy51MUpLJ1g.review_text: Ditto to what others have said (cool, historic venue).  I also think it's neat that the artists seem pretty stoked to be playing there as well...so always a good vibe.  Except for the time a drunk bugger knocked me in the head at an O.A.R. concert.  Oh well, it happens.

EZGdtTxbMpZ4E3KkLstE1A.review_text: The Fillmore is a gem of a venue.  I recently saw the Black Crowes at this 1,200 person venue and easily positioned myself right next to the stage with full view of everything going on in front of me.  It's simply a pleasure to watch a good act in an intimate venue instead of an arena.  The Fillmore has the history and prestige is continue pulling good acts to the small, charismatic venue.  From the guy greeting people walking up the stairs to the free Bill Graham apples, you get the feeling that this venue cares about what they're doing.  It has a soul.  So get there early and tour the posters on the walls, grab a drink and an apple and get to the floor to claim your spot.

NC9v04V0Il5YkjLFfZZ5bQ.review_text: The Fillmore definitely has the intimate feel when you watch a concert.  You can get up close and personal with the performers when you are all the way up in the front.  As you walk down the hallway to the stage, you can see pictures of bands and artists that have performed there in years past.  Hopefully my band will play here someday, haha.

ApkavjkgoOX-lGSIn8f08A.review_text: The Fillmore is one of my favorite venues in San Francisco. The atmosphere was good and the other patrons friendly on the evenings I've been there. Drinks are on the pricey side.

CMQ_rgY7GUzw8-LeaPoGsw.review_text: Saw an AWESOME Jamiroquai show here.  Love the chandeliers and lighting.  The history of this place is amazing.  Totally dig on the apples!  Minus one star for the entire floor feeling like it's going to collapse.

riWDgbauId8TK7YFVgMNJw.review_text: I love the history and the venue, but I'm only going to sit upstairs. I love it there the most:hanging over the rail, staring down at the musicians.

eWV_zVbcwlhJbsn3DubQtw.review_text: I think the Fillmore is my 2nd favorite music venue in San Francisco. I love the purple glow the ceiling gets against the crystal chandeliers and the red velvet curtains. I love the musical history that the venue holds and to think about all the legendary performances that have occurred there. The posters all over the walls are fun to browse as well.  I have never had an issue with sound here so that is good. All of the shows I have seen here are memorable to say the least, some good and some not so much. The venue pulls a wide variety of performers for our listening pleasure.  I hate if you are midway towards the back of the room it is hard to see (I am 5'7", I don't think I am short but this place makes me feel short). I hate that if you want to, there is NO where to sit because it is usually reserved.

lcoBlH4rD87pD7xOlXzDkQ.review_text: Kavinsky was an hour and forty five minutes late to the stage on November 4th, and did not play long. After the show, my friend and I used the restroom after gathering our things from the coat check window, and when we came out, we were rushed out the door by staff who seemed to be closing very hurriedly. It was a strange and offputting end to a short evening. Nice place, though.

ug_HUEWfUrizX9DNT0Aehg.review_text: I've been here for several shows and its always a good time! The staff are friendly and the place is clean.

VrKc-_vV2nJzqUk8jQImbQ.review_text: Cool venue, lots of history. It's always fun checking out all the old posters upstairs and the chandeliers and balcony seats give it a classy vibe. I've seen some good bands there and it's the only place I've ever been drinking backstage so it holds a special place in my cold, yet still-beating heart. Rock on Fillmore!

J7fmfD8q5v64eAmHE4dI6w.review_text: This is a GREAT venue.  It's small and intimate.  It has sooo much history.  The nachos are decent (not expected at a concert venue).  The drinks are strong.  Beers are pretty cheap.  My red bull and vodka was expensive, but I was at a concert, so I expected to pay a bit more.    I look forward to seeing many more shows at the Fillmore in the future.

ZZ1iiAsRJfSBCxzJ6AEL2Q.review_text: I've seen many, many shows here. Its a great place just oozing with history. I highly suggest taking a stroll upstairs to check out the posters. You could almost classify the upstairs as somewhat of a rock n' roll museum. Sound is decent, but it can be loud, sometimes rendering the vocals indecipherable. Tickets are overpriced, which is why I avoid shows here sometimes if I can stand missing a band. The big plus about seeing a sold out show here is getting the poster commerating the event. Be careful though, sometimes they run out. I suggest moving to the back for the encore so you're closer to the door. I recommend it, but if you live anywhere in the Bay Area and you like music, your're going to end up here at some point.

sZCLIvqhKPXZimcpey5p7g.review_text: Love it! Saw Girltalk here, as well as Ben Gibbard. Very different vibes.  Nice big space, not too hot (I hate that), bar in back is easy to get to.  Funny story- I walked into the building and saw a man talking to a Fillmore employee. The man said, "Hey, is there a smoking area here?" and the employee said, "Yeah," to which the man replied, "Where?" and the employee said, "Out the front door, right by the post office!". I dunno know, I thought that was pretty funny. Perhaps due to the cocktailing I'd done earlier.

C9bD25sowxyzHn5IhVroWg.review_text: Went to the fillmore last night to see wale. Everything went great except the drinks. They are more expensive than a drink at Levi's!   I thought the sound within the venue was really great. I could hear the lyrics and the bass effect was just awesome.   Tons of parking available since it is located across japan town. Neighborhood can be sketchy around so make sure to be in a group when you are leaving the place late at night.

DHT-Z-JF5V6_U0HSWErrXQ.review_text: Maybe I'm an old fart, but after standing for 3 hours watching the Pumpkins (which was amazing, btw), I started feeling like my knees were going to buckle. I don't know what I'd do to change it, cuz part of its charm is its openness that allows you to stand wherever you want, but maybe some more of those tables on the side should not be only reserved?

es3lKKd_APbnkxI7MFhW7A.review_text: This is a pretty cool venue.  I enjoy the history aspect somewhat; hell, even my hippy father got excited when I told him I was going here.  Of course, I am utterly unexcited by the fact that the Grateful Dead played here, because the Grateful Dead sucked.  This is just a side rant of mine intended to inure my hippy fans to my complete and utter hatred of jam bands.  No, I don't want to get high and listen to the Dead's set on April 21, 1971.  I'd rather stick bamboo shoots under my fingernails.  So, the sound here is pretty good.  I wish the stage were higher though,  because the tallest guy in the place always stands in front of me.  The last time I was here, however, karmic payback appeared in a slightly different manifestation:  Marina girl with giant purse.  I had to do a quick mental check with myself (I was a bit intoxicated) -- are we at Hot Chip?  Where happened to the cheerful dancing electro-kid who was just next to me?  Well, Marina incarnate decided that she had to be right in front of me during the last five songs or so (and I mean practically on top of).  I don't take kindly to people invading my personal space (especially when I'm trying to dance), so I gave her a not-very-friendly shove.  I'll give her credit, though, she actually whipped around and seemed ready to take me on.  I was buoyed by about six vodka tonics and a shot of Jameson, though.    I gave her the signature look of death that my brother and I both do very well.  I had already decided to grab her hair with my left hand and break her nose with an open handed upward motion with my right (oops, I fell into your nose!)  She looked at me, exchanged glances with her little toadie friend, and they sidled over about ten feet to the right.  She then proceeded to sway off-rhythm, half-heartedly swinging her left arm in a semi-circle.  Are you dancing or air-jerking off your semi-limp frat boy boyfriend?  Shouldn't you be at a Dave Mathews concert or something?  Bah!  Bad rhythm, an unnecessarily large purse, and a lack of self-awareness in a crowd put you in the expendable portion of the population.  Congratulations.  Here's hoping that you won't be at the next Fillmore show I attend.

56NWgfYChWGSPpxcSW19jA.review_text: this place is awesome, they always have a good band/artist showing. Definitely check this place out.

ZCgJbuBhHiGZd9yZ_kq6qg.review_text: A great venue, love this pace.

K0zrsXqu55JPwT4dnvNUDg.review_text: Just came here this weekend for the One Republic Concert.    IT was great.  I think the way they got it set up is fantastic.  The chandeliars were really nice and the way they hang low enough to just give that light sparkle in the room when the lights are darkened, it gives it some classy feel.  the area is big enough for the crowd to get a good view standing up.  even the balcony area is at a good distance to just enjoy the show.  The Fillmore has had a rich history in the music industry for artists to come and perform for bay area locals, and it shows in the hundreds of pictures/posters of artists from even the 60s framed and mounted on the walls in the lobby, in the rooms, and across the halls.  Just an absolutely amazing place.  Drinks are decently priced too.  about 4 bucks a beer?

sMgs1e2yxylzaTmb4t1nMg.review_text: The more I go to other venues, the more I realize that the Fillmore is about as good as it gets in the Bay Area. Often imitated, but never duplicated. Give me a bite of that apple.

bW2LMBS-D-qAgXfpeof3UQ.review_text: I LOVE this venue!!!  This is my favorite place to watch a show because it is very intimate and you feel like you're watching your friends performing.  Its mostly general admission which is great because tickets are cheap and you can move around and go to the bar without interrupting anyone.  I would love to watch Snoop Dogg here cuz I know he likes to perform here.  Plus, the staff is super friendly and you get a free poster and apple at the end of the show....BONUS!

7umyS0zBuIrXlrVDjBR1CQ.review_text: It looks like it's correct now. Yay!

h3Yg3OE9uD6XEAPyEm3qEQ.review_text: Great venue. Easy to get drinks and you can get a good view of the band from just about anywhere in the room.

ddGJKrlTc9aePT35-i-_3g.review_text: $9 for a Makers and Coke, $8 for a Stella. Really?! No posters that night for some reason. Aside from that it is a pretty incredible place to see bands. Good acoustics, nice overall. Just won't be getting drinks there again. I think bars should have to post their drink prices so you know before you order.

P2fXcmsU_vrs4zB2IfsHnQ.review_text: The only place I go to watch a show! Seen some of the greatest performances there! Always fun and never a dull moment whether it's with the performer or the crowd!

k1NEXdF1frI-Ojw5Wz03Vg.review_text: Went once a while back for a Stereophonics concert (I think The Leaves opened for them)... cute atmosphere... small place. Only thing that annoyed me though (no one but this person's fault of course) was some girl left her drink on the ground RIGHT next to my foot so I kept having to pay attention to it so I wouldn't kick it to the ground. Grrr... But anyway it was memorable. Loved the bucket of apples they have at the end.

wlF44erpoT6Sm82EjlsAfw.review_text: I honestly can't express how nice these people are at the Fillmore. They gave away free apples at time I was there for Tycho's tour. Not only that, free water was being established around the bar. I thought that was a simple, yet clever idea since most venues will not do that. I would like to make a shout out to the care-taking staff that was gracious enough to take care of my friend after an incident had occurred. You guys are the best! Reminds myself how there are still good people in this world. Overall, great venue, chill atmosphere and chill vibes all around.

FNQyEtGRC8-GU659D7zAHw.review_text: One of my favorite venues, I love coming here and seeing the history of all the past acts that have performed here. Their sound system is excellent, you can hear and FEEL the music pounding in your chest and it is an awesome sensation. They often hand out free posters after shows which is always nice.

Y6s2HEIcQUcBAMWdDnQ8OA.review_text: My first Fillmore show was the Get Up Kids back in 2002, and I havent been able to leave since.  Its my favorite venue for larger shows for many reasons.  I love that even tho its big, the shows still feel a little intimate, and you can see the bands from pretty much anywhere in the venue.  The drinks are a little pricey, but I've had more expensive AND smaller drinks at other places.  Free apples AND posters?  LOVE IT.  except that one time there were no posters at the Yeah Yeah Yeahs show.  It sold out, there should have been posters.  not bitter at all :)  ANYWAYS, the staff is always nice and pretty helpful.  I've always had a good time there and met some excellent people there.

sNzcFf1ssrVKmMtVY4weAg.review_text: The size of the venue keeps everything intimate. Depending on who you see, crowd may get crazy, but it's something you should expect by the artist you chose to buy tickets for. Sound quality is great. Ambience of the venue is on point. Since 2004, small venues make me look down on stadiums! 4/5.

B7A8EhUulVRTzr83dtvV7g.review_text: I really enjoy shows at the Fillmore!!  The Fillmore is old, historical and just a really cool venue to listen to music!  Upstairs there is a second bar, you can order food and watch the act from the decadent luxury under beautiful chandeliers :)  2 great perks at the Fillmore:  1. FREE posters for sold out shows! As long as the show sells out with enough time you will get a free poster at the end! The posters are only handed out after the show, you have to wait until the end to get one! Check out all the cool past posters on the walls upstairs!! My mission is to find which band has the most on the wall... any help greatly appreciated :)  2. FREE apples! The Fillmore helps with your '5 a day' with a huge rustic iron bath tub of apples! Though at a recent show (Mac Miller) there were no apples :( Apparently they were worried all those pesky kidz (very young audience!!) would throw the apples on stage!

Iqfc_JtaStZwPG66WsBkLg.review_text: I felt like I was in a chique Dolche and Gabanna inspired music hall!  This place rocks!  I just saw Girl Talk perform.  There are two levels and no seating, so you can choose to chill upstairs, grab a bite to eat from their killer, slightly overpriced but hey they have a monopoly on food menu, or dance amongst the throngs of fans in front of the stage.  After the show, the give you a free "Fillmore" poster of the band.  These things are collector's items and they give you one!  Sweet!

9woUfX_PsUiZcRY0aSWfEQ.review_text: This is my favorite venue for shows.   But beware, the tickets sell out fast for the Fillmore so if you want to see a show there, you've got to buy your tickets early.   It's a really cozy place, with glittering lights, a beautiful atmosphere and such an amazing history of wonderful, wonderful artists playing there in the sixties. That's one of my favorite things about the Fillmore. And they're still booking amazing people to play at the Fillmore.   And they give out free posters at the end of each show. I love that.   My favorite shows at the Fillmore so far have been Metric and Regina Spektor. I really want to see Broken Social Scene play there but the show sells out so quick!

BKxQJJAh_0Jtv4MqxbjkMA.review_text: We did shots.  My best girlfriend got banged by her man in the corner.  I ran into a roommate from 13 years ago.   But do I really need to say more after the banging comment?  The concert was awesome and the space great.  No lines for the pisser, drinks or coat check and it was sold out?

M_4EmxzznybTzMwT7FDg_g.review_text: There is so much history here!  About 4 or 5 years ago, I saw Joe Satriani as he was filing his Live in San Francisco CD / DVD.  I was right in front, having been waiting for a few hours in line.  Another great show!  The security in front makes sure nobody is smoking anything ... another plus!

08jfo0j-qbcs5yKefByVKQ.review_text: I hate trying to find parking for this venue but this is my absolute favorite place to catch music acts. I can't really add much more that the other 288+ reviews have already noted but, man, this is a San Francisco classic. When my favorite bands play here, it's a dream come true; always, always a good time.

sHCl4mBKitWjW2tWdZIbaQ.review_text: Ok. So maybe I'm biased because...er...i work here. But I effing love my job, so let's clear something up, folks.  1. The man at the top of the stairs, his name is Tim, and he's that lovely in person, too.  2. Quit whining about being searched when you come in a venue. It's for your safety as well as ours. Trust me, that one time when the off duty cop got drunkedy drunk and started waving his gun around, it wasn't pretty.  3. The staff present at the shows has absolutely nothing to do with merch prices, how many bands are playing, your drinks being too expensive or convienence fees on tickets. All those things have to do with the jerks up in corporate that get paid WAY more than most of us ever will. The people you see nightly get paid jack and we're there cause we love music. Be nice and even say thanks if you had a great time.  4. There are no ins n outs cause we're an all ages venue. Get over it. Get nice and drunk and grab something to eat before you come, if you are feeling really cheap. You can always call the venue and ask the lineup, there is almost always a real person in the office answering phones, just for you.  5. The bar is how the venue makes money, which is how we stay in business and bring you quality shows. Drink heavily, but not too heavily. We really don't want to kick you out, OK? And that bitchy bartender or coctail waitress you complained about would probably be nicer if you tipped her more than a quarter.  6. Shows have to sell out two weeks in advance for there to be a poster. It's your fault for not buying your ticket earlier.  7. Behave yourself. That guy who bit off Pat's thumb is is some serious legal trouble.  8. Have fun. You make the show. Never pretend like you're too cool to enoy the music. If all else fails, go find the Led Zepplin poster up in the poster room. Ask someone working if you need a hint.  Oh, and by the way. We don't want to be owned by Clear Channel either, but somehow, we still manage to enjoy our jobs and our shows. You should try it.

0B3WbaM1hnn3Xut1bitSyw.review_text: Hippies and history and good times and standing and especially swaying wherever you feel like it. Yeah Yeah Yeah! Speaking of Yeah Yeah Yeahs, I hope Karen O does a show here.

wmQiLXiYpiiIjJQnsdeSOQ.review_text: I wonder what Sia would think of The Fillmore's chandeliers. They add a great touch of character to the venue. Space is big -- compared to Slim's, which is smaller.

F9T7tl3KcRGgLkma4GoN6Q.review_text: One of my favorite venues in the bay.   It's an easy enough walk or bus ride to BART for those who live outside of SF like me, which is great. Midnight walks through Japantown and down Van Ness are always cool!   Free posters and apples sometimes and the decor/ambiance is great. The chandeliers are cool.   If you look up and to the left when facing the stage there's a balcony where the band and their guests sometimes stay.   Awesome venue! I've always had a good time here.

HFfOJElAMRT17IfVG0y5iw.review_text: You just can't deny the history of this place. They greet you on the way in and then you just look around in awe at all the posters and photos of the acts who have played there. The sound is fantastic and the ventilation did a good job of getting rid of a lot of the smoke. They still haven't figured out a solution for the tall guy that's always standing right in front of me.

DS0Idr2XDhz5e7ZfSy0dYA.review_text: Not crazy about the sound system here but it is a fun place to see a show. For most times of the year the men's room here is insanely hot so maybe that's designed to not let people stay in there and smoke dope and shrooms too long. One extra 1/2 star if the system allowed it, for providing free apples (a long time tradition), usually one free poster per attendee upon exiting, as well as a nice exhibit of various musicians/performers who played there.  All I can say is most of the big name or up and coming bands (especially from EU or UK) when they first tour, play here first  then move on to bigger venues and thus losing the club intimate feeling, and if you miss them the first time round, you have nobody but yourself to blame. Acts like Coldplay, Doves, Sigur (D)ros (sorry but I almost fell asleep after a few songs even though I dug their 2nd album), Johnny Marr of the Smiths, Metallica, The Cure (doing promo shows) and many more.
