dp1DWBrBvDc49PirfCAqQg.review_text: OMG this place was great. Why? Because I SAW METALLICA HERE! It feels like the floor is going to give way at any moment, it feels like an super old building (cuz it is), and if you are short it is rather tough to see the stage from certain places. But it is awesome. The upper level rocks, the bar is decent (so i heard) the food is pretty good, and the acoustics are great. This place is great.  PS- yea it isnt in the BEST part of town. However , if you park in the Japantown garage near the hotel, you will be fine AND will play hardly anything for parking

P5bUL3Engv-2z6kKohB6qQ.review_text: Perfect size, layout, and acoustics. They bring in great acts to a fairly intimate environment. The only minuses are if it's crowded, the tallest M.F. somehow always ends up in front of me, and the cattle herd exit you have to endure at the end. Of course there is the bonus of posters if you do get out on time.

FRbFinnuNeWVXjAn_yjucw.review_text: I've been to concerts at the Fillmore before. For some reason I was not very pleased with the staff, but I went back this week for Two Door Cinema Club, and they definitely made up for it. They were super friendly this time around. I really appreciated them letting us bring water bottles in and not being overly-paranoid about people taking videos (they still stopped people, but they weren't yelling constantly like at other venues). The only time I thought they were being harsh was when I was buying merch. I bought one of the opening bands' CD and their bass player tried to hand it to me himself, but the staff wouldn't let him touch it. I don't understand why, but I guess it's some sort of protocol. Oh well.  I love everything else about this venue though. It's intimate, it looks cool, the sound quality is great, and you get a free poster on the way out!

skknTsrzKjSEg9b2mN2GjQ.review_text: Since I just moved to California I have only been here once so far - saw The Dresden Dolls. The staff was helpful, the bathrooms were clean and the wait at the bar was not long at all. The free water was nice also because some clubs charge for that. The posters they gave out at the end of the show were awesome!   One thing that sucked was there was no beer available on draft because something was "broken".  That was not cool.   The Fillmore reminds me of the 9:30 Club in DC but is cleaner. GO!  Oh and there is plenty of parking in the Japantown garages.

T9qcS0XCa_wEGsntk6sp-A.review_text: Had a great time at the Jesus and Mary Chain concert a few months back. The place is a bit worn down, but a lot of music history. Got very close to the performers and that added to the experience. Cool posters post concert if the performance is sold out.

UCn9wNpGoW4R8I-skfKghw.review_text: San Francisco's music scene might not be as amazing as it once used to be, but The Fillmore is, has, and always will be the cornerstone of the biggest shows to hit the city. The hall is beautiful, there's an incredible amount of photographs taken over the years hung on the walls and there's always ample room to dance. The drinks (especially the beers) are a tad on the small and expensive side, so if you do see a concert here, I suggest getting a little toasty at your local dive first.  Above all, The Fillmore is an important piece of San Francisco history. You owe it to yourself to go there at least once or twice while you live here.

4IjRYOqZ8D9N3q9vpleIbw.review_text: I've been to this venue twice, and so far it's one of my favorite places to go see a show.   I like the dance floor, and how there aren't any seats so you are free to move around.   If you want to be close to the stage, be sure to get in line at least 2 hours ahead of when they open the doors. But, when I went to the Owl City concert yesterday, we came to the line just minutes before they opened and got to stand in the 3/4 row (since everyone else was moving around)  The drinks are expensive, I have to say. Some kids behind us ordered a couple of sodas which were $3.25 each.  At the end of the concert, they gave each of us a free poster.

VhPngvnmlvlB_63vY6PQAw.review_text: Hands down the best concert venue in San Francisco, if not the world.

_Hum_JURLFwrAtAnzO2n-A.review_text: I love the Fillmore!  This is one of THE best places to catch a show.  It's not a big venue, but it makes for the perfect setting when you want to be up close and intimate with whomever you're here to see.    I love the fact that when you walk out of there, they give you a keepsake poster...  That rocks!  If you're short, like me, it's not a long way to go to squeeze around the place and find yourself right by the stage.  :-)  It sort of reminds me of the Troubadour in LA.

_vWS8TQDH7qqjXLzGDG8tQ.review_text: I like the Fillmore. It's an institution and a solid venue for decent sized concerts (probably around 1000+ but no where near the arena-sized 10,000+) in San Francisco. You still have a chance of standing up front against the stage and getting the band's sweat on you when they rock out and toss their head. I like the intimacy of venues like this....kinda hot.  The security the night I was there was...loose. I smelled all types of substances permeating the air including but not limited to: cologne, breath mints, BO, beer...  Worst part of the whole night is trying to exit the venue after a concert. The stair cased entrance becomes a narrow funnel that the entire building is trying to exit from. I would NOT want to be there in a fire drill. However, the Fillmore anticipates the slow-ass exiting with free apples & a commemorative poster.

TUce-uBQTWsZG5YAjOHShw.review_text: I love this venue. It's a great place to see a show.  The food is also pretty good, great if you don't have time for dinner before. There are enough bars so there is never too long of a wait. Be sure and go upstairs and check out the poster room...it's a rock n roll museum.  They also have a DJ or band playing in here before the headliner takes the main stage. The staff is friendly but then who wouldn't be happy working in such a cool place...?

ox6XdBAshwypScOBSWB0GQ.review_text: We were here for a show and didn't bother wasting on drinks however pricey or bad according to some other reviewers. Pattie Smith is still stunning after all these years!! She came here for a good reason, great  historical venue and audience.  They keep the tickets at affordable prices, offer apples and free posters. What more can you ask for?   Very close to Japan Town, where you can find a large parking lot and plenty of good sushi, ramen places.

QuCBcF8A8uITz-Ke5vUv2g.review_text: For music fans, the Fillmore is somewhat of an ever evolving temple. Before you go to yor first big concert at the Fillmore, check it out on a slower night. walk in, grab yourself an apple, and then just soak in the atmosphere.   You think you're fired up to be at the Fillmore? Imagine the guys on stage.

3mNz5nQFTIBQm0oU5mBR0w.review_text: Wondrous venue and walking distance from the crowds I shake it with  SITREP  My ex-girlfriend took me to see Gary Numen play here and I've been in love with the place since.  Along the way I've seen other artists I love, such as Peter Murphy (with and without Bauhaus), Switchblade Symphony, Sonic Youth and many many more.  SETUP  Small small balcony, though there's a sweet upstairs room that doubles as a seated chill space, but also sometimes has a smaller band stand where another artist can play to this crowd.  But the main floor - which usually is standing room general admission permits a considerable amount of dancing, and moshing, and mingling with friends.  Kinda go in circuits around the perimeter.  Find myself getting smashed up against the stage riser, but them I'm chilling in the back talking to sound engineers.  It's all good.  THE BAR  Typical San Francisco for venues of this size.  Plan on $6 for a beer and $8-$10 for a basic mixed drink.  I'd be pissed if I was in Sacramento or Seattle.  But in San Francisco, this is par for the course.  THE PARKING  It sucks.  Plan on that fact.  So either take mass transit, walk (which is what I do from the Haight, or Fell Street (depending on who's flat I'm staying at) or plan on an hour to park and walk if you are just coming down for the night - like I do many times - from Sacramento.  THE LOWDOWN  The Fillmore is a great place to catch a more intimate vibe, but with a still sizable crowd.

XQMaAvF3YUslCD-0tZY1xg.review_text: Best Live Music Venue in SF!  Overall acoustics are fantastic as others have stated - stage is at a perfect height and angle along with a large and wide floor space.  Place only holds 1200 people - and there is not a bad spot in the house. Alcohol Prices were fairly standard for a venue - $9 for a Buillet Rye and $12 for a 24 oz Beer.   Free Posters for every sold out show and free apples at every show.  Tip: Every Sunday between 10 AM and 4 PM - the box office has no fee ticket sales which saves about $10 per ticket.

neVRN1MJ3IpNbhEO1IeXFw.review_text: I feel really bad about giving this historical place 2 stars.  I really do.  But, think of this as more of a reminder to myself to go back and re-review.    I went there for a Comedy Central taping last week.  And granted, it wasn't to see a band, and i'm sure that makes a huge difference in terms of atmosphere, lighting, crowd, service, etc...but that night, boy did the years show.  The floors were sticky, the chairs falling apart, the curtains torn, and the smell undeniable.    That said, I am definitely not against going back to see one of the great bands that passes through.  I'm sure it has all the history for a reason, and I look forward to updating my review!

IRQTr0jNZV1t2s5l3GKf6Q.review_text: This is the greatest music venue in SF. I saw The Cult here 2006, and they rocked the place off the foundation!

dPTtL27RZ8O_E0VYB9lRQw.review_text: How can anyone not love The Fillmore? It's legendary. If you haven't seen a show here, what's wrong with you?! Seriously!   The Fillmore is the perfect size venue. The sound is alright. But damn, seeing Nikka Costa and her band was pretty darn amazing! And The Roots!? Can anything have gotten better than Questlove from the legendary Roots crew come down to the floor and use his drumsticks on a garbage can and drag it through the entire floor area. I was an arms length away from him! Can't get nothing better than that.

BwCTd0eAwqVJNM_HIZxutQ.review_text: HAIKU REVIEW  Back in the Sixties, Bill Graham barreled some apples to counter LSD.  What he envisioned... Words cannot honor legend. THIS is rock and roll.  Poster room upstairs Won't tell you half the story. Just wait, you'll get yours.  Every Fillmore show Feels like magic -- for the band, For your friends, for you.  Hendrix, Morrison, Joplin, Creedence owned this stage. You feel those spirits?  These chandeliers glow. That band comes on and thunders. Perchance this night, we dream.

Vb2JXxqXbd_dUhZs53V5EQ.review_text: Considering all of my concert experiences, in terms of the best venue I've been to, the Fillmore is hands down the best: It's intimate, completely general admission (the only way you should ever see a show), the acoustics are good (it's actually not terribly loud, yet very good sound quality), and food and alcohol are readily available.  Get there early since it's completely general admission (I got there about an hour before doors opened, and I was able to secure a spot at the railing next to the stage).  I was torn between going to the bar first or having to stand farther from the stage, but lo and behold there was a waitress walking around taking orders from the crowd before the show.  $8.75 for a paltry 8 oz or so of Red Bull vodka and a lot of ice, but the ice came in handy to sip on later.  Cameras may be listed as not being allowed, but the staff was ok with it as long as the flash stays off when the show starts.  Parking at the Japantown garage on Geary (one block away) was a cinch and reasonably priced for SF (max is $15), but beware, they accept cash only.  I think if I tried a little harder, I could've easily found parking on the street too.  I was a little disappointed that I didn't see the infamous bucket of apples or free posters after the show, but the experience was awe inspiring enough to still warrant a rare 5 star rating from me.  By the way, Jimmy Eat World was freakin sweet tonight too, but this review is about the Fillmore and is completely unbiased in reference to the band.  From now on, I would easily go back to the Fillmore to see any artist/band that I remotely like... it's that amazing.

qLmkS7VA1pxc_78GjUyvqw.review_text: it seems silly to try and describe the fillmore, i mean, shit, everyones played there. plus a lot of nobodies come thru on a tuesday night.  we all know whats up with the fillmore. but as ive discovered and grown to love about the fillmore is that its different for everyone and its different every time.   it started easy enough: i was working at starbucks (meh) on fillmore and ofarrell and so, naturally caffinated the crew at the venue. this led to heys and his which led to come to this free show gabe, dave chapelles in town you want to meet him? sure, i guess i can get you in again, oh gabe, why dont you have any other friends, stop coming to shows you dont even know just because they are free. and then that starbucks thing fizzled out and so did my hook up.  flash forward a yearish.... atmosphere.  my friend mylo calls me up "gabrizellllllle! where you at you hoodwinkin son of a bitch, girl, you better get your ass to the holiday inn in japan town cause we goin to atmosphere" this was a no brainer. mylo is one of my favorite people, easily excitable and hilarious. says shit that i dont even understand and smokes a wild amount of weed. we grew up together. hes aces.  so i go to this hotel room. we drink and drink. southern comfort, y'all and i dont normally fade this way. but i never turn shit down. so its about twenty minutes into this show when someone passes me a blunt and suddenly i think i should go outside and smoke a cigarette.  well. well. theres no pretty way to say this. the staff in front of the fillmore were asking me to move down the street for about five minutes before someone had to come physically shake me and move me past the busses to the "smoking area." i didnt hear them at all. i was so so so stoned.  i decided to promptly call my boyfriend (he was good while he lasted) who responded to my "come get me. im getting kicked out" with "gabe, its only 930" but he came and got me and we watched family guy and mylo called me a bitch ass trick who got too blazed and missed atmosphere. which i regret. terribly.  but then nights can go like this: flash to another year ish  me and ames are at mew and some hottie boys in some indie band weve never heard of (theyre good with new openers like that) gets on stage and were all meowing and cat calling in the front like the little hussies we are and then they say the most beautiful words "if anyone has a place for us to stay tonight, wed really appreciate it" and ames and i are digging our nails in each others arms and laughing madly, oh universe, you are so crazy! so of course we stay after, the boys come over, promises are made, photos are taken, hearts broken (theirs naturally) and in the morning as they stumble off to a show in canada we know its not playing at the fillmore but the party at my house that theyll remember most.  i guess what im saying is that it is what you want it to be. was this helpful? ;) ps. its only missing a star because they employed a boy i used to date. this is helpful because my drinks are free and troublesome because i get wasted and try to hit on him, forgettting we used to date........watch out for that

SbtaLPew4Je9TB9yCHnWQw.review_text: Can't think of a more entrancing, historical and just damn tight place to see a show. Stepping into the Fillmore just oozes history, style, and San Francisco charm. Visit the room where it is filled with concert posters from all time greats in every genre. At the door, take an apple (or four), which possesses a gloss that looks so unnatural, but I guarantee it'll be the juiciest, most orgasmic apple you've ever tasted in your life. I swear they must genetically modify that shit. Take a look upwards towards the ceiling and check out the beautiful chandeliers that line it. Even though this is a pretty big venue that probably holds at least a couple thousand, it feels as intimate as your grandma's living room. The acoustics are on point, and the crowd is chill. The only negative to the Fillmore is the fact that they only have 1 exit so there is a traffic jam that rivals the 805 south at 5 pm. However that is a small price to pay to check out the heavenly experience of the Fillmore.

M19NwFwAXKRZzt8koF11hQ.review_text: Review #1214. Nice local venue hosting many concerts and comedies. Came here for Kyle Kinane's comedy show. The line was really long the evening I visited that went around a full block and this area can get really windy so bring a warm jacket.  The venue itself is slightly older but definitely with good nice old charms.   While many were seated this evening they also allowed standing room by the bar which had the same great view and some standing areas are even closer and clearer.  The staff here was very very nice and the line did move along rather quickly so kudos to them. Definitely one of the venues in the city that I enjoy especially it's on the Fillmore.

ra3OzaxpILytSjHRRKoT8g.review_text: in all my years, I never went to the Fillmore, except finally to see Willie Nelson (how did I get to be a Willie fan?  Who knows.  If you listen to Stardust (I'm a standards person, not just a former punk rocker), it starts you down the path.  Then, he grabs you with pretty near everything (I'm getting all country now).  So the Fillmore's a big venue, but crammed up as close to the stage as I could get?  It felt plenty small.

Npm3q_h7jM3K25R_24zAPQ.review_text: The venue is pretty classic. You could have seen Janis Joplin here for $3 bucks once upon a time. That was sweet. Now I have to cough up at least $25 to see a band here. Not that I'm complaining. I've seen some really awesome bands here. The decor is all old concert posters and pictures of bands. Otherwise, your experience of the Fillmore will always depend on the bands you see here.

-WsAXw5yO-d9_pxFCOMHSA.review_text: My FAVORITE place to see a live band in San Francisco!  Make sure to line up early to get front row!  Also, make sure to stay until the end and get a free poster as you leave.

abMIw41Injf2rIMzMRUm7g.review_text: After being here a few more times, I'd have to say this is my favorite music venue in San Francisco. Excellent sound, great space.

NeXRy1C7PxS7bvIcQ3SymA.review_text: I agree with Christian M. that parking is easy to find on the streets!  You don't even have to search in the garage but if you decide to, there are three garages in the area:  -Japantown Center Garage (Geary & Webster) -Garage Annex (on Fillmore between Geary & Post) -Fillmore Center (Fillmore & O'Farrell)  As for the venue itself, it's cozy and intimate.  It's all standing so wear comfy shoes!  I like how there are chandeliers all over the ceiling.  The floor is a bit dirty and you can feel the grime as you walk but just don't think about it.  If you are standing, remember to stay within the white lines otherwise the staff will nudge you back in.  In the back, there is a bar for to get your drink on.

Ktd04SKOw89dE2DPOCj2wQ.review_text: Fillmore fits the billmore!  My favorite place in Nor Cal to see a show.  Its pretty simple - rectangular and medium sized, but well decorated.  The sound is always good here IMO. Get there early and grab the front of the balcony if you don't feel like being part of the crowd of if you are vertically challenged.  If you sit upstairs, you can take a minute in between sets to look at the poster collection from past acts and munch on the free red apples that are in abundance at the Fillmore.    Once you're done enjoying the show, go outside and collect the free poster that you will probably get to commemorate your evening.  The only complaint I really have about this place is that the bathroom is always 90 degrees and nasty.

6cqL8IZz7gh-yzMTTC_wWA.review_text: Nostalgic, with just the right amount of grit and class. Recently caught Devo here and for as amazing as the show was, I'm not sure enough gets said about the acoustics or the sound system. There wasn't a bad spot in the venue -- just crystal clear sound, nice low end, and an obviously skilled guy in the booth. I can't wait to return.

O2GjqZCGvjbYWL2xh6uQCw.review_text: This place is great and has a lot of amazing history.    However, they seemed to have raised their prices from 6$ to 8$ a beer.  To me that seems a little steep.  Maybe the bartenders were running one on me.

Uqg8zgMw-JYJNpjVtFXqng.review_text: This is my favorite place to see a band.  The historic location makes the night somewhat "special" and the smallness of the venue makes it an intimate experience. You can see the band from just about anywhere.  Fabulous.

52oH4DrRvzzl8wh5UXyU0A.review_text: It's a nice, intimate venue. Get there early cause you'll wait in a long ass line for any performance. I've been here for John legend, De La Soul, Music, Michelle Branch and several other shows and I've always been able to go right to the front of the stage cause I get there early. But it's intimate enough for everyone to get a good look. The bar is easy to get drinks at and the bartenders and front door people are always helpful. The only bad thing is the ladies room i always packed! But that's pretty much every venue

zTkWFiZm_BW1Ya3xMW5uZA.review_text: My absolute favorite music venue in SF.  They give you apples near the entrance, and you often times leave with a poster.  Drinks are easy to get at the bar, and have a decent amount of alcohol in them.  The acoustics are fantastic, they serve food upstairs, and the posters are most entertaining.

mo5HJBt6yrgarxcUXLyqyA.review_text: Saw Willie Nelson last night at the Fillmore, thought I should see this legend in person before they make the movie about his life, and as always it struck me how great a venue the Fillmore is to see music. This is a true San Francisco treasure one of those things like the hills and the fog that seperates us from other cities.   Despite being bought by the corporate giant Clear Channel, the Fillmore keeps a friendly, easy going non-corporate vibe, that is San Francisco at its best.

eEkTOX6SzCHxZFnsA86xbw.review_text: Some of the best shows I've ever seen have taken place at the Fillmore. It's worth seeing a show here for the history alone. Be sure to check out the photographs and copious posters that line the walls both upstairs and downstairs. It's amazing to think of all the people who've graced that stage.  Other things I love about the Fillmore: free apples, fantastic posters in honour of the shows that sell out, friendly staff, great sound, and an all-ages venue that works. San Francisco is extremely lucky to be the home of the Fillmore.  EDIT: I have to mention that the staff is especially hospitable to friends and family of the performers. One of my good friends has headlined here three times now and each time has been an absolute pleasure. I've experienced my fair share of boisterous venue staff at other clubs. I realise that they're there to keep the fans safe and out of restricted areas, but some venues treat the performer's guests like they're trying to scam the staff. The Fillmore is the complete opposite. They're extremely accommodating and want to make sure that friends and family have the best time possible, and always go above and beyond to meet this goal. They also have great VIP facilities to provide guests and performers with a stellar view from the boxes above the stage.

HDlXhmp4-YyuB9Kqde94_A.review_text: setting aside what a great little venue this is, can I just say that the food is fantastic?   I bought my husband a cheeseburger just as the kitchen was closing. It was AWESOME!! I expected concert food to be a "bend over, sucker" experience, but I actually feel like we got our money's worth.

022aferdlco0xwl9VL4B2g.review_text: It's a great space (+1 star), but that's all The Fillmore has going for it. Here we go...  "Corporate" doesn't necessarily mean "bad", but it does in this case. The Fillmore is a LiveNation/Clear Channel venue, so there are video screens on the wall running ads.  The staff SUCK. There are few things in the world as maddening as a person who lets a miniscule amount of power to go to their head, and the doormen at the Fillmore are among the worst. The bartenders are old, uncool and cranky.  Beers are small, expensive and come in clear plastic cups so they look like urine samples. Red cups, please.  If you saw a good show that, that's great. But I'm talking about the venue itself, and it sucks.

eOp1mWb77Q3F5EWVVx4nCQ.review_text: Simply put. the Quintessential concert venue in NorCal. just go. Doesnt even matter who is playing the ghosts here will keep you entertained! The lovelies who serve during sold out shows need to be tipped large!!! They are spectacular!!! Criuse on down for a show and stay around forever. Dont forget your poster at the door!!!

dim5Svrt-B1jvvQsOIX22A.review_text: I consider myself to be a lucky girl.  That is really random crap comes my way quite a bit and makes my life really interesting.  My first experience with the Fillmore is a good example of this.  I've been wanting to go to a show here for a long time, but I have a problem embracing new artists and music.  In all honesty, there are only 2 artists that I would give my right one to see.  They are U2 and Willie Nelson.  So how cool is it that my first show at the Fillmore is a Willie show!  And I didn't have to give up my right one to see the show!  Unfortunately, I was so preoccupied with getting to the front of the stage that I really didn't get a chance to explore the venue but it's very cool.  The Fillmore folks have everything covered too.  Since I didn't dare move from front row, I thought that my Whiskey River would be running dry.  No way!  The cocktail waitress regularly made the rounds to make sure that we were sufficiently lit for the duration.  And the people surrounding us were cool enough to make sure that we were lit in other ways too.  Willie was awesome!  He covered most of his classic tunes, and although there were less musicians than I was expecting, they were sharp and on key.  Well except for the Good Hearted woman duet.  He should stick to just playing music and not singing.  The posters that they distribute at the end are well worth the wait and will make a nice addition to my apartment.  Can't wait to come back!

cMSZp7Go1bPKEQMYqStaXA.review_text: Saw SMASHING PUMPKINS here last August. It was absolutely memorable. Its a small, intimate venue with good sound. I could almost feel Billy Corgan's sweat. Minus one star for expensive drinks.

0E1ZKpJBoyRSB7LKA6p5vg.review_text: Ah, let's see, who have I seen here? I remember seeing Mighty Mighty Bosstones and St. Etienne, and another group I can't recall... each time it was great fun and a good venue. It's standing-room only, so if you don't like crowds, you won't like the Fillmore. It's right along major buslines off Geary, so public transit isn't a problem.  Fillmore brings through a lot of great music and has an amazing heritage of great artists passing through. If you need parking, try the Japantown garage on the opposite side of Geary.  A caution to the single woman venturing down this way in the evenings: don't go alone if you venture south into Western Addition. WA has its creepy moments during the day (including a KFC with bullet proof glass between customers and the cashier), so go with a group of friends.

_v3z81xBi0ywHD14NqsNbw.review_text: The Fillmore is a nice, roomy venue, and they even have an upstairs area where you can look over the stage and crowd if you're not in the mood to be elbow to elbow with a bunch of strangers. Be warned though - all beers on tap are $9 per pint. They do offer a "deal" for a 24oz Coors on draft for $9 too if you're feeling wild.

jJlYRJXPdIolKbuqGiZ-CQ.review_text: This is my most favorite venue to listen to music in the city! I love, love this place.  Where else do all the new and old musicians play in SF?  Right here at the Fillmore!    There is nothing like walking in, grabbing an apple and then making your way onto the dance floor to save your spot.   The bartenders pour a great drinks- no complaints!  The lights start to dim and then they turn on the disco ball and you know that it's going to be a great night.  The music always sounds fab and the crowd is there to have a good time.  No one in your space and you always have room to dance.    I love that you can be 2 feet away from the band and sing along or you can be in the back at the bar and still have a great view of the place.   And there is nothing like a limited Fillmore poster!

bG6DkJKwhKMMQ0Z3GSOpmA.review_text: The Fillmore is steeped in history but it never feels old or outdated.  I was there with my girlfirend for Andrew Bird & Apostle of Hustle last night. We ran into a friend on the way in, sold an extra ticket to him & watched the show together, then ran into two friends on the way out (free poster, woohoo!) & got a free ride home.  The fact that it's one of the most legendary venues in the country aside, The Fillmore just Feels Lucky to me. Do I really need to get into they specifics of what makes it so special? With a legendary place like this, I think It kind of goes without saying.  [Which is really to say that I'm lazy today... but if I don't review the Fillmore now, when am I gonna do it?]

hkOiI-ctPYFuurzJZF6H9Q.review_text: Wow.  The posters.  The music (saw Morcheeba there last night - A.Ma.Zing... with a British accent to boot :).  The balcony.  The lights.  The drinks.  The views.  The coat check girl (who arranged all 5 coats on one hanger and then laughed as we carried the coats out like a corpse).  The acoustics.  The apples.   The history.   It's got it all.

xNKvmFn9FkyOo2gResdC0Q.review_text: I love the Fillmore!  Did the press/photography for The Testament/Lazarus A.D. show here. The chandeliers make me happy.

-dwzGfMkie647nJg-Ix6JA.review_text: You pretty much get the jist of the places from the many reviews already on the place. It's a killer joint to experience. Plus, your cell phone pictures come out decent... it makes it look like you were right by the stage- since that what you basically are when you're at the Fillmore.  I'm seen several different shows here & all have been really kick ass. The bartenders are friendly, especially the older rocker dudes. Last time I was there, I thought I had lost my keys but thankfully they were found & given to the coat check lady. They have apples out in the lobby area, & they've always been delicious, with a side of gin & tonic.   Though remember it's typically general admission, it's a giant hall. So do expect people to try & squeeze their way in towards the front. There will be people taller than you in front of you, & you just have to deal with it & try your best to get a glimpse of the show. Also, during the last show I went up front to meet up with a friend after getting a drink & some crazy girls were telling me that I was in their space. In the end, the show was fabulous!

rAU7K52qPWNSKDx6GGtJhA.review_text: I liked this music venue, for the few seconds my friend and I were there.  We went to see Angus and Julia Stone, if you don't know them, check them out.   We got to watch Angus and Julia perform a few songs.  It's a small enought venue that you get a good view of the band, unless there's someone tall in front of you.  Also, what's with the security guard telling me to stay behind the line when some girl with no rhythm passes it. My friend pointed out the acoustics weren't good either, I agree.

mZfnWW_DiZ3297rte-1JhQ.review_text: One of the best music venues in SF, resembles the European venues. If you are a music fan: don't leave SF without visiting The Fillmore. Great atmosphere and staff, big names, no seating in front of the stage, drinks available during the show, great climate control and a free apple and poster after wards. What else do you want? BTW in case you want to frame your poster: Cheap Pete's on Geary has the special Fillmore/Warfield frames.

l-ECea3knk6W_euS6-dSag.review_text: Billy Idol = Sold Out = No Poster?  WHAT?  Great Venue, but on poster?  REALLY?  Okay, so I was pretty upset that they didn't offer a poster for the sold out Billy Idol concert.  Can you tell?  I guess because he is a bit of a my history as a kid growing up, and I was really looking forward to that Fillmore Billy Idol poster for memories.  Not really sure why they didn't do a poster.  Someone said he may have sold out very close to the concert date - but it is Billy Idol.  C'mon, you should have had those posters pre printed months ago.  Okay, enough of that.  Great venue, great space, good acoustics, you can roam around which is great, bartenders aren't overly nice but not bitchy either and they pour good drinks.  Chandeliers inside as you are rocking out to whomever you are seeing = awesome.  If you haven't been - go early and check out the the wall of people who have played there.  Awesome.

UzUnpnlH1n346MDgaFMOmw.review_text: My not-so-little brother and I bought tickets to see Broken Social Scene at The Fillmore last week. I knew it was sad that I'd lived in the Bay Area for over 3 years and not been to this venue...but I had NO IDEA how sad. Little did I know how much this place would rock my world.  I'm speechless at the sheer numbers of amazing artists that have graced the stage at The Fillmore.  The history is mind blowing. The upstairs lounges/bars are so super 70's cool.  I love it.  In fact, I would be happy to spend a Friday or Saturday night, just chillin in the lounge with a glass of wine, checking out all the rad posters that adorn the walls.    The room itself where the artists perform is equally breathtaking in all its' retro-vintage glory.  I was mesmerized by the chandeliers for half of the show .  So classic. The room is the perfect size.  Intimate, yet large enough to get a crowd going.  Not too cramped so that you're smelling the person's armpit next to you while they're jumping up & down.  Plus, they blast the A/C and keep you nice and cool.  So nice of them!!  Seriously, I want to have a private party in here.  Get some old school artists to come in and rock out with me and some good friends.  I need to get the hook up.  Yes, this place is the kinda place where magical things happen and rock & roll fairy-tales come true.  I'm already booking tickets for another show next month.   I'm going to become a resident groupie at The Fillmore, just you wait!

URHf5mueYVR0vGuVPr1oUQ.review_text: The Fillmore is probably my favorite venue in San Francisco.  Both times I've been the crowds have been really great, and so has the music.  I recently saw Flogging Molly there and was a little scared when people started moshing and jumping around (hey it was fun when I was 18, but I'm not young anymore), but everyone was respectful and no one got hurt, it was a really fun show. I thought the free poster at the end of Sara Bareilles was a fluke, but I got one at Flogging Molly too.  I just checked out the calendar to see what other shows I should go to so I can start a collection.

hdQmOQmMZgN10AZZBxn1fQ.review_text: Decent Venue but be careful when dealing with Live Nation/Ticketmaster. They are scumbags

uDYNXKTd_cixNNfsyWg57Q.review_text: The Fillmore is great for intimate concerts and shows.  Located in a great area with lots of places to grab something to eat or a few drinks before or after.

5YuePrm0xXUjPJlP2VEW9A.review_text: As a venue, it doesn't get much better. This place is just awesome, so much history! Grab your apple, head upstairs to look at all the posters and be sure to get your own poster on the way out.  My beef is with the fans at the Jeff Tweedy concerts on February 8th and 9th. What the heck is wrong with you people??? Why on earth did you feel the need to shout out ridiculous comments at every single thing he said? Why are you still shouting out requests? Do you not trust him to pick his own goddamn songs? And to the woman behind me who shouted "Jeff Tweedy is an asshole!" No. You're the asshole lady, in fact you're an asshat! WTF are you doing spending $40 on a ticket for somebody you know nothing about, pushing your way up to the front and ruining it for everyone else???  Five stars to the people who go to enjoy the music and treat the artists with respect. Five stars to the awesome waitresses and coat-check people. Five stars to the white-haired friendly guy at the top of the stairs who welcomes everybody in and says goodnight at the end!  I love the Fillmore. Can't stand some of the asshat fans.  Oh, and to the guy behind me screaming "JEFFTWEEDYROCKS!JEFFTWEEDYROCKS!JEFFTWEEDYROCKS!" For about five minutes non-stop at the top of your lungs. You really scared me. You scared Jeff Tweedy too. You might consider seeking professional help.

aBfT6rp0tfhEyc7fWeuYJA.review_text:
Gotta love the Fillmore.  For people who don't know that there's a three hour difference between 8 pm and 11 pm - there's no explaining the Fillmore to them.  ["Doors opened at 8pm. Feist wasn't slated to play till ~11pm. Huh? A two f****** hour wait?"]  Ya gotta check the listing, or if the opening act isn't listed, call and find out the lineup, and then do the math....   
  Every show I've seen at the Fillmore has been great, even the shows that sucked.
   (Note in response to d.a.'s note to me: There are always opening acts.  Regarding their policy that you not go out for drinks elsewhere during the show and possibly come back loaded, which would jeopardize their liquor license if you left their establishment drunk off your ass even if they hadn't served you -- and your accusation that this represents "bad customer service" -- considering they are operating a business with posted rules and subject to the laws of the land,  I'd say the problem is not bad customer service, but bad customers.)

YmyYr3QPx30y2QYF8ZrkKw.review_text: san francisco is chopped full of great venues for music. from tiny little places like bottom of the hill or the independent, to more larger spots like the fillmore!   the fillmore is a classic spot and has hosted some of the greatest bands. it's location is in japan town, which is perfect for public transportation. sadly... now that i think of it... it has been a while since i've even been to the fillmore. i believe my last show there was to see dredg; which i still have my poster for! :D regardless of my lameness in seeing a show there in quite some time, i HIGHLY recommend. the sound is great, service at the bar is great and everyone there is always havin' a rockin' good time!

zTE8KUu2ukFQZ67fZypLtA.review_text: this one is tough to rate.  objectively, i'd rate it low, but subjectively, it's a different story.  it's not the nicest place to see a show, compared to some other venues in the city.  it's old, the ground shakes, the purple chandelier lights make it look like some haunted house, and it takes FOREVER to leave after the show ends.  Kinda like, when you're at the tolls to cross the bay bridge, it gets all traffic-jammed and once you're past the tolls you're scott free.  i never understood why it's so hard to get out of that place... it's so slow to get out of the main room but once you're in the hallway and the exit the pace picks up.  anyways.    oh yeah, drinks are small and expensive.  i ordered a vodka tonic, which they served in a PLASTIC CUP for $10!    but all the shows that i've been to at the fillmore have been really great.   i usually arrive just when the opening act ends and i still always manage to weave my way into a good spot and get a good view of the performer.   i've gotten to see some of my favorite bands here, and that always leaves a special impression.  and i love the fact that they give out posters.  i'm trying to collect them.   so, yeah, fillmore, you ain't all that but for some reason i'm still smitten.

8H9kvoPVaRQ2KckUACFCuA.review_text: My favorite venue of all time. Not too big, not too small --thats what i like about it - even when it's packed, you still feel like it's an intimate show.

Ngoitt973ygRCubn6tW9GA.review_text: I gotta be honest. After all the hype (mainly due to their unique poster sizes and historic shows), I was a little let down by the Fillmore.  Don't get me wrong, they draw good bands and the acoustics are nice, earning one star apiece, but there's really not much separating it from other good venues in the city (Great American, I'm looking in your direction). Of course, there's tons of history, but that's negated by ticket prices. Basically I'm giving them 2 extra stars for the shade factor of having a bucket of free apples.

lU9JP5Rxu-tineBODGWX0A.review_text: I like history.  It's fun and old.  The Fillmore encapsulates both qualities; and this is evidenced by the spartan framed concert posters obsessively mounted to cover nearly all the positive space of any of it's vertical walls.  Other endearing touches include the two rows of chandeliers that line the main atrium, general admission pricing for the stage right balcony seating, a full service concession stand with side act lounge performers, and a friendly top o' the stairs greeter.   It's reeling to think how many musical generations have passed each other (figuratively or literally), the older influencing the younger.  I wonder how often modern artists pause in reverence to the greats that shared the stage before them.   Ah, if only those hallowed, molding clad walls could talk.  They'd say, "there is a lot of sidestream pot ingrained into our plaster". I dunno, despite all that somehow a $40 ticket with a $9.95 service charge for  a one hour and ten minute show, and two $7 well Vodka and tonics in rinsing cups lead me to wonder, "what price, history*?"  *N E R D-come on fellas you were also forty minutes late...still Chad, man, hook a brother up with an industry job, we used to kick it back in the day, 'member?

Vnja4xoPVQ7BLXIsVy_cFw.review_text: Wear comfy shoes because unless you are like first in line and grab one of those balcony cocktail tables, you are standing all night. There are a few more tables along the wall on the ground floor, but they always seem to be reserved for the band or something. Small enough that you can easily run into your friends if you didn't make a firm plan for how to meet up.

8QMRRcq9d2DHDdcWZ3kQAA.review_text: I don't think i'm an expert when it comes to music venues.  In fact, i've only been to a handful of concerts.  I started my concert watching at a late age.  Anyhoo, i came here to see Natasha Bedingfield, The Veronicas and Kate Voegele.  When i got into the hall or room or whatever you call it, it looked quite classy with chandeliers and velvet looking  curtains.  Usually that stuff looks blah and gaudy, but it looked nice here.  I also think its because it was simply decorated.    The bar was open and quite spacious, however drinks cost me an arm and a pinky toe.  I stopped drinking after spending 20$ for 2 small drinks.  Small being the key word.  I wouldn't have minded if they had more alcohol and the cup was a tad bit bigger.  Maybe i'm just spoiled with cheap drinks now.    I would suggest wearing comfortable everything.  You'll be standing a lot.  And watch out for a short fat Natasha Bedingfield lover who will push his way in front of you and elbow your chest while dancing and cheering and screaming.  These are my warnings.

SZdWb5Byjlxpbj3dHcNOig.review_text: The best place to see a show.  The Fox in Oak. is close, but the acts that play here and the history that oozes out of the place....amazing.  You are only going to go here if you want to see a band that is playing, but this is the best place to see them.

mzGn1m7bwmMV0n9_2RK-jQ.review_text: Diverse bands?  Check.  Crappy acoustics? Check.  Legendary?  Check.  Overpriced shows?  Check.  Mobs and mobs of unruly fans?  Check.  Great neighorhood for people watching? Check plus.

Fb4IkSuAmEchILfkAUswsA.review_text: This is probably my favorite venue...although I'm a huge fan of the Warfield and The Greek Theater. This place has a ton of history and you can see it all over the walls with old concert posters (The Who, Cream, Grateful Dead, etc). I've seen about 5 concerts here and love how small it is. It is standing room only and there's not a single place that you can stand that is bad. Ofcourse the drinks are pricey, but that can be expected. If you get a chance to see a concert here, I would highly recommend that you do.

pK-aWPU1g8sI93jb3OGCsQ.review_text: I've enjoyed every show I've seen at the Fillmore.  They have clean bathrooms and the wait staff is incredible.  They walk around in the crowds and bring the drinks to you while you are busy dancing or rocking out.  I really enjoy the posters they give you when you exit.

tfDSt2MZ4Nz4UWX-2d-_HQ.review_text:
The Fillmore is a historical place. So many hall of fame musicians have played in this venue. From Santana to Greenday it's a great place to watch any band intimately. The walls are surrounded with classic poster art from the 60's to the present.  In fact, once you leave the show you will recieve a poster of show you just saw.- depending on availability, of course.
  Quirky fact: Once you go up the stairs of the main entrance, you will see a bucket full of apples. It's a tradition started by Bill Grahm as sign of 60's giving spirit.

mGken2qeT9lN_ZCtNMPyMg.review_text: If you ever get a chance to see your favorite band or any band at the Fillmore, you should go! Has a lot of history, the sound is awesome and it's a great location. You can park, at your own risk, at Safeway parking lot. It smells when you first go in, but you get use to it. I didn't get a chance to have a drink here, but that goes to show you don't have to drink here to have a great time.

vXYxtW_JpMMdjNzcw91u7A.review_text: Well, I think it goes without saying the The Fillmore is one of the top/best venues in San Francisco.   It's a combination of the beautiful chandeliers, the history of the building and the perfect dual level and size. I can't find much bad to say about the venue itself.   Sadly, the staff leaves some to be desired, though I do think they're getting better. I'm not a big fan of their food but totally appreciate that they even have a kitchen that does serves substantial meals.  I think my biggest beef with The Fillmore is the lack of control of the "scalpers" on the corner. Obviously there's not a whole lot that can be done about them, though I don't see an abundance of them at any of the smaller venues around the city. I guess thats the nature of "concerts vs. shows". I do however find them to be extremely annoying not to mention completely unethical. I have been treated very poorly by some of the staff of The Fillmore which I thought was totally unmerited, though I can certainly understand where the frustration roots from.  None of the above mentioned "gripes" will stop me from seeing a show at The Fillmore. The place is so inviting and such a pleasure and I do know some good people who work there.

eydaYzZbJ-2cLcEDA5d5hQ.review_text: The Fillmore gets a ton of ink as a great place to see music in San Francisco, and rightfully so.  While there are some really great things about the Fillmore as a venue, for my money, what makes this place special is the history, the energy, the tradition, and the lineups.  The upstairs is a great vantage point to see a show, so if you have a favorite act you want to see, get there super EARLY and get yourself a table overlooking the stage.  The floor can get pretty packed and crowded, so if you're not tall (I am) and if you get claustrophobic (I don't), or, worse... if your date does.... then be forewarned.  Parking can be an issue on and around Geary, and with the Boom Boom room across the street, parking can be a pain.    Don't forget to get a nice refreshing delicious chilled red apple on your way out ... courtesy of Bill Graham (did I mention great tradition?).

C2MlFhbt7vZWBnxuS40TUA.review_text: I came to the Fillmore to watch Atlas Genius, and absolutely fell in love with the venue. Located in the heart of Japan town with The Social Study just down the street.   The venue itself is spacious yet very intimate, which is so much better when you're listening to a band that you enjoy.   Full bar, nicely ventilated, and friendly staff. YAY!

vaQPHmzVAxOGNEtG3YLqjQ.review_text: Awesome place.  Big but still small enough to be intimate.  I saw Citizen Cope here last night and I had a great time.  Three bars, plus upstairs seating and bar.  The staff was friendly besides one old dickhead bartender.  They ran out of certain beers at one bar but if you just go to the other one they will probably have it.   Altogether a cool place, highly recommended.

Z4EcmBn7y82Wnfhl8CWB1g.review_text: I saw The Weeknd here almost a year ago (Late review, I know). Anyways, I love the history, intimacy, and art work in this place. The staff is really friendly. They also had a meet and greet with him after the show and gave out free posters which was way cool! I just wish they had enough for everyone that came instead of running out.

kWI4vMa6HX66hMb_OvgmSQ.review_text: Giving the Fillmore a 4/5 for all of the intangibles and for many wonderful memories over the years. But the sound quality for the Psychedelic Furs show last night was dreadful. I was standing right in the middle of the floor and it was just a terrible mush of noise, everything cranked up too high and overmodulated. I don't know if the band or the venue handles the sound, but someone messed up.

IbWSdnPb8UXbOS_J-sjrSQ.review_text: Bill Graham's house of sound,  Great shows; finest poster art,  Love the chandeliers.

ypOck0aEvaVnbECNFECpHA.review_text: I have enjoyed every concert I have been to at the Fillmore.  This is a great venue for many reasons. For one this venue is on the small side which I really like. The floor here is great because you can see the performing band fairly well even from the back.  I really enjoy venues on the smaller side because of having that visibility.  It is more of an intimate show.  I also like that there is no seating except for the balcony.  I am the kind of person that must be standing at a concert.  Sitting down while having a high energy live band in front of you is just wrong to me.  Get up and feel that music!  Also, it is easy to get a alcoholic beverages quick as well as non alcoholic as they have a self serve water cooler at the left corner too which is a great idea as no bartender wants to keep dishing out water at a concert.  Other than that how can you not love the chandeliers, the history of the great bands that have played there shown through the slew of posters on the wall.  If the show sells out (which very often does) you get a poster at the end. This is enough to keep me coming back.

FpOste6Fh4ppO7jol-JlQw.review_text: I really like going to the Fillmore to see bands. The atmosphere is cool with their chandeliers and you can get quite close to the stage. Sound quality of the venue is pretty good too. Parking is just a bitch... it's on the border of a good neighborhood and a bad one.

kVAX3H7CeLpLO4VCpG_K9Q.review_text: I agree with most reviewers that this is a classic SF venue with a spacious dance floor, good sound, and unique atmosphere. The only complaint I have about my experience at the Camera Obscura concert on June 8, 2009, was the attitude of the staff. While the waitress in upper bar was polite and helpful, most other employees I encountered were not in the least bit courteous. When lining up outside, not much direction was given to customers as to which line they were to get in, and a staff person yelled at the next customer in line to go to the window if they hesitated at all. During the concert I witnessed an employee grab a chair that a woman was trying to move from a table in the upper bar and gruffly say she couldn't move it. When the concert ended the employees were so eager to get people to leave they almost threw them out. My husband and friend were told to leave the bar area while waiting for me to use the restroom, and I heard others being told to wait for friends outside although it was only 11:30. I would not recommend a woman waiting outside by herself because of some of the people who congregated in the neighborhood. I feel that it's unfortunate that the staff didn't live up to the status of the venue.

iIn_sZxyyg5yv6jcAzcYFA.review_text: It's hard to hate the Fillmore.  I've seen dozens upon dozens of shows here since the 90's and simply have nothing negative to say about it, except of course the other concertgoers, but then that complain applies to ALL SF venues.  Maybe I'm just getting old.  Wait, I *AM* getting old.  Get off my lawn, you damned kids!  But back to the topic at hand, the bartenders are nice, the sound is uniformly good (unless the band's mixer stinks) and while it can get crowded sometimes, it never gets "Slim's-crowded".

zG6CNNmoid_KeXMtxTJSlQ.review_text:
Holy SHIT!  I am in love...No REALLY....I MEAN IT...with Spencer Krug, Wolf Parade's hot, brilliant, stolen voice, on fire, smoking genius.
  I think I slept with the poster last night.
  My poor date.

tODLF3MdIHT1zBfqSglJGg.review_text: Definitely one of my favorite venues. The sound is great, dance floor is huge, and like Gill said, it's amazing to think of all the great artists that have been there. Also, chandeliers are super classy.

MI5iO2V6s7LjxOxXZ_hVGQ.review_text: A San Francisco classic, what else do you need to say.  There's not a bad spot on the whole floor to stand.  The atmosphere is cool and you can understand why Jerry likes to keep an eye on the place.    If you haven't been, you're missing out.

Z7PZNpOfQu9xnQQSwpYKLQ.review_text: Do NOT patronize Live Nation or its Affliates!   I was absolutely humiliated at The Fillmore SF when I went to pick up my will call ticket for A Perfect Circle on Nov. 16th.  My brother gave me a great birthday gift this year.  Although it was a late present, he purchased a Meet and Greet ticket for me.  When we realized the ticket had his name on it and was only able to picked up via will call, my brother called LiveNation to resolve the name issue.  We were given specific instructions on how to address this problem.  Live Nation said that I should take a copy of my brother's credit card and the print out of the Live Nation confirmation page to the venue on the night of the show to pick up the ticket.  My brother even went as far as making a copy of his credit card, license, confirmation page, and confirmation email for me to take along as I flew from St. Louis, MO to San Francisco, CA for the show.    When the box office opened for the Meet and Greet ticket holders only, I was belittled as I presented all the information Live Nation instructed me to have.  I was accused of stealing my brother's wallet and ticket information.  As I explained the instructions given to me by my brother from Live Nation, the woman in the box office kept interrupting me, accusing me of nonsensical scenarios.  Her tone was not professional in the least bit.  She was yelling at me as if I were an idiot for flying across the country in attempts to steal my brother's will call ticket.  When I was not able to name the person my brother spoke to at Live Nation, she ended her accusations with calling me a liar.  "Now you're lying to me.  You're a liar!  You don't need to lie," is what I had to endure since she held my ticket.  I was afraid that she wouldn't let me retrieve the will call ticket if I stopped her from talking down to me and calling me a liar.  So, I stood there while she yelled at me in front of everyone for no good reason.  It was embarrassing, unprofessional, disrespectful and uncalled-for.  Unless you appreciate being called a liar and a thief by the woman running the box office, please spend your money with other venues.

OoND3zlU8KhVuPSE7N6gmw.review_text: The Fillmore is one of my favorite venues, and it's a favorite of artists, too.  There's a great history that goes with this place as you can tell by the innumerable posters all around that are custom-made for shows.  The venue is a great size - not overly big and not too small.    The venue has floor space on the bottom floor where I think you have a standing chance to make your way toward the stage.  The second floor has minimal tabled balcony seating and more places to stand.  I have always found a place to see easily, and the vibe here is great.    With this sized-venue, everyone there wants to be there, and it seems the crowds are the type that know all the lyrics to all the songs and not just what made it to the radio.  You might even have a chance of brushing elbows with your artist while there.    I'll wait to give it the fifth star when I verify that the women's bathrooms are decent...  What prevents me now: no easy access to BART which means I'm parking a couple blocks away at Japantown and fighting traffic to get there.

6QN6BdpcDKXNS9Xq_7pECQ.review_text: since clearchannel bought the fillmore, this place went down the drain fast.  I've been to over 20 shows here in the past and never had nothing but a good time.  the overaggressive new security here now sucks.  other than the supervisor outside understanding that i didn't know you can't leave and come back other than the designated smoking area.  oh they have signs, but they are small and the staff does not tell you when you're going in or out.   this place is being run by NAZI's now, i got thrown out after two songs into the headlining act, when i got shoved by a couple and i shoved back out of instinct.  then the big fat security gaurd grabbed me instead of the bigger guy that instigated and threw me out.  nice job fat arse, way to own up and be a man.  I've never been thrown out of a concert ever before, and this was ridiculous, i even had strangers as witness saying i didn't instigate the situation.  one star for the vintage venue, bartenders and the hot black girl that gave me advice.  one more star to the supervisor that let me back in, other than that, i wouldn't go back.   what a waste of $30 for nothing, $70 if you include drinks at the bar.  oh and BTW, clearchannel sucks arse and they own the SFweekly, so boycott!

IDVX4Is4CanREchBmpFXoA.review_text: I made my first pilgrimage to Northern California's Mecca of classic music shows just last night.  Embarrassed to admit that I had never been to this esteemed institution.  My cousin, a couple of friends and I went to see Lez Zeppelin and a number of other all-girl bands.  I won't add much since other Yelpers have covered it, but I do have to say I was in awe of the Poster Room, and stumbled around the edge of the room with my eyes fixed on its walls for a good hour.  Amazing history here....

gfTt6x6bLEpqPu9vIwgwmw.review_text: I love, love, love the Fillmore. I have always dreamed of going here, and I finally had the opportunity the other night to see Robert Earl Keen-who, by the way, was simply awesome.  I consulted my trusty Yelp before heading over to find out about the venue (I mean, besides the legend) I wanted practical info, like how early do you have to get there, when do the doors open, where can you park?  Yelp was helpful, but here's my personal take on The Fillmore. Here's all the stuff I was wondering about before I went:  #1 What time to get there? I guess cause REK is a Texas band, sort of country rock, maybe I didn't have to worry about getting there early (maybe he's not that big in SF). The show started at 9 so I showed up at about 9:30. There was an opening act-v. funny scruffy looking guy with sort of a cool voice named Hayes Carll (with 2 "L's," that's not a typo). I'd go see him again too.  #2 Where to park? Place was easy to find, no line to get in. I had a little delay because when I went to my garage, turns out my car had to be jumped so I couldn't drive (no point in driving 10 mins, then parking the car and having the battery die in the middle of a Japantown parking lot). So, I had to take a cab. I heard there was parking about 2 blocks away at Japantown Center, but b/c my car was dead, I didn't get to test that out.  #3 Can I get a cab home? I was worried maybe I wouldn't be able to get a taxi home after the show, but the band got done (way too early at about 12:30) and there were homeless guys on every corner with flashlights flagging down cabs (that were probably already coming over anyway) to pick up any wayward or inebriated REK revelers. P.S. The band's bus was parked right by the door. I was so tempted to wait for them to come out (recovered groupie).  #4 How is the staff? I was also worried about the staff (based on some of the reviews) but they couldn't have been nicer to me. I got a great spot right up front, no one stood in front of me and I had the perfect view. The guy at the top of the stairs was welcoming. (I didn't see the famous apples). The door staff was pleasant enough (they just did a cursory look into my bag). The staff looks like typical aging rock star wannabes, heavily tatooed and pierced, but everyone was very cool to me and I think they really love the music.  #5 What about smoking? I was also worried about smoking (based on some reviews).  I have long hair and am always afraid of some drunken idiot waving their cigarette around and catching my long locks on fire. I also hate the smell. A couple of knuckleheads in the middle of the crowd fired up some doobies, but it was far enough away that all it did to me was fleetingly remind me of high school.  #6 What about drinking? I was also worried about having to buy drinks/2 drink minimum because I'm not drinking at the moment and I thought I was going to have to pay, like, $10 for a cranberry juice just to hang. But, no problemo, no drinking necessary.  #7 What about the ladies room? Next on the list, I was also worrying about the ladies room, which tends to be a disaster in these situations (lines around the block, overflowing toilets, vomit, I could go on). But I went right after the band wrapped up and while the floor was kind of damp, I didn't have to wait AND there was toilet paper and a trash can so I gotta say-what more can you ask for at a legendary landmark?  The sound system was a little inconsistent-sometimes great and sometimes not, but overall, I couldn't have enjoyed this band and this experience more. I wanted the band to never stop playing. I'm almost afraid to go back I had such a good time. Next time I'm going to look at all the posters.  I'm headed to Slim's for a Reckless Kelly show in a couple of weeks and I'm curious to see how it compares.

YlJNqoHqIssCHP25h2sUFA.review_text: I can't tell you how many shows I've been to here...nor how many more I will go to.  But no doubt in my mind that this is my favorite medium sized venue in the city.  Obviously a great history with the venue....as soon as you walk in, you see pictures of the people who have played there over the years...amazing.  I love that no matter where you stand you have a great view....that you don't have to leave your spot in the front to get a drink as the waitresses come to you.    The only thing I don't like about this venue (hence the -1 star) are the staff they hire to "guard" the doors.  Immature, negligent morons...this guy was blasting rap music and rough housing with his friend while he was supposed to be "guarding" the back entrance.  Yelling at other "questionable" employees.  It was almost embarrassing.  I understand the need to hire big/tough guys to be intimidating, etc.  But the one main guy wasn't tough or intimidating...just annoyingly loud and obnoxious.  Waiting outside after was already painful as it was cold, but it was made even more painful having to listen to this guy blast his music and watch him dance around like a fool.  But despite all this, I'll be back to the The Fillmore again and again...

TSdV_lsddT4F3TJvmdmXag.review_text: Smashing Pumpkins (an epic 3.5 hour show).  She Wants Revenge.  VAST.  And tomorrow, A Perfect Circle.  Probably even more, but due to my wild and wanton youth of, well, going to concerts completely sober, I don't remember.  I can't exactly hear well anymore, either.  (It was a Big Deal when I could finally come to the Fillmore and order a beer.  I'm all grown up!)  The Fillmore never disappoints, whether I am by myself, with friends, or even with my mom.  The place reeks of San Francisco history (with which they hit you over the head - photos of all the bands that have played there line the walls, including the Doors).  The concert hall itself is lined with red velvet curtains and sparkly chandeliers dangle from the ceilings.    Not that you notice when the music starts, because it's a medium-sized venue, and you're likely up close to the stage.  (If Billy Corgan happens to be singing to you, it becomes even less of an issue.  Oh, MY.  Did you know he's tall?  I had no idea.)  Acoustics are good, beer is expensive, and you're guaranteed to have a good time.

j6wi6vCSwRmLddf9JX9QAg.review_text: I'm very sad about the canceled Dethklok show but this place has been going down hill since Live Nation took over.  pros  ~not too big ~gorgeous venue ~can park at the Kabuki  cons  ~expensive drinks if you can fight your way to the bar ~expensive drinks if you can get the bartender to stop flirting   with the customer before you and serve a drink ~forced to deal with ticketmaster  If I don't get refunded for last night's tix INCLUDING 'SERVICE' CHARGE-I'm over this place for good!

qY_Fqotvurh57OUPdwsjxA.review_text: How can you not love the Fillmore? They get awesome shows, give out sweet post-concert posters, and the quality of sound and space is predictably wonderful. They have the apple tradition, iconic greeter, decent drinks, nice employees, an efficient enough coat check, and most importantly, generally attract a fun crowd.  I love that you can grab anything from a swank dinner, pizza, or sushi nearby pre-show, and can easily grab a cab home or out after.   One note: don't try to bring in your Sharpies. Apparently they've had "issues" with them and my favorite was nearly confiscated until I reassured them I'm no teenage vandal, but merely a dedicated list maker.

X9NXcUK6nkcUPJs3qNT6qA.review_text: I've had a great time at all the shows I've seen here  So excited to go back for the Pumpkins!

lPEw9TDXwgflO16jFxZSbQ.review_text: All this AND a free apple?! Wow. Long may they rock.

IBZMvu2dTKy-j23qCJgVWQ.review_text: The Fillmore was a great place to see Bryan Adams. (This was years ago.) I'd never seen one of his shows before, so to see him in this intimate setting was fantastic! I love the sound quality here. There's an eerily special feeling about being in a place where so many legendary acts have played. That is, if you care. If you don't, it's just a small, cozy, warm place to see a concert.   I think the evening was unfairly good for a rock concert. Very civilized crowd, no pushing nor shoving, not even any b.o. or drug smell. Guess a higher class of people are into Bryan Adams. I think a venue like this is worthy of his talent. Sure wish more acts could/would play small venues, impracticality notwithstanding.   Personally, I like being able to sit at a concert, and that wasn't possible. Everyone stood for the entire time. It was worth it though.  My date paid for our concert tickets (don't be so impressed; I sprung for dinner!), so I don't know how much it cost. However much it was, my date did NOT get laid, which he'd seemed to expect...doh! Dating can really be ridiculous! Or I'm really old-fashioned!  Oh well, I saw a great show so I was happy! Neener neener neener...

ermgOO9meehk-dfG0Fsfhw.review_text: I really like this venue, I saw matisyahu here, which was cool.  I'd say something about how it was funny to see so many orthodox jews here dancing, but i dont want to offend anyone... It's a nice venue and works for me.

oyafQewwib7_gyboN5zP6A.review_text: This legendary music hall doesn't disappoint.  Beautiful building, good acoustics and a decent size...  big enough to have a good vibe from the crowd, but not so big that the crowd gets overwhelming.    I love seeing bands that play here several nights per year (like Railroad Earth, or other Jam Bands) -- every time they come, it feels like they're coming home to perform at one of their favorite places.    But my absolute favorite Fillmore memories come when I see a band play their first show at the venue.  Many times it's a "breakthrough" moment for the band, as the Fillmore has such a reputation.  It's awesome how excited these new bands get, and sometimes when I see the same band at a different venue later on, they're just not quite as jazzed.    Whether it represents "home" or "making it" to the band, I've never been to a bad show here.    My only complaint is the excessive fees Livenation tacks on for online ticket purchases.  So annoying!

RdtxmBQJ8qcpwnkH7pJD2w.review_text: I love these old venus! I imagine a time of old when couples would make a night of it, going to the ballroom, listening to the big bands, dancing the classic dances while sipping cocktails that ended in "gimlet" or "collins".  Pat down by security at the front door (not me, but definitely the men) to check for cameras (but not weed apparently). Small bathroom with long lines (as is usual, being a girl), but really fab venue. Open main ballroom with upper balconies. Sound was good at a recent concert (Cake). Good number of bars setup to accommodate those of us who want a cocktail with our music. And posters and red delicious apples post concert.   I love places like this. Bad ventilation. Small venue. Bitchy staff.

l7APd9D45Hzzm4TeWAcgmg.review_text: Saw the Lawrence Arms here - awesome venue.  The security tripped out on me as I went outside without asking them for their 'permission" and I barely got back inside - I guess I should be so fortunate when I read others stories.  The sound was the best of anywhere I've been - although I need to learn to stop standing about 10 feet away from PA speakers with no ear protection!  Sigh, good times.  This place is definitely worth checking out for those who have never been - it's a historical monument for crying out loud.

2dHv6iSsCfCxjl1538ckdQ.review_text: The Fillmore is a classic venue that can't be missed.  I love the size of this place, not too big, yet big enough to attract acts that won't (can't) do small hole in the wall joints.

kVwvb9vW0sPBGryY8slB-w.review_text: I went here for the Macklemore concert (round four, still AMAZING), and I was very impressed.  It's vintage looking and definitely has personality.  The personel gave out water and kicked out people that were smoking on the bottom floor.  Also, got a free poster!   Tip #1:  Since the general tickets are standing room, get there early if you want to be in the front row.   Overall: Liked this place, a lot!  I would come back here.

1yOolvcXwg1K80hFm3NK7w.review_text: Everyone knows exactly how awesome this venue is. The posters at the end of the night are off the hook, the drinks are strong and well priced as well.  A recent discovery though is a bucket of apples which sit at the entry way, I guess it's been a traditional since The Fillmore opened.   Great venue, this place should be part a historic landmark of SF.

pR1zHvaWixOCPTEsbsRiRg.review_text: I have seen many concerts here. From Erykah Badu, Cypress Hill, the Meat Puppets, Smashing Pumpkins, etc. This venue is so intimate no matter where you are standing you will have a great view, unless you are standing behind a really tall person. They even have servers that slice into the crowd to take orders so that you so not lose you spot, hoe genius is that! The Fillmore rocks and I love the free posters that they give after the shows!

LSTy4uYzx4M9jR7EFgYZcQ.review_text: This is not a review of the Fillmore as a concert venue.   (it's my favorite place to see a show)   It's a review of their kitchen - which has gone WAY downhill since the last time we were here.   Whenever we go see a show here, it has been our tradition to stand in line early so we can grab an upstairs table and eat while the place fills up.   We won't be doing that anymore.    Shitty ingredients put together sloppily.   How do you fuck up nachos?    It sounds bitchy, but it use to be SOOOO good.  What happened?

bl40TJ6NyleKGx4JfOYObA.review_text: Great piano rock show by Page McConnell last Tuesday.  It wasn't too crowded--mostly pot-smoking, die hard Phish fans in the audience.  I don't care about him, especially, and I didn't bring any weed, but I love live music and wanted to take my little brother, who was visiting from St. Louis, to the Fillmore.  And the Fillmore is a sure thing.  Pick a show, any show, and get over there!  The drinks seem expensive but they're stiff and the cheeseburgers are yummy.  Order food upstairs in the cafe area.  Say HI to the bouncers and other staff at the entrance--they make you feel welcome even as they frisk the hell out of you.

9GCCoFw_UHiAHjZ4kygHgw.review_text: Best venue to see a show in San Francisco hands down. No competition! Ill be seeing Billy Corgan on the 15th and I cant wait because there is not one single bad seat in the house. Well unless you get the Yugoslavian basketball team in front of you like I did at the Killers ...but whatever. The place is great, and rich with tradition. I cherish each poster I get at the end of a show. So fun  TWO THUMBS UP

owhZlcoG5lSCThiR5MqOtQ.review_text: I've seen many great shows here, one of the best music venues in SF IMO. Historic posters and general ambiance are great. Drinks are expensive (as usual with music venues), but lines aren't usually too long, and the second bar in back is nice. They are also great at accommodating people with mobility issues. My friend recently tore her ACL, and is on crutches. They will set up your whole party at a table on the right side of the room, as well as allow access to the elevator for getting upstairs.

_wtXEXgvVc7ryMVrQW4EMw.review_text: Aaaaaahhh. The Fillmore! It felt like years since I'd been to this place (probably because it was) but I was here on Saturday to see Social Distortion - Yeah baby! I haven't lost ALL my cool!    Leaving the club, I was getting all reminiscent of past visits to see so many great bands over the years, from Liz Phair to Big Star.  As much as I hate crowds, I didn't mind being sandwiched in with the rest of the "herd" as we were slowly corralled out of the stairwell, because a) I was a little buzzed, and b) I knew I could look forward to at LEAST one of three things as I exited the building:  - A cool poster of the band (woohoo!) - A nice shiny red apple (ok they didn't have those on this particular visit but I was OK with it) - A big, jovial farewell greeting from the staff: "Thanks for visiting the Fillmore!!!"  Awwww! I love it how the doorpeople always do that last thing. It's so nice to see some things never Change : )

I0MMq4iYjDjERnSjp76HDw.review_text: This is such a beautiful theater! I would give it 5 stars except that my car was broken into (parked on Geary) while I was there, so I have to say the parking SUCKS. Other than that, I love the place.

4zXEET9KfvpC6a2qoN2V5A.review_text: My latest crush took me to the They Might Be Giants show here last night.  It's a very cool venue...very steeped in tradition...very cool to see all the posters in the room upstairs...a chronology of the bands that have played here over the years.  It appears to be a strictly general admission venue, where everyone stands, except perhaps for the VIP sections upstairs.  I very much like this, as you can stand where you like and still have a great, somewhat intimate, view of the band.  All of the employees were friendly and helpful, and they seem to very much enjoy doing what they do...from will call, to security, to the bartenders, to the DJ upstairs.  It almost seemed to me that they know they are part of music history as it is happening, and behave as though they are appreciative of such an opportunity.  This, of course, is just my subjective observation, but you can get a sense of when someone is grateful and content doing what they are doing.  It really made for a very positive vibe...without any attitude whatsoever.  Lesbian ladies listen up...although nature has cursed me with a preference for men (simple but perplexing creatures) there is a very attractive female bartender on the main level that is a total hottie with a killer smile.  I didn't get her name, but she has very dark, long curly hair with very blond highlighted sections that frame her face.  She is a beauty, with a killer smile and lovely, warm eyes that will stop you in your tracks.  She oozed an effortless sensuality and genuinely friendly quality as she served us.  I can't speak for her sexual preference, but if I were a lesbian I would have definitely given her my phone number.  She was delightful!  As for me, I play for team hetero, so I spent the entire concert in the arms of my incredibly handsome and magnetic date...one of the aforementioned simple but complex creatures....and in that moment there was no where else I would have rather been.  We are both fairly tall...him over 6 feet and me 5'8 and wearing 5 inch heels....so we stayed toward the back of the venue and had no trouble seeing the band.  The benefit to standing toward the back is that you have easy access to the bar, bathroom facilities, and can exit rather quickly.  I also thought it was really sweet that when you exit the show, there is a friendly man who stands just to the left of the stairs, thanking you for coming, inviting you to return, and stating that he hoped we enjoyed the show.  Awwwwww.....does it get any sweeter than that?!  When is the last time you got THAT kind of love from a total stranger at his place of work?    FYI...the free concert posters are only offered when the show sells out TWO WEEKS in advance...so know before you go, so you're not disappointed if they aren't distributing them.

R_7aY1O4mNJdBbmnBzqhTw.review_text: I've attended about 2500 to 3000 live music events at various venues. Very few venues get 5 stars as The Filmore has received from me.   The first time I attended a show at The Filmore I was intrigued by the historic significance of the venue for live performances. Walking into the building is like walking into the past. The walls are adorned with posters of the performers that have played on the stage. I still haven't had an opportunity to look at all the posters.  The stage is well setup, lots of room. The sound system, from where I normally place myself is excellent from about 15 feet away from the stage. I like to call it the sweet spot.   When the band starts to plays, the floor starts to flex with the beat. The people are courteous. During the breaks you can go to the bar get a drink and get back to the same spot before the break.,unlike other venues. I won' t mention the venue.  A little tip for bands wanting to provide your fans with an experience. Book yourself at The Filmore.

aAeJAsRKC--Qkg1_LDzPcQ.review_text: I love the Fillmore! It's one of the BEST venues in the bay. It's big and spacey but intimate enough for you to enjoy the show from anywhere you stand. I've never had a bad experience and I've been to a LOT of shows here.
