I'd take away a star for parking but I always end up finding awesome parking (sometimes right away but usually after a few circles) and the free posters at the end makes up for it. =)

UnwlB_CahheIvLuANmcWBA.review_text: A little while back I was sent to work an event here. What was the event?....METALLICA 30 yrs going! Now, I am not a"METAL HEAD" however I can appreciate not only the sheer tenacity of a group such as them, but the history that has come through that building!  Such is my review about. It did seem as though if the "next one" did come that building was coming down.  But I really did not care. Everyone and I mean EVERYONE has performed there. Knowing that made it a pretty cool day for me! Even more so, my friend, who is a Metal Head was outside with no ticket trying to get in!! LMAO

q48tKJZG2wwBhzNPWeaBtA.review_text: Kathryn T. and Leggy Laura B., on foot, somewhere on Fillmore north of Geary...  Kathryn T: I feel like we've passed Geary already  Leggy: We passed Geary a while ago...  Kathryn: What? Why didn't you say something???!  Leggy: Well, I though it was on Fillmore [looks at ticket]. What the fuck, 1805 Geary? Why isn't it called "The Geary?"   What a fantastic venue! I can't believe I've lived here for an entire year without seeing a show at the Fillmore.   Oh, and it's not *that* hard to find. Actually, you can't miss it:                                                                   I                                                                 I                                                                 I                                                                 I G                              ******************     I E                                         THE                I A                                    FILLMORE         I R                               ******************    I Y ___________________________ I_______________  FILLMORE                                           I                                                                 I                                                                 I                                                                 I                                                                 I                                                                 I                                                                 I

S774-lIfd1i5u4kxG5NBbQ.review_text: Great place to see a show. I saw the Smashing Pumpkins here last year and it was fantastic. Any place you stand you can see the stage.

1xvmDofA0MvWDSD2hJAvyw.review_text: Probably the best venue in the city.  Its small and intimate with the most incredible history.  All the best artists from back in the hayday have played here.  And the posters on the walls remind you of that.  There is a restaurant upstairs as well as a number of bars scattered throughout.  And if you're lucky and stay till the end of the show, they hand out free posters of the band you just saw.  I love this place.  If you live in SF, make sure to catch at least one show here.  It's totally worth it.

ZkOmb0VTGQRQEWhhvBn0Zw.review_text: If rock were a religion (and I do believe it is) then the Fillmore would be the cathedral for SF.  I'm a whole-hearted So Cal dude, so for me to compliment a Nor Cal establishment means A LOT.  I drove up to see the Smashing Pumpkins in the summer and the first thing I noticed when entering the venue were POSTERS... galore. It seems like nearly every rock band has strummed a power chord that echoed through its walls. The Fillmore is in no way the stereotypical trashy rock venue. There's a certain classy elegance to the place with an attitude of course.  The only reason the Fillmore lost a star from me is because for what ever reason that night, we were not allowed to go out and light up a cancer stick. I mean seriously, I drank 5 gin & tonics + whatever else in the parking lot (shhhh), I need my nicotine!   Overall, in the words of my fellow Nor Cal folks; the Fillmore is still HELLA COOL.

KSy4ygB4k_rSaUj9_U7vMg.review_text: I love this place.  There's so much history!   Not to mention, they give free apples and posters.   In between bands' performances, I enjoy looking at all the framed posters and photos on the walls.   They have a nice upstairs room to hang out  and listen to some unknown musicians before the show.  I'm giving it five stars even though their drinks could be better.

IgYlW_2YYeTg2uyg_9V52g.review_text: A classic old time venue that is intimate enough for any large or small act. My personal reccomendations are to see the more established bands here in this smaller setting. The best part is its history and charm. For concert goers or casual fans, it's a must. For city dwellers, take advantage of purchasing your tickets there (sundays I believe?) to avoid those surcharges.

Mt0CBc2ExBfu9A8GnWlk4g.review_text: How can you not love the Fillmore? Apart from its shady location, you get free apples if you want, a kindly old man greets you amiably; a large, spacious wooden dancefloor to get down, lovely chandeliers up high and a myriad of posters on the walls upstairs. The Fillmore is just so grand. Also, I've been to some great shows here, like Ladytron and Hot Chip. You can never complain about the free posters they give out at the end when shows are sold out as well. I love you, Bill Graham for giving us the gift of the historical and beloved Fillmore :)

5-adubQIwf-LBMFyl7r11A.review_text: Awesome place to see a show! Not too massive, but big enough to attract some of the bigger acts. I have many fond memories of this place. An sf music staple for sure.

0aEsYrwrBHE4LRgvv-A2yg.review_text: I only knocked a star because it always seems like I have no cash going into the place and hate playing ATM fees.  Ugh.  Otherwise, I've seen the Pogues and Yo La Tengo here and really, really enjoyed both shows.  It's such a cool venue!  The balcony, the furniture, and the awesome acoustics, not to mention the walls absolutely covered with band fliers.  Really dig, and it's like a whole TWO blocks from where I live.  Sweet!

CFxgyVEQxmnfpg3JvK2DnQ.review_text: This place is alright.. in my opinion, either not intimate enough (on the edge of the crowd), or a little too intimate. I guess either one can be a good thing, depending on how much you're feeling the music. It does host some pretty rad shows, though, so I cant complain. And, free posters... yea baby.  UPDATE: having experienced a wider range of music venues in the area, and having seen a few more shows here, I will say that the Fillmore is one of my most-liked spots. This, due to the location, the size, the optional balcony seating, and the acts it draws.

JsEIuZPzsbF0DTENYTcrdQ.review_text: It's a great venue, but it's totally gone down hill. I feel like I live back in philly again with the way I get searched when i walk in.   Plus, the bar tenders and security treat you like dirt a lot. There is one cool guy who works the top of the stairs at the entrance. He's old school and he rocks.  Probably one of the few things left there that is good since CLEAR CHANNEL TOOK OVER.   barf.

jxdGL90JR1b6UTvfxwW9TQ.review_text: Okay...I just cannot stand all night. Not in heels, not in flats, not even with my ass leaning against the wall.  Yes, it's beautiful in here, and rock legend vibe oozing all over the joint and very nice people who work here and easy to see the stage even from the back.....but still. No can do. I tried, my friends, I tried. And let me tell you - not being able to stay for all of Trombone Shorty KILLED me. Oh - and not only me - my 12-year-old son (admittedly tired from a long day already) couldn't hack it until the end because he simply couldn't stand the whole time. Missed out on his poster :-( Now it can't go along with his Jamie Cullum poster :-(  :-(  :-(  Yes I know there are benches in the lobby - but you can't see from the benches in the lobby. And the side tables/benches are impossible to get so don't even hope to do it. Anyhow, I'll just have to see bands at the Warfield and the Fox which have seating options.  If I ever could get a seat here it would be 5 stars, no question.

SZq4WeQXRFkU5JtesPjVkg.review_text: Easily one of the most perfect venues I've ever been to for all of the reasons listed here.  Love the history and the old-school theater feel and the bartenders are quick and friendly.  In fact, all of the staff here are typically very friendly.  That goes a long way in my book.

xObzTAC6gsFH6XKhc9yRYQ.review_text: A poster, and apple, and great place to watch a show. Try to come early, and tons of street parking. I really don't know much to say best this is the BEST PLACE to see a show!

J3GhokDy-I4GHvpHebc-Eg.review_text: SO.  I fucking love this place!  Why?  Because I fucking LOVE Jarvis Cocker.   I'm sitting at my favorite greasy spoon last saturday, and pick up a Guardian to check out what's going on that night.  And bam!  Right there in my face is Jarvis Cocker at the Fillmore!  WTF!  OMG!  Where have I been the last few months?!  With my head under a rock?!  How did I not know this?!   Seriously, time to stop focusing on work so much. My head started spinning, and it was a very good thing I was sitting down.  So, in spite of the very cute young guy reading the Economist (no kidding) next to me trying to pick me up, I had to high-tail it out of there.  Then what?  No surprise, there are no tickets left! Craigslist, my dear yelper friends, is a veritable fucking wonder.  I love Craig now too, b/c he hooked me up with a fan named Bruce, I got the ticket at face value price.  Unbelievable.  Awesome. Okay, on to the Fillmore, this place is fantastic.  Nice seating area upstairs with a very tasty veggie burger and drinks, and then an open floor in front of the stage which felt very intimate.  Not so intimate that I'm gonna throw my bra up on stage or dangle hotel keys in front of Jarvis like some other chicks, but y'know what I mean.   And how was Jarvis?  Everything I thought he would be.  I didn't hear any Pulp classics, but they were so unneeded.  The Jarve is an amazing songwriter, and his performance was that of an artist who really knows and accepts himself, and this was the essence of his "cool".  Could I have had this experience at a big stadium?  No.  Thank you Fillmore!

fwOWGMHDOl62VCVVX7FTEw.review_text: "Can I have 2 Cran & Vodkas please?"  "Sure...be right back."  *5 minutes transpire...*  "That'll be $43.00"  5 stars for that awesome ownage by The Fillmore.

8w8ZB4jT-s6-mP3m3kG-wg.review_text: Some are critical of the Fillmore, but that's what happens when you just show up for the free (and usually disappointing) posters. The sound can be a little too hot at times but I love this place - even when I had some dopey white guy behind me singing along at the top of his lungs when I finally got to see Spoon here the other night. It's OK dopey white guy. We all get excited sometimes.

7z-Crwkwo3wyngtjFhdJ9A.review_text: I LOVE THE FILLMORE  All-American Rejects had a concert here back in '04~ and it was my first concert in SF.  It's a huge venue with chandeliers and two floors  to chill on.. a huge stage and awesome sound system/lights.   They didn't let us bring in a camera but not sure if this rule has changed.  (hope so..)  It got really crowded but ... it's a concert ... I had a really great time.    I love the chandeliers...

DufatVBYtlSm96ReNzHL8Q.review_text: venue/sound is good. The two women bartenders on weekends are bitchy and one doesn't know the difference between tonic water and normal carbonated water.

vs7MuwvZyEDRRzKoeCyXzw.review_text: I mean, come on - this place is legendary.  I've been to quite a few concerts here and to be honest, I'd see anyone play at the Fillmore.  There are 3 different bars inside and the bartenders are awesome.  Hardly ever have to wait more than a minute to get a drink.  Only thing is there are restrictions on where you can stand but security will promptly tell you to move if you are in the way.  I love the posters of all the artists upstairs and the legends downstairs.  All around great vibe at the Fillmore!

-YriBqQEyD42GaGMd1LNgA.review_text: Is only the BEST place for Live Music

BFwteX1YUsNi67_S3q0Mkg.review_text: What an amazing venue!! Simple love the Chandeliers (kindof halloweenish with all the lighting!), sound system, and diverse crowd.   Definitely will look forward to attending more concerts there!

-vdo-XDggc2QNmdqRA9YOA.review_text: Seriously, I'm review # 598?! Holy crap! I guess I'll keep this brief then...  The Fillmore is great, a beautiful historic venue in the center of the City with great sound, friendly staff, and fantastic sight lines from pretty much anywhere in the house. It's no wonder so many good bands choose to play here year after year. I have friends who frequently fly up north from LA to see shows here because they just can't get over how great their Fillmore experiences always are. I wish they still consistently made the concert posters for which they've become so distinctly known but beggars can't be choosers, right?

mphxa3ZNSmw4M33-4nq1oQ.review_text: Saw Imogen Heap there last year and was impressed with the sound quality. The free apples and posters definitely make this venue distinctive from others. Decor is nice, lighting is just perfect. For my concert buddies and I, Fillmore is definitely our favorite venue. It's not too big, which allows closer interaction between performers and audiences; yet, it's not too small; at least big enough to accommodate more popular artists.   Parking isn't too bad either since we can always park at Japantown's parking structures.   Can't wait to see Yeasayer @ Fillmore on April!

HT8kyFqLLDsyHGZ34LMtcw.review_text: Probably my favorite place to see a show at.  Great acoustics, intimate feel, and so much history at this venue.  I've seen a  lot of different shows ranging from hip hop (The Roots) to rock (Smashing Pumpkins) and they have all been great.  I also love that after a show you usually get a poster.  If you have a chance get there early and look at the posters and pictures of artist that have performed there over the years.

q8iD3AScUmve99Fv3lrvOw.review_text: Listen... I have seen concerts all over the country at venues large and small, and there is nowhere I'd rather see a show than at the Fillmore in San Francisco. This is it people, the original, one and only Fillmore - no matter what ill-conceived branding idea LiveNation comes up with, remember that THIS place is the REAL deal. Music as we know it comes from this place. The staff at the Fillmore is the best: knowledgeable, polite, helpful and funny - in a word, pros. The main room is awesome - not too big or too small, the sound is phenomenal, and the acts that come through are top notch. They have several bars so there is rarely a wait, and the food they serve upstairs in the poster room is pretty good. The posters themselves are incredible - they have them all framed and hung in order, so it's like going to a rock and roll museum where the history of the San Francisco sound is displayed in a chronological kaleidoscope. And if you happen to get hurt or become ill at a show, the Fillmore Medical staff will take the very best care of you and make sure you have a safe way to get home, instead of kicking you out into the street or calling the cops (or your parents). And best of all, after some shows the staff passes out a real Fillmore poster of that night's show to you as you leave the building. There really is no place like it anywhere! Respect!

ZZlylZYQK2YgkugH42ieOQ.review_text: Venue is spacious but slightly outdated, staff is friendly and there is a lot of space to roam around from the main floor. My biggest gripe is their lighting, the strong blue and purple lights drown out anything that it shines on - it's an eye sore when you're watching a performance for a few hours. It makes it hard to take decent photos!

OFNFtTc48LmXNk_NeZe9dw.review_text: Great place to see your favorite artists. Get there early... head to the front and enjoy! I have yet to see a bad show at the Fillmore. I have seen all types of shows here too and it is great no matter what genre, age group, or craziness level it gets in there. The only thing I dislike, but I wouldn't take a star away for it because no matter where you go... there will always be the "I must get high while at a concert" crowd... I don't get it... is it really that much better if you kill some brain cells?   The convenience fees can be avoided by getting your tickets at the box office when they are open before a show or on Sundays from 10am-4pm.

GX1hc62D2u_QkZKy_yHRHw.review_text: Fuck the filmore. I waited in line for hella long which isnt the issue. But the fact that i couldn't buy a drink was hella weak, specially when they tell me the bars closed but i see people still buying drinks. If i need a special pass tell me that dont lie to me. Then on top of that every where i went i kept getting moved from. I cant stand in this area but when i come back around people are huddled there. I cant sit on the couches even tho im the only one in the whole section. Shit was hella weak, specially for some shit that wasn't even packed like that so fuck the filmore, your business is no longer welcomed with papp johnson

mMqGnoQgsivB8ZvSsvnIIw.review_text: The way the floor shakes is going to make you worry about your safety but after awhile you wouldn't care.  They also give you a free poster for every show.    Chris from We are Scientists jumped into the crowd for a bass solo and would have stayed there forever if Keith didn't say, "hey buddy, I think it's about time to make it back here."  and even so he jammed in the crowd for another minute.   Kyp from TV on the Radio pointed to a dancing girl a few feet to my left and the bouncer picked her up and put her on stage, where she rocked out with the band for a song.  if I were to ever make it big that's what I'd do too.  I'll throw a stick at a girl and knock her out, then a groupie can carry her unconscious body onto the stage and place her next to me.  I just have to practice my aim.  "Here you go," says the groupie. "This is not the girl I want!" "Hey, I just followed your stick." "But he is a man!" "Dude, what you do is your business."  I'll just keep throwing until I get the right one.  *swoosh*  Somewhere in the room someone wails.

-M7-eB1J7k9avBrYWSaBiQ.review_text: So with nearly 500 reviews written about this place, I don't think there's any really original praise I could heap on The Fillmore, but hey.  This place is in my book the gold standard of friendly service and an all around well managed experience.   From the guy in the hat cheerfully greeting you at the door, the giant tub of fresh apples to keep you rockers scurvy-free, to the intensely intimate concert venue experience, The Fillmore really has it all.   Now, I haven't seen many Yelpers note this, but I recently learned that The Fillmore also has really great food.  Now, I wouldn't have even considered that this place might have decent food if it weren't for a series of pre-concert mishaps that had The Fella and I arriving kinda late for our viewing of Camper Van Beethoven.  We got there during the opener and ducked upstairs to see if we could fill our empty bellies with chips or something.  The guy working the cash register suggested that the food is actually quite good, so we went ahead and ordered a hamburger and a plate of Peking duck.  The hamburger completely blew away our expectations and the Peking duck was actually amazingly good!  So, next time you're coming here for a concert, consider eating here too!

YUP31CYNNuQe-7KR1bCMiA.review_text: ive been there a few times with my friends thing about this place that i like is that you are able to smoke in the rooms i forget if k-net lets you but w.e their very w.e if you bring food or drinks inside  plus their music selection is verry good they have soo many upto date songs also they have happy hour something b4 9 if i can remember

rlnWz8Tm_bnp5IBwnpcjcA.review_text: Ok so i have seen some pretty good shows here (animal collective) oh wait ok so they were the best.  the best this place has to offer is the free limited poster they hand you on the way out. this is cool because it's only offered that night so its an instant collectors item.   the cons:  the bouncers are dicks the drinks are way way way overpriced the shows are way overpriced the food blows the crowd usually sucks   the pros:  free poster decent sound  screw this place go to bottom of the hill, 12 galaxies, balazo, or the hemlock instead

gjhzKWsqCIrpEd9pevbKZw.review_text:
I suppose it really all depends on who you're coming here to see. 
  When I saw the Roots here I loved everything about the place. I loved that the band could hop off stage, walk into the crowd and play drums on a trashcan right next to me. The size of the venue seemed perfect.
  But then I ended up on a not-so-great first/last date here to see Howie Day with Anna Nalick & Missy Higgins. Everything about it seemed off (except of course for Missy Higgins as she was great!) from the crowd to Anna Nalick's annoying ass commentary. Sing, punk! Don't talk! We did not come here to hear you talk! And your singing is barely better!
  If an artist I love is playing the Fillmore, I'll come. But it would be hard to get me here for someone I'm lukewarm about. I guess the venue itself just doesn't do a whole lot for me.

MGhKNO12impia4GKUvdcAA.review_text: Pros: Free water Constant drink girl service Good sound quality Nice size dance floor Legit lighting Next door to KFC  Cons: Lack of rap/rock/reggae shows (big problem) 1 bathroom that is always dirty as hell

VJeELbzN2bS5Kw-tur4Oag.review_text: I kid you not... Walking into this lovely venue for the first time this past summer for Dita Von Teese's burlesque show was my own kind of religious experience.  My whole life I'd heard about the many shows my parents had seen there in the '60's.  And unfortunately the whole time I lived in SF 1990 through 1992, the place was closed for earthquake retrofitting (grrrr).  And then since it reopened, I hadn't yet partaken in a show.    So, walking in, walking up the staircase, being welcomed by the workers, the apples near the entrance to the room itself... quite the experience.  It's definitely one of those places that oozes nostalgia.... lush... dark.   And it was everything and more than I thought it would be.  I imagined the actual auditorium/stage would be pretty big and it's not at all.  The floor is general admission, with no seating, but no matter where you are, you can see well.  Very intimate.  We ended up upstairs, where there happens to be limited seating/tables and it was perfect for Dita's show.  The cocktail waitress serving us was excellent and really charming.    Overall, such an amazing night and I can't wait to go back and see another show there!

YP4C1LrSjZXu5351MW7kWw.review_text: One of my favorite venues in San Francisco. This is a place so full of music history with more made every show. Like any club/venue, the food and drinks are pricey, but the food is pretty good and most times big enough to split with friends. I've always had pretty cool staff which is always a big plus. Even though shows are available through ticketbxxtard, the box office is open every Sunday at 10am for fee-free tickets. Box office also open on show nights, but I think there's a service fee.

99NcsApGTVHpDClWSW8_iQ.review_text: Saw the Black Crowes here two weeks ago.   Old School fans = old school hair. This woman looked like she was straight out of "Married to the Mob" and kept telling us to back off from her hair!  Venue is small, which provides a good vibe, fairly good viewing from just about any vantage point. We opted for the balcony.   Loved the posters as we cruised out and the free red delicious apples! As someone with a safety background, I'd be a bit concerned about the evacuation procedures, but otherwise enjoyed myself a good ole' hot boxed time.

7iF-6RIVvUfk_ibomp5Xig.review_text: The Mo-Mo in the 'Mo. My positively absolutely favorite venue in San Francisco. Okay, so I've only been here twice but both times were the best. First time I was here to see Kelis and N.E.R.D., before The Neptunes blew up. I was all up close to Pharrell. I was determined to meet up so I stuck around out front after the show and, yup we talked and I scored an autograph and a hug out of him. Anyhoo, back to the Fillmore. It's small enough so wherever you're standing, you get a good view of the performers. There are no seats, only the balconies on the side. Second show, I saw The Roots w/ Big Daddy Kane & MC Lyte. Excellent show, great crowd, no pushing or shoving, just heads nodding, shoulders bouncing, and hips shaking. The drinks from the bar are decent. The bathrooms are nice and clean with lots of stalls, another plus.  If you're into meeting the musicians after the show, this is the best venue to do it. Since it's small, the musicians can't really run away from you. So hang out front near the bus, groupie style. Or you could be lucky enough to meet someone inside. I got to meet Tre Cool, drummer for Green Day and my sixth grade crush.  There's a Taco Bell & KFC near by so you can load up on carbs before you get wasted or a post doobie smoking carb fill up after you leave the Fillmore.

rATb3uJZEKCLrB1G1c6K6w.review_text: sometimes i forget if i'm supposed to review the venue itself or the band i saw here.  to get it out of my system, dethklok was fucking metal, the most brutally entertaining evening i've had in the city in recent memory.  the lyrics "go forth and die" truly changed my life, as did the words "awaken, mustakrakish."  next time i see them i'm going to join the mosh pit.  there were devil horns going up everwhere.  hannah montana wishes she could compete.  dethklok played on monday, but they were supposed to go on the previous thursday.  they didn't play on thursday because there was an electrical fire.  the root cause of the fire remains unknown, but what i heard from some pissed off teenager was that someone overloaded a sound board.  i can pretend to know what that means, but i'd rather just be pissed off at the venue for inconveniencing me and wasting my evening.  there were about four hundred angry metalheads who felt the same way.  fuck the fillmore!  i love being juvenile.  anyway, they got themselves unfucked and fixed their shit, and a severely truncated dethklok show came back to town, and that's when i finally glimpsed the inside of this overly-famous place.  and like all historically significant rock venues, this one was underwhelmingly dirty, their sticky floors coated with generations of old beer.  for some reason i was expecting it to be bigger inside, what with smashing pumpkins playing here and all.  it looked like my elementary school cafeteria.  of course the sound system rocked.  man, for $6 beer in small plastic cups, you'd think they'd be able to afford urinals.  it feels awfully strange to piss in a sink.

PoNdPzCIZEv_mXwZP0C4Ng.review_text: Awesome concert venue, cozy, good access to bars. There is even food, snacks served. The bathrooms were clean too.

Mj5f9C-rVEuMDgmMW3Zm3w.review_text: Another SF favorite venue! It's easy to take public transportation to this place. I've been here so many times & each time has been an outstanding experience!

jhPAC7UyPiRFNPlNQYMMXg.review_text: Shady. Completely shady.   I used to like this venue. It's one of the better venues in the area.. but their lying, stealing staff is what earns them this 1-star review.  I took my camera into a show one time. Sure, no big deal. Apparently, cameras weren't allowed that day.. but they never advertised that online or anywhere else until people got to the venue, and they didn't advertise their camera check-in service, so I had no choice but to carry it in. Once inside, I hear a PA announcement saying that "no FLASH photography is allowed". Naturally, I assumed this meant that non-flash photos were okay.  As I'm taking pictures during the show, a bouncer pulls me aside and confiscates my camera. He says that he's going to delete my pictures of that night, and then I can pick up the camera at the front door after the show. Obviously, I consented.  A couple days after the show, I noticed that MY MEMORY CARD WAS MISSING. Yup, those THIEFS stole my SDHC card without my consent. Not only was it an expensive card, but it's a COMPLETE VIOLATION OF MY PRIVACY AND MY RIGHTS. Not only is the card mine, but the contents of the card are completely private and they, BY LAW, are not allowed to confiscated it without my approval.   I contacted them via their website. NO RESPONSE. I had to send an angry twitter message to get a response, to which they claimed that the BAND MANAGEMENT took the card. That's complete bullshit. They gave me a phone number to call for the Fillmore office, which had a 20+ minute recording of upcoming shows. Great.  Another angry tweet later, they finally give me a phone number where I can speak with someone. Though the lady on the other line was helpful, all she told me the same thing, and would not let me speak to the manager. They just told me to contact the band via their website. Obviously, I got no response from the band.   Needless to say, I gave up rather than to continue wasting my time. However, that doesn't mean that I'm still not completely angered by these events.  Come on guys, we all know that no band will steal a memory card. We also know that it's completely F*ed up to tell someone that you'll delete their photos, but instead, STEAL the memory card. We also know that it's a complete violation of my privacy.

0GHsxjCk-Ynzx4Ihj8tjPQ.review_text: I went to watch Hot Chip (hotchip.co.uk/site) last night at the Fillmore.  The guy at the door patted down my friend and asked me if I was carrying knives in my tiny wrist-let purse. Hmmm... It was my first time at the venue and since it looked really small and ghetto from the outside I was pleasantly surprised when I walked in.  Big open space with a huge stage and dance floor, high ceilings with black light chandeliers.  The Fillmore reminds me of the Great American Music Hall in some ways but a lot bigger.  I really like the venue and will definitely be back to watch more concerts in the future.

ZKkW7G2KbahwQGOdjjaSdg.review_text: LOVE The Fillmore!   My first time there was to "experience" Soulive who were absolutely amazing!   I danced all night long...well at least until the music ended and it was time to go home. They're coming back in September so maybe I'll see you there?   Anyhow, this venue is all about fantastic music, a great work-out and chill people! What more could you ask for?  ...Um okay, maybe more chairs on the main floor for those occasional breaks from crazy dancing but if you're wearing nifty jeans for the night, it's not so bad resting (sitting) on the floor!   You don't go to The Fillmore to look good anyway! It's dark - just dance and let loose!

VHdY6oG2JPVNjihWhOooAQ.review_text: Sadly no poster this Saturday, despite a sold-out show, but I have to say that I had a Fillmore Apple for the first time yesterday night, and it was probably the best apple that I've had in years.  Just the right amount of crunch. Just the right amount of sheen. And eating it while grooving to Galactic was beyond What's Up.  Trust.

4h4unLs0_kpiBsJqtZS27g.review_text: Is there a hipper and more quintessential San Francisco music venue than the Fillmore?  The acoustics rock, the setting is intimate, the vibe in general is warm and fuzzy down to the snazzy chandelier.   Totally stoked to see Doves there in a couple of weeks. I wish I could give 4.5 stars but the 4 is just the inconvenience for me to get to, which is a tad biased..kill me. I heart the Fillmore.

b76FcjQd1RkpnP6I-ajhjw.review_text: This is a pretty nice venue. They had a bar along the left side of the building along with a few balconies, which is a nice touch. I kinda get the Phantom of the Opera feeling with their beautiful chandeliers. When light reflects off of them, it's gorgeous! It's a great small venue where everyone can feel intimate with the band playing and you have a great view at all points. I've come here several times to see Boyce Avenue and have always been able to stand in the front. Restrooms have a lot of stall also. Great venue!

NOcbsiXZ22p2BgkYGyI1rQ.review_text: I probably can't add anything that hasn't already been said but as a born and raised SFer, I can't believe it took me 39 years to finally go to The Fillmore.  I'd heard about it all my life...my mom and aunt used to see all the legends back in the day.  I decided to treat myself to a concert for my 39th birthday and was not disappointed.  I was fascinated with the poster lined walls, the velvet curtains and the chandeliers.  Plenty of bars, great acoustics, sophisticated crowd, staff was personable.  I had a very pleasant experience.  Not to be missed if you are an out of towner or a native San Franciscan.

qkreXL6AorI19QA3f2wvlQ.review_text: This venue is just right: not so big that you can't see the band; and not too small that your personal space is violated.  I saw Jimmy Eat World here, and it was awesome!  My friend and I hung around J-town to grab some dinner since it's close by.  And since we got there early, we grabbed seats in the dining area on the second floor.  I heard you get free apples?  I didn't see any.  But it's cool.  All in all, it's a historic, beautiful venue with friendly staff and a chill vibe.

437yu8bLf5Rq7Q2SJanaiQ.review_text: Other than the Warfield, i will like to go to this venue for my concerts. Great size, ambiance and good location in case you want to enjoy the nightlife after coming to the venue.

pw9A988_rBWSERhTYlf-nw.review_text: Although I'm a little ashamed to admit that I JUST went to a concert at the Fillmore I must say it was one of the best I've ever been to. There really isn't a bad spot in the place. The crowd wasn't too big and we never had a problem getting to the bar (although we were there to see Matisyahu so that could have been why the beer crowd was so thin). Beer was a little expensive but what SF venue doesn't rape you when it comes to that? The sound was just plain great and as someone trying to kick the flu I'm going to comment on the air quality, great. I knew there were people smoking but I barely noticed a smell or haze. We stood in the very back and even that felt insanely close. I can't wait to go back.

RQPiK7lAH-1eeCwD4TPqSg.review_text: Not too shabby of a place, it reminds me of Webster Hall back in New York.  The crowd really varies with the performer you're going to see, but there will always those annoying drunk people at every show.

E7o9NTPIDT8EVhz1dRwqlg.review_text: FRIENDLY staff!  This legendary venue has a super friendly staff, great shows, and an overall pleasant vibe to it.  I thoroughly enjoy and look forward to attending events held at this San Francisco staple.

VjUuaL2A0QwrRZ8hDdFf7Q.review_text: this is probably the best music venue in the city.  i left my heart at the fillmore.  -2nd floor with food and additional entertainment -really spacious, well ventilated, yet still intimate -great sound system, beautiful chandeliers -free poster after almost every show -free washington apples that are super crisp and juicy  buy your tickets at the box office on sunday to avoid the fees.

u7Uv97_feX1iiATbf_BCyQ.review_text: I hate to admit this, but the cute girl who patted me down at the door was the most action I had all day.

b1TLsiRhQdfbbXahqFkVtg.review_text: The venue itself is AWESEOME.  The problem is that it is run by a bunch of jerks.  I'm not just railing against Clear Channel here (I think there is a word limit on these things).  The folks that work here forget that the people coming to see a show have paid at least $30+ to come out for the night.  The least they can do is be polite.  They act like they are doing us a favor by checking our bags, giving us stamps....  throwing us out of the way when they need to get by.  This place can make a good show great.  As long as you don't interact with the people that work here.

IviPrdkUHKJewg5_aS5XlQ.review_text: I was here to check out Steven Wilson's performance. Bar was alright, ok drinks, ok bartenders. The venue was also alright. Bathrooms were a little weird. There were couple of really nice people in the staff but one security guy inside the theater was just plain rude and unreasonable. He really spoiled my evening because I was focusing on just having a good time checking out one of the greatest musicians I have been listening to for about 8 years. He told me not to stand in front of him as its blocking his view. I have been to a couple of concerts but never heard that before. After being threatened of being kicked out, I gave in to his pathetic attitude and focused on the music. This place gets good artists and that is the only reason I will ever come back here.

_vk88Fk8e7_HkXSMb9M9AQ.review_text: Pretty chandeliers & music by Sage 'mutha fuckin' Francis!! Yes please, can I have s'more?!  Beautiful setting to see any band. Good times..good times.  Minus 1 star for that bitchass chick on staff being mean to fans for taking pics, when no other staff member seemed to mind.  Get some cock or somethin...lighten up!

NAN8AAQSoTLVEE_b0a7asw.review_text: Came out here in May to check out The Weeknd. Got to the venue just in time and there was a pretty big line. Once we got in, we were standing in a pretty good spot not that far from the stage. The atmosphere is cool, you can almost feel the history behind the place. Got a couple drinks before The Weeknd went on, average price and not very strong.  The show was dope though, no opening act which was cool with me. He went on at a good time and didn't have us waiting for too long. The sound system was great and everyone was into the show. At the end they gave out mini posters, making the show even more memorable. I'll definitely be coming back here for another show in the future.

RoA9mDVDKEwsdNrH4MH3IA.review_text: I came to The Fillmore for Bill Burr's Comedy Central taping and I thought the venue was pretty good. I can just imagine how great it would be to come here for a concert, because the venue itself, along with the stage, is not too big so almost every one in the audience gets a good look at the performer. Not bad, not bad at all. :)

z8FjRjn3gcY0XyjgcwcOOg.review_text: as far as shows go, is there a better place with the amount of history?!?!?!  not really asking, just being witty with the first line.  just imagine the drugs done at this place over the time...  you get a poster if the show sells out?  yeah, place is fucking unreal...

sEtGnbtsLHTXTV3QoHZrUw.review_text: Brings back memories to go to places that you frequented 40 years ago! Looking up at the posters I could almost remember all the shows that I saw there but then realized I it was just wishful thinking and all the posters are cool! It's kind of neat to see the transition in art styles throughout the decades as well. Apples are still in the same spot as you walk up the stairs and into the venue. Saw Trombone Shorty and was not disappointed one bit with the performance or  lighting.  What was nice was the flow of air through the place, not stuffy at all. We'll be back!

eu19K9KfnvvubzWuv4l6Wg.review_text: This is what i do... I go to live music.  As often as possible.   Spent Friday and Saturday night this weekend, both at the fillmore. Reasonably priced shows, decent priced drinks, and always a good time.   There is a real sense of history and awesomeness at the fillmore. My hallways in my house are actually lined with the posters i have recieved at fillmore shows, and bought the frames at cheap petes.  The only reason i docked a star, is because i should have at least 15 more posters than i do compared to how many shows ive been to.  Its customary.  Go to a show, get a FREE poster on the way out.  I think it has something to do with how soon the show sells out, and if the band wants one and probably a few more things...but BOTH shows this weekend...FRIDAY AND SATURDAY, NO POSTER!!! Its what i look forward to!  not just the music, but what will the poster look like?  total downer.

d7DCa-j4lHGei1eIl0d3kQ.review_text: What's not to like? Chandeliers, apples, alcohol (translation=very sticky floor), awesome performers (just saw Xavier Rudd and Mishka here the other night and it was incredible!)...my only complaint is visibility. But that's more my fault for being a short person, maybe if they offered platform lifts you could attach to your shoes when you come in...hmmm...height equality...I like the sound of that...

_81UszeBJ9xjuI4X4fpPxw.review_text: reminded me of London gig venues, but i was watching primal scream with loads of brits....  my only criticism would be can't work out why they wouldn't have better signage outside.  even something to show who's playing the next night..  i'd lived here for 6 months and never knew where it was even though i'd walked past it 20 times.

m09oEf5ccSOs9EAiIPY-GQ.review_text: Tim the greeter has been fired by The Fillmore!  Tim is the greatest greeter and good guy that shakes your hand at the top of the stairs and give off good vibes that get you ready to hear the music.  What can we do to get Tim back???

RAjs8yhXbsLBHUwajHZ2NA.review_text: My ultimate venue. The sound is awesome. Whether you are in the back or against the barricade you are bound to let your body do what the music is telling it to.  The atmosphere is amazing. The chandeliers hanging from the ceiling are actually on, they aren't just decor. They are functioning light fixtures! The posters are amazing! I wonder where they are going to put more of them since all the walls seem filled. Oh, thats another great thing, if the show has sold out before hand you will generally get a free poster (while supplies last) on your way out. Free memorabilia! Score.

69bKvoKzrJO4gd9X_Tozqw.review_text: caught the Dragonette/Little Boots show here. Paid homage to this historic American SF venue and drank a Budweiser. only Absinthe is probably more apropro here. took a scene kid picture. checked out the various rooms. the Fillmores' atmosphere that particular night: british pop meets hippy alterna-goth. gypsy punk meets tribal belly dance. If the Fillmore was in highschool - he/she would be the too cool for school kids - -  that smoked in the back of the gym near the grassy area; whilst playing guitar, picking daises, braiding each other's hair and playing hacky sack.

DJmCjo8KJpWYe0HsYFwiBA.review_text: Larger than the Warfield without the tiered sections so a bit harder to see the stage. But this venue makes up for it with the killer posters of past performers all over the walls and swanky decor.  Chandeliers on the ceiling = gorgeous.  Apples = yum. Free posters after show = awesome house decor.    Fillmore, don't ever stop doing what you do.

zPUXrKhF4XYWXeyS5NJJZA.review_text: Came here to see Taking Back Sunday/Thursday tour.   I have always wanted to come here since many bands have played at this venue.  Turned out the venue was very nice.  Nice upper balcony viewing area.    The bar is just a bar.  Liked the sound in this big room.  Huge chandelier on top.   And of course, general admission :p   Stage was a good height.     Will be coming back again =)

zZhBiivvN4Iq-hyzS9XvMQ.review_text: I'm with the others, and think we should stage a revolt against the terrible conditions outside this otherwise fantastic venue.  I think working for Clear Channel probably makes people hate their jobs (I heard that some or all lost their health benefits when CC took over) and they vent their frustration on the people they have to deal with.  I'm not excusing the patronizing, always brusque, and sometimes downright nasty things that have come out of the mouths of Fillmore staff, I'm just saying that it's a trickle-down sort of evil.    At any rate, it took a strong cocktail (and the friendly greeting of that guy at the top of the stairs) to restore my faith in humanity and put me back in the mood to dance and have fun after a half hour of waiting out front for my friends.  The moral is, don't give up if people are mean.  Fun awaits inside.

o03ZwIhEEbKLxffxBmcuUw.review_text: Probably the best mid-sized venue in the city. Every time I come to a show here I'm surprised to remember that it's owned and run by the heartless corporate entity of LiveNation, because everyone is so nice and seems to actually care about music. They also really care about preserving the legacy of Bill Graham's original vision for the club, so there's a lot of interesting historical tributes to geek out on as you wait around in between acts.  Of course, none of that really matters if the show is bad, but the production values here are outstanding. The sound is always perfect and the lighting guy is so good that twice now I've seen the performer call them out by name during the middle of a set for doing a great job.  Obviously a venue doesn't really need reviews - if you want to see a band, you're going to go wherever they are playing. But The Fillmore deserves some praise for the outstanding job they do year after year.

EEsebIgDtv18cZt-2UizkA.review_text: Having seen well over 1,500 bands in the last 20 some odd years, I have easilly been to virtually any and every small (and big for that matter)concert venue in the Bay Area and the historic Fillmore, S.F. wihtout a doubt clocks in as one of the best.  Because I'm a south Bay lad, I never did get to frequent The Fillmore named after its originally location at Fillmore Street and Geary Blvd. but I was able to start attending it almost regularly after it re-opened in the mid or late 90's.  If I could find some kind of database listing of all the concerts ever held there, I might be able to colate a listing of shows I've seen there which I'm sure though many are only a drop in the bucket.  Be sure to check out the "poster" room up on the mezzanine level of the building containing "psychodelic" 60's style band and show promo sheets that are commissioned for bands selling out the venue and handed out to attendees at the end of the show.  There's never a bad seat in the house at The Fillmore but be prepared there are actually very little seats at all but nary a better place to see your favorite band.

PRiSufjS2Vf_BgR34eguJg.review_text: Saw Ozomatli play here a few years ago.  The Fillmore is a great concert venue, museum and historical landmark. The walls are filled with pictures of all the great artists that have played the club over the years, and you get a sense of the history that has occurred inside. This also gives the Fillmore a bit of mystique that most venues will never have.

OXYtOFX9xXukagW5Ku5dfg.review_text: I've been to the Fillmore a few times over the years for different bands. It's a solid venue. Really great place to go for shows!!  Spacious, cool concert posters line the walls upstairs, several bar areas (they are so expensive though), upstairs seating--one seating area even has a little stage for small performances!   The lighting is generally well done, the sound system is usually perfect, bathrooms are pretty nice, and the service is very professional. They even have a tub of apples for you if you feel like eating one!   There is a coat check ($1.50 per item...so cheap!) but once you check something in you CANNOT ask for it back and put it back in. Make sure you have all the things you need before you check your stuff in or else.  Only other gripe is that it's a little hard to get to the venue! It's pretty much around Japantown area. Accessible yet time consuming by bus.  I like the Fillmore.

FRSoGLPQI16pus03avyaSA.review_text: The Fillmore is an outstanding concert venue, and truly one of the best. This is San Francisco's finest and truly a gem. I'm so happy that the Fillmore is so close to my hood, and have had the privilege of seeing artists like (then up and coming) Ben Folds Five as well as the Fratelli Brothers. Whenever I enter the main doors, get carded (yes, I still do at this place at least), and walk up the stairs, I get chills knowing that many great artists like Santana, Grateful Dead, and Bob Dylan (to name a few) have performed here. I've had many Fillmore experiences, and my most recent one was watching Ben Harper and the Relentless 7.  My Top Two Most Memorable Fillmore experiences:  1) In 2005, I was invited to a private corporate event led by my BFF, who is also the lovely Yelper (and currently MIA until August), Jeannette Z. At the time, she was in a band (of the several performing that evening), and yours truly was front and center as she performed. For those of you who don't know, the girlie can sing her heart out, as she has been doing since she was little. (BTW, I know this since I've known her since junior high). Anywho, I'm one of her biggest fans, and as she performed on that stage, I beamed with such pride and  took pictures like I was the paparrazi. *That same night, another fellow Yelper, Michael H, and his band were also performing. MH is also a musician, and a very talented drummer.  He was captivated by JZ (who wouldn't be, right?) and sparks flew. Yes, I was there when those lovebirds met. :0  2) Black Crowes Concert - A number of years ago, my friend (a huge BC fan) invited me to their performance. At the time, Chris Robinson was still married to Kate Hudson. Before the show, Kate and son, Ryder, were hanging outside by the side entrance. Later on, I looked up to see Kate at the balcony, with a drink and a smoke in one hand, and the other hand swaying as she grooved to her man's tunes. It was awesome. This show totally rocked and wished I brought my camera to capture the moments. Duoh!   I love everything about the Fillmore, from the outside architecture to the interior (with all of the concert posters of previous performers in the hallway, hanging chandeliers in the main room, etc.,). All of the artists that I've seen here have commented on how awesome and intimate this venue is, and I really couldn't agree more. Not many places can have you so up close and personal. The acoustics are great, too. There are several full bars inside, and the wait can be long (as the servers usually have priority). You definitely get a "high" here, whether you bring your own or get it by secondhand. After the concert is over, the concert high continues as upon exiting, you get an official Fillmore artist poster!

C7AngbgK1l4oaK3A6_ylfQ.review_text: Old school decor, killer sound-system, intimate venue.   What more do you need?   The Fillmore is an old-school-esque music venue. You're most likely going to be standing all night in a large loud sweaty group of people. Like all venues, they charge for water. Like all venues, they get very VERY annoyed if you sneak your own wine/liquor in (hello? It's how they make $$. I'd kick your a** out too if you brought your own food to my restaurant) Be normal, be human, kick back and enjoy being a part of the throng.   And if you don't want to be "harassed" by the guys at the door, leave your hoodies & giant purses in the car. The venue gets hot, so you won't need your coats, and if I get stuck next to some chick with a suitcase for a purse, I make sure to dance *extra* hard on her toes everytime that thing smacks me.

08-KJWiwWtqkB7eRi0gSGw.review_text: One of the best venues ive ever seen in my life. Every show there is almost the best ever, every time i go. The history of this place doesn't hurt either...

NdJU6JBARMBojLtTRMi6gw.review_text: I went here with some friends over the weekend to go see Delta Spirit.  Kinda of a hipster band, but I pretty much showed up for the venue alone.  I've probably been to the Fillmore about 10 times and no matter who is playing, I always enjoy the show.  The Fillmore is great because a bunch of fun places to eat a drink are only a short walk away.  Harry's bar on Fillmore is always a good place to eat and start off the night before a show.  My favorite thing about this place is probably the fact that they never over sell a show.  Even with a sold out show, there is always room to roam around.  The bathroom situation kinda sucks, but with one bar upstairs, a bar on the side and two in the back, waiting for a drink is never a problem.   Be sure to check out the upstairs bar and see all the pictures and classic Fillmore posters of bands who have came and gone.  It's quite an impressive line up.  This is a great intimate venue to go on a date or even just a group of friends.    Every now and then I'll pass on seeing a favorite band I might have seen a few times already....  Shoreline?  No way!  Great American Music Hall?  Meh!  Warfield?  .... I guess...  Fillmore?  Let's do it!    And there is always the possibility of getting a ready kick ass poster!

C5Pf0I0YZEEw2cG8yTcH4Q.review_text: Here's the thing, you can't really be "done" with the Fillmore.  In SF, there just aren't unfortunately that many places where certain acts want to go.  And yes, the history is brilliant and the legends that have been through that place are phenomenal.  But the attitudes of the people that man the doors are out of control -- they get close to, and sometimes do, ruin the great shows that happen within.  The people that run the front door are aggressive, completely hypocritical by acting as if they are running a nunnery inside when the air is actually as thick as it can be and - in short - just plain obnoxious.  I'd rather see music somewhere else.

-4BEUkLvHQntN6qPfKJP2w.review_text: I know i don't really have to preface this, but i will anyway. Yes The Fillmore has a great history, many great bands have played here, it's apart of San Francisco, Grateful Dead, Free Posters, Apples, blah blah yes it's has all of that, terrific.   But the fact of the matter is today this place feels more like a prison than a music venue. I don't know if it's just me, but the people that work here are just jerks(everyone except for that one guy who stands at the top of the stairs to greet you, he's nice.) For however many years i've been coming here it's always "You can't stand here","Let me see your hand stamp","Back up","You can't do this","You can't do that" blah blah blah I mean seriously, does anyone here like their job? Grumpy old roadies who never made the band. Sorry if i'm sounding harsh, but i just wish one of the employees would smile for once.   Anyway, on top of this, is the Clear Channel/Livenation connection. Now NORMALLY i could care less about corporate ownership and all that junk, it really doesn't bother me or concern me... but The Fillmore has definitely changed for the worse. If the Livenation advertisements and gigantic drop down projection TV Screen weren't annoying enough, THE PRICES TO SEE SHOWS HERE HAVE GONE THROUGH THE ROOF. And no, i don't think its just the price going up as the years go by. I swear, i usually don't care who owns what, but this one just rubs me the wrong way. Hows LIVENATION for historic Fillmore History.   I mean, i've seen great acts here, but this place is not my first choice for venues in SF. I really wish i could be in the hundreds of reviews to give this place 5 stars, but i'm not.

Wtz_dG85kvC31H3ESQDm7A.review_text: Recently went here for the Regina Spektor concert after having not been here for 3 years... I was extremely surprised and obviously did not remember it correctly.  The interior was great with chandeliers with plenty of space to enjoy your night.  On top of that, the sound was exquisite and sharp.  I was terribly impressed.  Their staff was friendly, bar drinks not bad.  Our bartender definitely had a heavy hand.  $6 for a vodka Collins, which I think isn't bad when you would get charged double that in most restaurants.    I subscribed to their mailing list so I can go again as soon as possible!

K5F2Xfm0xz2XkwAzB3UWaw.review_text: The drinks are overpriced.  And to add insult to injury they will overcharge your credit card tip amount--watch out for this!!!!

zYTKVr_nnwV8gK9KETqvMQ.review_text: Undoubtedly the place is legend for hosting fine acts.  However, the ticketing process and some of the folks who work there are totally corrupt.  I witnessed staff at a Duran Duran show and this is how they work it at sold out shows: some scalper on the street has copies of a ticket they offer to sell. They collect a few folks that will pay cash to get in without official ticket.  A staff guy from inside having a secret deal with that scalper comes outside just when the show starts and there is lots of commotion, collects those people's cash out of sight, pays off the scalper, walks the folks in by having a secret arrangement with the door folks (they get a share of the proceeds later),  and bingo, another bunch of people made it inside. That can happen in several rounds depending on how popular the act is... Maybe this is common practice in venues like this, maybe the owner should know how their fine staff works...   Realize that this place may often be crowded beyond official Fire Marshall capacity which has its own repercussions. Also makes all the people who wait in line or did not get a ticket look like fools.  I'd rather see artists now at a less shady venue.

xsAgGwNWuoKZfKmj_WjKpw.review_text: Nothing really wrong with the place, I just have to give them one star because of that prick in a Slayer hat who was taking people's alcohol when they weren't even on the premises. Stop the power trippin, boy!

IUXmQbiQSG97Aez2rOKmcQ.review_text: Free Apples  Concert Posters after (almost) every show  I mean, what else can you ask for?  Great sound and ambiance too-- and artists truly LOVE performing here since it's such an iconic venue.

nW7kOwA42JlgOufVxprPZw.review_text: It's The Fillmore! I mean, really, it's THE FILLMORE. How can you give it anything but 5 stars? It's a San Francisco classic. Everyone comes through here at one time.  We've been many times but today we were here for Ozomatli's OzoKids Concert.  Some people never get to see a show at The Fillmore but my kids got to see a show at the ages of 3 and 5 and they have NO idea how cool it is. None. Let's just hope that at some point in their lives they will realize how cool it is!  Anyway, I love The Fillmore. It's such a great venue. Lots of space and if you want to escape the crowd and noise, you can just head upstairs to the bar area and watch the concert from there or if you want even more peace, you just go into the restaurant area.  Everyone who works there is super nice, which is surprising in the city.  Such a great place and such an awesome concert!

HcciAbTkNzkPjrA3uNrYnw.review_text: The Fillmore is THE  San Francisco venue as far as I'm concerned. Perhaps this is just the opinion of a wild-eyed city newbie, but I've seen close 20 shows here over the years and every one of them has been epic. I think it has something to do with the historic nature of the venue and bands really feeling the vibe on stage; the spirit of Hendrix or what have you.  Security does a paultry job of keeping my trusty flask out of my pocket, not for a lack of trying though. And a camera is usually pretty easy to get in as well. There are some quality spots to eat up Fillmore St. so fuel up preshow.  Get there during the opening act and nuzzle in amongst the hipsters, stoneys, and fraternitics as a close spot is unavailable without a struggle once the main act has taken stage. See ya'll there

PNTbcuPX5V81XibwrNzskg.review_text: This venue is beautiful, and  a classic in SF. Plenty of room, great band posters, good bar...and of course the best in music... HOWEVER- the staff is rude...Cecilia and Lane (I think) were working in will call and treated my friends and I with complete disdain. They were rude repeatedly to my friend and when I later went to ask their names (politely) they wouldn't tell me, sarcastically told me to have a good night and turned around. I rarely write poor reviews, or have negative interactions with people- it was INSANE how terrible they acted, this alone could make me think twice about going here if I have another choice for a group i like.

r9VkVP_4d2_KMHA9ZN2c6w.review_text: Before I can properly review Miyavi's recent gig at Slim's this past Thursday, I have to start by posting my review of him from last year at The Fillmore.  Enjoy. ============ Date: 15 June 2010 Location: The Fillmore, San Francisco Screaming fangirls and devoted fanboys gathered together last night to welcome back J-rock (en.wikipedia.org/wiki/J-…) sensation Miyavi (myv382tokyo.com) to the San Francisco Bay Area. Miyavi first exploded onto the Japanese visual kei (en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vi…) scene back in 1999 when he first joined the J-rock band Dué le Quartz (en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Du…) at the young age of 17. Miyavi, back then known as Miyabi, blew the world away with his addicting and mesmerizing guitar-playing skills. Since the break-up of that band, he joined forces with J-rock heavy-weights Gackt, Yoshiki and Sugizo to form the group S.K.I.N. back in 2007. Now, Miyavi has become a sole force to be reckoned with on the J-rock music scene, standing apart from his peers with his unique style of fusing many different genres of music to form his own brand of revolutionary rock. The concert itself was electrifying, and did not seem to last long enough for the fans to get enough of the J-rocker. The decided lack of special effects put a strong emphasis on the musician prancing and parading around on stage, allowing the audience a first-hand demonstration of the rocker's key talent - his unbelievable ability to play a guitar like no other. It is perhaps Miyavi's gift for the instrument that reminds me so strongly of heavy-weights Slash (Guns 'n Roses) and Lindsay Buckingham (Fleetwood Mac).  Miyavi's abilities to play his guitar without the use of a pick, and to even be able to play while holding the instrument to the back of his head while dancing around on stage, is nothing short of amazing to watch and sets him apart from many other rock guitarists that I have seen over the years.  If you have not had the chance to witness this young man's talents, I highly recommend watching the video to his hit "Survive" (youtu.be/cfQ-DK0TalY) or this live version of "Are You Ready to Rock" (youtu.be/IsdCItNx7tg) where he plays the entire song and all the instruments by himself: There were several highlights to the show, to which yours truly was up front and dancing along with all the other fans in the joint.  At one point, during a lull where Miyavi was drinking water and the crowd quieted some, a fangirl screamed out "YOU'RE SEXY!" to the man.  The reaction was truly memorable.  After laughing at the outcry, he saunters up to the mike, pulls up his shirt, and speaks in a husky tone "Oh really?"  The fans went wild. It was most refreshing to hear just how fluent the artist was speaking English, much to the delight of his North American fans. More key highlights of the two-and-a-half hour concert were his spraying the audience with his water bottle (which yours truly got smacked in the face with), after which he chucked the bottle out to some lucky fan in the crowd, and saving a poor young lady that was getting pushed harshly into the bouncer bars at the front of the stage by rabid fangirls behind her trying to get as close to the J-rocker as possible.  He loved the crowd by screaming back at them in the exact same way the fangirls were, which only incited more rabid screaming, to which he more than happily reciprocated.  The screaming match was hilarious to witness, having never seen that done from a musician before. Miyavi also played a few songs from his upcoming album in the fall, a couple of which had the face-splitting titles of "SuperMotherFuckingBitch" and "Ah-Ha!".  (Even the bouncers were laughing and rocking out to the first one)  Look on iTunes or at your nearest J-rock friendly music store for when the album hits shelves in October.  The new album promises to be everything one can expect from the man, and much much more. But perhaps the most mesmerizing moment of the entire night was when Miyavi shared with us his trials that took place over the past year, in which he got married and had his first child, a daughter.  The audience screaming out "omedetto" (Japanese for "congratulations") and "Happy Father's Day" really spoke of the joy that his fans shared with him for a couple of his greatest moments in life. At the end of the concert, Miyavi walked all over the front of the stage waving to his devoted fans and shouting his love and appreciation for his San Francisco fanbase from where he could before finally leaving the stage.  The night was truly a work of magic, and yours truly was one of the many happily infected. Miyavi, we wish you a very Happy Father's Day, and much luck and love from all of us here in the Bay Area! Miyavi Official Website:  myv382tokyo.com

cFGODGxDp4uiSVsnMGG8ug.review_text: Stepping into the Fillmore is like stepping through the gates of musical Heaven. I would almost move to San Francisco just to be able to go to the Fillmore for every concert, I'm actually in love with a place... I've seen The Black Crowes there and it's an all-around magical place.  The staff are one of a kind; genuine, sweet, caring, and chill.  The coat check is 75 cents per piece which is amazing!  The beer is cold, grab an apple on the way in and a free poster on the way out.   There is nothing wrong with this venue - I want to live in it!  Even waiting outside the Fillmore for hours in the rain was a beautiful time because I knew where I wanted to be when those doors opened. If it's your first time at the Fillmore I suggest you walk inside, take a deep breath, look around, shut your eyes... just feel the vibe, man.

aqWXHhcR_CdmKmxggFOlEA.review_text: I lost my Fillmore virginity to Dan Band.  Saw my first show at The Fillmore last night, and it was a great venue. It's small enough so that everybody feels involved and there isn't a bad spot, and the bar area is big and can accommodate a lot of people. I appreciate the efficiency of the place in getting tickets from will call, drinks from the bar, coats from coat check.  Treacherous stairs as you exit. As I was leaving, a girl totally ate it and fell down the stairs. The guy at the door said, well, "there's the first one of the night." I'm sure there must be at least a half a dozen of those falls every night...just make sure it's not you.

tGKclv_2sBJPay9IocOOjg.review_text: My boyfriend, best friend, and I came here for Mayer Hawthorne's show this past August and I have never been to a more beautiful venue.   it's historic, convenient, and not to mention bursting with charm. As if that wasn't enough, the staff are crazy friendly and the drinks are undeniably strong. I would definitely consider attending more concerts here as it is an intimate venue - standing room only. My concert experiences prior to this were only in stadium or arena shows, and after joining the masses who have patronized this fine establishment, I can't see it any other way. Why sit literally miles away when you can be up-close-and-personal at the Fillmore? (Probably because stadium acts are far more popular, but you never know who will roll through this place.)  With potent drinks, personable staff, and an ambiance like no other, the Fillmore has completely and totally lived up to the hype as one of the best venues in town.

Ud6j2HN40qEhycq2PuwcBA.review_text: Amazing place to watch any show/DJ, performances. Came here awhile back to watch this one chick sign altho I forgot her name...but this past Fri, we came here to watch Paul Oakenfold DJ! It was a memorable night and Paul brought the house down....amazing mix, great slide show and the hall had great acoustic alongside beautiful chandeliers. We had a great time, thanks to Raoul for that one extra tic!!

VrVBC9Sni1JluW9FlrAERA.review_text: Saw Grace Potter and the Nocturnals here for the Huzby's birthday Feb. 5th.   GPN put on a terrific show. We'd go back to see them anytime.  I may be tipping my middle-aged hand, but standing from 8 p.m. until 1 a.m. in moderate heels does tend to wear a gal down--especially when fighting off an ensuing monster cold. I ended up adorning the recycling bins for about twenty minutes between shows. By the final finale, I again propped myself against a bottle bin in the lobby while waiting for the disgorgement of the more stalwart fans including Mr. G. I was in fine company. There were loads of young ladies in heels taking a load off on the lobby bench.   Apparently the camera policy is in constant flux based on the performers' preferences which meant Huzby had to check his Canon. They took good care of it and let me pick it up before the show was over as long as I promised not to go back inside. Fine by me.   Here's the thing: You want to be as tall as possible so you can see above the crowd, so you wear heels. But there's a trade-off. Standing for five hours in heels is a bee-yatch!  Next time--platform sneakers.

rjBdmmqEq3XbVI1lvd13Eg.review_text: this is by far my favorite place to catch a live show in san francisco (or anywhere else).  it comes closer to perfection than any venue i have been at (and i've been to LOADS of venues all over the US and the UK).  the sound is good, the size is perfect, the staff is generally fair and friendly, and the apples and the (if the show is sold out) poster are great little perks.  i also love the poster room.  great vibe!  if one of your favorite bands is playing a gig at the SF fillmore, do NOT miss it!  i've seen the indigo girls here too many times to count.  i've also seen quite a few other acts here, the black crowes being the stand out of those.  i heart the fillmore so much that even *passing by* it on geary and fillmore makes me so giddy!

m5cBT7OYfn0HM0d-RCsdZQ.review_text: Built To Spill  W had me accompany a group to catch this band in live action and since I had never been to the Fillmore, it was going to be an exciting evening for me.  I was totally surprised because the venue is misleading.  A small entrance, large venue upstairs and expansive at that.  The staff stamping in people were extremely nice as were the bouncers checking in people.  One even apologized when they had to direct everyone to the left of the building during intermission (all the smokers congregated and I had to escape due to the impending doom to my scarred lungs..long story)   "Sorry miss, you could stand behind me.  Or go back inside," he apologized.  The venue is huge, with lots of standing room as well as benches lining the walls (good luck getting those) and galleries set up along the balcony.  However, it does not help when I had two twins (they looked like the red haired tall twins from Harry Potter) stand directly in front of me and pull a Mona Lisa move on me.  Every inch/angle I moved, they followed in front of me.    The concert was awesome.  Good acoustics and the sound effects were not overcompensating in any way. Most of the concerts I've been to have also resulted in my being smashed from all sides or my toes getting smashed.  People were mostly respectful of space, except for the occasional splashes of beer from being surrounded by happy people.  What I enjoyed, was munching on an apple from the tin bucket when I waiting between the sets.  I was encouraged by the number of men who grabbed these crunchy apples......even more so than women.  Bathroom was relatively clean and moved quickly, which is somewhat surprising for a concert hall.  In all, a positive experience and enjoyable one at that!  I'll be back!

ibSIRYjrJG2oaLHDL2fhog.review_text: Definitely one of my favorite music venues.  The staff is great and low key.  Love the intimacy with the artists.  Get there early and grab a seat on the balcony!!!    Have fun fashioning a pipe out of the complementary apples, and (at most concerts) enjoy a free poster on your way out the door!

vITUu5axrTbQEnpOO2WIRA.review_text: the fillmore is by far my favorite concert venue in sf.  great sight lines, good sound and lighting, intimate without being too crowded, decent ventilation, free apples (!!!).  it's my favorite place to see a band that i actually care about.  it's not without its problems, of course: ticketmaster (but i live nearby and can purchase tickets at the box office, so whatever), clearchannel, and high drink prices.  but nobody's perfect, and those are problems of most venues that are booking major national acts.    i've seen a lot of great shows here, and the fillmore has never detracted from my experience.  that's about all i can ask of a concert venue.

l1yg9l-2ZF_1j102YYlpNg.review_text: The iconic music hall, and still a thriving venue for live music.  It's amazing to just come here and take in the posters and pictures of bands/shows from days past. That said, the venue's present is clearly as important as its past. The Fillmore retains the vibe and intimacy of an indie music venue.   The acoustics are anything but indie, mind you. Be it a bare-bones indie-folk act or wall-of-noise shoegaze band, a Fillmore show will be one of the best sounding shows you'll ever attend. And you'll get a poster afterwards to commemorate the gig.  For those driving, I'd recommend the convenient Japantown parking just a bit east of the venue.

qvVsERle-sO2YgnG0Hb1kw.review_text: Amazing spot to see a show. The venue is gorgeous, with a classy, vintage vibe unlike any concert hall I have seen before. Acoustics are great and the view of the stage is easily seen from anywhere in the standing room area. The only downside was the pricey drinks, but everything else made up for it. If you live in SF or are just visiting, this is a must-see destination!

PcZmmylkBTLTdxtesgb-sA.review_text: The Fillmore has a ghostly look and feel of great performers of years past.  Now, if I could rate this place on looks alone or when it's completely empty or when only a bands devoted fans are there, I'd give it another star or two. However, we're talking a music venue here that can house more than a couple of hundred of people which seems to attract anybody who's just heard about a show from any one of the city's lame radio stations. The problem is that the crowd that goes to shows at the Fillmore sucks. I've seen bands play in various venues throughout the U.S. and Europe. So, I've seen a variety of crowds. The problem is that a fair share of the crowd at the Fillmore will talk during a show. I don't mean short blips like "ah, they're playing my favorite song" or any short phrases like that. I mean, people will go on and on about whatever the **** they want to talk about, even during low key songs. One person or another will find it hysterical to yell out a certain Lynyrd Skynard song title, just because. Another will OMG themselves to death because her BF just spotted another hot guy. It's beyond frustrating if you're there to actually listen to the band's performance. I'm not there to listen to the next "great" thing that will come out of the mouth of the person in front of me. Perhaps if the SF crowd would stop being so Self Fanatical about itself, it might forget about itself and have a good time, while letting people amongst it enjoy it, too.  Said crowd has taken some years to realize that it's okay to dance at some of these performances. Star for that!

4pzr6KuS85859EICMI7MDw.review_text: I love you. Wish you would have allow cameras in the shows I've been to here, but it's OK since they were unforgettable. I've seen VNV Nation and Chromeo here and the shows were both very different. It still baffles me how the cocktail waitresses can get through and around the crowd. It's so nice to jam out in place that has so much history, and if you don't know, take a slow stroll through the hall at the top of the entryway stairs. The venue is an ideal size, not too big nor too small, and you can usually find parking within two blocks, and there's a ton of food nearby.  Need I say more?  LOVED IT.

ITP16OhQ0KqU7Vt8zDX--g.review_text: I love the intimacy of this venue! If you're in front row, most of the time you could find a way to shake hands or touch the artists on stage. (that sentence didn't really come out right. Whatevs)   Went to many concerts here from Senses fail to Rooney. If you wait outside long enough, you could meet the artists afterwards (if they're chill). Met the band Keane and  got their autograph.   The building looks kinda crappy from the outside but I like it. It has that cool ghetto look to it.  Another sweet thing about this place is as you're walking into the auditorium, you'll pass by framed photos of previous performers dating back to who knows when.   I'm not 100% sure that it's still available but you could also buy concert tickets at their box office before shows and on Sundays. Saves you from paying fees that ticket master would charge online.

nsawcqioX0NDmqsDsM8L4w.review_text: Just being in a place where so many great musicians played was a great opportunity.  I saw Travis here and they put on a good show.  The posters covering the wall were SWEET!  Definitely worth going at least once your life.

5zqKhzuSmVq5CkZ05b7Kww.review_text: The Fillmore is my favorite venue for concerts! It has so much history and character. At every concert, you get the funky concert poster and an apple on your way out. I mean, how cool is that tradition?! The staff always seem really friendly and as laid back as they can be without letting things get out of control. The venue itself is a good size -- not too small, not too big.  During the opening act, be sure to go upstairs and check out the poster room where they've framed many of posters from famous artists who performed there. It's like a who's-who-in-music history lesson.

_cB_0BNWc5_VMI1JjgP-OA.review_text: Hands down one of my favorite places to see a show. I have been going here for about 9 years and have never been unhappy with the venue itself. The purple/blacklight lights hang over the crowd, giving this the perfect atmosphere. The cost of shows very but the sound is clear and the best of the best play here. If your favorite band is playing here, take some time to go see them. Did i mention they give out free apples ?!

6trig3ELazzzTQjL1lnRLA.review_text: It doesn't get any better for live music in SF. The venue has great sound and a great layout. The history in this building is unmatched. Always a fun evening.

tlF74D0tq6R4rSdMPbwt4w.review_text: The venue itself is quite nice and I have no problem with the inside decor or the feel that it leaves me with. The one thing that needs to be changed is the asswipey security that think they can do whatever the hell they want. Not only do they look creepy, but are ignorant, rude and annoying. I would suggest staying out of their view before they decide to screw up your night. Seriously, the Fillmore is the Fillless while those fools are there.

BCbPFrcdfvPEnnNoWPCdPg.review_text: How can you not give the Fillmore less than 5 stars??  Its as classic as it gets....

T6IT8bL--h0HTmmcef6lBg.review_text: You haven't lived until you've seen a show at the historic Fillmore! Wait upstairs for the band in a comfortable bar. Their bar food isn't bad and reasonably sized for 2 or more people! In the bar, you must wander the walls and see the historical posters of some of the most famous bands in American history. If you're lucky, you'll get to take a limited edition poster of your show at the end of the night!

0FodgHLOC8oxknAlcaYx6w.review_text: I treasure the posters I have earned here after a night of destroying my kneecaps. Some happy times indeed. (Cursive & Yo La Tengo)  This is a place where it's ok if you're not totally hip. That's a pro.
