RYhtdZpUu5mZGxzfe9CipA.review_text: Normally I'm one of those "OOH, THE HISTORY OF THIS PLACE" kind of gals, but for some reason, the Fillmore doesn't register on that level for me. Even though it totally IS a musical/historical landmark--which is absolutely hard to deny for one second after you climb those stairs to get in, and see all the photos and posters that hang on those walls as memorials to concerts gone by.  Personally, I tend to think of the Fillmore from the concert-going perspective. And from that angle, it's pretty swell. For a large-ish venue, it doesn't feel huge--so you get the benefit of well-known acts in a still-kind-of-intimate setting. The sound is good (critical for concerts, of course), and the sight lines are fairly decent, even if you're fairly far back in the crowd. Compare this to the Warfield, where for some reason I always feel like someone's head is in my way, no matter where I'm at, and I seem to get a better view of backstage than the stage itself. YMMV.   So why am I never totally jazzed about the Fillmore, despite all it has going for it? Maybe it's because I'm always craving a spot to sit here, and they are fairly hard to come by. It'd be nice if they had some tables set up, but it just doesn't seem to be that kind of joint. And that's pretty normal. Just be ready.   That said, it IS really fun to get a poster on the way out, so be sure not to miss that.  Pro Tip: If you like looking at rock memorabilia, get to the venue early so you can spend time looking at the photos and posters. Then you can say "It's NOT POSSIBLE that Beck played here in '94. That would mean Mellow Gold came out 20 years ago, and I'm still in my early 20's! I mean... right?"  Or, perhaps that's just me.  Anyway, on a scale of Heaven (+) to Shoreline (-), the Warfield is definitely on the positive side of things. Just wear comfy shoes, and you'll be in business.

vB8YCXg61Knx81tZ-E180A.review_text: This is an absolutely hot place to see live music. I was there to see The Prodigy and it was amazing (this comes from a chick who's done Coachella and Austin City Limits, so I know a thing or two about getting close and personal to see a live band). The max capacity is 1,250 people, so it's a pretty intimate yet roomy space. The key is to get there decently early and be committed to standing if you want to be close to the performers. I think that's one of the things that makes this a great space is that you can stand 4 feet away (or even closer) from amazing artists. I liken it to a high school gym where you have a local band playing on a platform stage and you can stand so close they sweat on you.  The coolest part about seeing shows at the Fillmore is after each one they hand out free posters of the event. Take that you vendors who want to charge $15 for glossy poster prints! (Little known gem-each poster has an "F" hidden in it. Look for it the next time you have a chance)

EBCx-v9I16v6fJnrQ_ze1Q.review_text: Peeped out the John Jegend/Common Show here...very roomy and very easy to get drinks (although overpriced).  Sound system is straight bangin!!...but not ear piercing.  Will be back for the Jamiroquai show.

ZBCyYF24MQoYmBDgA9kTGQ.review_text: awsome venue and awsome acts. parking is decent but if you have to you can park across the street @ the Japantown parking garage, just note the time they close

fH-RScWTogvVp093PVEZNA.review_text: I've seen more concerts than I care to admit here!  The historical aspect is indisputably significant...I love sitting upstairs before a show and seeing posters I hadn't noticed before or staring at some of the photos while being herded out after a show.  Just awesome to reflect on the impact The Fillmore has had over the years on the San Francisco music scene.  There are only two things I've ever really been irritated with here: 1.  Sometimes the staff behind the bar is really slow and not very courteous, while the staff on the concert floor rocks...I never will understand how she always finds me!!  2.  Posters...LOVE THEM...please Fillmore, don't skimp on this!  I went to a concert recently that was definitely that particular artist's first show in a year...and no posters.  A friend I was with said one of the Fillmore employees had fessed up to just being lazy about it since their schedule has been so hectic this fall.  We love them - please don't disappoint us :)

Mlx7ZLwbhzjU7RmRVs4ngg.review_text: Pretty awesome venue, if not for both the historic shock value and also the great sounds you'll hear.   Been here twice now, with about a 7 year gap in between both visits. Both times it was a great show. The sound is always the most important thing, and it really doesn't get much better here. There's a reason why this place has lasted as long as it has.   The venue itself is gorgeous. The chandeliers that adorn the ceilings are such a great touch, and they create a perfect ambiance for the show. Also, do yourself a favor and get here early one day so you can talk a walk around and take in a little bit of music history. Just knowing that you're standing in the same venue that all these legends on music is enough to give me goosebumps. It could possibly double as a museum if it allowed itself too.   Always look forward to concerts here.

EUDuSd11Fhxm6ioLgvxFEQ.review_text: I don't even know how many shows i have seen at this place.  I have enjoyed almost every single of them...   The venue itself is classic, and you can see every kind of band on their way up, at the top, and on the way back down.  Also, I love the upstairs room with all of the old concert posters.  If you like seeing live music and a band you are interested in happens to be playing the fillmore, get some tickets and enjoy a great show.

RnwGZFn6wQE8yzyT1aEI5g.review_text: Wow, wow, WOW. I'm from Los Angeles, where there are a ton of amazing venues, but I have to say that the Fillmore blows LA out of the water in terms of coolness.   I was fortunate to get to see Billy Corgan here a few summers ago (2005). I got there about an hour before the show, and my husband and I were lucky enough to get a spot right next to the stage. It must be something about San Francisco people or something in the Bay Area's water, but when we went to get drinks in the middle of the show and came back to the main room, no one seemed to care that we wanted to push forward to get our spot near the stage back. In LA, people usually want to bust your head open if you do so.  This place is fabulous....awesome bar, awesome atmosphere, awesome people. Enough said.

QrOde6JC3CMb3AQB08IxDg.review_text: Pretty good place-nothing spectacular but nothing bad.

mAhty2OHDTtLm00quB5Xjw.review_text: Like the Warfield, worth checking out the Fillmore just for how historic and intimate it is.  Live Nation is revving up their advertising *revenue* so expect that to be part of your experience.  Came here for the first time in 7th grade with a friend. He fell asleep during standardized tests the next day.

8Nvvqnb60aFlZutylZd-Aw.review_text: A cool classic SF location.  i have been to two concerts there.  It's great old SF location.  Did I already say that?  lol  Well this place embraces the 1960s and 70s with all their posters all over the place.  Sure I like LSD as much as anyone else but I don't care for these old posters.  I do like some of the old photos however.  When I went the bathroom was kinda trashed.  When i went people inside were smoking a lot of pot pretty openly, that was a bit of a shock.  They serve alcohol here, you can walk around and pretty much ignore the concert if it is getting on your nerves.    The staff was super cool when I went...good vibe.

U8MN8gvl3OLnpC5EURTrnw.review_text: Saw Daughter and her opening band Bear's Den perform here and both were absolutely amazing. The sound quality and reverb of the venue is nice, as well as the fancy chandeliers and interesting and vintage looking decor.   They give free apples but I'm one of those who is positive dirty hands have been all over them so I would never take one myself.   The staff quality is very sub-par. Impatient and seemingly I-hate-my-life quality of people. It was easy for people to smoke blunts on the floor and security wasn't doing anything about it (hey that would be okay if people weren't smoking disgusting old man  weed but they were, and puffing it in other people's faces). A young white girl in front of my girlfriend and I was jumping up and down (drunk) and then just passed out like a rock on the floor. BOOM. 15 minutes later no staff, no security, but some guys around her were trying to help her up and carry her off the floor.   Other than that, this place needs to ditch the dance floor and invest in seats. Long wait times between opener and headliner made my legs tired for days.

RaD5TX018SIoEVhpxn_iOw.review_text: I was excited to visit the Fillmore the first time- the bartender was attentive and helpful, however the concert staff on the floor and near the upstairs balcony went out of their way to make my husband and I feel unwelcome. We were treated like intruders on the employee's private concert time. I can't wait to never return.

4ywZLLQQR0HXtVugJEMZkQ.review_text: Sound was good, venue is alright. Wouldn't let me in with my spikes on my kutte so I couldn't wear my overkill and testament gear to the show. So that sucked.

7EaPhtI69HEcGAvX0tFEkA.review_text: The Fillmore is one of the greatest venues for music and comedy!  Although you have to get past security and stand in line until the doors open, it's a great place to see some of your favorite performers.  The posters and the apples are my favorites!  The women's restroom is my least favorite thing.  A few things to remember:  -Want a table upstairs or a spot in front of the stage?  Get there pretty early and be prepared to stand in line and make sure when doors open, you head straight upstairs or claim your space on the downstairs floor.  -Watch for girls with long hair thrusting their bodies in every direction and hair flying about.  Some girl's hair got stuck in my ring I accidentally pulled her whole head back.  Fortunately, she apologized to me for being so spastic!  -Watch for the stupid drunk girls trying to get attention.  There are a handful of girls like this that frequent the Fillmore and it's not pretty when their holding a drink and shoving there way past you.  -Don't be scared to tell a tall person you can't see.  If you ask nicely, they usually move.  Overall, the Fillmore has a nice mix of people and a good vibe but that has more to do with the artists and bands that headline!  Thanks to some great musicians, the crowd is never really that bad.

8OgnC6Im-UN-IIeXCkmm_Q.review_text: I just saw Mike Doughty at the Fillmore, and what a great show, but this is a review of the venue not the band.  How can you not love the Fillmore.  Several bars, a wide open floor, and even some seats if you don't mind being away from the front of the stage.    It also has great history, and you gotta love the posters.  Yes they still give out posters, at least at the show I was at most recently.  If you love the band, see them here, if you don't love the band, still go see them here.

cZAYWsMFdKSwrAlRtRjnSw.review_text: The Fillmore has to be my favorite venue in SF. I usually go here all the time for shows and sometimes The Regency and Warfield. They book great acts here and I would say the venue is a medium sized venue. If you are watching from the back you have a clear view of the artist. The sound is super great and clear as well. I am a concert photographer and have to say this is by far the best venue when it comes to lighting. The staff is super friendly and polite, they greet you when you come in for the night. They also give you free apples as a snack. The drinks are a little pricey but they do have fresh (lemons) water out.

_tHjjf_pvM7i0QALYsKxdQ.review_text: Went to the fillmore the other night for some standup, was pleasantly surprised at how the venue adjusted because I've only ever been there for music shows. Good seating, table service for drinks, great vibes. Looking forward to going here again.

-EoaB87gPD41BM67j1fGCw.review_text: One of the sickest venues in the city!  This place has so much history it is literally pasted on the walls.  There's a reason why the raddest artists play here.    I dig the fact that you can get right up front or hang back in the wings, be in a pit or just grab some drinks and some decent barfood.  The bartenders know exactly what's up and security is actually nice wtf!?!  I saw my first show here back in the day and many others since.  Writing this review I cant wait to add to my free poster collection when I come here for NOFX!

N25XbMni2oNugGBkO85Baw.review_text: this place has the best acoustics of any venue i have ever been to. and all the history on the walls is amazing. love love love the place.

kIxtMTVrei0nj099L5WChg.review_text: I know it makes me decidedly unhip to give a 3-star to the Fillmore, but I guess I've ended up here for the wrong concerts lately which just haven't worked.  When I saw Wilco and David Gray here years ago, standing was fine.  But Lucinda Williams and more recently Jose Gonzalez (with Mia Doi Todd)?  I needed a chair.  Even if it was in the back.  And then those booths upstairs they kept empty, tempting me with their twinkling citronella-style candles.  Instead, I competed for wall-leaning space, then pushed forward only to be surrounded by awful talkers including second-pick frat boys, an overly effortful hipster guy who kept encouraging his drunk girlfriend to sway with him (and who yelled at the guy suggesting he go to the bar), and annoying airhead women talking about everything from how drunk they were to cooking technique.  Come on people.  It's too expensive a show for that kind of ignoring and ruining.  And my feet stuck to the ground where I was standing.  Not standard beer and food in carpet.  Something like superglue.  Yeah yeah, and the place is classic, the chandeliers are gorgeous, and there's apples.  I'll be back the next time there's someone I have to see.  But I'd take the Warfield balcony over the Fillmore floor any day.

-K2Tcgh2EKX6e6HqqIrBIQ.review_text: The original palace o'funk, and I ain't talking about the music.  This place reeks - old ciggie smoke, bo, farts, spilled old beer - you name it.

DLrptiHwqa0JLYFJsp4vzg.review_text: Robinson brothers at the Fillmore... Beautiful old school venue, not much for people watching, we'll call that crowd dependent, but always worth the price of admission.

q0HDybhT0V9dXrs63_WqWQ.review_text: How have i never reviewed The Fillmore?! I guess the third time really is the charm. Saw a few different shows here in the past year: Phoenix (A-M-A-Z-I-N-G), Ladytron, The Faint, Dredge, As Tall as Lions.  Their events have always been relatively organized, you wait in line in front of the post office, they call you up, feel you up (via frisking/security), stamp you up (if you're 21+), booze you up, and then you dance your face off. See? Organized.  The main dance floor is a decent size. You can rock out front row and get tossed around if you're small like me. Or you can hang towards the back and still get a great view of the stage and not risk bodily harm.  I could go either way (like a bisexual - Cleveland), both hanging on the dance floor or sitting upstairs by the balcony. I don't need to bump uglies with strangers in order to enjoy myself and dance. Their food menu is nothing special, yet satisfies you if you are unable to eat before a show.  And free posters of shows on your way out. What could be better?

ZCRu62ymZW8ibZkY6qZh-Q.review_text: Avoid The Fillmore. It crams 1200 people in one giant square, has an inane restrictive camera ban, charges way too much for shows, uses TicketBastard, is run by Clear Channel, and, to top it off, the staff are arrogant, unfriendly and unaccomodating.

7vZymr7LG2-a4u-LCV94XA.review_text: One of the best music venues in the bay. The Fillmore has a great variety in it's shows and every time I've been the sound was great. Free apples are nice. As are free posters at some shows. The old collection of posters is fun to look at. Purple chandeliers make an strange and awesome atmosphere. Great venue with great history.

5V1azKNKRbnmxu2bXDy95g.review_text: Despite the grumpy bartenders, I love, love, love this place.  Who doesn't?  The poster room upstairs is one of the coolest rooms I've ever been in, ever.  The walls are literally lined floor to ceiling with posters.  Reaaaaally old Fillmore posters all the way to present day.  It's so awesome.  The chandeliers are very pretty downstairs.  This place just has so much history and such a good vibe.  Awesome venue that is most definitely haunted by friendly ghosts of rock 'n roll past.  I mean, rumor has it Carlos Santana used to sneak in through a bathroom window.  Drinks are kinda spendy, but you're at the Fillmore.  And don't forget to stay to the bitter end of any sold-out shows...they only hand out posters for sold-out shows and they only hand them out *after* the band is done playing.

ghRwENzjazf5b94m5ga5NQ.review_text: I dig this place!  The posters alone are worth a visit...the frisking just bumps it from 4 1/2 stars to 5!!  You rock my socks off, Billy Graham.

d7-1w0E34ojZQZ8ei7W_MQ.review_text: I will start by saying last Saturday was my first time at The Fillmore. I have to say it was pretty magical. After entering the front door, I walked upstairs and was greeted by an old guy in a cowboy hat with a little gleam in his eye as he said, "Welcome to the Fillmore." I felt like I was in Detroit Rock City about to witness Kiss for the first time. The venue was super awesome, complete with chandeliers, balcony seating and lots of sweet posters. The main reason I left so thrilled is because the Violent Femmes rocked that joint. The whole fucking floor was shaking. Gordon, I love you. You fucking rocked.

WecuAsHBDZGj7Z6_sJcQAw.review_text: The history is incredible. So many years with so many bands ranging from the obscure to the popular, rock to pop and everything else in between. Totally dug the posters of old shows hanging everywhere you look. You are in an iconic venue.  Yet most of the time I was thinking to myself "you know, I wish I were at Ruby Skye".  Compared with Ruby, the ventilation is terrible, even with the music (Groove Armada) about half the speed of a DJ. It was hot, sweaty and uncomfortable, and making matters worse were the incessant pot and cigarette smoking. So disrespectful, and it was disappointing security wasn't enforcing, well, the law.   Veggie sliders off the food menu were good (and thanks for the side of house hummus), drinks are a bit expensive.  Third star is out of respect. I appreciate the Fillmore for the place in history it serves, I just don't think I'll be back anytime soon to create some of my own.

JgPUVaNG4vArVLVO7uR9nw.review_text: Went here for the free Maroon 5 concert and had an amazing time! It is a small venue, but nonetheless an amazing place to hold a concert. Make sure to grab an apple before watching your show. Also if you're a bit tipsy or drunk beware of the stairs!

PxV-kSdgt6IfAhlpnK_uGQ.review_text: One of my favorite venues AND they give you free apples.

PZAxZEq5s6o8EEkiwDHRJA.review_text: I'll make this short and sweet.  This venue has a rich and fabulous history and for good reason.  The sound quality here is amazing.  Hands down one of the best I've ever heard.  The auditorium is just the right size for an intimate show experience with a few hundred of your closest friends.  The drinks are pricey, but they have free apples.  Show up a bit early not just to get a good spot, but to take in the amazing gallery of photos and show posters that line the walls.  I saw Broken Social Scene here a week ago and cannot wait to come back.

edvxFqaTuqVdstoMHh0z2A.review_text: No other venue in the Bay Area compares to the Fillmore.  It's a must.

eCgDdwA-zA7unxyT68XOdQ.review_text: What can be said? It's a classic and timeless! I saw Volbeat there. This is a late review.

NOq2SPYWZ35EvzxzwVt-kw.review_text: Great venue. Security was quick and efficient with their searches. The person who checked our tickets was polite. The place is alot of big empty space, perfect for a rock show.They have a full bar and the bartender was great, they have newcastle on draft! I had an awesome night there and would definitely go back despite the unsavory neighborhood it is located in.

lqEshkGlPoDWQqedICadGw.review_text: one of the most historic landmarks in san francisco, i was so excited to finally see a show at the fillmore. even after living in san francisco for a year, i wondered why it took me so long. i caught m. ward here on friday night and i have to say the show was amazing. my friends and i had our arms on the stage, front row and center and had the best time ever. the cool waiters and waitresses that move through the crowd and bring you drinks, along with the lush decor of the venue gives it such a classic and wonderful feeling.  apples and posters on the way out are the best way to end the night. i can't wait to go back! :]

cx6CMeztrzFYAY0gpaC3Mg.review_text: Review #299.  I really had to think long and hard for this one. I didn't want to waste this review on just ANYTHING.   Suddenly, the light bulb goes off. YES! The Fillmore.  I have been an avid under cover rocker groupie since I was 18. I've seen countless shows in SFO. Maritime hall was my monthly hang out. I skipped out completely on the "Sound Factory" phase. LOL  Friday 6-20, I saw She Wants Revenge LIVE. OMFG!! They were amazing. I play the bass so I have a profound appreciation for musicians. This band sounds just like their album only BETTER!   This venue ROCKS. The sound system is awesome. I had room to jump and do the crazy rocker girl hair lashings (with out hurting anyone) and I was also able to make my way to the front. Close enough to watch the guitarist's fingers in action. (drool)    At the bar, drinks were $8 for grey goose vodka shots -I'm not complaining. A nice buzz for under $20 beats any club night! Still feel like you need a club ambiance? They have cool chandeliers all over and a clean bathroom. Can't ask for more!  Grown up, Glam'd up under cover rocker groupie shall return!

JnGtgOPpkjyWOvWM0SYEXg.review_text:
is that tommy pickles?..is that chuckie finster?...what are little rugrats doing out at night with grandpa?..i guess school hasn't started yet....reminds me of a high school  auditorium....crystal chandelier lightings hanging up above...
  am i in a land called honah lee?...puff, the magic dragon...there are kids all around......*cough cough*...
  as for the gnarls barkley...wasn't sure if i wanted to rock out...or just groove...mixed eclectic beats...funky vocals...fusion of hip hop, alternative and rock....chef and cook outfits was cool...colorful monster poster was cool..."oooh..look at the pretty colors"....beru x 5, jack x 1, glenlivet x 2 = happy buzzin' hen....

OQImub6evGiBTwpQmoVUjA.review_text: Great venue. Great staff. Great shows.  Don't forget to grab an apple on your way out! Nothing better than chomping on a juicy perfect red apple on the way back to the car, dishing with friends about how the show rocked.

i72fdXYYPunDWN5YJJOJYg.review_text: Death Cab for Cutie- $40  Kinky- $20  TV on the Radio- $25  Collection of a dozen one-of-a-kind show posters- $100  Losing my shoes while climbing onstage at the Girl Talk show- PRICELESS

ksLEtpBAdVGaEramRXYYSQ.review_text: This is an excellent venue for live music. The atmosphere is great and they attract some amazing talent to their stage. Go see a show here!

iVMa2jbZ90fXO1BL4SbYwA.review_text: I love the Fillmore.   Its one of my favourite places to see shows in the Bay area and the history alone makes it worth a visit.   They still have the apples at the door (thank you Bill!) and the staff is for the most part genial and helpful. (Note however to the balcony staff member who got irked about me taking a cell phone picture--do you really think I would have gotten anything even remotely decent for sale on a Droid phone from that distance. Chill bro!)  Unless you really can't stand crowds, stay on the floor.  If you don't have balcony seats upstairs, chances are you'll have a better view from ground zero.     The drinks are reasonable for a music venue and there are several bars about the place, which makes getting drinks easy and fast.  The food upstairs is good though a mite expensive.  And you get a poster of the show when you leave!   My only complain is the lobby set up.  Having the store, the woman's room and the coat check right in the way of one of the exit doors of the ballroom is nuts.  Getting your coat after a show can be like swimming upstream in a flood tide and claustrophobic.

XjAzSoztB6HCPZncnzcKqw.review_text: Can't say enough about this rad venue! The parking situation is pretty challenging, but it's that way for everything in SF, so no surprise there. Great space, waiters, and the concert posters at the end of the shows are the best thing since sliced potatoes! Definitely gives you your money's worth in entertainment and extras!!

Gsg0KxkQUeDjRaqf66k1Sw.review_text: JAMIROQUAI KICKED ASS HERE LAST YEAR!  WITH SO MUCH SMOKE IN THE AIR (wink wink) you almost couldn't see the stage :]  Great Venue for sure!

CiYRhDyFbsDbWR45uv822w.review_text: Love the bit of history for this place.  I like how they have a kitchen upstairs too... not that I have eaten there.  I've been here for two venues, and I loved it.  I loved the history, and the apples...:-)  Depends on what you see here, but the times I've gone, little seating and mostly standing room.  But it was fun.  The acoustics are good here.  It's a nice mix of people too.

ZWe5wfQb0Na_kD2DUoBtFA.review_text: This is by far my favorite Venue to see a concert. I love that there is a bar onthe second floor, I love the people who work here, and I love coming home with a Poster after feeling great about a rockshow. Also not to mention eating an apple on the way home is great way to sober up after a few cocktails. There are also great options for snacks, I highly recommend the nachoes. Lastly, if you do get a poster here, please keep it! Its a limited edition print, so you never know one day it will be worth a lot of money! I highly recommend going here on a monthly basis, I do!! It is a historical San Francisco music establishment that feels like  home.

XfMzHipwq46kIeQtiikFUA.review_text: This place seems to get good reviews because of the history. Well, the history is history. Clear Channel owns it now. We were subjected to a large advertising screen before the show and some tables hawking cell phones or something. The main floor is just a large auditorium - nothing special. A surly old bartender who has apparently lost his hearing due to too many rock shows got pissy with me because he completely misheard my drink order. There was feedback throughout the Gnarls Barkley show, which is inexcusable. The crowd had far too many teeny-boppers and yuppies who glared at me because I was dancing. Sometimes it seems that people in the Bay Area don't like to have fun. I liked the free poster after the show.

GtydL3IpjoLH5MYLDUgSxg.review_text: For the first time being at this venue, I really enjoyed it. I had tickets to go see Karmin (yay! Karmin!). Never having to be here it was hard to find a bit since there was a street spilt but thanks to the huge bus in front, my friend and I got there fairly okay. For it being in Japan town, parking was really easy and close to the venue. I really do appreciate close parkings to venues.   Once we got in, we went up the stairs to the huge room. I love love the chandeliers above and there were rows of them. There is also food to order upstairs and room to actually sit and eat. We watched the show from downstairs. Being close or near the stage you are still able to see from all directions.   Will have to see more shows here.

7tEUgFoRzy_TkOgzPQzCkA.review_text: The Fillmore is and always will be the shit.  I love this venue; it's not the Fox, but it's pretty rad.  It's so awesome that most events come with a free poster, and apples, too.  I cannot wait to plaster my walls with them, the posters, not apples.

Valva2MGzBW8ux3641YINA.review_text: Free Apple, Free Poster, Great Venue with alot of history. Also easy to see the stage all around. Love the Fillmore! Staff was friendly also.

_WHJzZTmIPJI1vH5xq9Mrg.review_text:
"I thought it would be bigger...... a lot bigger" a friend said to me once though he was thoroughly impressed..regardless of attending a number of shoes in venues spread across Germany & Mexico City.
  The area has a lot to offer depending on what you want, but I won't go there. 
 Drinks are fair and and the staff is great, especially considering all the crap they encounter. 
 Hey, if you came to my door lookin all froggy what would you expect?

XEqZvK-YLqt_7CbmvWgQxA.review_text: This review is a bit past due....   Ever since Imusicast closed its doors, I've been looking for a new favorite place to see my favorite bands. A place that is not too far, not too small but not overly large ( a place that is just Right). Coming to the Filmore I feel that the have filled the shoes most perfectly of imusicast then any of the other venues that I am been to due to the great friendly staff to the way the venue it runned and organized. The Fillmore is clean, secured, friendly and FUN. This venue allows you to get up close to the bands and still have room to move around between the surrounding fans.   and don't forget the goodies on the way out!- free apples and posters :)

1wGmJNbjrugmxHh3i8f9YA.review_text: If I were a giant say 10 stories high, I would choose to hump The Fillmore.  I just saw Rodrigo y Gabriela here - which ALL of you have to hear - wait NO, go buy their CD and listen to until you fall asleep touching yourself.  They are it.  The Fillmore has a way of making you feel like after the show's over the band is going to want to come to your house and jam while you show them what great weed you have and then break out family photo albums.  I really like seeing shows here and then telling people how stupid they are for not going here enough and buying Rodrigo y Gabriela's EF'ing cassette tape, 8-trak, CD, record what have you.  And then if they try to go to a show here and whip out their Blackberry to "record" the show, I give them the red eye salute and tell them to _______ it.

eKUGKQRE-Ywi5dY55_zChg.review_text: "Feelin' so fly like a G6... when sober girls around me, they be actin' like they drunk..." *Raises Hand* :T  James Prohgress Roh, H O L L A R! *ahem* Now, that I got that out of the way...  On Thursday, 9/16, I came here for the Mike Posner and Far*East Movement Concert (mainly for FM). Three other groups also performed XV, Stephen Jerzak and 2 AM Club which I'm not familiar with so my friend and I came to TF at about 8 PM. There was no line, so we got in w/in minutes.   Upon entering, a metal basket filled w/ Red Delicious Apples welcomes you to a nostalgic hippyish music arena. I wasn't born until the early 80s, but the TF is a place that I can imagine my parents coming to in their bell bottoms, platforms and waving a lighter back and forth.   1st FLOOR: *Stage w/ standing area only *There's small tables and benches to the right of the stage which you can snag *Main Bar to the left upon entering the stage area *Main Restroom: 7 stalls in women's restroom which is really clean *Merchandise Window near the staircase to the left *Smoking Area is outside to the left near the USPS office  2nd FLOOR: *Café and Bar: Prime Rib, Burgers, Hotdogs, Nachos, Quesadilla, Mozzarella Sticks, Chili, and Salad ($6-$13) *Balcony seating on the upper left corner w/ about 8-10 tables for 2-4 people. A major plus is you can order food and drinks at the tables so you can avoid waiting in line at the bar.  STAFF: All of the staff, ushers, bouncers, bartenders, and servers were very professional and very friendly.   BAR/DRINKS: We got Remy shots at the bar downstairs and upstairs in the balcony area. The bar was very crowded downstairs, so it took about 10 minutes to get a drink.   I honestly don't understand how some Yelpers can say drinks were expensive at TF. *scratches head* If you're comparing it to Happy Hour specials, than perhaps. All of the drinks were comparable to any local bar, restaurant and cheaper than most clubs. $20.50 for two Remy VSOP shots??? A STEAL especially when most places inflate prices for a special event.   *Beer: $6 *Wine: $6-8.50/glass *Well Cocktails: $7 *Top Shelf Liquor: $10.25-$10.75  $25 min for CC. There's an ATM located on the first level.  AMBIANCE/DÉCOR: TF has a very 70s vibe to it; large burgundy velvet curtains, faux crystal chandeliers, and a huge collection of rock posters that lines walls of the 2nd floor.  My biggest complaint is that there is NO ventilation. I felt like I was sitting in a sauna room at the balcony level and it wasn't even packed.   PARKING: Street parking and there's a parking garage located a block and half away across from Yoshi's which is cheaper than parking at the J-town garage. It's $3 for the 1st hour and $1 for every add'l hour.   As far as the concert goes, it was just blah. We couldn't really get a good view of FM w/ drunktards and boppers jumping and waving their hands in their air. Mike Posner was a little disappointing. So much so, that we left early before he sang, "Cooler Than Me".   There was an FM after party at Infusion. Some of my friends who didn't attend the concert went and I'm STILL kicking myself for not going (not a fan of Infusion). They were literally inches away from FM and even got to take pics w/ them. Ugh, excuse me while I throw yet another tantrum....*POUT*

Da4Nk1dmIOU044Qc0gfPnw.review_text: I gotta say, I fail to see what is so great about this place. I went to my first show here recently, Sharon Jones and the Dap Kings, and I was super excited highly anticipating a great show at a historic iconic venue anyone in music has heard of. I knew seating would be limited, but, limited=pretty much non-existent. There is some seating on the floor along a wall that is reserved for handicap, and some tables and chairs upstairs that fill up immediately upon doors opening. I think some employees had them reserved for friends, but, OK. We did find a table with no stage sight lines but figured, "hey, we are here, let's enjoy the show". Regrettably, the sound mix was horrible- it was muddled, and not at all sharp. The experience was lacking and I am disappointed.

BbBzub67X5sAHHTEtk2GAA.review_text: I love this venue :)  It's intimate and perfect for concerts! I was once in the front row for The Veronicas and Natasha Bedingfield.  I came another time for 2PM and was near the middle but I could still see relatively fine. The pushing and crowded-ness is part of the experience!  No assigned seating and STANDING only - first come first served, so come early if you have a concert!  Near the 38 bus stop, the area is not TOO shady if you don't venture off to the Fillmore side, lol.

kofiqkPOeo1loQHsVbxQXg.review_text: I first came here to see The Juliana Theory in concert and I remember it being a solid venue. I've been here for shows a few times here and there and what I like about this place is how spacious it is, but at the same time, it gives off that cozy intimate vibe. I know...it's a contradiction, like most things in life...  They have a nice little bar for the 21+ although they are an 18+ venue and sometimes all ages. A lot of good talent passes through here and the sound is good.   I didn't truly appreciate The Fillmore until I was dragged around to a bunch of other venues to check out shows and such and suffered from tween and prostitot invasions and claustrophobia.   Oh what experience does to a jaded soul...

0I99ibr1vy7yiHIUdo3Zyw.review_text: What can I say about The Fillmore that hasn't already been said?    Well, it's amazing and is heralded by EVERYONE as a San Francisco staple as far as concert venues are concerned that EVERY music lover MUST make a priority to visit at least once!  (Phew!  Gosh I can be long-winded sometimes.)  My very first concert in San Francisco was at the historic Fillmore and I couldn't help but be blown away -- the acoustics are incredible, being amazed at seeing the throngs of posters on the walls of bands previously played in days past, feeling that strange sense of fellowship one tends to feel when being one with a handful of other music lovers just like yourself.  I've seen Stars, Architecture in Helsinki, Broken Social Scene, and Yo La Tengo here, among other fantastic shows.  C'est magnific!  Anywho, I love the free posters they hand out here for the sold-out shows.  In fact, I love 'em so much, I frame 'em all (Thank you, Cheap Pete's!  An ensuing review to follow...).   ;-)

K9ejqgRQsGQOuM43hKtN8Q.review_text: Ode to More of Fill:  "Oh, the Fillmore- YOu rise above the rest, Compared to other SF venues, your shows surpass all tests, You give me free posters, from each and every show, Bjork and Micheal Franti, Spearhead, Brett Dennen, and Mo'.  The Fillmore is the bomb shit- Damien Marley would agree, Sevendust has been thru there, and even Muse was seen. The balcony is swingin', the blue chandeleirs a treat, The pits moshed, and souls rocked, have all been so sweet. Minds blown, heads throughly ROCKED.  You have brought me Ani DiFranco in the flesh, Goddess of folk,  funk-possessed! A good view from anywhere, and sound that's not too bad, Some of the nights I've spent with you are the best I've ever had.  Nevermind the Ticketmaster service charges to which we're all WHORES! I can't even recall the countless acts I've seen here, which have blasted open my ear's doors.  Thank you Fillmore, Thank you very much. GOOD NIGHT!

S8nyk8xt0MHrdwilzCKjgA.review_text: I don't have much to add. I'm in love with The Fillmore. The sound was excellent. I saw The Black Angels. I parked at the Japantown pay lot nearby and spent all of $2. Drinks are pricey here, so if that's your thing, come prepared ($$$).

ZOY3wZx-nDaVWJBP6h4ntQ.review_text: I freaking LOVE the Fillmore!  It is my absolute FAVORITE place to see a concert.  I don't think there is a bad spot in the joint.  The bars in the place are good, although a little pricey, but whatever- it's SF, most bars are pricey.  I love the little posters you get as you're walking out!  Music sounds good, small venue, landmark of the city, what more would you ask for?

t9YV7lYieU6TnLfRNeOzWw.review_text: The sound is excellent, you can see the band from almost anywhere (as long as some unaware *sshole doesn't stand right in front of you), the history is amazing, Blue Cheer played there, etc.  Great!  What knocks The Fillmore down for me is the egregiously overpriced drinks.  There is no excuse for a $6 domestic bottled beer.  What is this, a Giants game?  I call bullsh*t and I mean TOTAL bullsh*t.

VK0bI-bc2o_oXMRXczPunQ.review_text: I've seen so many bands at the Fillmore...from Echo and the Bunnymen (yeah, what?!?) to Umphrey's McGee (oh hell, yeah!).  The Fillmore is a beautiful venue with a rich history, awesome poster room, free posters at the end of the night for most bands, and good bar service.  I love this place and will miss it with a passion when I leave SF.

5vXqog3DHrRXADKUg78B2w.review_text: People might think I'm crazy for seeing Spoon three nights in a row at the Fillmore. I actually thought I might be crazy at one point.   But then I went. I saw. I conquered. And it was an incredible experience. To see your favorite band for a Fillmore residency when you happen to be a major music nerd is really beyond description - you get to compare and contrast set lists, witness new guest appearances and band interactions each night, and believe me, Spoon did not disappoint on any level. This was all truly enhanced by the Fillmore's perfect atmosphere, cold beer, and genius lighting designer (seriously, whoever was in charge of the lighting deserves a friggin' Nobel Price for concert ambiance). Britt Daniel ended their set last night by saying "we won't ever forget this experience," and neither will I.   Also, I got to hang out with some seriously cool yelpers during this whole experience. In order of appearance: Suzanne A., Keith M., Pamela D., Trey C., and Mike Z. (complete with his super cool wife). How lucky am I?

i_AwdRWTooVI-CkGxVIWVw.review_text: Guaranteed best seats in the house at this venue no matter where you are with a great atmosphere and legendary history of artist performances.  The last concert I saw was the Breeders and it was amazing. Better than the Warfield although the Warfield has other benefits such as a better balcony and larger capacity but in the Fillmore all tickets are General Admission making every seat the best seat (so to speak). Highly Recommended

Oz3fPHwNBCP8o-rEHBl1tA.review_text: I love that you feel like so much has happened in this place...check out the posters upstairs in the balcony. It's small enough that you can actually see the bands...and you leave feeling like you've witnessed and been a part of something in a different way than seeing a show in a sports arena.

zr29K-tN08M7XQsSDaP1Fg.review_text: this venue was better than i thought it would be. i'm not a fan of big places, but the fillmore wasn't too bad at all. i don't particularly like that the merch is off to the side in a not convenient place. buses stop directly in front of the building, there are some shops around for quick eats, and you get a free poster upon exiting! they allowed cameras when i went (which i wasn't too happy about because i had already stuck a disposable down my pants! sucka!) so if you're close enough you can get some good pictures. also, there's this one guy who works there and he was HELLA crazy. like, i was on bus and he kept asking me where he should put his poster because his last craig david one was stolen. i gave him some good tips about decorating and he told me what happened on the last bernie mac.  -1 star because it's still pretty big compared to slim's or bottom of the hill.

Xhfn9CDIHwNaUDjPpsBm7A.review_text: It doesn't get much better.  I always get a wave of exhilaration walking up those steps and then seeing the amazing photos lining the walls.  I hate that I have to buy tix through Ticketmaster, though.  That's the one thing that will stop me from buying tix to a show that I'm 60-40 on.  The service fees are ridiculous.  But if you go to a sold-out show be sure to stick it out through the encore for your free poster.  Depending on the show, the poster makes it worth it regardless if the band showed even up.

qqmst5S4N4kBXOn3Th3I8g.review_text: This is one of the larger venues in the city so more well-known artists play here. It's probably the next step down from places like the Shoreline Pavilion. Parking can be difficult as with anywhere in the city, and it's not located near market and the BART stations so you'd have to catch a muni or a taxicab. I like it, but I prefer smaller more intimate venues where you can get close to the stage.

eWk2Jb9lL0EiUPq5c3hjkQ.review_text: One of my very very favorite venues in the city! If an artist I want to see is touring more than one venue, I always choose this one! Great artists tour here, usually at reasonable price ranges, and its general admission so everyone stands (at least everyone I'm around, some may sit, but I'm always very near, if not at, the stage) and it maintains an intimate fun, atmosphere.  Also there's free apples (interesting running tradition/trait they got goin on)   that you can grab at on the way out.  Lots of cool signed and framed posters/portraits of many artists on their walls (history has taken place at this venue!).  Sometimes free posters on the way out. Plus it's just groovy and  edgily decorated. Even in and around the bathrooms. Friendly staff too. One minus: there have been a couple times when the soundguy didnt balance all the acoustics too well, mostly with the result of the singer being the least heard. & along with it difficult to understand the lyrics at times. But this is a problem I've run into all over the place, and definitely not venue-specific.

UJV92-v6CXyKx4h6ny1I2w.review_text: I'm going a different direction here.    Here are some tips for people who are scared of the big city(who don't live in it) like me and get intimidated.  You know, the kind of intimidated that might keep you from going to a show because someone writes shit about getting robbed or their car broken into.    *  Take Van Ness to Geary and then vice versa to get out.  Let's not play with the Google maps that suggest side streets.  *  I didn't park on the street because of all the reviews that said your car will broken into.  I had to park a little further but I think that was necessary for car safety.  *  I parked at the Japan Town garage 2 blocks away  and took all my stuff out of view of the car.  Its well lit and very cheap (50 cents an hour).  There are a lot of people an staff in there, while not immune from the smash and grab, seemed like a good option.  *  With 2 blocks to walk I really recommend walking with somebody and not bringing your entire wallet/purse to the show.  Leave it at home and bring your ID and some cash and maybe a single credit card.    *  Go early.  Easier parking and even though doors say 8pm, they let you in 30 mins earlier...well at least the show I went to.  Hopefully it will still be light out.  *  Leave with everybody else at the end of the show.  Strength in numbers.  I didn't find the north or south side of the street any more or less creepy but people say stick to the south side.  I passed some skeevies on that side at the bus stop, so I can't rec.    The shows end early(by 11pm) so the real nasty zombies aren't out yet.    Be safe and enjoy the show!

dTcYw_RuYUm-j83emwDnUQ.review_text: Come here if you want to enjoy acid apples.  Hippy Hangout!!!

O8i10nA3Dh1bfqF1IWWvrA.review_text: I find the Fillmore to be a great experience. It would get 4.5 if that was an option. I personally enjoyed hearing Willie Nelson cover a Janis song...ahh, the history, so. great.   The size is great, as are the freebies, apples and posters, oh my!   It loses a star for the drunks that fall all over the place and don't seem to have friends with them to help out. Arms are flying, beer is spilling, drunks are angry when asked to leave or peace out. weird.   Willie did a great job here...highly recommended!

tU3sDq7hTMZs6VSnyolI1A.review_text: My favorite venue in town, next to the Warfield.  The Fillmore has the same nostalgiac feel to it.  I love the balcony seat, so long as I can get up close to the stage for an eagle's eye view of my fav band.  Les Claypool turns this place into a circus, Billy Corgan made it as mellow as could be, and Ozomatli turned the place into one big party!  Take some time to walk around and look at all the posters hung on the walls.  So cool.

VKHzPLata1ygaWuPKwLdAA.review_text: I love the Fillmore. enough said.

KnFQ7vgf109pRI4fyMqgwg.review_text: I went to the Fillmore for the first time over New Year's Eve. While it may be hard to separate three days of debaucherous celebration from a more objective assessment of the venue, I was sober for a few minutes here and there, so I will make a valiant attempt.  Parts of it were just what I expected: the drinks were way overpriced and watered down, the line from the ladies' room crowded the lobby, and you can get dizzy just breathing, because the atmosphere seems to maintain a ratio of 3:1 air to pot smoke. This doesn't necessarily distinguish it from any other venue. What was spectacular about the Fillmore was the layout and the dcor. The open floor area is nothing new, but the balcony allows early arrivals to secure tables that overlook the stage and crowd. The view is spectacular, and you get table service so that you don't have to miss the show standing in line at the bar. The back room on the second floor also features a small stage and tables to chill out at before or after shows. There is also an impressive array of framed concert posters from past shows that cover most of the walls.   As for sound, I was really amazed that the venue sounded as good as it did. I guess that should be expected considering all the live recordings that have transpired here, but I was still impressed by the acoustics.   The other truly amazing thing about the Fillmore: the people who worked security were so, so nice. Very helpful, very professional, and very courteous.

AL4A1tD_JFUyO6Dp_yCARg.review_text: The best large venue in San Francisco. Not a bad seat in the house, and the food is suprisingly tasty. I have been to over 50 shows here and I plan on see about infinity more.

kTZaKrqESMdMn-t6ptmedg.review_text: There's nothing I look forward to more than getting a poster at the end of a show.  And for that reason alone, this place rocks above all others.  But throw in the fact that this place has all of the insanely awesome acts come though along with the tremendous musical history and there's no comparison.  I've yet to have a bad experience here and hopefully the good tunes will keep on rolling.

vSTi9G85c5c8RNPFIEMETQ.review_text: My favorite music venue in San Francisco. The history, the vibe, the decor, the awesome artists that perform here...Extraordinary!   Plus I have fond memories of meeting the members of my favorite band, Midnight Oil, here. I also met them a second time at the Fillmore a couple of years later, and then a third time at the House of Blues on Sunset Boulevard in L.A. But you always remember your first.

DaLuHdGrTVuMYTxigEDpfg.review_text: I love coming to The Fillmore for shows. Growing up in San Francisco, I have come here for so many shows over the years. In fact, my very first concert was at The Fillmore. I saw Hoobastank. (And I am definitely NOT proud of that fact. It was not my choice.) I've also seen everyone from Hanson to Dita Von Teese. That sums up how versatile the Fillmore is. Everyone stops by here at some point.   How can you not love a place that passes out free shiny red apples? Don't worry. Unless you're Snow White, feel free to accept an apple. Free red delicious apples is a tradition that's tied to the Grateful Dead. Going to guess their fans liked using them as apple bongs. Free posters for selected sold out shows is pretty awesome too.   Parking in the area can be a little tricky if you cut it close to showtime. I just park in the Japantown garage. It's not outrageously expensive at night.

oW2bCSJ5bIHyRnoZvkHwDg.review_text: I don't know why I was so mean last time.  It has gotten much better, and reminds me of the lovely ole timey concert going experience.  Well done everyone.   Anyhoo... I usually miss the shows staring at all the bills.

RQR-bncvVssevK_WIPWvCA.review_text: I realized that, as a person who goes to a fair number of concerts during the course of a year, I should Yelp about all the venues I've been to. So I figured I'd start a long line of reviews with probably my favorite - the Fillmo'.  I've seen a lot of great shows here - Coldplay's first US tour (I was on TV - back when they had the Live at the Fillmore show on KBHK TV), Sigur Ros' first US tour, BRMC (several times), Travis, Basement Jaxx (massive subwoofer between the crowd and the stage), David Gray, etc.   It's got great history, sound, free apples, friendly greeters, etc. I love the Fillmore!

sL3Onn_3L9eKH3fBU5XTBQ.review_text: I have no idea how many great shows I have seen here! this place is small enough to see some of your favorite bands up close and personal. plus there is so much music history here! I love going upstairs, getting a drink and looking at all the bands which have played here. and another plus is sometimes you get a free poster after the show!

veLWPGA-1MMtcRNDYWm-BA.review_text: The best place on earth to go see Blue October & I look forward to seeing them again in March!  I love the history, and the tradition that this place embodies.  I have all the posters I have collected over the years from shows - framed on the walls of my office.    I love the red delicious apples, and the vibe. I love the chandeliers.  I love that you can come here on a Sunday morning and get tickets and not pay a service fee.  I REALLY love that, matter afact.    You can't help but walk in here and feel a little bit of always, with each step, a transformation back in time.

jN9Q7s0Bt8BSNpYiCa2SRA.review_text: As far as music venues go, The Fillmore is one of my favorites. Sure, its standing room only and when the music gets going there are people sloshing and spilling their $8 whiskey sours everywhere. And if you are offended by plumes and plumes of smoke..well this might not be the place for you. But it is such a place of music history and you feel it as soon as you walk up those stairs.  We went to an incredible concert here this last Friday (Martin Sexton and Ryan Montbleau Band) It was nothing short of amazing. The whole vibe of the Fillmore and these talented artists made it an evening I won't soon forget.

58v49MNYAJXxzxNsJvsoKA.review_text: I've been to the Fillmore probably about 50 times give or take! I absolutley love the Fillmore. I've seen some of the best performances of my life here and I've seen some memorable ones too. Some of the most influential bands have performed here in the 60's including Hendrix, Pink Floyd, Led Zeppelin, Aretha Franklin! Some big names and it's continued that tradition since it's re-opening in '94.  Can I just give props to the lighting designers!!! Every show I got to The lighting is freaking cool! I've never seen a repeat or anything ho-hum there!  Ok 2 tips if your seeing a band @ the Fillmore. Get there early so you can take a look upstairs @ the posters! and leave pretty quickly after the show ends and you may get a poster of your own!

0VSYg6fElU8br_iSOeulGg.review_text: It's a standard indie rock venue.  On the plus side, they give you free apples and free earplugs.  Sometimes they give you free posters when you leave.  On the negative side, Live Nation is pimping out 'The Fillmore' as a brand and starting a 'House of Blues'-like chain of them around the country for some reason.  Otherwise, my only significant memory from The Fillmore is to never go see Cat Power live unless you really need a nap.  Or a free poster.

Gy7RgkjAazR361DPUquCZg.review_text: Been there for the first time last night to see Phantogram, and it was amazing. Loved the old school chandeliers and overall vibe, and full bar was awesome. Free posters and apples were the perfect end to an awesome night.

pKSQpYEyaV6s38GVEOtxzg.review_text: What can I say?  It lives up to all your expectations.  Watching Paul Stanley on that stage was the highlight of 2006.

5KhlJvKL_gh4ACpmn82Yow.review_text: If you like live music...a visit to the Fillmore is with out question mandatory! Classic San Francisco in every way. You feel as if you are walking through a time warp the minute you get to the top of the stairs. The history is dripping from the walls.....a pre show beer in the poster room is required. I love to go and look for the posters of all the shows I have been to.....the BEST place I have ever seen a show and I have seen some great ones...Blues Traveler, Stone Temple Pilots, Elvis Costello, CSN, Buddy Guy, Tom Petty..Gomez. The list goes on and on. I can not say enough about the Fillmore. One of my favorite places!!!!

ec6dD21w001YnmR1p6ZbNg.review_text: I love this place. Went to see One Republic here at Fillmore. However, the ticket did not mention anything about other bands. There were about 5 bands opening for One Republic. One of them was The Phantom, if you watch the O.C. they were the one singing "CALIFORNIA". I did not know who they were, until they sign that song. Not that I watch the O.C., but I've heard the song before.  If you want to get close to the band you have to go there early and wait in front of the line. The place was not that hard to locate. My gf doesn't like to stand for long time, therefore we were sitting by the bar. I think, it was the best spot in the house. It was our first and won't be our last, I'm going to go there again that for sure.

yTFlhnkPonxylwfzBVh56g.review_text: The history. The feel. I saw Goldfrapp there and she had the whole place rocking. You can spend hours in the upstairs poster room alone simply gazing the walls. The food smelled good too. Great Venue. Good Vibes from Audience and Staff. They say no cameras but its pretty easy to get em in and everyone camera phoned the show.

ZbOK_2m4kifew3lzTep1yQ.review_text: Before going to The Fillmore for the Ministry concert, we decided that it was probably a good idea to get trashed. So we went to the Boom Boom Room and had...more than a couple of drinks.   We arrive to The Fillmore and of course, ordered another drink. Stayed for the opening act, and went upstairs to try their delicious food....that I was too trashed to eat much of.  Then I had another drink.  Thank GOODNESS the drinks held up throughout the entire 2 1/2 hours of moshing. I have to thank Rob for holding me up the ENTIRE TIME, and recommending I wear my combat boots.  I'm definitely looking forward to attending more shows here (Spoon in September, anyone?...anyone?)  5 stars for getting punched in the face the first 20 minutes of moshing.

nmiJ5fFouffXmoNXThJyjw.review_text: I love this venue.  Historic feel and the layout is great, even though I never get there early enough to get one of good seats upstairs.  Only catch with The Fillmore is the staff at the window and downstairs (no problems with folks working the restaurant and bar areas):  they are unfriendly, rude, aggressive, and arrogant.  They act like douchebag rock stars.  I have a thing about politeness and when a degenerate wage-worker with a superiority complex is unnecessarily abrasive for no reason, I ding points.  This gripe is rooted in more than one experience on more than one occasion, with different members of their staff.  I think a lot changed (for the negative) when Live Nation or Clear Channel signed an exclusive with them.  But I'm not sure.  All that aside, it's still a classic spot that I recommend.

64fMh0AYS1e7wb0QKHqC0g.review_text: It's pretty nondescript from the outside, but it's got everything a great venue needs!  There are only seats upstairs and a few off to the side, but you can see the stage very well (well, unless you're short like me) no matter where you stand.  There's a bar at the back and off to the side of the stage.  There was a wait at the ladies room, but it wasn't bad.  Security was great - the performance was not to be filmed or photographed, and the guards were on top of it as well as they could be and without being total dicks.   We saw Dita Von Teese's show Strip Strip Hooray!  Fucking AMAZING show and The Fillmore was the perfect venue for it.

pj7ludY9j7M_ptGnadhC_A.review_text: Let me recap my rock star night... it all began with my getting rock star ready at my pad, then we all went over to my friend's apartment to preparty before cruising to the Filmore to see Steel Pulse, a reggae legend.  I already was prepared for a fun night out with my crew and my Sparks really kicked the night off right. We got to the Filmore where I was greeted by my friend who works the front door.  We were escorted in and the reggae was puuummping!  The show was amazing.  The staff was outstanding.  The type of venue staff that let you be, let you dance, and most importantly.. let you party with the Rock stars on stage.  Steel Pulse was on fire!  The venue was beautiful with crystal chandeliers and the sold out show was crowded but not at all packed too tight.   I will be back again and again.

XgCBzxoBgTq60lBpg4dqdg.review_text: As we all know, the Fillmore is a very historic music venue in the city.  I am a fan because this is the style many venues have adopted and mimic to be successful.  What makes the Fillmore better than many in my opinion is that it is upstairs which gives the wood floor a slight movement with people and the music.  I LOVE that and concrete floors cannot duplicate this feeling.  I love that they still check coats and she will let you double them up for one charge instead of two.  Parking issue you say?  I say not.  Mall one block down the street with tons of underground parking.  Only cost me 4 BUCKS last show.  I spend more than that on a coffee most places!  I love the Fillmore and keep the shows coming!!!

WcKhdyAJd3YIRemYr6pAFA.review_text: Right after the complementary pat down (hey, can you check my prostate while you're down there) and after the alchy-hol hand-stamp you will be greeted by Tim. Tim is just a regular guy who is retired and is now a greeter for the Fillmore. Cause he loves music. After the hello you come upon a bucket of apples. Why Apples?? Back in the hay-day of psychedelia when you saw a concert at the Fillmore, they always had a tub of apples that had been soaking in LSD. Take the apple, take a bite, and enjoy the ride... Bill Graham could also be seen handing out apples and posters at the end of a show too.   Now the fruit is sans drugs but it is a fantastic nod to the past. This is what I love about the Fillmore. It remembers its past while looking towards the future. i love bringing out-of-towners here and taking them upstairs and showing them the concert posters. It is honestly like a pictorial tour of rock n' roll history from the 60's to the present. I still look at them every time I'm there. To see who played when, who opened for who, etc. They sill give out concert posters but only for acts  that sell-out and you have to have to stay to the end of the show to receive it. i love getting them and have some framed posters hanging in our house now.   Many bands play here and most consider making it to the big leagues when they headline the Fillmore. That's why so many acts record their shows here and release it for sale. It is a big deal to perform here. The venue is intimate and gorgeous and this really adds to experience. it has soul. It's not all roses and sugarplums however. Unless you can make it down to the ticket window you do have to go through Ticketmaster and drinking in venue isn't cheap by any stretch of the imagination.   Interestingly enough, this was the original Fillmore West but at one point the neighborhood turned so unsafe they moved it over the Van Ness where the Elite Club is now. But after the Earthquake in 94 they moved it back to it's original location. This all happened before I moved to the Bay Area so I can't speak of the other location but for its current...It is easily my favorite place in the world to see a band play. As long as I live in SF I will always check out bands here... probably long after it is cool for someone my age to goto concerts. That's right, i will be the creepy old guy attending the concert by himself.   Fillmore, look at what you are doing to me!

K1lkv1Zpnzsl3n08Zv04kg.review_text: "Sweeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeet disposition..."  The crowd sways to the sweet melodic sounds... one girl is yelling in my right ear. I want to smack her.   It continues, sweet melody resonating across the room.  "a moment, a love a dream, a laugh a kiss, a cry our rights, our wrongs a moment, a love a dream, a laugh a moment, a love a dream, a laugh"  She yells off beat again, now I want to smack her and her boyfriend in the head, for letting her yell offbeat and thinking it's adorable. You are just ruining this moment for me, and yet also making it more memorable.   This is what a concert is about, or at least any one worth attending. It's about the loud annoying child behind you. Or the group of insanely tall amazon business women who decide the smart thing to do is to link arms to get out of the joint, when really creating an obstacle harder for them to get out with as well as a giant wall for other people. Or the dozen plus folks that managed to sneak in joints and puff them nonchalantly in front of children, or better yet, ARE children.  But yeah, that's what a concert is about, I saw The Temper Trap. It was awesome and the piece de la resistance... a free poster at the end of the concert. Value win.  P.S. I've also seen Modest Mouse here live for a private company showing, also very good. Plus the upstairs room has the best collection of the posters that they give out here.

2HMimmsrNZrGCi_V90Prlw.review_text: This venue is alright. The staff is horrible (why the bad attitudes?!). Acoustics are good. Drinks are $8 (beer/well) and up... The floor is bouncy.  I only write reviews after a particularly good or horrible bad experience. In the vase of the Fillmore, its the latter.  I had a photo credential for a show and approached a bouncer to ask what the photo pass meant (there was no pit, side stage was inaccessible). He was SO RUDE and rather than answer my question like a reasonable human he was physically threatening and started yelling at me. Going outside was an episode of 3 different people aggressively telling us that we would not be let in if we left, even after the understanding that we were going to the smoking area. Then, some power tripped door guy tried to make me take a 10 minute "time-out" before he would let me back in last night. Even with press credentials he insisted on X-ing my hand before he would (very reluctantly) let me back in.  What is up with the bad attitudes? Maybe last night was a fluke but I feel strongly that I will not be returning to this venue anytime soon. There are way better places in the Bay Area to see a show.. don't waste your money at this one.

YIGfwfx749ZSI_Q0nZyGNQ.review_text: my most favorite music venue HANDS down....I love this place.    If I could see every concert here, I would be in heaven - super intimate, not too big/not too small, just right like baby bear's porridge.

m7ZeYWWAhh_OQQ4kO0qKOw.review_text: I've been there twice, really good place, nothing to say against.

0OGtVvlnDK598SRz5JDKWQ.review_text: Been here a few times now.  As a frequent concert goer, I dig this place as one of my favorite venues around the U.S.  Saw Metallica XXX there, night 1.  Saw the Tragically Hip there in 09 two nights.    Heading back in a few weeks for Gomez.  Can't wait.  Rock me Fillmore, rock me hard.

QXZn9G1UiN6PcQHhRuCiQg.review_text: Amazing place to see a show! Crowd depends on the band, drinks are light on the good stuff but what a great venue!

cth0NPkBES5a5p1D-5dybQ.review_text: Good times were had at The Fillmore.  I used to live a block and a half away and man was that ever the best. I love The Fillmore because it's a small enough venue to make a pretty intimate show - then again most venues in S.F. are. It's pretty convenient too - right along the Geary buslines and the 22 which is also an owl. Free posters. Beautiful antique details in the interior. God, I love this place.

CcOZLOAeKx0RTuuYD3OCyw.review_text: Food: Good Beer:  Good Bartender: Cute Music:  Good Restroom:  Bad all in all one of the better places to see a music concert when looking for new mixed with nostalgia.

y1nqu0J8Eq1560qpMQvjfg.review_text: I avoid this venue. I've seen Ani DiFranco and Amos Lee there twice respectfully and I've been miserable each time. First of all, it's a standing room only venue. Now in my thirties, I've earned the privilege of having seat. I'm also super short, so unless I arrive super early and stay in the exact same spot all night- I'm screwed. I know it's legendary and all, but I would rather drive to Napa or Santa Rosa to see a show than spend a night at the Fillmore.

F2m7Fzme8ZN1unuLsW0XoA.review_text: So I've been here several times, and now I'll only go to this venue if there's no other option when seeing the band I want to see. First off, as someone who works with sound for a living, I have to say that the acoustics of the space could be a lot better. It's basically a big black rectangular box, so it's kind of boomy and you lose a lot of the tonal clarity. Secondly, all the drinks are waaaay overpriced. The mixed drinks are tiny and weak, and what you would expect to pay for a stellar Belgian ale at any other establishment will get you Heineken or Sierra Nevada. And then there's the dance floor. Sure, it's nice to be able to see the band, but dancing? That floor gets sticky fast so good luck. It's probably due to the fact that the waitresses, as part of their job, have to weave in and out of the crowd with drinks, spilling them in the process. By the end of a show the floor starts to feel really gross. Of course, if you want to take a break from dancing, good luck. There's no place to sit really. Once before a show I tried to even sit along the benches on the wall when there wasn't even anyone there, and I was asked to leave the area. Add that to seeing bouncers trying to tell people where they can or can't stand on the sidewalk (wtf?), and I've about had it with this venue. I only give one star for the apple, which I have been known to snack on sometimes (not really much of a pothead). The Fillmore might be an historic venue but it definitely misses the bar for me. I'd rather go to the Independent down the street.

PDMzyUvdCJd8Da_FuD4anA.review_text: No need to add another in depth review for the 5 billionth time.  Go just to see the awesome wall of concert posters...its cool going back in time!  Oh also Ratatat was there too...cool.

MxluzI5vFj4f8nB1bPJk_g.review_text: Love love love this place. The Fillmore is full of history, life, good times, and of course, good music. I've come here by myself when a friend ditched me last minute and with huge groups where I can't be bothered to list all the names and all of the times, I've always really enjoyed myself.   It's awesome for so many reasons, and one that I really appreciate is that they house a huge variety of artists ranging in a wide spectrum of genres. There's something for everyone, and mostly all of the time, it's really good music.  The parking isn't bad once you get off Geary. Or the easiest, most efficient way is to actually take the 38/38L which stops right in front. Though going back might be a little sketchy, but if you're with a group it should be fine. But if you're a real San Franciscan, you'll figure it out . . . and if you're a real San Franciscan, you have to at least have seen one show here at The Fillmore (and have a kick ass time)

MS2ekUa-KAERjQ0xmCrfoQ.review_text: Great venue!  I just saw broken social scene here last weekend, and the show was amazing! The upstairs area is cool, because you can sit/chat/relax up there til the show starts (and even during the opening act if you dont care).  I love how they have all the posters framed of people who have played there.  They also have a bar upstairs which is pretty cool.  You can even order food if you want.  There are reserved tables in the upper balconies, and im not sure how you get them, but they had a good view of the stage.   The downstairs floor is crackin!  This is a great place to go to rockout and dance while youre listening to your fave band perform.  The place is kinda small, gets kinda crowded, and gets kinda hot, but all in all, its a cool place to check out.   kevin drew, i love youuuuuuuu!!!!!

XQ_JSYsiymIw51Ni042M-A.review_text: For those of you who don't know, The Fillmore IS music history. The Fillmore is more important than a movement because it's been host to every movement since hippies first said, "The man is schwag!"   It's muse. It's the canvas. It's where you grow up and then, where you're born again.   The Fillmore has been host to bands ranging from Jefferson Airplane to Nas and Atmosphere. The vast breadth of music has undoubtedly influenced many into the world of creation. I know that when I decided to go to music school, the Fillmore was one of the reasons.   The floor is where I spent most of my time because it's where the action is. But I've had some very memorable conversations during warm-up DJ's and bands up on the mezzanine level. In fact, one of my best friends went on his first date with his wife at The Fillmore. I was there to chaperon of course.   The point of The Fillmore it to give everyone a chance regardless of genre. If you walk in with a closed mind, you're not at the right place. But if you're there for the experience and your open to the new, you've arrived at the right place.

IYmw8q8C-lTb3kMucoHy4Q.review_text: This is the stuff of legends. If you need proof, there's photographic evidence along the walls. It took me a while to really appreciate all this venue has to offer. Prone to snobbery, most places others swear by are subject to my utmost scrutiny. On my second visit, I was sold. Various lounge opportunities, spectacular sound, and gorgeous chandeliers (not acoustically significant but nice to look at). I haven't had a bad time here yet.   Bonus, when shows are sold out, they print posters for the headliner, which are good for both nostalgia and framing.

0udgQbyppi1nj2DW0HqrLQ.review_text: Came to see Enanitos verdes concert ( famous Argentinia Rorck band ) with my girlfriends it is a standing room only we came 2 hours before the concert to make a line outside four people were ahead of us. Once inside we stood in front of the stage. Personally it is worthy to come early if you want to see your favorite band really close. Couple of Security guys are at the front those guys were nice the gave us free bottle of water we were so thirsty for jumping and screaming a lot. There was no pushing, no drama, no fight that night, just the smell of some weed. I had a great night I only pay 45 bucks to be at the front rather than paying $500 somewhere else. It was my second time here, the first time saw James Blunt. This venue is perfect for that. They will give you poster of the band that is playing but that night  they didn't give us poster of my Enanitos Verdes :( booooo that is why minus the star.

ADdBQh0FxmaMy78WoSbkuA.review_text: What a cool venue! The boy&I came here to watch Ben Howard play, and we went up to the balcony because well, I'm a bit vertically challenged and the people down on the floor were much taller than I am, so... seemed to make sense. We snagged some chairs and sat at a booth. Before the show, we looked around at all the posters, trying to recognize bands... it's really really cool. The acoustics were really nice, too! I'm glad that we got a chance to watch one of our favorite performers at this venue. I definitely like it better than the Regency Ballroom!   I hope I'll get to come back sometime soon...!  Oh, and free concert poster afterwards? Yay! :)

Ct456aEICzDfn03MHZCzsw.review_text: The only original thing leftover from Bill Graham is the free apples. The thing is that you can dance and not be stuck in a chair for the whole concert. But what is up with the reservations for the tables by the side of the dance floor? Food served, but you don't go there for the food. The sound board guys think that a good concert consists of volume on the speakers so loud you lose your hearing after 40 minutes because they are already deaf and wearing ear plugs at age 30.

pCGhLbFA8Q2N_LypEOdHcw.review_text: Phantasmagorical venue for any show.  It's big, but small enough to remain intimate, even cozy.   Absolutely amazing shows,  although security is annoying at best, and gruesome at worst.  Be prepared to be patted down, fondled and felt up.  If your lucky, you'll get a reasonably attractive security guard.  Unfortunately, you won't get lucky.   Despite the intrusive security, there still seems to be no end of pot inside, by intermission the stage was almost obscured by billows of smoke.

kxhr5NtIxeJ-G6fy5uYwWQ.review_text: Great music, free apples, and often free posters.  I've been to seven shows there and have gotten posters five times.  The walls of my apartment are slowly being covered...  It's big enough to generally not sell out instantly, but small enough where a 5'1" gal like me can usually still find a spot on the floor where she can see the band decently (without showing up early and camping out near the stage).    Make sure to check out the area upstairs where they have the walls covered in posters from previous shows.  They serve food up there, too, but I think I was more interested in the old posters.  The entryway also features photos of people and bands who have played the Fillmore.    Overall, one of my favorite concert venues in San Francisco, for sure.

Nd9VeCv885fxyHMMhRM2tg.review_text: Before you say anything, I used to live one block down from this place, so needless to say, I practically lived here for a while. Now here are my reasons why I hate/love The Fillmore.   1. I'm 5'2" and this venue does not provide enough of a slant in the main floor for people my height to see over anyone taller than the average female. Most shorties have this problem and therefore they all flock to the front rows.   2. Although drinks are available to those standing around waiting through opening acts, the plastic cups are constantly being dropped by concert goers and needless to say hardwood floors + beverage= one sloppy mess. This is a constant problem. Oh, and as most venues, ventilation is mainly through oversized fans only in certain areas of the floor. Good luck to feel a breeze if you're smack in the middle of the venue for a sold out show.   3. Go for the history of the venue as you walk through the main hallway into the floor. You'll spot endless amounts of photographs from Joplin to the Dead, Hendrix, and Aretha to name a few.   4. Go for the wonderful collectible posters they hand out at the end of each show as they are one of the few places to have this and red apples to goers in a basket by the entry area.   5. For sound quality, try Great American Music Hall, Yoshis two blocks away, 365 Bimbos. For closeness factor The Fillmore, Slims and yes Bottom of the Hill - even though it is practically impossible to find cabs there in the middle of the night. Venture out, SF has plenty of places to catch great music.

p0MVKgzEbtMDmFw0jNRZ0g.review_text: I would have given The Fillmore 5 stars if our car hadn't have been broken into and my personal effects strewn about the street all over the neighborhood.    I saw the Indigo Girls here a few years ago and it is an awesome place to see live music.  I love that you can stand right in front of the stage and dance your booty off because all the people who want to sit will sit in the tables that line the side of the dance floor.  The acoustics are great and the venue is small enough to make a concert feel more intimate.    Definitely tops my favorite concert venues......

DNeeQureAf8XnOi-kXCAGA.review_text: I really loved this venue-- and I've been to a lot of concerts, in a lot of different venues.   The place is small, which is always nice. There's no place to really watch but the pit (which, is the only place to watch).   What was really amazing about this was the decor-- everything was painted beautifully, and chandeliers hung from the ceiling. Definitely can't wait to go here again.

NkSsUU8oMQELFjpYMN0ifQ.review_text: Me & my Guy came here last night to see Queensryche~ and hands down, this is one of the most beautiful venues I have ever been to in SF.  The chandeliers!  The wide open space! The wonderful view of the stage from just about any angle! (brilliant designer that one) The efficient staff! ( hey Van, you rock!) The clean bathrooms, never a line!  The $.75 coat check! (NOT a typo).  Love this place~ there's a reason it has survived as long as it has~ Bill knew what he was doing.

9yPITTB_nUpXkau8IqfPqQ.review_text: A good venue to see bands and the size is just right. Like any other venue that has free standing, get there early when you go see a concert there.
