If you stay until the end they give you a free poster of the artist you just saw. I'd go back again with the right artist performing.

8cU-EmiRkTIjpiLu-kOLAg.review_text: Best place ever to see a concert. The Fillmore will make rockstars out of even the most medicre band. First of all, there's not a bad sightline in the house. You can be right at the stage or near the bar in the back and you're still closer than you're ever gonna get at most shows. What sets the Fillmore apart from, say, Great American, is the history- it's just oozing from the walls. You can feel it when you walk up the stairs, you can see it with all the legendary posters and you can be a part of it with the complimentary poster you get after the show. Bill Graham knew what he was doing. It's nice to see his tradition and legend carried on in probably one of the Top 5 venues in the US (hell, maybe even the world).

s1DSkbdFEuO3ODbMWQqSvw.review_text: If you're not up for crawling through crowds to get to the front, get there early enough to grab a table upstairs.  Food is pricey, but it's nice to know you can catch dinner while you watch.  Even if you're not upstairs, though, you can find a spot in the back to chill and still be close enough to see facial expressions.

27En0DDgdf0_0qK_hjXcLQ.review_text: Absolutely amazing!  There's a bar downstairs and upstairs, so you hardly have to wait long to get a drink.  Sure, drinks are a bit pricey, but it's all relative to the establishment, and this isn't happy hour at your local dive bar.   There's limited seating upstairs, and if you really need to sit down go upstairs or go outside! Don't make the same mistake I did: I sat on the floor in a spot that I *thought* was out of the way and nearly got trampled several times.  I don't really know why these people ended up falling on me unless they were trying to walk through the wall, but regardless, there is NO safe place to sit anywhere on the main floor!   Last time, I got a well ventilated spot in the center towards the front, but the slippery hardwood really stifled my dancing :( The lines for the bathrooms are LONG, but your turn comes pretty quickly. Can't wait to go back!

E9fPCP0mqm4S-G18RjYxmA.review_text: Other than the fact you have to stand the entire time for a show, it's a great venue.

i4Cg2-Jlp_YylfiJOMllGw.review_text: I went here with a huge group of friends to watch Audien and it was so much fun! The venue is located right next to Japan town. You have to park on the street, but honestly it wasn't too bad since we came early. The security is the same as any other place, they check your ID, pat you down, and then check your ticket. Once you're in it looks very vintage? Not sure if it's the right word, but you can tell that this place has some history with all of the groups, bands, DJ's, events that have been held here. There are tons of pictures on the walls of past performances which is cool.   The venue itself is quite small. Even though there are 2 floors with balconies, the dance floor is really not that big. The sound & light production was fantastic. Everyone including myself was jumping with excitement throughout the event! The bar was very quick at refilling the water station with fresh clean cold filtered water which is why I gave them a 5/5. In other events the water they give for free is from tap or some other dirty source. Everything went smoothly and the bathrooms did not have very long lines. Overall a nice small intimate venue that I wouldn't mind going to for another event.

lztkkUMknbjA84sccaaxpQ.review_text: where else do you hear the best bands sin the land.  good people, good music, good vibe, good time

0sPPamYvk77rDOYECr_85A.review_text: By far my favorite venue in the entire city proper of San Francisco to see a show.  I love walking in and being greeted with a warm "Welcome to The Fillmore" followed by grabbing an apple and seeing all the founders of rock-n-roll before walking into the main room and seeing the purple lit chandeliers and the place abuzz with anticipation.  You can feel the history in this place.  It is electric.  You could see some random new-comers play here and they will kill it just b/c they have to if they ever want to play here again.  I've never seen a bad show here.  Plenty of bars for your imbibement.  Great sound no matter where you are.  420 friendly and rocking it for decades!

GXn4ZsasLKh0qZ5g3nIqcQ.review_text: This place is magical. I think there might still be acid floating around in here from back in its prime concert days. I turn into a screaming groupie girl when I come in here. Easily the best place to see your favorite rock band. And you get a poster that your stoned and drunk ass gets to try and keep intact on the way home.

zAF--quEXsxrIDceOAAAzA.review_text: Gorgeous inside, great sound. Bartenders who know how to take shots. If a band I like is on, I'm there whenever I visit SF!

r_C9dbTsrHx4bJTUSmfPZw.review_text: A nice intimate venue with friendly staff. Beats going to the Shoreline any day of the week.

KBNceewFFeTK-vnv6Y-s7Q.review_text: O-zo-mat-li ya se fue, ya se fue!!!!  I love Ozomatli!!!  I love the Fillmore!  The two coming together are like Bono and the Edge, champagne and strawberries, a calm beach morning in Hawaii with snorkel gear.  It just fits!  Ozo rocks! I love this band, their music, their social activism, and just the energy they bring to a show.  I love how the Fillmore floor pulsates and moves with the energy of the crowd as we jump, stomp, and bounce to the music.    Ozo rocks because they got a bunch of dudes who had never even heard of the band or their music, jump, stomp, bounce, and scream like a girl!

rLWE2zHZzsA3PGMSdpKEOQ.review_text: ive been here 9 times (counting the posters on my wall) and all shows have been good - awesome. i went to built to spill last month and forgot to discreetly pack my weed so when security asked to see my purse, i opened it and there was my gram of weed. he stared at it for a second or two and said, "you're good"  a couple of weeks ago, i did the same for the black crowes and had my pipe in my pocket. the guy frisked me and was feeling up my pipe for a good few seconds and then he says "you're good" haha. any place thats cool with weed is cool with me. on certain nights, this place is continuosly up in smoke. you can smoke close to the fire aisle where the bouncers hanging out and you're good.....  of course, everything else is pretty good. there' a large area on the second floor where you can sit and hang out. (there's always seats). they give out free posters traditionally. the sound is always good....  the only problem i have is that they tax too much on merch. merch is always expensive here. even when bands actually WANT to sell thier merch for reasonable prices (grizzly bear), the venue will insist on adding five or so bucks per item.

sOhv5LHFsyf8t1JpgnocMQ.review_text: The Fillmore is a legendary historic venue in San Francisco because this is a historic place for rock music. They always try to offer the best current music. I was surprised at the medium size of the venue. I thought it would be bigger. Also, the venue has poor interiors. They need to refurbish the space to make it a ballroom. The stage was small. The poster collection is really neat and fascinating. I saw The Kills there and it's really easy to see the band from any part of the floorspace. It really wasn't that impressive compared to The Wiltern LA or 9:30 Club DC or any venue in NYC. I think they have to work on it more.

09mn7aohZCKH-ae0HlVb4Q.review_text: I have been attending shows at the Fillmore and the original Fillmore West since around 1968. I admit that I do not get to the Fillmore much lately maybe twice a year. I did have the unfortunate circumstance to attend the Willie Nelson show this last Friday. Show was good but I ended up having to leave early...actually I should say two thug security morons carried me out.  Apparently, I was standing in the wrong spot and was told to move by this meth - head security guy. He told me I needed to be behind some white line painted on the ground. I was by the way maybe two inches over the line. I moved about four feet down line to find a spot more clearly behind it, asked the guy if this spot was OK.  He walked by and rather than answering my question, pushed his shoulder into me. I naturally tensed up to accept his aggression. Next thing I know another security thug shows up. I tell them to take their hands off me and to get their supervisor. They pick me up and drag me down the stairs to the sidewalk out front.  Unbelievable!  For the record I am 55 years old and was with my wife who is also mid 50's and two other couples of similar age.  I thought that the music industry learned their lesson regarding hiring thugs as security at Altamont in 1969 my experience would suggest otherwise.

WjXzBDRVKMXs-PvFighu5g.review_text: The Fillmore = LIVE MUSIC AND ROCKING OUT to some  funky tunes.  I love this place.

CgEdfrnONQh1zaligWs2cg.review_text: The best shows I've ever seen have been at The Fillmore. Intimate and loud, just right!

zORQY85qUfWiIEltLOxG1g.review_text: Oh Fillmore we had some good times.  I had my first concert at the Fill when I was a little tiny adolescent with braces, bushy eyebrows, and a bowl haircut.  Yes, I was a Filipino Ugly Betty.  I remember I waited in line for hours so that I could stand in the front row and hopefully lock eyes with Ashly from O-town.  What was I thinking?  I remember my friend and I waited outside after the concert so that we could catch a glimpse of O-town boarding their tour bus.  Man, I was pathetic pre-teen.    I attended random concerts at the Fillmore through the years: Hot Hot Heat, Kate Nash, etc.  I eventually learned how to pluck, I outgrew my anoraks, and got rid of the metal headgear.  Alleluia!  Recently, I attended the Fillmore to see Santogold and Alice Smith (both were AMAZING, may I add).  I didn't wait in line for hours like I did when I was little, but I have to admit that I still try to push my way to the front so I can take a billion pics (the nerd in me admits that it's so I can put it on my facebook).  ...some things never change.  -1 because it's a pain in the ass watching a concert at the Fillmore when you are a 5'4" Filipino girl.  Why does the tallest person in the room have to be standing right on front of me?  Also, sometimes it gets way too crowded.  If that's the case, prepare to get grossed out as the person behind you humps you while trying to reach the stage and the guy on your left accidentally brushes his sweaty armpits on your head while waving his hand in the air like a complete moron.

iRNCdVNJyN8rLLMGWi0UtA.review_text: I saw my FAVORITE band Minus the Bear here for my birthday in late 2007, and not only was the performance amazing, but so was the venue!  The Fillmore has SO much history, it still does the poster if a concert sells out beforehand and there are always apples to be had!  The venue itself is an awesome relic, from the chandeliers, to the poster room-- but my favorite part is its' sheer size.  It's relatively small, and is the perfect place to see a band up close!  I hope more of my faves play at the Fillmore so I can go back soon!

z73utYRpqXc7mrM_5xhTJA.review_text: Anything less then 5 stars for the Fillmore is just wrong.  This place is legendary and continues to set the standard for music venues in SF. Along with the well known history of this place it is also well kept and visually its breathtaking. When you go to see a show the one thing you hope for most is that the sound will be good and this is one venue that rarely disappoints. On more then a few occasions I have seen artists take the stage in tears because this was the realization of a dream they had since they were kids. I think that says a lot about what this venue means in the music world.

tQ4WGeF62UmIG60yfU1OfQ.review_text: When you get the chance to see a concert at one of the most legendary venues in the entire country, you take that chance.  Right?  I went to the Pomplamoose show earlier this month. it was a great experience.  The entrance was not what I expected, but mostly in a good way.  I expect a big marquee sign, lots of shiny lights, etc.  Nope, not at The Fillmore.  The entrance is small, almost seems a little seedy and sketchy, but it adds to the atmosphere.  If there is a sign, I didn't see it, just followed the crowd to find my way inside.  If you are visiting San Francisco and you have an appreciation of music, history or both, definitely make it to The FIllmore.

nvCjFVR10e8rZ2X33-vG0w.review_text: Who doesn't LOVE the Fillmore!  Hubby and I have a great time whenever we go.  Just saw They Might Be Giants there and they rocked!!!

dYARtVwnvsaS3gjORUmq-w.review_text: Classic SF rock venue.  Drinks and food served (pricey but not unexpected).  Love the beautiful chandeliers, wall-to-wall vintage posters and classic rock pix.  A true SF original.  Oh, and you can get great free posters of the show you just saw to on the way out!  Although I haven't figured out yet if this  happens at every show (I confess I snuck out of one of the recent Smashing Pumpkins shows about ten minutes before it ended cause I'd had enough of the jam sessions so not sure if there was a poster created for that stand -  but that's a whole other story).

QmbWAkM89w2fxF0WPVoFsQ.review_text: OMG - It's Only the best place in the city to see your favorite band play.

SA6VpUZiG29LneMTa9Xu6g.review_text: Fabulous venue. So beautiful. The staff is so friendly and helpful. They give out posters of the show you just saw as you leave. The stage is small, the floor close, and the intimacy of the crowd and the performer just feels really good.  AND THE HISTORY, YE GODS, what a spot. It's amazing that it used to be the actual place for the 60's psychedelic experimentation movement, for blues, for the Beats, punk, everything. Any decade since 1910 that you'd wander in there, something awesome and memorable would be happening. Although I have only experienced the Fillmore post-2000, I attended 3 excellent shows that were highlights of my concert-going experiences.

7zxKUufAVxL45lMz2A7ypg.review_text: Instead of a review where I am actually writing paragraphs (english class was a challenge for me cause I have no patience for grammar), I will list why my rating is at a 3 out of 5 stars with the good (AKA why The Fillmore deserves stars) and the bad (why the Fillmore loses stars).  GOOD:* a lot of history (look at all the walls decorated with old posters);  *gorgeous interior;  *a lot of top notch bands perform here (the bigger the act, the better it is that you get your tix when they go on sale or you will be assed out in like 5 minutes);   *big concert floor, yet still one would consider it intimate;  *if you're lucky to attend a sold out show, you can get a poster (which decorates the walls);  *many bathroom stalls; * a good place for a band to have background visuals;  * FREE APPLES (better than spending $9 for a soy burger).  BAD: *OWNED BY CLEARCHANNEL!!!!! (-2 stars just for that),  *decent sound,  *overpriced food and drinks.  Shows I've attended: Atmosphere (twice), Jurassic 5, DJ Shadow (solo, not his Product Placement tour), the Scratch tour (Ztrip, Jazzy Jay, Xecutioners), Stereolab [yes, a lot of the stuff I've seen is hip hop related, so sue me. and yes, Stereolab is hip-hop in my POV.]  Shows that I have missed: Prince, Coldplay, Dave Chappelle, plus a shitload of others that don't come to mind, but those three are the "big" acts that I wouldn't have mind seeing if the tix weren't so damn expensive and didn't sell out in 5 minutes.  Show I am hoping to attend: GNARLS BARKLEY! (if anyone goes to this show, please post your thoughts on it. thanks.)

HXHVEg2a2QIkPcoIThGM6Q.review_text: I love this venue and everything about it. Its rich musical history, the atmosphere, the servers that are attentive to your needs when you're sitting on the side, and free apples? I'm definitely a fan.   The one thing I'm not a fan of is the expensive drink prices and the fact that I have to go to an ATM to order. Also, the lack of parking available. Sure you can park at the garage near the Kabuki, but who wants to pay when there's free street parking after 6? I had to park, maybe 3 blocks away which isn't such a huge trek. I was actually quite lucky to find that spot. So if you're planning on heading out there, your best bet would be public transportation or hitching a ride with a friend.  Overall though, I love this place and any musical act that I like that performs there is a great combination. And you get a poster at the door after the performance? I'm sold.

HIuUKol8R5S-KoOdWCLmCA.review_text: By far the most intriguing and entertaining venue that I've been to. We came to see Gramatik and ended up being more interested in the venue's history and music art than the performing artist. Excellent layout with good views and chandeliers. Drink prices weren't killer but still manageable. Would love to see a more intimate show here sometime.  Definitely will make a visit again next time I'm in San Francisco.

JGCl9_pVdard7b316lhsmw.review_text: The Fillmore IS music history.  Rock n' roll flows through the water pipes, it wafts through the air, and it covers the walls.  It is a beautiful venue to see a show at.  I can (and have) spent hours wandering through the place looking at the concert posters adorning the walls.  Probably one of the greatest venues in the entire world.  So why didn't I give it five stars?  Because fuck "Live Nation" and their ridiculously expensive service fees.  I love venues that allow me to buy my tickets on ticketweb or tickets.com.  I wish the Fillmore did too.

NKKW2bUyFUGy15-Fvc0KJw.review_text: Went to see Radioheads. It was a small theater, people smoking while the band was playing, security really didn't do much except make sure we weren't sitting on the reserved seats. Overall good for a concert.

-ZSPRpYyNYVVeiBWr9uAJQ.review_text: Free apples, free custom posters, and a solid heritage make The Fillmore the best midsize (1199) venue in San Francisco.  Definitely try to catch artists here before they move on to The Warfield or the BGCA.  Smaller venues like The Fillmore and Great American Music Hall are the best places to catch ascending artists.  The neighborhood is slightly 1970s seedy, but safe enough.  The Muni 38/38L has stops adjacent to the venue, so access from Montgomery BART is a breeze.

DgTuz1-ZpMw-rN9OTSSEaA.review_text: I love The Fillmore.  I've been here twice, to see The Maine.  The staff is nice and they're really organized, I've run into problems with other venues not beng organized and not the friendliest and I'm glad The Fillmore is not like that!

BzUgv3R694FZeT7IEo0hBw.review_text: Best venue in a city full of great venues.  Fillmore tops them all for a few reasons.    1.  Even when it is "sold out" it is never elbow-to-elbow "I can tell this is your favorite band because you keep rubbing your sweat-drenched shirt on me and you just knocked my date over" crowded.  There is always room in the rear, so to speak.    2.  The History   3.  The Apples  4.  The Posters: both the ones inside hanging up, and the ones they hand you on the way out.    Getting a cab after a show is a production, but heading up the street for a post show-libation in Pac Heights to wait it out is always a good option.

RLsHM4k6TYIzM65PgULaNg.review_text: Excellent venue for live music in SF. You'll see mostly larger acts here. The sound is pretty good and you'll get a poster at the end of the show. If you decide to make wall art out of said poster, know that you can purchase a frame for it at Cheap Pete's over on Geary and 7th.

oKE0RLbreFv1zr5zkM3ddA.review_text: Great venue. Many full bars, free apples, lots of history.

DidzypgpXglItySlEoRaVw.review_text: Absolute favorite venue ever!!! The chandeliers have black lights in them, totally cool! Mellow security and just the right size for a good show.

AAMlM0YNXW_RYIVV5xakWw.review_text: Never been to a show @ the Fillmore that I didn't enjoy.  I am the kind of person who way prefers standing in a pit to sitting in the stands, so if you're the sit down type of person, maybe the Fillmore isn't the place for you.  But if you like a place that's small enough to get cozy with your fellow concert-goers and have a great view of the stage from anywhere, yet big enough so that some pretty big names come through.. yea, you found my fave venue in the city.  I'm always impressed by the servers who take an order from you while you're standing in the crowded pit and somehow manage to find you again with your drink.  That takes some serious skill.  I mean.. there are times when I go to the bathroom and it takes me like 20 min to find my friends in the crowd again.  But really the fifth star is b/c the people who work here are super cool.. I brought like 20 students here on a field trip one Wednesday morning and we got to go on stage and backstage and get a very informative and fascinating history of the venue and the bands that have come through.  I think the moment that summed that whole trip up was one of my students saying, "How can I get a job like yours?" to Tony B.  It's always nice that if you buy your tickets from the box office on Sundays, they won't charge you a service charge.  And it's very accessible by muni.  And if you're lucky, the free posters are a pretty cool, unique souvenir :)

4wDZAs9a30snc4ufjLbUBQ.review_text:
I've seen so many great shows here, I can't be sure which ones stand out over the others. Me'shell N'degeocello, we love you. Truly. 
  ATTENTION YELPERS! ME'SHELL WILL BE AT THE INDEPENT ON JULY 9TH, 2006. SEE YOU THERE, LET'S HAVE A DRINK.
  You must see a concert here to believe it. Huge floor, food service, multiple bars and usually free apples and posters.
 While supplies last.

p0eUDSeVTi8nk7pywF_Hmw.review_text: Went to see the Pogues here a while ago.  Gig was grand although Shane seemed to treat the stage like the kitchen at a party and wandered on and off it as he wished.  The bar service was, frankly, appalling.  The guy had punters lined three deep at the bar and he was counting his tips and serving no-one.  Drinks were small and very expensive and served slowly with the affected disinterest of a disinterested teenager.  Nearly ruined me night.

DkFR-AE68Nr0jRR8mKQmlA.review_text: This place is killer!!! They get awesome bands to play and it's such a great venue to view them.  Large dancefloor and beautiful decor.  Seen countless shows here and have always been satisfied.  Go Fillmore!!

p-rz5nElTuSyUV1Dzui6Yg.review_text:
The Fillmore..
 I love it. Small enough for an intmate show, and large enough to gather a substntial audience to inspire an atmosphere. This is a great place to see a band. Not as beautiful as the GAMC, but the history alone is enough to enjoy going there. 
  Went to see The Meters there this weekend. What a great show! It was one of 6 reunion shows they are doing. They did 2 nights in SF. 
  These guys are truly a staple having created a genre of music. Funk. They are THE original thing. The fathers of the funk.  They made something like 25 albums over a vast career. They broke up in the 70's and reunited in various permutations as  The Funky Meters.
  No matter how old you are you have heard their music and dance to it. If you can recall even hearing about the Neville Brothers you have heard the Meters. Art Neville one of them. No other band has been sampled as much as the Meters, ask any DJ.
  What is amazing is these guys are all approaching their 70's for the most part, and can lay down a groove better than 20 somethings anyday. The most uptight person will be shakin their ass at a Meters show.
  Anyone who has heard of Ozomatli can thank the Meters for that.
 WIthout these guys there would be no funk.
  But I digress....
 If you like SF history, and espeicially music history and design walk around and look at all the show posters on the walls. Classics all of them. Upstairs you can get some food (if you wanna call it that) and keep looking up. Concerty posters dating back to the opening year. They even have posters from Winterland. Winterland is now a resaurant, but it, like the Fillmore was a fabulous place to see shows waaaay back when. hahahaha
  So get out there and go to a funk show. Remember the fathers of  the funk. And when you do, do it at the Fillmore get out on that floor and shake your backside.

dYbIkLXPSXDpq8ZhKSmNeg.review_text: I've been seeing shows here for years and I finally had my first Fillmore apple while enjoying Guster and Good Old War.  That apple was delicious.  Cool, crispy, and sweet like an apple should be.  Good job Fillmore for not skimping on the quality of your produce all while giving it away for free.  The greeter at the top of the stairs at the entrance is a nice touch.  I like seeing  a place stick to its traditions even if they aren't profit oriented.  A great room for music.  No obstructions, no clutter.  Just a floor and a stage... ok and a second story seating area if you want to get technical about it.  I don't think I've been to a show yet where the sound wasn't great.   Leaving after the show kind of feels like a cattle run but it's worth it.

Bp-TQEtc6Vs6ldnLgjqglg.review_text: so many concerts, so many good memories: cat power, black rebel motorcycle club, feist. these are just some of the great bands that roll through this venue.   intimate yet grandiose, you have to get there early enough to walk through the upstairs bar and seated balcony area, where the walls are mounted with historical concert posters dating back to when the hall first opened.   this is a little piece of san francisco history and i hope they never shut it down, although someone really needs to fix the lighted sign outside asap so i know which shows are coming to town!!

PWMRXCXdOG6B_FXe-Lj-JA.review_text: Felt privileged to be in such a place where many great musical talents have performed, Dylan, Hendrix, The Doors, Milli Vanilli  Space is awesome, Nice high ceilings, wide doorways, Excellent ventilation system keeps the crowd cool and cuts through the smoke, *cough cough*  Upstairs back room has more psychedelic rock posters than a R Crumb  exhibition  Lots of paid parking garages there, but we were easily able to find a street spot a few blocks north on a side street off fillmore  Many nice restaurants and bars in the area for pre or post concert festivities  4 margaritas to the wind later and a couple of other unmentionables (passed along by strangers) and was giving the car keys to anyone else who would take em  Even funnier is that I recognized one of the ticket scalpers outside that I sold (dumped) some extra tickets to outside the warfield a few weeks ago. I said hello to him, but I think he wanted to stab me in the eye  Ozomatli rocked 'da house BTW

XG-JynrbKiiNaqT4ffdI_w.review_text: Rocking venue, cool atmosphere and lots of history. Great place to see a show, definitely check the upstairs if you can.

04fUX1xIrj12Bfhx9a_8KQ.review_text: The Fillmore. Where do I begin? I've seen so many Great bands here, and such a wide variety. Psych Rock. Punk. Metal. Hip Hop. You name it. Very 420 friendly, and waitresses who fight their way through the crowd to bring you drinks, so that you don't have to! Awesome!  It is one of the city's larger venues, but still flawlessly manages to capture the intimacy of a smaller venue, making almost every Fillmore experience a "classic" show. The vibe is definitely right at The Fillmore. I don't know if it's the acoustics, the chandeliers, or just the energy of all the legendary musicians who have graced the stage in years past, but either way, the Fillmore wont dissapoint. If you haven't been there, GO. NOW.

xQwp_9V1O71m-ynSgig0nA.review_text: I'm ambivalent about this place. Being one of the first venues I went to for a concert and all the great shows I've seen here over the years, I almost feel obligated to give them a decent review, but then again, I'm not reviewing the performers.   That said, I love the pictures of the artists/bands from different genres/eras juxtaposed all over the walls AND the free poster they give you after each show. I hate how I have to struggle to see the stage even when I'm only a few feet away. I'm short, but I'm not THAT short.  I hope they install a slope for us short folks one day or make rules that permit only short people to stand in front. I also got kicked out of here once before the band even came on (Tragic, I know).   Hard liquor is pricey and only draft beer is available. They're a bit uptight about people drinking. They're also Nazis about no underage drinking, which I can understand, but do they really need to stalk you to make sure? Also, if you've been to smaller places like Great American Music Hall, you might start to think this place is too big for small shows. For those that don't already know, it's all general admission (no assigned seating) so show up early if you want a good spot for those big-name artists.

GUu9sWlvGeqYUgriD7f9Mg.review_text: Walk in and you're immersed in music history. The walls are covered with photographs and posters from legendary performers from The Fillmore's past.  They've got all genres covered: The Grateful Dead, Miles Davis, BB King, The Smashing Pumpkins, Cypress Hill, The Killers, and the list goes on.  The classic décor, mood lighting, and excellent acoustics are what really make The Fillmore outstanding.  What I love most is the intimate, standing-room-only concert space.   Spectators in the front row are literally an arms-length away from the stage -- close enough to feel the bass reverberate through your entire body and maybe even get some beads of sweat thrown your way.  But if you're not like me and prefer to keep your distance, the floor is spacious enough for a good view from any angle.  You can also watch from the balcony upstairs, but seats up there are hard to come by, unless you show up early and eat at the restaurant before the show.  Besides, who goes to a concert to sit down? I sure don't!  There's a full bar on each floor, although the main bar is next to the stage so it's often crowded.  The drinks are not cheap, but unfortunately that's typical of most concert venues.  There are more bars in the surrounding area if you're looking to get your drink on before the show.

lixTHPjgKrbVlth-PF2U4Q.review_text: OMG I WAS JUST THERE YESTERDAY NIGHT for Dir en grey's concert! oh gawd kyo rabu rabu rabu rabu [drools]. There were an ASSLOAD of people so it was really hard for me to breath along with the bad BO people had..I had a fun time seeing Dir en grey though hahahaha...if anyome here KNOWS Dir en grey and LOVES Dir en grey then you kick ass :)

zT0PuDsIV-S7M-W_NaX9vw.review_text: An awesome place to see a show.

LksuiNKspbDOZYNOkDx1bA.review_text: The last time I was here to see Girl Talk, I felt like I was at a high school dance... except on crack.   How can you not love this place? The music is always top notch, the energy is contagious and the people watching is purely entertaining. I recommend becoming a repeat visitor (aka a concert whore like myself). You'll feel a bit of nostalgia every time you come back.

9gRl8OsCnVtBrrd-xSTb9w.review_text: Sweet venue!  Attended the Ting Ting's show last night and had a blast!  Good drinks, awesome space with chandeliers!  Awesome crew that worked there too!

UzG5IHFUu6H1UyCRbqHHZw.review_text: i introduced myself to Fill this past monday at the girl talk concert. he was a clean, well dressed gentleman.  ...the kind you'd come across in an old black and white film.    i offered him a mildly sloppy, vodka-induced grin.  'i'm not gonna remember this opening band tomorrow.  ...nor will i remember dancing on stage.'  'that's quite all right, miss,' he replied.  'your friends will have photos.  they will remind you that you were the meat in a dancing girl sandwich, and that you had earplugs in your bra.'  and we danced the night away, to melodic, booty mashups.

5DJBmy8rq6R08zkAhp1AvA.review_text: Great room with consistently good sound.  Perfect atmosphere.  This venue reached legendary status long ago.  The only reason I'm withholding the last star is b/c this venue for the booking.  Yes, I realize it's San Francisco, but how many times can Phil Lesh and Friend's play a single venue without it getting old.  I was beginning to think they were the house band.  I can't imagine they still draw a crowd?  Really?  That being said, this is the perfect venue to catch your favorite band just before the arena tours begin (or 10 years later).  It's just the right size - you can squeeze your way up front without too much trouble, and there's always room in the back if you need a breather, even at a sold-out show.

HC1ehl5_T79__izzteqkwg.review_text: Surprisingly easy to find parking at this famous concert establishment.  Saw Natasha Bedingfield, the Veronicas and Kate Voegele in concert.  Love seeing the famous stars that have performed there on entering and exiting.  The Bar area is generous.  And I would try to get into the 'box seating' on the upper balcony (left of stage) if you can.  No seating for our concert on what seemed like a large wooden floor.  May want to keep your stiletos at home, ladies.  Mostly casual with plenty of space to shake it.  Decor is chandeliers and curtains with splashes of purple and burgundy.  Long lasting SF staple that will not go out of style anytime soon.

qr1pI_M35pIb6N5nMzSKMQ.review_text: I used to love the Fillmore.  I used to go to shows there once a month.  Then Live Nation took over.  What a bunch of corporate assholes.  I hate the Fillmore and will never go again.  They ruined the Fillmore by putting a corporate megatron on one wall and denying us the famous Fillmore poster.  Screw this place and all the corporate dicks that profit from ruining what made the Fillmore legendary.

mnmzy_EZf6m_jwSoZQpcNQ.review_text: Went to The Fillmore last week to enjoy The 1975. Probably one of the nicest venues I've been so far! The venue was absolutely eloquent and had great vibes. The best part of it all was the fab coat check because without that all my crap would've fallen out and what not.

UQFE3BT1rsIYrcDvu_XVow.review_text: Still the best venue in San Francisco. Been coming here for years, eaten my fair share of apples, introduced by my amazing Dad when I was almost too young to know what that musty "smell" was in the back rows, and enjoyed everywhere from the floor to the upper bar to the back of the house.   This place imbues cool vibes and rich history at every turn.  Also some of the best acoustics short of Davies Symphony Hall.  Catch good bands here while you can, before they get "great" and upgrade to the BG Civic Auditorium and the dreaded HP Pavilion.   Tips? as if there's anything you don't already know. (1) they don't give out the posters til the last song. (2) wash the apples. (3) the back right bar is often overlooked by people and a much shorter wait than the main floor bar. (4) great acoustic singer/songwriters on the second floor from time to time. (5) cheapest coat check around, but make sure you get there before that last song or you'll be waiting a bit.

Fm_B2DANFMNa5zkzw01AKA.review_text: a legendary venue for live performances from music to stand-up comedy.  get there early so you can get dibs at the front row - standing general admission unless seating is provided.  there is a restaurant upstairs, but havent tried theri food yet.  the acoustics are sharp, crispy and boomin.  great for a mid-sized show, very appropriate for intimate live music shows. located at fillmore and geary, take the 22 muni if you can't drive.  parking is tough, but i always get away with parking at the safeway parking lot.

OnagJ2dnPjfRRT4a_CgKCw.review_text: Awesome music venue...coat check and all... Full bar with decent selection of booze..and..are you kidding me? Nachos on their menu?  Okay..all that aside..it was great to see Pete Yorn play there last night...It was standing show but people were kind enough to make room for this 5ft girl to see...

VQ6x2hVgp7UXnTRDNtXwXw.review_text: As you take your first step into San Francisco's Fillmore, a chilling sensation of something magical fills your body. Surrounded by the poster lined walls of all the live acts that have graced its stage, you are welcomed to another part of musical history.  At the main entrance, it's tradition to take a red apple from the wicker basket at the top of the stairs. Make your way over to the souvenir stand and take a peek at tonight's Fillmore poster. It's another Fillmore tradition to hand out posters to all who attended sold-out shows. Head upstairs to the Poster Room where you can kick back with a drink and food while you listen to local live acts on their second stage. Move across to the balcony bar and chill out the with friends while being surrounded by red velvet drapes, show posters and conversations of music and memories as you gaze down on the show and crowd below.  Now it's time to head down for the opening act. You never know who might be the next Led Zeppelin or White Stripes. Grab another beverage from the side bar and find your spot on the hardwood main floor. There is not a bad spot in the entire place. Look up and marvel over the beautifully lit infamous chandeliers that dangle above like angels of sound. Feel the vitality build. Listen to the keyed up voices and the see the anticipation in the eyes of Fillmore's gathering.  As the stage hands disappear into the wings and the lights go down, the entrance music of the main act stretches the venue's intensity. Not many occurrences in life can compare to those first few striking seconds when the silhouettes of your favorite musical act walk across that mystical and historic stage. Well, that is until the first sound wave pours from the speakers like volcanic electricity. And that's when it hits you. You are now a part of something larger than the music itself; you are now and forever the energy that is the Fillmore West.

cHzhv2AY3Zirj_9pddNDiw.review_text: i've been here a few times and it's def my favorite spot for a show.  saw the roots this week, was all the way up front and center almost got whipped w/ blackthought's mic chord!  love the posters and the sound.  the only negative is there's something weird abt the women's bathroom.   maybe they're too narrow?  i don't know...

2fN8mN7uUjOw-QqtcgYqXQ.review_text: Came here for Geographer. Doors open 7pm, 1st opener started 8pm, 2nd opener started 9pm, and Geographer started 10:20pm, ending around 11:30pm.  Pros: -decent acoustics -free apples  Cons: -dirty bathrooms -servers constantly walking through crowd to deliver drinks, blocking my view -hardwood floor sticky before show started -music too loud, especially bass

B_n1dqlys5u302n0YUn5NA.review_text: Similar to the Great American Music Hall -- good music and generally good sound, gorgeous interior.  Bands often film documentaries here so you might show up as a 4 pixel-high blob in some DVD!  Sweet.  Most shows are standing so wear your tall shoes if you're short like me.  But I've seen one show where they brought out tables, which was quite nice.  Leaving is annoying because everyone has to go out the front door, and the process is slowed when they hand out posters at sold-out shows.  But they have free apples!

vXrUBAIN4aoCt7F5p0kU_g.review_text: Very beautiful venue.  Feel in love with the chandeliers. I wish they had more seating room.  My feet were so tired after the concert.  Call me old, but I like sitting down after being up for over 3 hours. This goes out to people with disabilities, I have no clue how you can get around those stairs?  Please look into if they have a separate elevator entrance before you purchase your tickets.  Music was super loud and powerful. I could feel it in my body.  Took the option of wearing ear plugs.  Funny thing, when people were jumping in unison to the music, I could feel the floor bounce with them.  Kind of scary since we were in an older building on the second floor.  Ahhhhh!

ZfEwveJ9LAgOKBGkg82mCA.review_text: I've came here to see many bands live but the only thing that gets me is that theres no mosh pits or video recording allowed, and the security is really up tight about it too, pretty good sized venue

DHWZ6CHJ_tFrAF3oyG4GZw.review_text: I will not ever be back, even for my most adored acts. LiveNation seems to be on a crusade to ruin live music everywhere, and they've done it with what used to be the best live music venue in the bay, at least for the kinds of acts that play there.   $12 beers?  really?  Biggest-possible douchebag bouncers, who clearly take advantage of their jobs as their only opportunity to exercise some kind of control. I know it's crowd control, guys, but some of us have brains and don't like being treated like criminals.  That's really all it takes for me to never go back there.  At least they still have the free apples.   For the amount of money you pay for a show here, do something else.

FzCXLo135Gi4byNcMbb8Zg.review_text: Club Passport! Available on LiveNation.com now! Here's what you need to know... $49.99 all in, no fees. Access to participating Fillmore shows for the rest of the year! LiveNation.com/clubpassp…

aC18_dfyo6y5ryZT4sqsnA.review_text: I wanted to roll my eyes @ this place but it was pretty great. Nostalgia galore and never in my life has there been so many bars in one venue! Not a bad seat in the house & plentiful meeting/drinking room appreciated.  Worth going to the show early just to roam & drink w/ friends. Very impressed.

FzyPWaU57e3c9APJnN1zFg.review_text: This is my absolute favorite place to see live music. It's hardly worth it for me unless I can actually see the performer's faces, and here, I can always be right at the stage. I'm especially freaky about people around me at concerts, I seem to attract those folks who go a little overboard in their dance/art/epilepsy and I have a hard time tuning them out even if they are in my peripheral vision. I really need to get to the front.   The whole place is gorgeous as well, you could spend hours just looking at all the posters and photos everywhere and pontificating over the history that has been made there.   Front stage at the Filmore is a good place to be.

9YiwYGep_t0WM7H_X19soA.review_text: yum.  My first time at The Fillmore was in June to see Death Cab for Cutie. Amazing show by the way.   The Fillmore is awesome. The building is old but a classy old. It's really nice. The sound was great in there and it's seriously the perfect size for a medium sized show. LOOOVED IT. I enjoyed getting a free poster at the end of the night also. It's nice to know that you come here and walk out a part of history.   The waitresses are really awesome too. Props to the gals that work there.

SYE4V-wJ-PW8_tVULjXyxw.review_text: The only thing to know about this venue is to BELIEVE the sign that warns you to empty your pockets before coat check.  Never again!

uT6ORAzPlEcLJRZv-MMCqA.review_text: Its been a long time coming but I was finally able to take in not one, but two shows at the Fillmore in one week!  I love everything about this venue from the velvety looking walls adorned with some of the best posters ever, to the sound and intimate environment that the Fillmore provides. Also, appreciated the multiple levels and multiple bars.   The first show I caught on Tuesday, Wiz Khalifa  with Yelawolf, was a blazing smoky memory. Despite the fact that the show started a bit late the whole crowd was vibing to the pre-show tunes, lots of reggae. Yum.  The second show I saw on Friday was actually a comedy show, Aziz Ansari. I was surprised that there was actually seating, as the ticket said standing room only, but I was thrilled to pieces, grabbed a seat and a brew and was ready to laugh. Even his opening act Dave C. was amazing. Great show.  Perhaps one of my favorite things about catching a show here are the "deceptively free" posters that they hand out as you leave. Make sure to grab one on your way out...

BOU25_BWQnLdFJBKUe2XdQ.review_text: Came here a few time for an Ozomatli concert. This place is Hugh. The place isn't the cleanest, but it is a concert hall. The people who come here are lively and really into the music.    Just when a concert happens there are always guys standing outside one buying tickets people want to sell and his friend who sells them to other people. Parking is very difficult, so plan ahead.

PpKS9amBrX7AZ5zDklTQWQ.review_text: I was just at the Fillmore last night for a show. The show itself was great. The selection at the bar was nice. There was a big basin of apples at the door, a nice touch.  My complaint is regarding security. You've got to have competent security in a large space like this. There were 4 belligerant drunks leaning on me the second half of the night. When my friends realized this girl who could barely talk was a pin-ball between us, someone gave her a gentle, and I mean gentle I'm a person not a wall nudge. They responded in drunk fashion and started name calling and threatening. Someone got security and one man came. It was like herding kittens. He had no control over the situation. Meanwhile, as the security guard watched the guy throw an entire cocktail in my face. I asked if he saw that, and he said yes. And nothing. My friends had to help him herd the drunks out, and no one apologized to me. I think at the least, he should have brought another security person, and he should have apologized. If you're going to serve drunks, you need to protect the bystanders.  It's sad to me that a few drunks can ruin my experience, and everyone else's to a degree.

xsMd6OnEJ6_Np6Es0uxOIg.review_text: It looks rather non-descript from the outside, but you'll soon realize it's historicalness with the concert bills that line its walls from the past. I came here to see DJ Shadow and he did not disappoint. The sound system was awesome and not overwhelming at all. I was standing towards the front middle of the dance floor and had a great experience. They had some balcony seating. It's just too bad the bar was missing one thing to make a 'surfer on acid'. I must add that they have a great air conditioning system to keep the room temp comfortable and to pump in fresh air to push out the weed smoke (not that I have something against blazing though to enhance your musical experience). BTW, I have that "Enuff" song stuck in my head off Shadow's latest album (at the time of this review) called "The Outsider" which was performed at the show. With that, I can die a happy man now ;-)

QbewF-XkZNdyLDpNwDC-ng.review_text: Long Live the Smashing Pumpkins!!  Who wants to go with me to another concert?

jdGKRKVYotSgMf9xZOlqKQ.review_text: The area around the Fillmore is super sketchy. It's near Japantown, near a row of bus stops where homeless people squat and yell at passerby (even having dealt with similar situations in Berkeley for four years, I was still kinda frightened and would definitely not walk here alone at night).   The venue itself is pretty nice- perfect size for more intimate concerts. I liked how the upper level had some seating areas that were close enough to the stage that you could still enjoy the music.   Didn't try any of the drinks or food, but seemed like regular bar food.

kroQYWSj-BhIEXT4VwLRHA.review_text: Love this venue. Seen many shows, including last nights Cult show.  Great vibe, great sound, just great place to see music.  Many places to drink and eat before or after the show!!!!

CJwSYSsw36bPiN5hGyKPaA.review_text: So, I just finished up going here for two nights in a row of some Smashing Pumpkins shows (side note, all those other reviews be damned, they were awesome!!!!!!)    This was my first time at the historic Fillmore...I've always wanted to go here, having known about it for ever...and I'm glad I did!  You can feel the history when you walk in this place, and looking at all the photos around the place, you could only imagine how awesome it would be to see all of those great bands here...They have a sweet upstairs area with some nice balcony seats, lots of places to get your drink on, and a sizeable main floor.  Overall, I loved this place, and I can't wait to see some more artists play here...

_lbgVbWTvxV9VTVWU0YnwA.review_text: Hands down the best concert I went to, EVER!  We saw Jimmy Eat World and stood front row.  Got the guitar pic and all!  We had so much fun and plan on seeing more artists here.  YAY!

Bf87HcPERF9yiSjb2tQBqw.review_text: Stereolab at the Fillmore:  A perfect evening.  Every show I've seen here has felt just right.  I don't understand those people who say the staff are rude--I have always found them to be the nicest, most respectful staff among all the bigger venues in SF. By comparison, those cretins at the Warfield are completely intolerable.

ou8XxCnL03Jc85sqR1bcDQ.review_text:
every time a band comes to sf that i want to see i hope like a little girl that they come to the fillmore. thats how much i like the fillmore. with ear plugs (my hearing is a bit damaged thanx to standing next to the amps at too many hardcore shows back in the day) i can hear the music there so you know the sound is pretty good for a venue that size.
  just saw ministry and revco a couple of months ago. and i have to say, it was one fucking hard rockin' show. i was buzzing on that energy for days after. was it cuz it was at the fillmore? maybe. was it just cuz both bands were amazing for a bunch of has beens and still are's? maybe. was it cuz i was having flashbacks to the good times i had with my ex husband who knew all those guys and we hung out back stage with them when they were various pigface incarnations? maybe. was it the fact that al was drinking a ton of water on stage and seemed pretty clean? maybe. was it the fact that i got to see the show from the balcony with a bunch of other ex-punkers who happily mixed me into their reminiscing conversations about shows in the 80's? maybe. but probably because the scene at the fillmore is just right for all that stuff. 
  plus you get posters at the door on the way out and that rocks my artsy graphic designer world!

spzHnMRdrcoHnnjlCJx-dQ.review_text: The Fillmore always seems so promising, with its historic posters and suggestive bucket of apples in the gorgeous, ornate lobby.   That said, I rarely have a good time here -- the acoustics are fine, and the shows are generally top-notch, but if you're as short as I am (5'2") your options are to stand squashed against the stage, compete for one of the rare table seats in the small second tier, or stand at the back of the room and wish you could see something.   Similar venues, such as the Great American Music Hall and the Warfield, have more upstairs seating -- much more, in the case of the Warfield. And the GAMH has significantly better acoustics.   If you're small, and you're really dying to see a band that's playing at the Fillmore, come very early and snag an upstairs seat while you can.

hHoigAK81AtqSUtBmkqWjg.review_text: There are few concert venues which are intimate, nostalgic, have great sound, and have an amazing history of famous musicians who have played there at some point in their career. The Fillmore has all of this and more.  I've seen three shows at the Fillmore and all were so much more amazing because of the intimate vibe here.  When you walk in you'll see vintage style posters of classic rock acts who have played here.    The three shows I was lucky enough to see?  1) John Mayer/Norah Jones (2002) 2) System of a Down (2005 or 2006; cant remember) 3) Robert Randolph and the Family Band (2006 I think)  If you have an opportunity to see an upcoming band or one of your all time favorites (sometimes it happens) at the Fillmore, do not miss it! It is a once in a lifetime opportunity.

btiskuCkwExXY1Yyd5DMBA.review_text: Death Cab For Cutie at the Fillmore. I just felt all the music from waay before I was born to last night! I felt legends, miracles, inspiration, love, holy shit, I'll go on... Excuse me while I enjoy my moment....

qGi0xjK3HM3Lfr6kSwKZdw.review_text: I will excuse:  -The bartender who was rude to me because I didn't have a stamp, but I had an ID - I get it that you have to service many people at the bar. But really, you didn't need to be rude to me. Because really, I gave only give a little shit more about you then you do about me because you are pouring me beer. Smooches to you.  -The girl who was rude to me because she thought I was trying to stand in front of her. I will excuse you because you are short (and you were obviously too well aware when you opened your mouth to yell at me) and second of all, I wouldn't stand next to you because you reek of some hideous perfume you decided to bathe in previous to you being there that night. Concert etiquette in standing room only venues is to be nice, I think - because you really you didn't pay to own the Fillmore - you paid to stand somewhere inside of it. Get over yourself.  BUT... but... yes, there is a BUT.  This place is fantastic.  I've seen... JC Chasez (yes, I did), Ryan Cabrera (yes, I did) and most recently I saw Sara Bareilles (and all of this I did with a love in my life, Mily).  The place is a fantastic testament to how music should be heard and experienced. If you are not a experienced concert goer I don't recommend the place due to the issues mentioned above, but if you can get into it and are friendly - the Fillmore can be a place for some amazing shows.  Sara Bareilles was filming her DVD this night and that was a cool thing to see itself. She is amazing, cute, totally kept referencing to the legend that was the Fillmore. The place was still cozy enough so that the intimacy was not lost.  Do not miss the free handbills they hand out after the show, those are the most fantastic souvenirs. It's a great vibe in here... and quite possibly a wonderful date place too - if you are seeking to impress.

iXP76W5mCp8NY_Mu7-AFEA.review_text: You go once because it is an historic venue. You may go again because you thought the treatment from those washed up hippy heavies was a fluke. You don't go again unless, you just have to see the show. I find going to a show at this admittedly nice venue a bit like a visit to a state penal institution--you are frisked, commanded around by guys who look like they should be changing the oil on your Pontiac. For my money, this is a thoroughly unlikable experience that you should only subject yourself to if you have pre-medicated and enjoy a bit of the whip with your pleasures. Not me.  Where do they find all those ex-felons to man the "security goon squad" they put on the floor here? You will really want to take a shower after this place is done with you.
